description:
A tiny restaurant with a long bar, swivel stools and the smell of food that is beyond delicious.
I've been coming here for many years. I've tried just about everything (all delicious) but I always go back to the #5 white meat.  
While waiting for the food, you are usually offered a cup of tea which is the perfect thing on a cold and (or) foggy day. The portions are enormous and always served hot and steamy. The price is also extremely reasonable for the quality and amount of food that is served up
author: Paul G.

description:
One of my favorite low-key spots in SF! I come out to SF every now and then and this is usually one of the first places I eat at - the chicken is delicious and yes they give you huge portions for a decent price 

This isn't a place to come for ambiance, it's got that classic hole-in-the-wall feel to it (in a great way) and the woman who runs the place has been very nice every time I've come here. 

If you love unique flavorful chicken spots with great portions at a fair price and you don't care much for ambiance, this is the spot for you. I love this dam place!
author: A Y.

description:
6:15 Tuesday night party of 3. We got the last three seats in the joint at the counter, front and center. 
We were on the hunt for some easy and good eats, not fast food. This was such a great find! The Chef, server, cashier was just one woman, superwoman. Service may take a bit longer, and it may appear she's lost, but she's not. I watched her give people their bills verbally doing all the calculations in her head. In the midst of cooking, serving, answering phones for the endless to go orders, greeting people, taking orders and more she managed to stay calm and friendly not rushing any of her customers. I was impressed and I was totally distracted until I realized she was cooking my food. 
She is methodical with her ways. 
Food was bountiful and delicious! We will go back. 
People were waiting for seats or to go orders for the duration of our meal and she did not miss a beat, even chasing down a couple who left with their to go order without paying.
author: Elaine S.

description:
Dropped by literally after the gym. Was one of my go to places while I am here in SF.

I've been to Vietnam a couple times, and for them to say that its the best chicken outside of Vietnam is a pretty big statement. Boy did they live up to it. I got a #5, but unfortunately I came late one night and they were out of rice! I never thought that could happen. I substituted it for the noodle instead. The portions were very pretty big for the price and it was actually very affordable. 

It is a relatively a small location however can fit more people than I thought it could so about 10-15 people give or take.

It was pretty awkward trying to speak to the employees in Vietnamese only for them to tell me that they don't haha. I thought I could because they do serve Vietnamese cuisine, but I guess I was wrong. This could be a five star next time around because I need to go back and try their rice with meat sauce!
author: Timothy D.

description:
I will start and caveat this review by saying I'm biased because of my ethnic roots. I wanted to believe in the power of Cordon Bleu and it's King Kong portions of promised meat, but it wasn't entirely what I had anticipated.

I come from the land of Vietanmese cuisine, so I have a right to be overly opinionated when it comes to my people's food.

I don't think the offerings here are traditionally Vietnamese. While it is a variation of the grilled street meats you'd typically see in Vietnamese cuisine, it lacks the strong fish mark flavored paired with the perfect smokey after taste.

All of the combos are similar to one another with minor tweaks. The prices are fair (cheap for SF) and the portions are huge. You'd definitely get your money's worth eating here if you're a meat eater.

I originally wanted the Combo #1 with one cha gia, pork kabob, salad, and meat sauce on rice. They got my order wrong and gave me the combo with the two cha gias which was fine. 

The cha gia is tasty and huge. I wasn't a fan of the meat sauce (this isn't Viet at all btw), or the pork (it was dry for my liking). At the end of it all it wasn't my favorite but wasn't the worst but I'm sure this is the place of a meat eater's dream.
author: Connie M.

description: I've been here a few times on my trips up to San Francisco and I absolutely love this place. It's really hidden and small but perfect if you're looking for a low key cheap meal. My go-to is combo #1 I have no idea what the meat sauce is made of but it tastes slightly tomatoey with chunks of meat. It works really well with the rice, pork kabob, and imperial roll. They probably have about 7-8 bar stools and a couple of tables. Awesome meal for under $10.
author: Jane C.

description:
I'll do 4 stars on this one.  It is not a 4 star dining experience, but I thought the food was good, the prices were pretty good and I would probably go back again at some point.

Cash only.

Epitome of hole in the wall.  The place is not well lit, it isn't a good place to take a date.  If you want to stop in and have a hot plate of food real quick with a variety of different things on your plate, this does the trick.  You can also get the food to go if you want to take it home or eat in a park somewhere or whatever.

The imperial rolls are good and probably the best thing they have.  The chicken, shish kebob, and rice with sauce are not bad and I completely cleaned my plate.  The meat sauce isn't the most flavorful and I'm not sure where the meat is in the meat sauce, but it was okay.
author: Ty C.

description: Our best meal in SFO, this barely 5 ft Chinese lady runs the whole right in front of the 30" grill and  tiny fryer next to that, also pour rice or noodle into the bowl/place and her one and only helper hands out the order for her. Multitasking is an understatement to describe her!!
author: G W.

description: My favorite place to get home cooking Style of Vietnamese Bbq the meat sauce is the best and katie cooks with love ... great food great place Harding working and kind people.... I brought most of my family and friends there and they all love it‍
author: Maria W.

description:
It happens.  

Every once in a while a yelper drops into a non 5-star business and enjoys the experience so much that it causes them to think of all those places to which they've assigned 4-star ratings.  Then the brain gets to spinning:  If that other place was 4-stars and I enjoyed this place so much more, how could I give it anything but 5-stars?  

So I'm giving Cordon Bleu 5-stars and I'll say flat out right here: it is in no way a 5-star place.  

Cordon Bleu epitomizes the phrase "hole in the wall".  It's tiny, crowded, leaves a messy impression, and the first stool I sat on was so wonky that I immediately changed seats.  You don't come here for the exceptional atmosphere.  You come here for the excellent food at remarkable prices and, if you're lucky, the chance to watch and interact with the hard-working and engaging owner, Katie.  

From my counter seat I ordered Cordon Bleu's "Chicken Salad" ($8.78) which is one of the best deals in town.  Katie stands at the grill, tending to the chicken pieces as workers squeeze in and out of the tight space.  Other guests at the counter had dietary restrictions which she handled with aplomb and "what is that?"-questions which were addressed with a sample of the item in question ("Vietnamese spaghetti sauce").  I observed people who'd just finished their meal get up and order 6 more meals to go, then watched Katie handle special requests from patrons at the counter.  When she asked if I liked my salad I finally got the chance to tell her:  "It's delicious!" then went on to admit that "I haven't been here in years."

A dialogue sprung up, and I admitted that I'd last dined at Cordon Bleu about 30 years ago, before she purchased it some 25 years ago.  It's been around for 40 - 50 years now and that sort of longevity doesn't just magically happen.

Cordon Bleu's menu is a blast from the past, with only a single offering topping $10 but flavors that feel perfect for today.  The Chicken Salad, with its expertly grilled protein and fresh flavors is a satisfying thing of joy.  I could round the corner and get a $20 salad at Blue Barn which would be only half as satisfying.    

Parking in this 'hood is impossible but now that we've been reintroduced, I won't be waiting another 30 years to return to Cordon Bleu.  It may not really be 5-star worthy but that day, I was feeling it.  

Cordon Bleu steals today's award for the tastiest, most well-priced restaurant in San Francisco.
author: Tracey A.

description: Good value for a good meal! Pretty hole in the wall- a bit dirty- just don't inspect so much, but great for a fast meal. I got the number 1 special- came with a heaping of rice- yummy grilled meat, and even yummier imperial roll (done the Viet way with rice paper!) You watch them make it right in front of you and it comes out piping hot. The vodka creamy sauce is quite tasty as well.  Decent service too. Would definitely return to try their world famous chicken!
author: Vivian D.

description: This is one of my favorite Vietnamese place in SF, it's one of those food that makes you feel dirty, and that's usually a good sign. There are two Vietnamese lady working there, and you can tell from watching them that they're experienced. The five spice chicken is so delicious and moist. Every element of the dish (#5) hit the spot. Would come back again. (Also really affordable)
author: Kaylee P.

description:
Hole in the wall spot when you want quantity over quality. Cash only, the staff here is very nice but don't expect any bells or whistles. They take your food and drink order and deliver it to you promptly. 

I got the #5 and some of the shish kebab was a bit over cooked. It's cut very thin almost like jerky. The chicken was nice and moist and imperial roll was huge. I loved how crispy and lightly sour the slaw was. The meat red sauce left much to be desired as other uses mentioned. 

I saw other people with beers so I'm assuming it was byob. Pretty small joint might, good for lunch or take out orders.
author: Lindsay C.

description:
We have walked past this restaurant several times and I made a note to try it out. We finally came in for lunch on a weekday and the restaurant only had two other diners at the time. It's a hole in the wall shop, which are usually the best, and this one was no different. We sat at the counter and both of us ordered the #5, mainly because we wanted to get a taste of the many of the offerings. This dish includes a cabbage salad, thin marinated grilled pork, five spice chicken, imperial roll, and rice smothered in meat sauce. Wow. I I kept looking over at my fiance who looked at me wide eyed with each bite he took. He was a happy boy!

I took one bite of the rice with meat sauce and immediately felt comfort. This was comfort food! My chicken was a bit overcooked and dry, but the flavor was there. The pork was my favorite and reminded me of tocino. I loved eating all the charred bits. The imperial roll was huge and had an unbelievable crunch. We both left completely satisfied and ready for a nap. 

I will note that it's cash only! Also, I would give this place 5 stars but they close up shop at random times, so it's super sad when I get a craving, see they are closed, and then have to walk away sulking.
author: Sara P.

description:
Awesome, funky little spot. They do one thing here and they do it very well: Vietnamese 5-spice grilled chicken. I really liked the salad-cabbage and mint with a vinegar dressing and pulled grilled chicken. The wise old ladies behind the counter have seen some chicken in their day. Make no mistake, this is a unique, divey, must-try place. 

Highly recommended.
author: Cody H D.

description: If I could give this place more than 5 stars, I would. Get the number 5, it comes with everything. The rice with sauce is SO good and the Empirial Roll is untouchable. Typically a busy place and only seats about 15 people. Great experience to sit at the bar and watch your food being grilled. I go a few times a year and will keep coming back! Hope this place sticks around for generations to come.
author: Nathan M.

description:
I was a bit skeptical about the meat sauce on rice. I was eager to try the chicken, but also wondered: how can they make five spice chicken juicy and tender?  The answer?  They actually braised the chicken!  

I ordered the #4 at which point the lady behind the counter pulls a big piece of chicken from a giant braising pot onto the grill.  The fire from the grill licks at the chicken and then she pours some sort of sauce? Over it.  When it's done, she serves it on the big bed of rice with a tomato-y, onion-y, another drizzle of sauce and some cabbage slaw.  The chicken is indeed tender, flavorful, and juicy and the flavor of the chicken, the gravy, and the slaw work together amazingly!  I'm often not a fan of chicken skin, but this skin with the rice and gravy was just delightful!  Very satisfying and delicious. We'll def be back!
author: Kathryn C.

description:
Met up with a friend from high school here on my trip to San Fran. She's been living in SF since she graduated so I trust that she knows the really good places to eat!

She suggested here, not only because the food is delicious, but also you definitely can't beat the price, quality, AND quantity of food you get here! The portions were MORE than filling, I couldn't even finish my meal. And on top of that, my meal was less than $10 for everything!

I ordered the Number 4 on the menu, 1/2 the 5-spiced chicken, country salad, and their special meat sauce on rice. YUMMM.. The meat sauce is pretty tasty! And the meat was very juicy and tender. Ahh, I was surprised at the price and the amount of food I got! Normally in SF, everything is just so expensive.. So the fact that this little "hole in the wall' restaurant exists with the prices they offer, I was amazed!

My friend and her boyfriend ordered the number 3 and Mapo tofu to share, and even that was too much food for the both of them.

This is definitely one place I'll be returning to on my next trip to SF!
author: Cara Y.

description:
Everything in SF in just ridiculously expensive BUT... If you follow the natives, they know how to eat on a budget. My GF and I've been so lucky to have visited SF like on a monthly basis for the past year and we wanted to venture out of the tourist traps and try some hole in the wall places and we're so very glad we did because we ended up here.

As you can see in my video, this place is not very big and it's not the most glamorous restaurant. There's maybe 20-25 seats in the entire restaurant but we noticed that they make their money from their to go orders. While we are dinner here on a Saturday night, there might've been 10 people all night but their phone rang ever 3 minutes!

The food was AMAZING and CHEAP which is crazy not only bc it's in SF but those two usually don't go hand in hand. I really can't even begin to describe the taste but I'll give it a try: very fresh, authentic, and unique. And they give you A LOT of food!!! 

I can't wait to be back!
author: Jang N.

description:
Oh my dear cordon bleu,
I'm so grateful I stumbled upon you
The best chicken outside Vietnam 
Is an understatement for sure nom nom nom!
Feeling like royalty eating Imperial rolls 
Stuffing our faces with noodle bowls
The rustic decor adds to the charm
Come see for yourself, 
What's the harm?
author: Alisa W.

description:
A California St classic / institution.
This hole in the wall has nothing to hide. It's streetfood is honest and tasty. Come with an empty stomach because portions are huge. 

Service is super friendly.
author: John W.

description:
For the price and portion, the food is really good! The lunch specials are all under 8 dollars and provide lots of food! It's definitely a hole in the wall with a tiny staff and limited seating, but the staff is really nice and do their best. 

Upon seeing reviews, I was a little scared seeing that the woman cooking was using the same thongs to handle all of the food, but at least they were all meat. For the price, you can't really complain about sanitary issues. My only issue is that they are kind of disorganized and some of the "kebabs" are definitely over cooked, but they really try their best! I highly suggest going here for lunch, but don't expect fine dining!
author: Eric Joseph D.

description:
Love finding little gems like this. 

The meals are giant portions and inexpensive at that. I had the rice with meat sauce which came with 2 imperial rolls. While the sauce itself doesn't look all that appetizing, it was actually delicious. It was faintly sweet while having a nice, thick consistency that added just the right amount of meatiness to the rice to make you want more with each bite without tasting too heavy. But the real star of the show here was the imperial rolls. Supremely crunchy on the inside while being filled generously with meat, I wish I had more than 2 (even though each one was already large and filling). 

The kitchen itself is tiny and seats only about 10 people so the line can get long as it's just one main lady cooking, taking orders and serving. However, if you're willing to wait or get there at a good time, you'll be rewarded with some kick ass food!
author: Jason W.

description: This is our weekly dinner spot and we are so grateful for this little shop! It doesn't have many seats but totally works for our situation since we always get takeouts on the weekdays. Our favorites are the chicken salad (delicious!) and number 5 combo (hubby's fav.).
author: Emily Y.

description: great food, got the half chicken combo
author: Michael Y.

description:
This is a total hole in the wall restaurant on California St.  There aren't more than 8-10 seats at the counter area and a couple of tables in the back. I'm amazed that they could even fit that many seats in the small space.  I will just say it's cozy! We went after the Santa Con and the place was packed, but I suspect it's like that all the time because the food is so good!   People are hovering around waiting for seats to open up, it's that good. The nice part of sitting at the counter watching your food being prepared is that you may get a minute to chat with the owner of Cordon Blue, Katie, who is one of the nicest people I have met. 

I got the #5 which is Piece Five Spiced Roast Chicken, 1 Imperial Roll, 1 Shish Kebab, Country Salad, Meat Sauce On Rice.  The shish kebab pork was great and the imperial roll was huge and they were not stingy with the meat and veggies. The five spice chicken that Katie makes is full of flavor and melts in your mouth. I wanted to take some home, but we had many more stops and were staying in San Francisco, so no to go chicken for me.  Instead of serving the chicken with plain steamed rice they slather it with a mouthwatering gravy that is tomato based with some secret spices. It was a huge plate of food that we shared for just $10.50! 

My friend got the Garlicky Tofu which includes tofu and shitake mushroom in creamy garlic bean sauce served over rice.  Talk about another amazing gravy! You need to soak it all up with rice or just lick the plate.

Next time I'm in the area I will be sure to go back to this great place!  Oh, this is a cash only establishment.
author: Robin W.

description:
This is definitely one of the hidden, hole in the wall restaurants that you wouldn't know about unless you were a local. Cheap. Authentic. Delicious.

I was walking around the area looking for inexpensive food when Yelp showed me this place. I was surprised I've never heard of Corbin Bleu (especially since it has 900+ reviews and 4 stars). When I got here, I understood why. It's a very small restaurant that's not exactly the cleanest. There's counter seats and you can see your food being cooked in front of you. 

My sisters and I ordered two dishes (#3 and #4) and it was more than enough to food to fill us up. The portions are HUGE. You get some vegetables and a giant mound of rice per plate. They put this secret meat sauce on your rice. I have no idea what it is but it's amazing. The best part was the 5 SPICE HALF ROAST CHICKEN. I was shocked by how big the chicken was. They literally give you half the chicken. The marinade was perfect. It was heavenly. I recommend #4. The meat for #3 was a tad dry and no where nearly as good. 

And better yet, each plate is ~$8!! What a steal. Definitely coming back here for yummy and cheap food.
author: Melinda L.

description:
It was amazing! You have the feeling to be in Vietnam and the taste of the food is real and authentic. 
You have need to go there !
author: Laure C.

description: I saw this on yelp longtime ago... but jus decided to drop by after my friend said its really good...to me i love the grill pork, the imperial roll with vietnamese style wrap rice paper... the chicken not so special about it... it dont worth 1hr wait of my time for this food....
author: Michael P.

description: Cheap dinner near the Polk street before you get wasted, unmmm yeaaaaaa, but beware of long waits cause there is barely any seating and you might need to hustle to get your order in cause the chef is also the waiter so you better catch them quick, the food was good especially the imperial rolls, that was bombbbbbb and that meat sauce smothering that bbq pork yummmmmmm
author: Arcadian B.

description: Went there today to order food to go bc they wouldn't pick up the phone. Yelp said it was open; this was at 4p. I go in and the lady asks what I want and after telling her my order she said they were going to close for an hour and a half and that nobody was going to cook my order. Awesome service..not. Lost this customer for sure.
author: Jatziel T.

description: Great comfort food! This small Restaurant packs a big punch in flavor. The imperialRolls are so tasty and the portions are huge! The price is just right and you will leave full and happy. There are only a few tables and only a few people working so it can be a bit of a wait, however the food comes out hot, fresh and fast.
author: Sarah F.

description:
Cordon Bleu is a no frills hole in a wall kind of spot. Don't expect for bathrooms, do expect for small spaces and for hot food being cooked less than a foot from your face. Katie is a no bullshit lady who runs her space and she's all about being efficient. She's not here to make small talk with you or to hear your life story. She's just gonna cook your food and collect your cash. 

Portions are pretty big, we shared #5 which came with an order of imperial rolls, beef and chicken over rice with meat sauce. I can't attest to how authentic the food here is. The owners are Vietnamese Chinese, not ethnically Vietnamese. The cooking reminded me a blend of Cantonese Hong Kong cooking. Especially with tomato meat sauce over rice, it's a popular hong kong dish (baked rice). The 5 spice chicken was subtle, it could be a stronger. 

Not too shabby for $10.84 I guess
author: Virginia Y.

description:
This place predates the popularity of Vietnamese food but is now owned by Cantonese Chinese and moved about 50 feet.  I first came here in the early 80s and not much has changed.

Great value--2 half roast chicken meals for $20.  It's a tiny place and not the cleanest.  Get the food to go.
author: Joanna S.

description: Such a stellar restaurant. The food is excellently cooked, right in the front of the restaurant. The meals are incredibly well-priced and you feel as though you're getting a great deal - taste, quantity, price. A must-visit in Nob Hill.
author: Natalie Y.

description:
As with all the best ethnic food restaurants- they are always the hole in the wall places. This place is no different. 

There's some seating inside- 2 tables and the countertop. But I had gotten takeout. 

The food here was really flavorful. I got the five spiced chicken combo. The sauce that they have over the rice is so good. I've never had Vietnamese food like this before. And the chicken was so flavorful all the way through. Definitely a must try.
author: Jenny J.

description:
A small local mom and pop feel restaurant with minimal seating but her food makes me feel good, satisfies my appetite and makes me crave it from time to time.

I love her egg rolls here. It's nothing I've had anywhere else before.
author: Sol P.

description: I've got always my best time and tasty lunches in this little place. Not very pleasant to see at first and probably the menu has limited choices but surely once you try a dish, you wanna get them all. Recommended ones? I'd choose them all in once!
author: Matteo A.

description: Great hole in the wall. Bit of a wait on a weekend night but it was worth it. All of the food is cooked on the grill, fryer, or wok right in front of you. The #5 is what everyone gets here which gives you some of everything. The chicken is succulent and I think better than the kabob meat but it was all great. The mapo tofu was also really good and tasted just like home.
author: Dani T.

description: Simply GREAT! Not overpriced super casual and delicious. I love going here whenever I'm in a rush for dinner. Perfect for eating in or take out. I'm in disbelief that only two women seem to be taking all the orders! Definitely a must try.
author: Anne P.

description: Katie always keeps me coming back for more.  One of the first places I went to in SF and one of the only places I feel a loyalty to.  Cordon Bleu will never disappoint with Katie at the helm.  #5 is the best, but you may want an extra imperial roll, if you're really hungry.
author: Max K.

description:
This wonderful little hole in the wall has a very simple menu, pretty quick turn around, and filling portions at amazing prices. In fact the side orders themselves are like little meals themselves for under $4. 

The environment there is everything you'd want from a little Vietnamese dive restaurant. It's a tiny lunch counter that everyone eats around, making it a very homey place where it's easy to chat with a new neighbor.  But it's also super small so if it's busy you might think about taking your food to go.

I went for the lunch special and got exactly what I wanted. The food is very simple so I added a bit of the Sriracha which they have readily available. I was super satisfied when I left!
author: Graham S.

description:
I like hole in the walls, greasy spoons, and dives frequented by lots of regulars, but I really don't like raw chicken. Don't get me wrong - I prefer my chicken just barely cooked, and I think that the overwhelming majority of places overcook their chicken. I don't mind if the chicken is a little pink, but I definitely don't like it raw and bloody.

I ordered the Combo #4 which included a half chicken, country salad, meat sauce, and rice. The half chicken came in two parts - the leg and thigh were slightly undercooked - and I'm totally cool with that. It actually tasted pretty good. The breast and wing were kind of raw. Even the wing was kind of pink. The breast meat had the cool slimy texture of raw chicken and I had the taste of bloody chicken in my mouth afterwards. Gross!

Although most of the other reviewers said that their meal was cooked to order, the chicken most certainly is not cooked to order. Anyone who has cooked chicken on the bone before knows that it takes awhile to cook it, so many restaurants just reheat the chicken on the grille before serving, and Cordon Bleu is no exception. They actually keep the pre-cooked chicken in a tray under the counter about 6 inches from the floor, which is also pretty gross.

The owner is very friendly, and nearly all the other customers were regulars who greeted to the owner by name, speaking in English or Cantonese.  It seems that the Imperial Rolls are the thing to get - but I didn't try any.
author: Allen T.

description: Best meal for the money in all of San Francisco. Mary and the gang's incredible cooking has made me a regular. If you're from out of town, don't be intimidated by the compactness of the space. See if the table in the back is open or wait for a seat to open up at the bar. Get the #4 if you're pretty hungry or the #5 if you're super hungry--you won't be disappointed.
author: Chris W.

description:
Food - BOMB.com
Price - super cheap considering the prime SF location
Place - hole in the wall with really limited seating

Came here on a Friday night with the whole family plus grandparents. Considered ourselves VERY lucky to find enough tables/chairs to accommodate our big party. My older relatives did not want to sit at the counter because it was too close to the stove and they said they couldn't breathe with all the smoke. Whole family loved the food though, and the prices were unbelievably low. Every single meat was tender and extremely well flavored with just a bit of smoke. Oh, and portions are HUGE. Two people can easily share one order, leaving enough room for imperial rolls. Lots of people coming in to pick up orders to go, which is probably what I'll do next time I come.
author: Melinda W.

description: i still love this restaurant after all these years! got the no. 5 combo and it was $15 after tax and tip - amazing meal. the meats are cooked perfectly and the imperial roll is deliciously packed full of meat and fried to perfection. the meat sauce is insane too - just wish they'd give you more ladles of that per plate! would come back in a heartbeat.
author: Christina L.

description: Not sure about the hype of this place. I ordered the noodle salad with chicken n imperial roll. The space is pretty small but that didn't bother me at all. What I didn't like was the food. The chicken is precooked so all they do is put it back on the grill to heat it up. That made the chicken pretty dry and inedible and I did not taste any five spice seasoning on the chicken ...it was pretty bland. Also the imperial roll isn't a bad side but it looked like it was also precooked and they just drop it back in the fryer to heat it up and it wasn't very crunchy. I noticed that the cook uses the same tongs to handle raw n cooked food. Additionally they use very cheap iceberg lettuce for the salad and there was a good amount of water sitting at the bottom of my noodle salad bowl even before I poured in the sauce.
author: Mai C.

description: Very good lunch spot. I had one of the combos that came with 1 Imperial Roll, 1 Shish Kebab, Country Salad, Meat Sauce On Rice. So hearty and filling. Perfect for a rainy day when you want a warm, delicious meal.
author: Run.It.Off V.

description: This place will fill you up. The imperial rolls are great and the curry meat sauce satisfies a craving I usually get every few weeks. Simple comfort food stuff. I prefer to get my order to go since the place is tiny and usually crowded.. and you'll usually smell like the place if you stay too long. Definitely worth giving this place a shot as it seems to be a SF classic. I met a guy in Bali who had lived in SF 20 some odd years ago & he asked me if that place is still around, ha! So if it withstood the test against time, they must be doing something right!
author: J Y.

description: Crazy good generous portions. Atmosphere is awesome as well feels like home. Very intimate with the chef because they're cooking right in front of you.
author: Leon H.

description:
I haven't been back in 15 years. We had to drive into SF to get a travel vaccine not available anywhere near me. 

On the drive in, the debate started. Wife and I had to figure out where to eat. We were all over the place. Dumplings, garlic crab, Korean......
Then someone said, "hey do you think Cordon Bleu is still open?"  

Done deal!  We actually ate at a hole in the wall wonton house first. Then wandered a bit, and went to see if the meat sauce was the same. It was a pleasure to see the same lady running the place. The smell hit us and it was instant reminder of times past. I wouldn't say the sauce is exactly how I remember it, but I was still comfort food 101. The sauce is an enigma. I couldn't even say with certainty what meat is in it!  Chicken? Beef?  I don't have balls to ask. :). I just shovel it into my face. I told the lady we were from Santa Rosa. She felt compelled to keep putting more food on our plates not unlike a mom trying to fatten you up with love. More kebab, more drumsticks. 

I asked her," when you announce retirement, will you teach me the meat sauce?"  Her grin in response gave me hope!  After all, she didn't say NO.  

Thanks Katie.
author: Cliff L.

description: Really enjoyed the #4. It was a nice sized portion of chicken on top of a bed of rice and meat sauce, with some cabbage. Chicken was cooked very nicely on the grill and had a satisfying char. This is a great neighborhood hole in the wall.
author: Michael S.

description:
This is definitely one of my go-to places now. I remember hitting it up the first time for dinner and it was packed. It seems like most people go for the chicken. I stopped by for lunch another time and there were a couple of regulars. They were trying to guess what my friend and I would get and were both surprised that we weren't going to get #5.

I actually ended up getting the shish kabob with the imperial roll. As to why it's called shish kabob, no one knows. It really is just Vietnamese thit nuong to me. The meat sauce reminds me of my grandpa's Viet ragu. I guess this place just evokes nostalgia.

The portions are huge and the shish kabob is full of flavor. She sometimes makes them in batches so hopefully you come at the beginning of one. Finally, the pricing is reasonable.
author: James N.

description:
I'm sorry to post a bad review as this is obviously a small business. However, it was upsetting to see the woman cooking with the Same thongs used for raw meat, cooked meat to plate and handle the dirty rag she used to clean the grill. She also handled money with the gloves she had on without switching. 

On top of all that, I waited for 25 min for 1 plate to go!! I didn't wait for the food after 25 min and walked out. The food must be good with the reviews but I don't want a side of salmonella with it. I'm not sure how they passed the health inspection!
author: Joina L.

description: Ordered the number one. Very generous portions.  I was only able to eat half before feeling full. The imperial roll and the shish kabob were super delicious. The shish kabob tasted a little sweet and savory. I wasn't too impressed with the meat sauce that was on the rice. Didn't taste like much other than tomato. But overall, really delicious meal.
author: Annie H.

description: I've been ordering food from here since the late 70's and they've always been solid. Thank you Cordon Bleu.
author: Phil L.

description:
It's too bad that this place wasn't better. I really had high hopes. It didn't hurt that it has 900 reviews and four stars. We were lucky enough to get seats at the counter without waiting. The person grilling was nice, but several times I saw her checking meat, seeing that it was burnt, and still putting it on the plate or the takeout box. I know a lot of people like the meat sauce over rice, but the problem is that it gets the imperial rolls all soggy really quick. And it's like they expect you to eat the imperial rolls with the meat sauce. You have to actually ask for the fish vinaigrette that comes standard with imperial rolls at every other Vietnamese restaurant. 

Okay, one more thing. I hate to put this out there where everyone can read it, and I wasn't sure whether or not I should put this in my review, but I did see the woman at the grill put a half-eaten slice of pepperoni pizza on the grill to warm up. Yes, with all the customers' meat.
author: M T.

description:
When you first walk in, you may be a little caught off guard by how small this place is and I SMALL, and just a tad bit rough around the edges. Oddly enough, I think this is what makes the place so intriguing.

There are quite a few combinations, noodle dishes, salads, and vegetarian options. I went with option #1 which had the yummy meat sauce on top of white rice topped with pork kabab, a side of cabbage, and a deep fried spring roll, WOAH!!!!

The food is cooked right in front of you and literally grilled to perfection. Not sure what seasoning they use on the meat but it was divine. The meat sauce kind of threw me off at first but seriously it is worth trying. The flavor was so good, the perfect sauce to dip pretty much anything into. The pork was perfectly sliced thin, but it was a tad bit salty, almost too salty even. 

I LOVE spring rolls and egg roles so having this deep fried delight was like an added bonus. Prices are good, but space is super limited so I suggest ordering ahead of time and taking it to go.
author: Sabrina J.

description:
I've been looking forward to trying this spot for quite some time that when I finally made it, my expectations were so high that I was slightly disappointed. 

I ordered Combo 5:
+Imperial Roll: so crispy & delicious. Definitely coming back for this!

+5 Spice Chicken: very flavorful but not the best I've had

+Shish Kabob: a bit overlooked 

+Meat over Rice: a bit bland, needs some seasoning

Overall, a good value since it's enough for two meals. Limited eat-in seating so best for takeout.
author: Ruby C.

description:
To say that this is a hole in a wall is as much of an understatement as to say that Socrates liked to ponder. You walk in (if you're lucky enough to find a parking spot), and sit down on the warmest seat at the bar (if you're lucky enough to find a seat). Don't be surprised that it stays as busy as it does - there's only a few seats, and one two-top in the back, the other being a four-top that is sometimes taken up as their "bus" station - what's there to bus, not quite sure, as the gentleman dishwasher pops out to check for more work often. The place is run by two ladies, moving about behind the bar, cutting the chicken with the one pair of scissors between them, using the one pair of tongs. You eye the half-pints of nuoc cham sauce teetering on the corner of the bar. You order the #5, with all of their meat options, rice, and their spaghetti sauce (not unlike warmed-up chef boyardee, but better), or, you feel like something lighter, so you order the vegetable eggrolls over noodles. But will there be nuc cham with it? Will there be enough eggrolls? Better order more. You're so pleased when 10 minutes later, two souffle cups that are filled with the sparkling, clear, rose-and-gold colored sauce with those floating flecks that beckon you appear on the formaica counter next to the single dollar tip left by the invisible patron that preceeded you. You eat, suprised at its' deliciousness, surprised that in 8 minutes, it's all gone, surprised that already, you're heading to the bathroom, which is a whole 'nother kit-and-kaboodle. You try to glance through the curtain to look into the dishpit as you walk by, disappointed in what the vantage point lacked. You leave, tipping them over 50% to compensate for the invisible being. 

Step out into the rain, you know you'll be back, but this time, you'll know where to find a spot, you'll know to leave early, you'll know to bring more cash.
author: Pesya M.

description: Have been going here for years and it's such a one-off that I dream about it from time to time.  If ANYONE knows of an even remotely similar Vietnamese place in LOS ANGELES, for the love of God tell me where it is!  The Bleu is immense; may they live forever.  I've never found any place like it, what they do with savory meat sauce over rice and the barbecued meaty meatstuffs.  HELP, yelp.  Help!
author: John Andrew F.

description: I love this hole-in-the-wall BOYB restaurant. Great to have dinner with a couple friends and crack a bottle of wine or beers while you eat some greasy, flavorful food. The menu is also super simple where the number of things you get increases with the number of the menu item. No more choice paralysis. I always get the number 5 which is the largest meal which comes with chicken thighs, rice with meat sauce, three pieces of spare ribs and a massive fried egg roll. The chicken is always tender and charred on the grill perfectly.
author: Kyle R.

description:
We gave up after 15 minutes into waiting for Swan Oyster Depot and wandered here. Appeared to be a great decision. 

We had the Number 4 (chicken) $8+ and chicken lunch special $7+. For a dollar's difference, there was an extra piece of meat on the plate. The chicken was grilled to order and really tender. Rice portion was huge. Sauce tasted like baked beans and made it easier to polish off the rice. 

It wasn't crowded on a Saturday lunch but there was a steady stream of customers (mostly regulars). Quaint place with decent food at a good price. 

We finished our meal and walked back past Swan Oyster Depot with a satisfied belly. As expected, the queue had only moved a few steps front in the time I had my lunch. The SOD queue will be challenged another day, and I will certainly head here again if my heart wavers while being stuck in that queue.
author: Lindt C.

description: Get #5. It basically a sampler platter filled with goodness. My favorite was the spring rolls!
author: Jade L.

description:
This has got to be one of the best value for your money for delicious, authentic Asian food. It's a hole in the wall, with just seating at the counter and two tables in the back. It's a family run business (assuming that it's a couple running the place). You see everything that they're making behind the counter. When the place is busy, it may be slow, because it is literally just the couple taking orders, making food, and everything else. 

When you are walking by and don't see a line out the door, you must stop by to eat! The chicken salad is phenomenal. Combo #5 is the way to go - you get some of everything, including the grilled chicken (you can choose between breast and leg), grilled pork, and the imperial roll (THE best roll of it's kind in SF). 

But what really makes this place stand out is the meat sauce. I have no idea what this sauce is made from but it is amazing. They douse the rice with this sauce and I just can't get enough. 

So good! You'll also get huge portions for less than $15 for top notch Vietnamese food. Can't be beat.
author: Sally C.

description:
Really simple meal. Very tasty 5-spice chicken. 

Tiny place where they give you a lot of food, and they even don't charge very much.
author: T B.

description: Stumbled upon this place and so glad I did. Get the combo #5. It's so good. Love the simple menu and cheap eats. The place is basically an tiny open sitting with counter kitchen. Order with the cook sit down and just eat. Make sure you have some time because the place is super small.  It's also cash only. One of my favorite food places in SF.
author: Michael B.

description: Great food! Cheap, large portions, and locally owned. Would definitely suggest #5. Those imperial roles.
author: Sean M.

description:
Fave hole in the wall for a hearty meal. Been here twice. Tried the mix platter #5 (chicken, grilled meat, Imperial roll & rice over meat sauce) OMG it was the bomb ! 

Second visit we took mapo tofu with rice. Portion is enormous for one, best to come here with your foodie partner :-)
author: Hester D.

description: The food is good def a whole in the wall. If you know this before going there you want be disappointed.   I've been here several time never had to use the restroom facilities so my review is based on the restroom not the food. Although it's a whole in the wall I wasn't expecting the restroom to be fancy just clean. It was so over taken by flies and gnats that I decided to just hold it and take my food to go. Now I know rent is expensive there but bleach, pinesol, deodorizers and rubber gloves aren't. Just taking a little more time to  invest into your business will take you a lot further. Again my review is only based on restroom nothing that a little bleach can't fix. When the facilities improve I will update my review.
author: Yoni O.

description: No.5 Is ALIVE! All the numbered dishes are awesome, but my favorite is the No.5. The 5 spice chicken is amazing, in the dishes or by itself.. For take away you cant go wrong and if there is room at the counter, i like to eat in every now and then to feel like I'm in the mix watching the cooking going on infant of me. Also, the imperial roll is like a cross between an Aussie sausage roll and a traditional Vietnamese egg roll.. big and chunky.. Oh so good!
author: Chris M.

description:
I've found that the most delicious Vietnamese food is often served in hole-in-the-wall restaurants. The restaurant is very tiny. I think there were maybe 9-10 seats around the kitchen area and 1 small table in the back. The menu is also very simple. There are 5 entree options, 4 house specials, and some a la carte items. I ordered Number 1 (1 imperial roll, 1 shish kebab, salad, and sauce on rice) while my boyfriend ordered Number 5 (basically Number 1 plus a roasted chicken). The imperial roll was definitely my favorite part of the entree. I mean, who doesn't like fried food? It's basically a giant egg roll, but with much tastier filling.

This place is cash only but the food is so cheap, $10 should suffice. I look forward to coming back for more imperial rolls and delicious food!
author: Helen P.

description: This place is crazy good. I think I cried. My companions advised me to order the number 5, and I'm passing that wisdom along to you. Order it. The Imperial Roll has ruined me for all other rolls.
author: Melissa C.

description: First time here!  Absolutely loved this little family owned place! Food was so delicious. Will definitely be one of my stops on every visit to San Francisco. We ordered the number five.  The chicken was amazing. I can't wait to go back and try the vermicelli Bowl with Chicken. Looks amazing!
author: Allison R.

description:
I might have ordered the wrong thing so I'm not sure I understand the 5-star hype but I'm willing to try it again.

PORK CHOPS: the pork is super lean and didn't have a lot of flavor. I was hoping for that super flavorful pork and even with a fried egg on it but it was just pork on rice with a salad.  I wanted to like it more but unfortunately it was an average piece of pork on rice.

NOODLE SALAD: this is the tastiest "salad" I've ever had since it was mostly a huge mound of meat!  Comes with iceberg lettuce as the base, with rice noodles, an imperial roll, and "shish kebob".  But in reality the shish kebob is more like thinly sliced marinated pork.  This pork was a lot more flavorful than the pork chops and with the fish sauce was really good but seemed a little overcooked.  The imperial roll was crispy and flavorful. It was a little burnt for my taste but it was good enough that I would totally try it again.

Overall I think all the meats seemed a little on the dry and overcooked side but I can see how the flavor could be really good and it's like a huge portion of comfort food.  I'd try it again and maybe I'd be more adventurous and try the combos that come with "meat sauce" on the rice next time too.

Cash only.

Counter seating only and it's tiny so if you're eating in, there could be a wait. I called in a takeout order and they told me 20 minutes and it was ready totally on time!
author: Traci H.

description: This is the quintessential hole in the wall place that makes SF great.  We came here after waiting in line for 30 minutes at Swan Oyster Depot.  It's a tiny place with a bar and just a couple of tables.  The owner/cook is very friendly.  She takes your order, cooks it in front of you, and serves it to you.  We had a couple of the lunch specials with the chicken and also the shish kebab and imperial roll.  You definitely get a lot for your money.  Two lunch specials, a side order of imperial roll, and a Pepsi for about $20.  You could order another lunch special and it still would be less than what you'd pay for one crab salad at Swan.  There's something not quite right about that.
author: Ronny T.

description: One of the best and most unique dining experiences I have enjoyed in SF this far. Brought me back to my childhood growing in Tennessee. Very similar style to lowland country cooking with large portions, delicious meat and gravy (meat sauce). So much great Vietnamese in the city, but no place I have been has done food like this.
author: Zack K.

description:
I saw the cook fully burn a chicken leg. My friend and I thought "oh...she definitely won't serve that" "she'll probably grill a new one." NOPE!! That fully burnt chicken leg got put on my plate and served to me. This was after she picked it up and looked at the burnt piece for a bit and then proceeded to peel off the skin (because IT WAS SO BURNT). She then tried to cover up the missing skin with their gravy sauce. I do not mind charred meat because I actually like that taste, but I tried to eat the chicken and it tasted like charcoal and ash. I asked for a new piece, which she was annoyed at (the new piece was grilled to perfection).

The grill is out in the open so you can see exactly what is being grilled and I saw her burn another piece during my time there and again, gave it to the customer. The guy being served had the same look of amazement that I had - "did she really just give me this piece of fully burnt chicken?"

I will not be returning to Cordon Bleu.
author: Jennifer T.

description: Home cooking style kitchen with delicious food! I stop in here for a nice, inexpensive, filling lunch often. The combo #3 is my favorite and comes with a huge heaping of rice, several shishkabob slices, meat sauce and some cabbage. So good! I would definitely recommend stopping by if you are hungry and want a good meal.
author: Art G.

description: We just happened to spot this place walking around Nob Hill and decided to stop in since as the prices were really good.  For under $10 you can get a huge plate of delicious food and the service is great. The lady was so sweet, my husband finishes his food before me and she topped up his plate with more meat, rice and sauce. I had the 5 spice chicken combo, delicious flavorful chicken. My husband had pork and loved it. There is only counter seating but it's like going to eat at a friend house with their grandma and mom fussing around you. I love it!!!!!
author: Soolin W.

description: Huge portions of great food at a low price. Nothing wrong there. The imperial rolls are amazing, and the gravy is so satisfying. I definitely prefer the chicken over the shish kabob, but you really can't go wrong here. Tiny hole-in-the-wall, but worth stopping by!
author: Cynthia M.

description: This is one of my favorite places to get a hearty meal in Nob Hill. The owner is a friendly lady who does the grilling of the chicken herself. The place seats just about 10 people and has a cozy feel. I highly recommend getting the Imperial Rolls in addition to the five spiced chicken. Don't be surprised that the accompanied rice is drenched in in the secret orange sauce.
author: Young Y.

description: I love this restaurant. Katie, the owner is awesome. It's a small restaurant and when you get a seat at the bar, Katie cooks right in front of you. She is also very friendly and treats makes you feel welcome like your eating at her home. Everything tastes delicious with huge servings--I always leave with a doggie bag. Try the veggie spring rolls and ask Katie for some peanut sauce on the side. Nom Nom Nom.
author: Will P.

description: This place is a hidden treasure. Only fits a handful of people but Kate is the best host, the food is great and the servings are huge (seriously, I dare you to finish a whole plate). Only drawback is that the shop is cash only.
author: Juan S.

description: We decided to give this restaurant a try while visiting San Francisco. Arrived at the restaurant at a less busy time (around 2pm on Tuesday). There are only two other customers. The place is really tiny, can hold probably 10 customers at a time. We ordered #1 and #5, our local friend got a small salad. The price is very reasonable. however, the service is slow. The lady who grills meat, for some reason, decided to make supply orders. While she made a few phone calls, we sit at the counter and watched our chicken and pork burnt into charcoal. 20 mins after making the order, we got our all hard and crispy meat on the plates. Maybe it is our bad luck after seeing other good reviews. But those food are not appealing and we decided to leave.
author: Stan L.

description:
Great portion with low price! Me and my boyfriend ordered a No.5 and an extra imperial roll, and the amount is just right for us. So I suggest if you bring your friends, you could share some food instead of ordering one whole entree for everyone. The food is very good especially the imperial roll and the shish kebab, the five spice chicken is very tasty too! (You may not like it over burned a little bit, but I'm fine with that)

The place was very small and not easy to find. Only two ladies(I believe one of them is the owner) are working. So you may not expect too much "service" from them cuz they are busy cooking and helping everybody. But just be patient, they act quick and try not to let people wait. And they are nice too.
author: Sunny L.

description: Bomb!! Incredible Viet food. Large serving size and you eat well for about $10-15. Will 100% be back asap with friends. Oh, it's cash only please!!
author: Kyle D.

description:
I was exploring my new neighborhood and actually on my way to another place when I strolled past this gem.
I was intrigued because the view I saw inside reminded me of the mom and pop shops I eat at when in south east Asia. So, dinner plans changed and I decided to try this place. I was not disappointed!

First, this place is a mom and pop shop and I love the feel of being in someone's kitchen that you get from sitting at the counter.

Secondly, everything is made to order and the imperial rolls are really good here.

Third, the portions are huge so come with an appetite. I actually could not finish all of my plate, but I did not really expect to.

Fourth, this place is really affordable especially in such an extremely high cost city it's great to find a restaurant that does not charge a 500 percent markup on the food.

If you are a local or an out of towner looking to try a local gem then this is your place--and make sure you bring cash!
author: Corey H.

description:
The plated meal is best described as leftover magic.  Comforting, cheap and unrefined.

I've dined in and picked up take outs from here.  After parading along Polk Street all night, this place is a paradise.  However, subsequent visits were less impressive.  I felt like Goldilocks, filling my tummy with the good, bad and ugly.  Some pieces of meat were a little too dry and chewy, some burnt and others were just right.  

Comb No 5 has a little bit of Monica, Erica and etc.  It consists of several types and preparation of meats with a large helping of rice.  The steamed rice was covered in a red meat sauce--tomato/ketchup, onion and ground meat mixture likely with some cornstarch/flour for thickness.  I thought the sauce was necessary to moisten the burnt or dried slices of pork.  It came with a tiny quarter leg of chicken that was juicy and not burnt.  The Imperial roll was very greasy but would likely be delicious after a few drinks.  The cabbage slaw was the tangy amuse bouche that kept me eating.

I also tried the chicken salad.  It  was hard to navigate through the excessive mystery meat and burnt pieces.  I had to pull off the skin, cartilage, bone and pure carbon before diving back in for the kill. Skipping this one next time.  It was too much work.
author: Amy J.

description:
Great hole in the wall. Authentic. Hard to find spots like this in SF. Reasonably priced. Food is amazing. Atmosphere is intimate and pulls you outside the US. Patrons are friendly and worldly too- i like the positive, friendly vibes. Always have meat on the grill but have good veggie options for peeps like me. 
When you get there you gotta hope there is space to sit if that's your plan. It's a small place with limited seating. You'll also have to be patient to order and patient to get the food. It's worth it.
author: Nani B.

description:
Cordon Bleu is my favorite type of eatery.

Big portions, relatively inexpensive, and so, so good!

Cordon Bleu is on California near Polk and it's a tiny storefront wedged in betwixt a Chase Bank and something else. It's like a block from the TJs on California and a few blocks from one of my all time faves, House of Prime Rib.

There's a counter which has about 7-10 stools, a table that can fit 4 max, and another table that can fit 2 max. WARNING: if you don't get there when they open at 11:30, with seating limited as it is, you're taking a chance that you're gonna get there and it's full and you'll end up eating somewhere inferior because you were too lazy to leave a little earlier from work than you usually do. Get there early brah!

There's 2-3 little ladies that run the place and they do all the prep and cooking. Vietnamese comfort food is what they serve, and girl it is hella ngon (delicious in the vernacular)!!

Their menu is one page, they got 5 specials, the most popular being #5 which is a taste of everything good in the vietnamese world - shish kabob (bbq pork), grilled chicken (you choose either a breast or wing & thigh), a huge imperial roll (most likely THEE BEST imperial roll in SF), some pickled cabbage to balance the flavors, and if that wasn't enough, all that goodness is resting on a bed of hot, white rice TOPPED with their secret meat sauce! oh the fun you'll have!

It's all fresh and cooked to order right in front of you as the grill is literally in front of the counter seating, so there can be a wait, especially if the place is full, but worth the wait.

bring cash cause it's CASH ONLY no cards, checks, bitcoin, paypal, apple pay, or offers to wash the plates.

Here's to the ones who dream!
author: Ray R.

description: Decent food, I arrived at the restaurant before they opened and they were 20 mins late. Coming in, the old lady cleaned the grill with this towel soak in a can of water on the floor, THEN PUT THE TOWEL BACK IN THE CAN. I order the combo #5. Quick food, taste 3/5. Nothing special but it's cheap.
author: Quang H.

description: Oh the egg rolls!! So freaking good and cheap! And they are gigantic! I can eat one and be full for dinner. The other dishes are delicious too, but sometimes it's inconsistent.  But what can you expect for a huge $10 rice plate in SF?!
author: Phuong L.

description: Don't let the tiny, greasy, hole-in-the-wall appearance of this place fool you. Hands down the best Bún I've every eaten. I stopped in on a weekday afternoon after 3pm to avoid a wait. I ordered the noodle salad which included a large imperial roll, marinated grilled pork, rice noodles & pickled radishes over greens with a nice sweet slightly sour dressing. The pork was marinated to perfection...so tasty! Very fresh ingredients.
author: Lori M.

description: Have always walked by this hole in the wall spot but finally decided to check it out on a whim one Friday night. As usual, we checked out the yelp reviews and menu photos prior to heading over.  Initially tried to call in but phone was busy so just headed over. It was a very small place-counter seating for abt 10 ppl and 3 tables that seat another 8-10. Definitely a mom and pop type of joint which I love to support. Food was pretty good for the price point. Great value with solid large portions that was fresh and literally cooked as you waited. The one major downside was that despite ordering for take out we still waited nearly an hour for our food with the options being grilled chicken and pork combinations with imperial egg roll as an option. These are served with rice and some meat sauce or with rice noodle salad. All in all good food, good value, but be prepared to wait
author: Robert W.

description: I've had good and bad experiences  but I respect the work ethic of the owner. And, the food is always really good
author: James L.

description:
This is a good example of how you can thrive on a business with good social skills!
The owner is super friendly and has a strong customer base who keep coming back just to talk.

The food is horrid.  You sit there and you can see the process....it's worse than the leftovers I eat from at home....yuck!!!
Everything is made from stock and is disgusting! 

...and because I was a new customer, I was not given free peanuts to go with my food...such bias!

I would not even come out on a poor student's budget either....
author: David W.

description:
CASH ONLY

Best imperial rolls ever! My boyfriend and I loove this place! It's fun getting to sit at the counter and watch them make the food on the stove. The restaurant gets crowded since there's limited seating (best if you have only 2 people) but so worth the wait! I also saw a ton of people calling in to pick up their order.

Ordered the #5 (imperial roll, shish kebab, five spice chicken, meat sauce with rice, and small salad) which is ENORMOUS for only $10. Honestly that dish alone is enough to feed 2 people. It is so flavorful and the meat sauce over rice is really comforting and hearty. The imperial rolls are huge, deep fried and packed with meat/veggies. The chicken is so soft and perfectly spiced!

My boyfriend got the noodle salad which comes with an imperial roll and shish kebab ($9). Seriously up there for the vermicelli bowls I have had but I think the meat plates are the way to go. We finished both our meals but were so full afterwards. 

One of my favorite hole in the wall restaurants and love the amount you get for the prices. I highly recommend you check it out!!
author: Linda X.

description: Can't say enough how I love this place. Best value food for the taste. The meat sauce over the rice is excellent. Been coming here for 20 years
author: Alexei L.

description: A tiny little hole in the wall with very cheap, very tasty food. Their imperial rolls are to die for! Good spot for lunch or dinner by yourself or with a date who trusts you enough and is chill enough to disregard the lack of quality atmosphere.
author: Justin J.

description:
Kind of a wonder to behold. Tiny place where all the chicken is grilled, imperial rolls are fried, etc. right in front of or next to you. It does take quite a while for the orders to be prepped; they're super backed up with orders.

Was wanting plentiful veggies, so got the chicken salad, which was great, and very filling. Definitely want to try a meat place next time, though!
author: Shendi X.

description: Home cooking at its best. Bring cash and be ready to wait for a seat in the limited space. It's worth it, I swear. If you don't feel like waiting you can call in to order and take it home. The #5 comes with everything under the sun and could easily be shared between two (not-so-hungry) people. You get a choice of chicken leg or breast. The chicken breast here is not dry which makes it my top pick. The chicken salad is also a favorite of mine; it's refreshing and filling. Enjoy!
author: Alexandria T.

description:
I first came her when I was little and me and my mom saw a movie next door. That was 15 years ago and since then I go back any time I'm in the neighborhood. It really has't changed much since then.. If you like friendly faces, cozy small spaces, and deliciously large portions, this place is for you. It's basically one counter, and like two small tables in the back. The food is a great value for the big plate you get. Sometimes some food is burnt but you go along with it. The imperial rolls are hands down the best imperial rolls in the city. They're huge and hearty and fried! Yums. I could eat 100 of them in one sitting. 
I'm not a fan of the meat sauce - I usually get #1 with no meat sauce and i'm a happy camper. #1 is the grilled pork, imperial roll on top of rice with some side cabbage salad. I've also had their noodle salad which is good but could be greater if it wasn't soaked in sauce at the bottom, and wish they'd use cabbage instead of the iceburg lettuce pieces they use.
author: Veronica L.

description:
Wow happened upon this place because we were going to a bar nearby. Tiny place with a bar and a couple of tables. Two of the nicest ladies cooking and prepping food. Whole place smells amazing.
And the food does not disappoint. The meat sauce on anything is a must try. The half chicken dinner is delish and enough for two or lunch tomorrow. Noodle salad has an amazing array of meats and flavors. I'll be back!
author: Rebecca S.

description: A great little hole in the wall Vietnamese restaurant run by the chef/owner who prepares each dish with care detail and love. I had the #5 sampler and everything was tasty.  I'd go back if I'm ever in the neighborhood again.
author: Sasha B.

description:
So yummy. Huge portions and it's not expensive. Good price. Service is slow, limited seating, and CASH ONLY but I love it here.

#5 has everything. Five spice chicken (breast/leg), Grilled pork and a huge Imperial roll. I think its too much for just me, therefore I always order #1 grill pork or chicken with imperial roll. It comes with a side of slaw-ish and MEAT SAUCE. So good with rice. I can just eat that all day long. I have never had over cooked chicken and their imperials rolls are so good. Crispy and flavorful. My favorite "hole in the wall" comfort Vietnamese food.
author: Sandy B.

description: This place does the most simple dishes right.  Fresh grilled chicken off the grill over rice and tomato meat sauce.  The salad is also delicious! This place offers a quick grab and go feel with awesome value.  The only complaint would be cleanliness of the place, but otherwise it's a definitely a must try.
author: Patrick C.

description:
Really cool place in a darkly lit, blue-ish restaurant. You can see the chefs cooking the chicken and sauce out front.

Pretty solid Vietnamese food. I really liked their roast chicken (number 5). That was different from other Vietnamese restaurants. The noodle salad was standard.
author: Julianna K.

description:
No frills dining. We walked in Saturday for lunch and had no problems getting a spot. There's counter space with maybe 4 tables in the back.

There's a vegetarian section on the menu. Entrees and lunch specials come with a big pile of rice smothered in meat sauce. The portions are pretty big, and the food is fresh-ish. I say "ish" because the chicken is par cooked, though the kebabs were freshly grilled. The taste was good, but nothing amazing.

Great that you can get a meal for around $10. It does take a while to get your food, as there was just one lady cooking.
author: Eva W.

description:
I have lived in the neighborhood for several years and always seen a line out the door so I've been meaning to try Cordon Bleu for a while. I didn't know that they were "cash only" till I read the reviews so I'm happy that I had cash on me.
I ordered the #5 to go earlier tonight. The lady behind the counter was super-active and got the orders cooked quickly (1 Star). The Imperial Roll was greasy but tasty, especially with the vinaigrette (1 star). The shish kabab looked like no other shish kabab that I've eaten before. It seemed like beef to me but others have described it as "pork" on Yelp. It was flavorful but tough because it had been overcooked. The 5 spice chicken was very bland (and burnt) and was the biggest disappointment to me as I'd been looking forward to it the most - especially because I've seen it on their sign many times and assumed that it was their signature dish.

I won't be going back to Cordon Bleu again...
author: Viv A.

description:
Ever wish you had a little Vietnamese mom or grandma cooking for you while you sit in her kitchen and watch? No? What's wrong with you..

Not quite Vietnamese, but this place is just something out of a Ghibli movie. It brought me back to being a kid visiting my grandparents in Japan, sitting in their 8 foot by 8 foot kitchen/dining area while my Baba made us yakisoba. I ordered the noodle salad and it was delicious, a substantial portion, and $9.95. 

And quite frankly it's a tiny shitty place that is aesthetically only lovable if it makes you feel pangs of nostalgia or if you're one of those hipster kids who relishes any opportunity to take friends to the most unassuming hole in the wall places with incredible food. I honestly can't think of a place I've ever been that felt more like sitting in someone's kitchen getting something home cooked.

The only thing about this place that I'm not obsessed with was that it took 30 minutes for our 4-part to go order. It's worth noting within 5 minutes of opening the entire counter was filled with people and it was a one lady show for the first half hour. The half hour wait was pretty understandable, and I only mention it to mention a single non wonderful thing for its own sake entirely.

If I lived or worked in this area I'd eat here at least twice a week. I'm not joking. It just makes me happy. Go here.
author: Riki N.

description:
3.5 Stars

Came here for take-out during lunch. The restaurant  is definitely a hole in the wall type of place. I only saw a few stools for eating. (For sure not a place to come with large groups.)
Call ahead and place your order! We called and came 10 minutes later and the lady cooking behind the grill (maybe the owner?) was really nice. 
I ordered one of their lunch specials; 1 shish kebab, salad and meat sauce over rice. Oh my goodness! Talk about huge portion!! (I was able to eat my leftovers for dinner.) only complaint was that there wasn't enough meat and soooo much rice. Which became somewhat "soggy/mushy" from the meat sauce. I'd love to come back and try the chicken tho!! Their imperial egg rolls are a MUST!! So crispy, crunchy and good!!
author: Mimie L.

description: I've been coming here for many years. I've tried just about everything (all delicious) but I always go back to the #5 white meat. Walking in to cordon bleu is like walking in to the scene of a movie.  A tiny restaurant with a long bar, swivel stools and the smell of food that is beyond delicious. While waiting for the food, you are usually offered a cup of tea which is the perfect thing on a cold and (or) foggy day. The portions are enormous and always served hot and steamy. The price is also extremely reasonable for the quality and amount of food that is served up. For all of the times I've come and keep coming to Cordon Bleu, it just seems to continue getting better and better.
author: Patrique R.

description: I have been coming to this wonderful restaurant since 1977 and it never fails to disappoint. Moved to Sacramento from San Francisco in the 90's but always stop here when on business. Fantastic and ridiculously cheap!
author: John V.

description: This place from the outside you wouldn't know if it was good, however you can never judge a book by its cover. Once you go in it kinda feels like an asian home in a way. There is a wait due to how small the place is but that's no problem. Just seeing the staff there making food reminded me of my grandparents and my parents and it was a nice experience. Now back to the food. It's freaking good, hands down. If she happens to over cook a piece a meat, she makes you a new one. Just overall a great first time for me.
author: Kenneth X.

description:
Like previous yelpers said, definitely get the #5 Combo ($10.89 for enough perfectly charred chicken, 4 large slices of shish kabob, meat sauce ragou rice, and cabbage pile for 2 peoples plus leftovers). Seriously, if you get all those separately, it's like $18 haha. But heck even if it were $18, the portions are still totally worth it.

What really made the meal endearing were the two ladies behind the counter, who were so happy to see us enjoy the food and smiled every time my friend and I raved about what her secret to tenderizing the chicken was or how the Imperial Roll was like a dumpling disguised in cylindrical form because it was stuffed with pork and other veggies. The decor (pastel blue brick walls), the kitchen ware, and the smattering of chocolate bars and potato chips on the counter that the ladies were munching on made me feel like I was transported to a homey rustic cabin somewhere for a little bit :)

In the evening, the atmosphere is pretty great place for a date. 
WARNING: not enough seating for big groups.
author: Shelley C.

description:
YUM. Talk about the ultimate comfort food. Service is fast and it's so fun to watch it prepared right before your eyes. Quantity is massive and enough for 2 people to share. Egg rolls are probably my favorite part :) the rice plates are extremely filling and easy on the wallet. Noodle salads are also ginormous AND also comes with an egg roll. 

Restaurant is a little small but if you're lucky, you'll get a seat right at the counter. Their to go orders are also extremely popular and you'll probably see a million orders go out while you're eating at the restaurant.
author: Maryann S.

description:
Moved to SF 4 years ago and this is my favorite hole in the wall spot within the NobHill.

Right off the bat ordered #5: half chicken, meat sauce rice, shish kebab pieces, one crispy egg roll and chopped lettuce. NOTE: it's a heavy meal but well worth it. Closed on Mondays, gets busy Thur-Fri evenings (pre-bar hours) and it's a great Sunday afternoon lunch spot if let's say you finished boxing or the nearby gyms and want to load up.

Katie the main lady on the grill is very sweet and knows most of the folks since they're local neighborhood regulars. When ordering to go, it's often going to be a 15 min wait/ pickup since there'll either be other orders before you, people waiting for their food inside and just a packed house.
author: Kenneth L.

description: I wish I could give it a better rating, but this mom and pop shop was no good. It's a very small hole-in-the-wall place with little seating. You can see your meal getting prepped in the little kitchen area. The food was not great. There was nothing memorable about it. Wouldn't come back again. With so many places to try in the city, I can't justify coming back here again. (And I've had better imperial rolls elsewhere).
author: Angel K.

description: Cash only. Great for take-out or dine-in, though the space is small. Amazing homestyle comfort food, and I love going in to see Katie working hard at the grill. This food reminds me so much of the authentic Southern food I grew up eating. Definitely not the healthiest thing in the world by any stretch, but delicious, hearty, and really hits the spot when you are hungry. The portions are very large, and the prices are extremely fair. Cordon Bleu isn't just any old place: it's a neighborhood restaurant and a rich part of the San Francisco community. I can't imagine someone not liking the food or the service here. It's seriously just like going to eat a fresh cooked meal at home to me. I hope it's here forever. At this rate, Katie will be flipping chicken and stirring sauces until she arrives in a walker. She works very hard to keep this place open for us all to enjoy, so stop in!
author: Jared R.

description:
Type of place you don't want to write a good review about because you don't want it to get too crowded. But they deserve it. Five stars.

I thought the kabob and the rice with meat sauce were awesome.
author: Quags M.

description:
Things to order: 
#5:
5 spice chicken, imperial roll are delicious. Sauce with rice and cabbage comes next in taste. Not a fan of the charred meat. 
Noodle salad:
HUGE portion, lots of rice noodles

Will update will more as I try other things on the menu
author: Jackie W.

description:
Sooo the salad was very tasty with a vinaigrette/fish sauce with mint leaves and cucumber mix.  The spicy pork was disappointing as some pieces were dry and all three were NOT spicy !!! I would definitely come here again. 
Please don't arrive around dinner time 7 or 8ish expecting to be seated immediately. This place is not for the timid as you have to grab one of the cooks attention ANd make sure scoundrels don't take one of the 15 (not kidding).
author: Deanna N.

description:
Yummy grub food that satisfies and fulfills a grumbling tummy!

Do get their mambo numba 5 all the way from the menu!  It is loaded with all the goods - undeniable, freshly fried, grand egg roll, white rice topped with signature gravy, a side of pickled cabbage shreds, two slices of shish kebabs, fish sauce in a plastic container, which is great for dipping the egg roll in or poured over all over the intense load, and the portion of that grilled chicken meat!  

It was deliciously amazing and very fulfilling!  It can feed 2 people for sure or ONE grumpy, hungry person!

It's a VERY small shop!  I do recommend taking your heavy food package somewhere else - especially if the seats are all filled!  It is faster that way to devour the food!  

They cook and grill up the food in a sufficient time!  I enjoyed the enticing smell from the grill immensely and was salivating aplenty!  It's a cash only spot!

I love this grubbin' gem!
author: Tiffany D.

description: Tried the noodle salad for lunch today and it was yummy!  Although I usually get the #5, I will definitely be back for the noodle salad as well!
author: Siv L.

description: Food was delicious! Had the noodle salad. Was in town for work & my dad told me about this little whole in the wall Vietnamese restaurant that he used to go to back in mid/late 70s. So good!! I highly recommend you check it out!
author: April G.

description: This place is a tasty and cheap lunch fix! The 5-spice chicken entree is a huge portion for only $9! The chicken is thrown on the grill for a quick char, which is definitely tasty. You get 2 pieces. The leg was moist, but the breast was a bit dry. No worries though, there is a tomato-esque" gravy spooned over the rice to compensate. Overall, 3 stars. But nothing special here folks. Just lunch.
author: Chase B.

description: Huge helpings and very friendly owners at this small but serious-about-food hole in the wall on California Street. Get the #5 combo for a little taste of everything, and come hungry!
author: Andy L.

description: A serious hole in the wall, with delicious food in huge portions! Order a number 5 and you will leave seriously satisfied.
author: ddd H.

description: I ate here regularly when I lived in SF between 1995 - 2003, and I MISS THAT MEAT SAUCE. A friend who's about to visit the City for the first time asked where to go and what to do and I was so scared Cordon Bleu wouldn't be there anymore. I'm so glad it still is.
author: Chaia M.

description: My favorite hole in the wall restaurant in the City. The owner/ chef is a friendly Vietnamese lady who has been serving her delicious food for as long as I can remember.  Great food, super efficient counter seating and cheap. Love this place.
author: Viral V.

description: Been coming here since I was 11 and am now in my 50's!  Love love this place. Food is delicious!  The skewers, five spice chicken, and imperial rolls are a must try. Hearty portions are served each time. Place is always crowded with regulars and at times there's a long wait time to be seated, but well worth it.  Will keep coming to Cordon Bleu!
author: Katherine H.

description:
This was the best home cooking I've had in a long time.
