I got combo 10 and it was perfect. Big portions, friendly staff. It IS a hole in the wall and nothing fancy, but very authentic and tasty :)
author: Elly L.

description:
This was my go-to, low key spot during my 3 years in SF. Katie is a gem and works incredibly hard.

Vietnamese comfort food, you really can't go wrong. Tell me where you can get a ~$7 hearty meal in Nob Hill these days (with leftovers too)? This was one of my weekly eateries. 

It's typically packed, but you can place to-go orders as well. #1 or #3 highly recommended.
author: Sean H.

description:
Small hole in the wall restaurant that you must try. There are only about 8 bar seats and two tables each seating 4 people. I would recommend getting your food to go as it is a very small place and not good for big groups. 

I love their egg rolls, these huge luscious filling rolls each fried to perfection. Sometimes they even run out of their egg rolls so make sure you don't go too late. Everything I ordered from here was amazing and I would get again. I usually just stick with their mix plate (forgot what it's called) but it has everything (chicken/beef/egg roll/rice) 

Tip: call in advance to order your food for take out. They can be very busy and take a long time if you place your order there.
author: Justin Y.

description:
Yummy. Big portions good value. 

Get the venerable #5, can't go wrong.

I remember being skeptical about the gravy on the rice but in the end I can't stop eating it's savory sweet combination. 

I'm normally not a fan of bone in chicken parts but it was moist and fresh. The shish kebob isn't really a kebob, it's marinated flat meat grilled till its chewy. Like fresh jerky. 

I also try to stay away from fried food but the imperial egg roll was actually good
author: Tyler J.

description:
THE BEST DEAL IN ALL OF SF. 

Seriously this place has the best chicken ever, you sit there watching it get crisp on the grill and when you bite into it, the skin is crispy on the outside but still somehow extraordinarily juicy and tender on the inside. And then the combos are ridiculous, I mean $10 for the chicken, grilled shish kabob (pork?) meat, with rice, sauce, veggies, and an imperial roll? That's like prices from last decade! It lasted me about 2.5 meals too. This is really making me rethink my grocery shopping which I thought could save me money but now this restaurant has me second guessing!

Also a hole in the wall restaurant where the Asian ladies are actually super nice and friendly! It feels so homey I love it.
author: Zenia Z.

description: Great little mom-and-pop restaurant. We found this place via Yelp. We were looking for Vietnamese lunch, but were at such an off time nothing was showing up in our area except this little gem. Super glad! They cook your food right in front of you. GET THE CHICKEN. I got the chicken (upgrade) over noodles, yummy and refreshing. Their imperial rolls were delicious (esp with sriracha!!!). My husband got the #1 combo plate. Was good, but he wished he had chicken on it. Next time I am in San Fran I will come here and get what our genius restaurant neighbors ordered: a whole plate of chicken and a plate of imperial rolls each!!!! Very friendly staff.
author: Stephy S.

description: #5 is what you should get if you are not getting the chicken salad (which is deceptively huge and the pictures do not do it justice). The imperials rolls are also huge (not as good as tin or some other places but super filing). This is a to go drunken food place with lots of rice, sauce, and fillers. You basically can get a meal that feeds two for under $20. The #5 comes with pork, chicken, imperial roll, rice, and etc.
author: Lily P.

description:
Awesome.  A truly great meal.

I got the #1 with Imperial Roll and Skish Kabob.  Country Salad and Rice in Meat Sauce.  What a meal.  The Imperial Rolls were awesome.  The meat was great.  BTW - The real treat was watching the grilling.  And, smelling the grilling.  OMG.  It was really awesome.  

Good hall of food for a good price.  Recommend it.
author: Adam S.

description:
We got lucky and scored parking right in front! Whoohoo~! We went on a thursday around 1pm.
Sat at the counter, place is tiny. Not the cleanest, tried hard not to judge lol.

I wanted the #5 but hubz got it so I decided to try something else. Heard some ladies get the chicken salad...intrigued...healthy, ok me too.

So I don't like shredded cabbage..LOL shoulda read the description, knew my husband was gonna look at me funny for ordering a chicken salad...made entirely of shredded cabbage....OH FAIL...BUT!!! It was DELICIOUSSSS and had so much chickenn! I had more chicken leftover and no more salad!! I guess I like vietnamese chicken salad (goi ga) because of the fish sauce dressing! So yummy and the mint leaves that accompany it. The funny nice thing was that the lady randomly gave me a chicken leg when I was almost finished. So sweet! I kind of felt like I was her child..LOL she does kind of have my mom's haircut going...

The #5 was yummy also, the egg roll was on point, the sauce was yummy, the shish kebob (GRILLED PORK) was good too. He said he was only going to eat half...HAH! We finished EVERYTHING!!!

We are definitely coming back. It does get busy where the wait could be awhile. The two ladies who work here are hard working! Around $20 for two!
author: Christine M.

description:
I just love this place. Yes, they don't spend too much time on the presentation of the food-- and they sell you 'rice with meat sauce' so yes your plate might look like it was engulfed by weird looking pink goo but it's SO GOOD.

Quite frankly, I have had charred black pork and I just can't place my trust in having a consistent BBQ experience, which is why I always get the entree with 2 imperial rolls. These imperial rolls are the best I've ever had-- so crispy and full of flavor.
author: Jessica Y.

description: Great local spot for Nob Hill/Russian Hill run by Katie, owner/chef. My current favorites are cabbage salad and imperial rolls (see photo). Portions are generous!
author: yasmine m.

description: Best hole-in-the-wall ever!! I grab takeout from here every time I'm in the city. I always get the five spice chicken & imperial roll (don't forget the sauce)! It's really cheap and HUGE portions. Def enough for two, or for leftovers the next day. CASH ONLY~
author: Jenn S.

description:
Kinda hungry? #1
Really hungry? #5
Pretentious? go somewhere else.

I found this hole in the wall years ago and they haven't changed a bit to this day. 
Still a hole in the wall with a couple of tables and a short counter where most people end up sitting at since it gets crowded in a flash. 

Almost the same prices as back then to where you can have lunch or dinner for under 10 bucks. 

I'm in love with the #5: 5 spice grilled chicken served with an extra large crispy imperial roll, grilled beef kebabs, rice and cole slaw topped with house made gravy. 

Unapologetic, unpretentious american vietnamese comfort food at an affordable price with portions that have even a glutton like myself asking for a to go box. I look in every direction and there's always sriracha hot sauce within arms reach. 

I'm in heaven.
author: Norris T.

description:
Let's say you're a sensitive vegetarian soul. You know, the kind that wants to vomit when you see copious amounts of meat? 

Or let's suppose you are an OCD neat freak.  You know, the kind that wipes up every little drop of whatever fell on the counter right away and everything in your kitchen is buffed to a high sheen?

If either of the above is true, this is not the place for you.

But now let's suppose you are really stinking cheap, kind of okay with slobbiness, and not grossed out by dish tubs full of chewed meaty bones...  and you love Vietnamese homestyle food? 

Yes? Get in here!


No pho, but HUGE plates of food. BBQ chicken, pork, big fat homemade imperial rolls, one noodle salad, and one chicken salad. That's about it. Well maybe there's some sort of tofu thing, but Ms. Veg, this really isnt your scene. Trust me.
author: El B.

description: Katie is great!   Been coming to this hole in a while for almost 10 years!    Generous portions and fresh made dishes.  Excellent value for your money
author: Rodel R.

description:
When I lived in the city I came here often. Therefore I was glad to see it was still open and run by the same people. As many said here the owner is super friendly and talkative. I had:

Number 5
5-spice chicken - tender, juicy, smoky, very good
Imperial roll - yum. 
Shish kebab - pork cut thin, marinated and grilled. Good.
Country salad. Cole slaw. OK.
Rice with meat sauce. I watched them make a fresh batch of sauce. The rice isn't in a rice cooker but cooked in a traditional steamer that's seen a lot of use.
Overall a great meal, for under $12.
author: Massimo P.

description:
So much delicious food for an amazing price.

No frills just great simple food.

Largest imperial rolls this side of South East Asia.

Meat sauce over the rice is so tasty.
author: Andrew D.

description:
OK, this was not the place I expected. I was taking the California Street cable car one night expecting to enter a regular restaurant with formica tables, naugahyde chairs, surly waiters, and a sun-faded poster of the Eiffel Tower half-torn on the wall. You know, like Sam Wo's reborn. But I guess I wasn't really in the Tenderloin, and real estate is clearly at more of a premium on Nob Hill. Surely that's the explanation for the walk-in closet that is Cordon Bleu on California near Polk Street. It reminds me of any number of greasy diners in New York like Johny's Luncheonette (no second 'n' please) where the counter is pretty much your only alternative other than the large-group tables in the back.

It was pretty crowded when I entered but not fully. Because a couple of mouthy hipsters decided to hog three stools between them, I stood against the wall waiting for an opening. They were so self-absorbed that it took a five full minutes before one of them acknowledged I was perhaps wanting to use the stool to eat and only after leaving his money (cash only). Thanks dudes...hope the cable car doesn't run you over when you jaywalk across the street. The two women who run the place pay no attention to such matters... they have a grill to master and rice to scoop. I grabbed one of the few well-used, laminated menus on the counter and started to peruse.

Lemme see... there are five combo plate entrees, four house specials, and on the other side of the menu, four veggie options. The choices struck me as more pan-Asian than strictly Vietnamese... kinda Korean by way of Saigon with a heavy emphasis on country comfort food, in other words, pure catnip for budget-conscious slackers. I decided to order the $9 Number Five, which consisted of a Five-Spice Roast Chicken Leg, "Shish Kebab" (without a stick and served in thin slices Korean-style), a large Imperial Roll chopped and heavily deep-fried, a "Country Salad" (a.k.a. shredded lettuce with some dressing), and the mysteriously described "Meat Sauce on Rice" (see photo).

Ironically it was this latter item that turned out to be the most satisfying component if only because it sopped up the drippings from the other four items. I still couldn't tell what kind of meat I was eating, but it was sloppy-Joe-good. The shish kebab and chicken were a tad overcooked for my taste, even though that didn't stop me from devouring either one. Despite the tasty filling, the roll was just way too crunchy-greasy to eat comfortably without having nightmares of a coronary where I would have to lay down on the dirty-plate-covered counter since there would be no room for a gurney in there. OK, I'd still probably come back, give more explicit stink-eye to the entitled hipsters, and try to decode the meat sauce again.

FOOD - 3 stars...dinerific with a tasty-greasy meat sauce of unknown origin
AMBIANCE - 2 stars...I would describe it as claustrophobic but all those letters wouldn't fit in here
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...speedy multi-taskers, not much on smiling
TOTAL - has anyone seen Guy Fieri in here yet?
author: Ed U.

description: One of the best lunch spots in SF. #5 is an absolute must and for $11 it can't be beat. It's a small mom and pop shop so expect it to be a bit busy during normal lunch hours.
author: Chris K.

description: Can anyone tell me why every time I've tried to come on a Saturday night this place has been randomly closed despite being open on Yelp??
author: Katy C.

description:
I guess you come here for the food, not the service. The place is really small and feels a bit dirty. You sit at the counter, facing the grill. There were three people working there, but only one spoke English. They forgot to give us water. It was generally hard to ask for things or even to pay, because there was only one lady who ran the place.

The imperial roll is decent, a little bit too meaty. Maybe it's San Francisco style, but the wrapping paper is kind of thick, not thin like the authentic roll. The only upside is you get a lot of food. I wasn't very impressed with the meat sauce, it was more like tomato sauce and kind of bland compared to the fish sauce.
author: Nessa N.

description:
The chicken here is amazing. Katie (I'm assuming she's the owner) served us one of the largest and most amazing five spice chicken and vietnamese greens- salads I have ever experienced. The co-mingling of flavors and textures was out of this world. Also as a big eater it turned out to be THREE full portions. And after inquiring about the simmering red sauce she gave me a taste of the most incredibly tasting meat and spicy gravy that I can safely say was one of the best I've ever had. 
I can't wait to go back.
author: Glenn G.

description:
This is one of my favorite whole-in-the-wall comfort food spots. The owner is super friendly, the portions are HUGE and it's cheap.  

Get the 5 spice chicken and imperial rolls.
author: Megan M.

description: Been going to this restaurant for more than 20 yrs. true its a hole in the wall. However, this little corner of the world has great Vietnamese food. The service is good & very nice. The price is unbelievable. You get so much food for a low price. They have th best Ma Po tofu. Tofu is soft & delish. I love #5. You get 5spice chicken, meat kabob, egg roll, salad & rice w/ meat sauce. I'm salivating just thinking about it. There's usually a line so you know people are willing to wait for good food.
author: Dorcas C.

description: Their 5 spice chicken was great, but was clearly precooked and then reheated.  Cooked fresh would have been incredible, as it was, still a solid decently priced meal.
author: Jeremy J.

description: Hole in the wall setting. Authentic tastes. Generous portions. Great neighborhood hangout joint.
author: Sam C.

description: This restaurant is great for the price point. It's a hole in the wall restaurant with most of the very limited seating at the counter. It is cash only but there is a bank a few doors down on the corner with an ATM. I had plenty of leftovers.
author: Mandy T.

description: This is one of my favorite Vietnamese spots in the city and I've been coming here for years. This little hole-in-the-wall spot is located in lower nob hill right on California and Polk. I always get the number one which consists of shish kebab (pork), rice with meat sauce, salad, and an imperial roll for under $9.00.  That meat sauce is not your typical Vietnamese add-on, but damn it's super good! Also, their five spice chicken salad is super delicious as well! The place is super small and cash only. You can also byob if you'd like and this is definitely a place to hit up if you're in the hood!
author: EccentricAura A.

description:
Going there for the 3rd time as it has become a ritual over the last 3 months.  My boyfriend's cheap, I'm cheap and these meals are cheap but the portions are HUGE.  On top of that the food is great.  

Highlights:
-I have no idea what the meat sauce is but I'm sure they could bottle it and make millions.
-The chicken is charbroiled and is probably the best I've had outside of Thailand.
-The Imperial rolls are not like the ones you see at other restaurants.  They are the big mamas of all Imperial rolls.

Tips:
-Space is limited so if you don't want to wait, you can call ahead of time and just pick up the food to go.
author: Ashley I.

description:
we will always remember this place because their food tastes absolutely SUPERBBBBB! we went here twice for lunch and dinner and ordered the same set of foods

location: parking is a challenge because the only option available is side street parking which is very limited in this area. parking rates during lunch is somewhat around $2.25/hr

ambiance: the dining area is too small given that they have a lot of customers waiting to dine, pick up, or order to-go.. it gets crowded and thats were you get small space to work with going in and out. access to the restroom is a challenge and its not well maintained. not their strongest area but still not too shabby.

price: the food is relatively cheap given the big portion serving. ordered pork chops and chicken (#4), was like expecting just one piece meat for each entree but was surprised to see 3 for the chops, and 2 chicken breast. sodas are not overly priced

server/cook Cathy is very friendly and amazing.  she is the only one working on getting the orders, cooking, and serving it. 

the only other downside aside from ambiance is that they only accept cash.
author: Abby P.

description: I love this place. I had fresh 5 spice chicken salad and tried a bite of pork. It was cooked to order, healthy...all the meat is grilled over a fire. KATIE WILL WIN YOUR HEART OVER THRU YOUR BELLY!
author: Christina M.

description:
Truly the definition of a hole in the wall! 

Ordered the #1 Combo Plate: 1 Imperial Roll, 1 Shish Kebab, Country Salad, Meat Sauce On Rice 

Imperial roll: crispy, meaty, flavorful goodness! 
Shish kebab: made to order, well seasoned, large tender thin cuts of pork
Country Salad: refreshing acidity added a nice brightness to the dish 
Meat Sauce: on the sweeter side, generous amount of meat laced throughout the sauce 
Rice: great chewy quality, not mushy, not hard, just right

Price is really reasonable!

Overall Thoughts

Amazing food at an amazing price; exactly what a hole in the wall should be
author: Eddie W.

description: The food was not bad but it took them more than 50 minutes to bring us the food and then they brought only half of the meal and half later which was really strange. Make sure you don't go when it's too crowded!
author: Irina P.

description: Still a great plate of food after several years since I was last here. Had the #5 which included five spice chicken, kebab, rice with meat sauce and that delicious, huge (and best) imperial roll in San Francisco. Great price for all that food. Was an oinker and ate it all in one sitting. Tiny place with a very nice owner. Coming back more often for sure!
author: Jonathan P.

description: Great portion size for a great price. Great hole in the wall place. I usually always order the mixed platter which is chicken, grilled pork, imperial roll and tons of rice with meat sauce. One of the best imperial rolls I have ever had.
author: Joseph B.

description:
Made our last-minute weekend trip to San Francisco that much more memorable. Wish there was a film crew to catch all the initial faces of the people we were seated next to when they tasted their first bite (and ours as well). Great service, exceptionally delicious Vietnamese soul food. I can't remember the exact combo-number we went with but my girlfriend and I shared one (since one entree is pretty large). 

Be sure to order an Imperial Roll on the side. It's crispy and adds great texture to the abundant meat sauce over the rice. Good add-on side dish to get! Will definitely be making a stop here whenever we're in the area.
author: Diane A.

description:
The spring rolls are off the hook!!
I'm a big chicken fan and they do a good job of seasoning and cooking it.
Make no mistake this is a hole in the wall, but the lady's are nice and very attentive:)
author: Al T.

description:
The chicken is pretty tasty. Actually, all the food is tasty. We got a combo platter, and then also got a tofu dish. It was a LOT of food. People speak to the meat sauce... and yes, it is delicious. The imperial roll is also very good.

The key with this place is that the woman works the grill with her left hand, sorts the money sprawled out on the counter with her right, and memorizes your order as you give it to her, while answering the phone that never stops ringing. Outside of the guy running dishes back and forth and refilling the water pitchers, and the one other woman who handles all stove-top dishes, it is a one-woman-show. It is very impressive. 

Of course, the price point makes it an easy spot to keep coming back to...
author: John F.

description:
The walk to here from Powell Bart Station was awful, as it was all uphill walking. My legs were tired and my boyfriend was trudging along begrudgingly, claiming I lied to him when I told him about a small Vietnamese shop nearby that served home-made food at a higher quality than the fancy restaurants near the station. We arrived at our destination, and I could see the crestfallen look on his face as he saw the immediate surrounding area and the literal, hole-in-the-wall shop. We each took a menu, browsed through it quickly and ordered the number 5 and the noodle salad. Waiting for the food was hell. We were tired and cranky, staring blankly at a lady frying up imperial rolls, another lady in the back grabbing utensils and cups full of water for the customers. However, the wait wasn't too bad. Once the food came out, magic happened.

The imperial rolls are the best. They're so crunchy and none of that half-assed frying. This, this is what something fried should taste like. The chicken wing on my boyfriend's number 5 plate was tender and juicy, not overcooked at all. The pork may have been a little too thick and chewy for my taste, but it was good nonetheless paired with the hearty meat sauce over rice.
The noodle salad was delicious - like a rice noodle bowl you'd get at other restaurants, but this one already had sauce on it even before adding the fish sauce that usually comes with the order. The imperial roll was tasty as always, and the chicken pieces were also tender and juicy. It was a nice contrast to the hearty meal that my boyfriend had.

All in all, this place is amazing. Over 800 reviews - so why not pop in for a bite if you're in the area? Bring cash, and maybe a little more to buy extra imperial rolls for the way home.
author: Soomin S.

description: Place is closed at 2:40 in the afternoon even though their hours clearly state they should be open. Might be they are permanently closed.
author: Ty C.

description: Yum. Omg best Vietnamese food ever. The lady has been here for years. This is one of the best BBQ Vietnamese spots in the city. And it feels very homey. Just make sure you have not eaten all day because they serve you so much food.
author: Walter P.

description:
You know how they say - the smallest simplest places probably have the tastiest food? This is a perfect example. Plus - wooooah! Super big gigantic portions of food for super cheap price! And taste and flavor? - just like home cooked meals ^_^ yumm. And I'd any day go here to talk to the old lady who cooks at the counter ^_^ she is the sweetest. 

We went here on the way back from the Ghirardelli dark hour the day before yesterday. As usual, we checked the ratings on yelp, found it could be worth trying. It was a little challenging for us to find the place though it was right by the road. Firstly, the name board wasn't that noticeable and secondly, we were expecting a little bigger fancier restaurant than what we saw. Now, I am glad we didn't miss it. 

Its a small simple clean place with some high rise stools by the cooking area and two tables - one of four and one of six all pushed into a corner. We hesitated a little because of the state of the furniture and a little concern for safety, but i am so glad we gave it a try. Well, the furniture isn't maintained very well, but wait till you get the food and I promise you won't care about anything else. 

We ordered the number 4 and number 5. I don't know why, but for some reason, ordering with numbers gives me a good vibe in a restaurant. Two old Vietnamese ladies stood at the chef counter and took the order and started preparing it right before our eyes. When we got our food, it was as if three of us could have eaten one number 5. The meat sauce tastes awesome with the sriracha. The chicken is cooked beautifully! I generally don't prefer kebabs, but I loved it here. 

And after all that, it was just about 9 dollars! And - the most important - the restrooms are very very very neat :D

Of course yes! I would go to this place again n again!
author: Divya K.

description: Best imperial rolls. Just like my mom's recipe! The rest is ok but definitely go for the fried imperial rolls!
author: Catherine G.

description: Cash only but there is a Chase ATM right next door. This is one of those affordable dinners in SF. Sitting there for 10 minutes I saw three different people walk in and call the two ladies by name. One customer even brought her a pastry and coffee. Loved the small-town feel with good hearty food and the chance to sit and watch them grill. The menu is simple. Don't over complicate it. Get the #5 so you can taste the chicken and pork if you are coming for the first time. Imperial roll is a delicious super crunchy indulgence. Totally worth it. So much food I have an entire meal left.
author: Sarah O.

description: I understand why it's well loved. Two Chinese speaking women run the open grill carefully across a bar while patrons eat or wait to order watch every step of preparation. The best dish is the chicken, rice and imperial roll at a reasonable price and portion size. I was expecting more flavor and tenderness from the chicken. I gave it two tries and it fell short of my expectations. I like the atmosphere and the longevity of the restaurant so I think it is worth supporting this restaurant in SF. I would not go out of my way to order though.
author: Carina L.

description:
I thought this place was a tad overrated.
It was nothing special, just large hearty portions.

Tried the spicy pork chop which wasn't spicy. Maybe they mean it's made with lots of spices which I didn't really taste either.  The green onion oil-infused rice was too mushy in my opinion but not bad taste-wise.
The mint and cucumber salad that comes with is is pretty refreshing.

The entree combo #5 comes with 5 spiced roast chicken, imperial roll, shish kebab, country salad, and meat sauce on rice.  The imperial roll wasn't bad. The shish kebab (or actually a few thin slices of meat) tasted similar to the pork chop.  The roast chicken wasn't as flavorful as I'd thought it would be but it wasn't bad. The meat sauce tastes similar to Spaghetti O's.

The fresh spring roll tastes like the imperial roll but not fried of course.  So it's not like your typical nem nuong or shrimp/pork filled fresh spring roll.

We made a mistake by going to this resto on a hot day. The resto is pretty small and the heat from the open kitchen keeps the place warm.
author: Heejin L.

description: Pull up a seat (only a few inside) and watch as they make your order on the grill in front of you. This place is legit! Huge portion for $7-8 on average per plate. The sauce they pour over top the rice is an amazing compliment to the meal. Will definitely go back and bring new friends with who want a real hole in the wall spot
author: jonathan m.

description: If you are traveling and wanting that Vietnamese home cooking taste, then this place is it. Good prices + big portions + good taste = great deal...
author: Linh H.

description: Awesome place very delicious and filling.. The sauce on rice was amazing. Great place to eat on a budget and be full and satisfied
author: Jordan S.

description: I really like this place. Quaint restaurant, good service, and awesome food. I recommend the number 5 if you have a big appetite. Really good mix of everything. The imperial rolls are a must try...they are insanely good. Great neighborhood spot off Polk street.
author: Kevin C.

description: Good food, reasonable prices BUT go there at your own risk cuz you don't know if they are open for business or not.  You could try calling but they might not answer the phone due to the business being very busy or maybe they're closed.  The owner likes to close whenever she feels like it without warning or phone message, so you really don't know until you go there.  I've been disappointed many times going there when they should be opened only to be disappointed with a closed sign and locked doors.  Too bad....
author: Jimmy C.

description:
It's a tiny little place where they grill your food right in front of you. If you sit down and eat there, you get a smoky smell all over your clothes like you just went camping and had bbq dinner. 

Portions are huge! Be prepared to bring food home. It takes me 3 meals to finish one order. I like their five spice chicken, the rolls (this is actually really good, even after microwaving). The meat sauce they put on rice is a bit strange, but it tasted really good after a long bike ride (but what doesn't?)

Overall, I think it's good food, but nothing I would write home about. I like this tiny little place though, I would go back when I'm very very hungry and just want a lot of food.
author: Wendy K.

description:
*FIRST TIMER alert*

I finally made it to cordon bleu today! My friend and I stumble upon polk street and decided to stop there for lunch. Luckily there's not many people in there. She wasn't kidding, it is literally "HOLE-IN-THE-WALL" but everybody knows my love for these places! 

My friend warned me that it would be a lot of food. We ordered the lunch special with 1 piece 5 spice chicken leg and rice with meat sauce. 
The meat: I love the seasoning. the meat was cooked to perfection. The skin is super crispy! You can choose white or dark meat.
The meat sauce: not to sweet, it's like a gravy on top of the rice. I really like that.
We caught the meter maid taking a short nap after the meal, who wouldn't?! Perfect combination of protein and carb will give you a perfect food coma in this summer-like spring weather! 

There's probably a capacity of 10 people for this place. They've got a few seats around the bar and maybe 1 small table in the walk way. They have hooks underneath the bar which is a + for us ladies! It seems like a lot of the customers know the owner of this place. They are all on first name basis. She was super friendly and attentive. She almost made me feel like I was just at her house eating a meal. She even showed us pictures of her dog! Now who doesn't love a cute puppy?!

It's got a homey feel and hearty food, what's not to love?
author: Mindy C.

description: This is a great place to get some home made Vietnamese food. The place is very small but the food is very good at a very reasonable prices. The imperial rolls, the kebab and tofu dish are my favorites. The meat sauce is very tasty. I often drive more than 30 mins just to go here for lunch or dinner.
author: Ed M.

description: Best restaurant in the whole city. Best imperial roll and anything you put in the grill will taste wonderful
author: Shadi G.

description: Food is delicious and Katie is perfect. Ordered #5 and pork chops, split with a friend. We ate it all.
author: Dana W.

description:
Yes, this is not really a Vietnamese restaurant. It more like a Hawaiian restaurant, where there is a mixture of ethnic foods. 

Their menu is simple and there is really not many items to choose from, just different combinations of the same things. 

Their charbroiled chicken is good, but not really that great. The kebab is not kebab, but just pieces of grilled beef. Their meat sauce is somewhat bland and watery without much meat. 

I am also not sure how clean they are. I noticed that their fridge's temperature gauge was reading way over 41 degrees as the Health Department sticker on the door said the temperature should be UNDER! YMMV!
author: Tony L.

description:
Can we talk about meat sauce for a minute?  MEAT SAUCE.  What exactly is in it? Who knows but there is a giant vat of it on the stove quietly simmering away and its going on my rice. So yummy.  I always am on the look out for "meat sauce" but have yet to find it at any other vietnamese place, so as far as I know, this is the only place in the world to get "meat sauce".   

Large portions of meat, and excellent emperor rolls.

Perfect hang over food, this place brought me back to life after a night of bad choices.

Minus one star for the grunginess factor of raw chicken just hanging out in plastic tubs under the counter.  *Shrugs*
author: Bits F.

description: This place is a cozy little hole in the wall with big portions of good, homestyle food. The dishes remind me of eating at my grandmas as a little girl!
author: Phyllis T.

description: The food is so good (best imperial roll I've had) that we keep trying to come back, even though the hours are very unpredictable. I usually get my food to go, and have always gone with the noodle salad with either chicken or pork and an imperial roll. Their rice dishes look delicious too though, will have to switch my regular order up next time!
author: Kelly D.

description: Love this homey shop churning out quick Vietnamese dishes! It's so good too.. the meats are so well-seasoned and the rolls come out fresh and piping hot. The ladies are super nice, and the little counter makes you feel a little more connected to your neighbors, which is a bit rare in this big city. I can see this unassuming restaurant being a great local's spot.
author: Vivian H.

description:
I was really looking forward to trying this place out, with all the great reviews and the fact that the tiny place is always crowded whenever I walk by. I left a little bewildered about what people are so enthused about.  

Everything about the atmosphere says dive, from the old sign to the very limited plain menu to the start partan furnishings. Sitting on stools at the counter over looking the tiny cooking area, it's a not terribly appetizing view.  The 1/2 grilled chicken was pretty good, but nothing exceptional. The salad was little more than some shredded cabbage, and the rice with meat sauce just OK. I couldn't readily identify the ingredients in the overcooked imperial roll. The shish kebab was finely sliced and over cooked pork I think. Overall, the portion was huge and the price was cheap, which might explain its popularity. Clearly, though, I'm missing something that a lot of others see and taste here.
author: Rob C.

description: Tiny hole in the wall place but really amazing food. Had the noodle salad w chicken and no peanuts w a veggie spring roll. Amazing fish sauce!
author: Est K.

description: I was at Soda Popinskis and needed some food, so I stopped by Cordon Bleu before grabbing an Uber home. It's a tiny place with counter seating and a couple of tables in the back. I squeezed into an empty counter seat and ordered a number one to go. The number one is salad, rice with meat sauce, an imperial roll and grilled meat (I believe it's thin slices of grilled pork). The imperial roll was absolutely delish! Even after sitting in an Uber for 15 minutes, it was still perfectly crispy when I got home. Yum, yum, yum! The grilled pork (again, I think it was pork -- it was good whatever it is!) was perfectly grilled, with nice crispy-grilled edges. Even the salad was good! The rice and meat sauce was just okay, but was a nice foundation to everything else. I would definitely go back when I'm in the area again!
author: Asina G.

description:
Geez Louise!!!  Why has no one ever told me about this place???  

I know why...it's only cause they have minimal seats and no one wanted word to get out right?  Right?????  Thank goodness I happened to park on the same street as cordon bleu to head down to Polk st for a bowl of pho...

A small little counter with a few seats...one table in the back...everything is made right in front of you.  You've got the guy mixing the big tub of meat sauce with a paddle...a lady cooking up the imperial rolls and meat...and the other lady scooping up the rice and salad.  I don't know how they could even fit 3 people behind the counter.  

Wifey and I had to check this place out...we sat down...both ordered #5...which pretty much included everything on the menu on one plate.
5 spice chicken (breast or leg), shish kebab, imperial roll, salad, meat sauce on a heaping pile of rice.  This plate was more than enough to feed two people.  

I have absolutely no complaints about anything on my plate...the chicken was good.  The imperial roll was freakin amazing...huge and filled with deliciousness, fried perfectly.  The shish kebab was yummy...thin BBQ pork.  The meat sauce was the icing on the cake...or the icing on the rice? Man it was all good.  

Lots of people pop in and order stuff togo...probably a good idea since the seats do fill up.  

I don't know how long this restaurant has been here...but I feel like I've been missing out.  Go!!!  Go now!!!
author: Jen W.

description:
Just stopped in and got the 1/2 Chicken , will do the Kebab next time since its easier to eat at work ,  
2 things , the Owner is the sweetest person , I really like her ,  
also ,  there is something about Grilled Chicken that has a true Outdoor Barbecue Flavor :)
author: Joseph A.

description:
Where else in [S]NOB HILL can you bask in the glorious waft of charbroiled meat and get a gargantuan pile of food enough to feed an army for less than $10?

Let me preface by saying that Cordon Bleu is NOT an authentic Vietnamese restaurant. To me, it's a hole-in-the-wall, elbows-to-elbows, greasy Asian spoon with a menu melding of various cultures and cuisines:

*A Chinese Owner
*A French Restaurant Name
*Vietnamese-Style Charbroiled Meats
*Italian-Filipino Fusion Meat sauce

How San Francisco right? 

The MAGIC NUMBER IS 5 AT CORDON BLEU. For a mere $8.65, you get the following:
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Di4kb-1tnjP5OKFuV8qbUA?select=cXkp7pRWrKQS7wOy5q5sZA
An Andes mountain of piping hot white rice with an avalanche of savory sweet tomato meat sauce (similar to Jollibee's spaghetti sauce but not as sweet) topped with 1/4 five-spiced charbroiled chicken and 3 slices of shish kebab, a GINOURMOUS imperial roll (in length and girth). Talk about a mouth-full; no pun intended. Oh yah, there's also a pickled cabbage salad somewhere underneath that pile of food.

My favorite parts of the hodge-podge meal was 1) The hot and deliciously crisp imperial roll which was generously packed with a savory pork vermicelli mixture; and 2) The chicken (wing/breast) which was perfectly charbroiled creating an crispy blistering skin with a succulently moist center. I didn't detect much of the five-spices: fennel, cloves, cinnamon, star anise and peppercorns though but the chicken was cooked so well that it didn't matter to me. 

It's not an authentic, life-changing or cohesive meal by any means but a stick to your ribs, soulful meal that's (almost) a melting pot of San Francisco all in ONE plate! 

OTHER NOTES:
*Cash Only
*Parking is horrible in the area
*20 min wait for take-out
*Counter seating and 2 tables for sitting
*Don't wear your nicest attire because you will leave smelling like you've been doused with Sizzling Meat Eau De Parfum
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
I'm not sure why this place is regarded so highly. The venue is cramped and mostly counter seating. You can probably fit about 20 people in there. It's a hole in the wall that feels dingy and dirty. We walked in around 7pm on a Sunday, and there was a short wait. We took counter seating and watched the Cantonese-speaking ladies grill and fry an assortment of different meats. Honestly, the food looked very unappetizing. Also, I question their cleaning methods. They were using the same rag to wipe everything...gross. I was hoping for some good ol' pho soup, but was disappointed when I didn't see it on the menu. So much for "authentic" Vietnamese. 

I ordered #5 which came with a huge piece of roast chicken, an imperial roll, country "salad", meat sauce and pieces of grilled pork on rice. The boyfriend ordered mapo tofu with rice. Overall, you definitely get your money's worth. For under $10, the food we had could have fed a small family. The imperial roll was tasty, and the chicken was cooked perfectly. However, the pork was on the dry side and the mapo tasted and looked like something I could whip up in the kitchen. I looked around the room and gathered that this spot caters to mostly young people and bachelors who can't cook for themselves. 

I wasn't impressed, but I might come back sometime for their noodle salad. Oh, FYI - CASH ONLY!
author: Joyce S.

description:
UNbelieveable chicken and spring rolls. if you are trying to find way to eat protein and not stray too far from some paleo-like diet, this place might save you. 

Ridiculous amount of food, lovely conversation and service, cozy and reminds me of Hanoi's best street vendors.

This is one of thoe places that is a staple one-a-week destination. It's that good and that consistent.
author: Mike V.

description:
Asked my mom where she wanted to grab lunch for her 55th bday and she says Cordon Bleu on California. I said "ooh fancy" as Mom's gotten bougier over the years and she laughed, leading the (small) trek from her office.

The scene: hole-in-the-wall with a counter that seats 8 and 2 small tables in the back that probably seat 4-6 people (don't quote me on that). 2 women hustling behind the counter with pots of meaty red gravy and 5 spice chicken, thin sliced pork on the grill, and a deep fryer with imperial rolls ready to meet their delicious destiny.

I couldn't tell you which menu item to pick (although I prefer the big juicy chicken to the pork) because it's all great, but the #5 is a huge serving (maybe enough for 2) with a taste of all the goods so I suggest starting there. Simple spot that doesn't try to be anything more than just tasty, cheap homestyle grub.
author: Siobhan T.

description:
Cordon Bleu's reputation precedes them. I'd been hankering to try this place for ages after hearing so many fantastic things from friends. I finally had a chance to stop by with a couple gals last night.

The space is tiny, and packed the eff out. Clearly they have some devout fans. I can see why, too -- the atmosphere is so warm and exotic, I felt like I'd been transported to Asia. There's bar seating surrounding the open kitchen where sizzling meats are being grilled before your eyes, a pot of "mystery meat sauce" (which you will discover is delicious, and dribbled all over your rice) is boiling away, and a stack of imperial rolls are being dipped repeatedly in a vat of oil.

Those imperial rolls ... oh my god. The best Vietnamese spring rolls you'll ever taste in your life. They're also about 3x the size of a normal imperial roll, but hey, I'm not complaining.

The #5 (with an imperial roll, 1 piece of five-spiced roast chicken, 1 shish kebab, country salad and meat sauce on rice) appears to be the most popular dish. At almost $10, it's not cheap either. Honestly, the rice was really clumpy and overcooked, but the aforementioned meat sauce makes up for it. The chicken was super tender and the shish kebab tasted like yummy glazed jerky, but the clear winner was the imperial roll.

The wait is a bit of a downer -- my two friends and I arrived around 7:55pm, put in our orders around 8:05pm (although we were waiting at the register, you kind of have to be aggressive about getting your order in -- just like in Asia!), and didn't receive our food till 8:30pm. Total wait almost 40 minutes. I highly recommend you order first over the phone and then just come in for pick-up.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
I dunno what everyone is on. The meat sauce isn't that good. It's too thick for my liking and I also don't like the taste. I got the kebab which wasn't really kebab like but more like bbq...beef, I think? It was good though. Topped with rice and a salad. It's cheap!! Like about $7 for lunch. 

Too bad it's kinda cramped and ghetto..guess that's how they keep it cheap? Unfortunately the meat sauce was not all that so this meal was only ok.... I think I would pick somewhere else for Vietnamese food, personally. 

The bathroom is hecka tiny. It made me feel like I was in vietnam. Lol. I never been, but it's what I imagine Vietnam to feel like. Anyway.. Yea, the toilet seat is way low..so is the sink. I'm 5'5" and I felt like a GIANT!!! 

Cash only..nooo...... I never carry cash anymore. You never know when you're gonna get robbed in San Francisco.
author: Stephanie W.

description: Fast, good and reasonably priced. They work hard to please their customers. Order ahead ~20min for pickup efficiency.
author: Cem T.

description: This is such a tiny restaurant. I love to eat and watch they cooking meat on the stove. The Chicken Salad is so good, it only cost $8.5! Lunch time there are so many people here, you should come here before 12:30pm. Otherwise you may have to wait.
author: Vanessa Z.

description: Wow! Definitely BEST dive restaurant. More food than my 115 pound eating machine body could handle for $8.65. So big eaters rejoice and those that like to share there will STILL be food left over. Get the no. 5. Wooowheeee rime for a walk!
author: Marti H.

description:
The food is cheap and big portioned. The imperial rolls are huge! The meat sauce reminds me of chef boyardee. 

Hole in the wall but good cheap food!
author: Kelly L.

description:
9/17/13  Late Lunch

3-3.5*  I've been living in my neighborhood for longer than Obama and Bush's terms combined but have never eaten at Cordon Bleu. Why? Because it's a hole-in-the-wall (literally) restaurant with only a counter space wedged between Chase Bank and the now closed Lumiere. I didn't even know it's called Cordon Bleu---generally known to me as that little hole.

I stopped by for the Five-Spice Chicken/Imperial Roll Combo. For just under $8.50 you get a huge plate of white al dente rice spattered with this rosemary-ish Italo-Filippino (Is there such a thing?) meat sauce, two pieces of BBQ chicken (breast and leg) and an imperial roll.

Imperial roll is very hot and crispy, freshly made to order in the dryer and drained well. Its filling is a bit too meaty for me but most would disagree. It's a mixture of minced pork, liver pâté and rice vermicelli. Flavor is right on. The five-spice chicken (for which this place is known) is decent. I'm not sure if it's marinated with all five spices (star anise, cloves, Chinese cinnamon, fennel seeds and Szechuan pepper) but the meat is tender enough. It's a bit charred (the grill needs some good cleaning?)  Meat sauce is not my cup of tea so I'll just order plain white rice.

Overall it's decent and it definitely fills your stomach (or two). Good price. Be aware you'll smell like BBQ if you eat in because the grill is right behind the counter. CASH ONLY.
author: Matt Y.

description: I love this place and the owner Katie! Haven't been back there for a long time cuz moved to LA. But always good memories about this place. Good food good people. Katie made me love SF even more :)
author: Ting K.

description: I love this place -- really huge portions at $10 a meal. I generally call ahead and pickup because the place itself is so small and can be kind of stuffy with the grill heat. I alternate between the #5 combo (five spice chicken, pork, imperial roll, and rice with a generous heap of tomato meat sauce) and the chicken noodle salad (cold rice noodles, five spice chicken, imperial roll, pickled radish). Cash only!
author: Shirley L.

description:
Hands down, best imperial rolls in the city. 
 
An order consist of one roll, but mind you that it is a huge portion. I like that the skin retains its crunchiness and there is a large meat filling.  

Meanwhile, I ordered the #5 Five Spice Chicken with barbeque pork, small side salad, one imperial roll, and rice drenched in the "tomato meat sauce." The chicken was slightly dry, but the pork was seasoned well with garlic, shallots, and pepper. The meat sauce was a bit bland. I was disappointed since my friends were hyping this up and it did not meet expectations. They were saying that there is a chance the meat sauce recipe may have changed since the taste and consistency did not look the same as it use to be. 

I also ordered the spring roll. Surprisingly, this is not the typical spring roll with shrimp and pork. Their spring roll is vegetarian with mushrooms, carrots, and glass noodles served with peanut sauce for dipping. It reminded me of the vegetarian dish  I usually eat at the Buddhist temple, except there is no rice paper holding it together. The filling was more on the salty side, so there was no need for the peanut sauce.  

Overall, I would go back just for the imperial rolls.
author: Becky Q.

description: Best grilled chicken vermicelli I've ever had. Cozy, affordable and always delicious! Can be long wait times tho as they're not many seats.
author: e h.

description:
I really like Cordon Bleu and woman to runs it. It's a neighborhood joint worth checking out. There is definitely something special about it.

This place is TINY so I don't suggest going with more than two people. I always like to sit at the bar. The grill is right in front of you along with the fryer, so you may smell of your 5-spice chicken when you leave.

Everything is really great but I can't say enough about the imperial rolls, meat sauce and 5-spice chicken. What you see is what you get and what you get is so so good.

Cash Only.
Check the hours.
Come very hungry.

I've been many times and I'll go again.
author: Mary A.

description:
My friend take me here a little spot  

Is very simple and easy not many items too chosen
I order number 4 my friend order number 1 we got a huge food I can't eat all price is very cheap :)
author: Chef Tickets S.

description: This place is amazing! The chicken salad for $9 is easily one of the best deals in SF. There's nothing bad to say about this place and the previous reviews explain it well. It's a  family ran hole-in-the spot with very little room, but the food is fantastic. The chicken for my salad was grilled right in front of me. The salad is a cabbage based with mint and carrots. Everything was fresh and the dressing was tasty. This is the reason we're happy to pay the absurd amount of rent we pay.... Seriously, why couldn't Twitter just open up their offices in Connecticut .....
author: Eucalyptus J.

description: I ordered Garlicy tofu which comes with rice. It was delicious. The lady who cooks is nice too she asked me how much spice level I needed. The maximum she said is 5 Chillies. I said go for it. Anyways I loved the flavor and it was cold outside so don't mind getting extra heat from the spice lol. Oh yeah make sure you have cash and there are atm's nearby. I usually use debit cards at retail as this is a very small place, but she was kind enough to tell me there was an atm nearby. The proportions of food are really big for the price you pay so its reasonable. So good food with reasonable price and good proportion.
author: Sandeep J.

description:
The food is very good but the service is always very bad,  always forget about orders.  They just don't care about their customers.  Their not orgonized. Sometimes it takes 30 min just to make an order. This place is just anoying. It's too bad because their food is really good. If you are in hurry just don't come here. 
I've been to this place more than 15 times. Something else who's anoying worth place is that they have spring rolls for sell on their menu.  But they never have them, always sold out. 
I think my review is fair.  After all those time I've been there,  i will never come back sadly :(
author: Kamel B.

description: Great location (i live across the street), huge portions that are filling at a resasonable price.  What else you can ask for?  Five stars!
author: Daniel Y.

description:
The food isn't fantastic, but it's nice to have a few simple cheap eats places around.

I got the #5, so I got to try a bit of everything: five-spice roast chicken, chicken shish kebab, imperial roll, country salad, meat sauce on rice:

- The roast chicken was nice and moist; I got a leg quarter. A little too charred for my liking, though.

- The shish kebab (not really shish kebab) was probably the best thing in the box, and went well with the little plastic tub of nuoc cham.

- The imperial roll was enormous and crispy, but kind of tasted of stale oil. The risks of coming in near closing time, I guess.

- The country salad was a small pile of shredded cabbage. As small piles of shredded cabbage go, it was fine.

- The meat sauce, I could have done without. Underseasoned and gloopy, in desperate need of a squirt of Sriracha. It might have been better if I'd eaten it there rather than taking it to go, but the restaurant doesn't have a whole lot of seating.

If I were still in college, I'd probably be a regular here. But since I'm not, it'll probably be an infrequent take-out spot. This three star rating takes the price into account, which is to say, if it weren't cheap, there'd be no reason to come here.
author: Nath A.

description: A friend introduced me to this restaurant 6 or 8 years ago, and I've been going back on every trip to San Francisco since then. The meat sauce is fantastic, and the imperial rolls are as good as I've had anywhere. The food can be quite filling, so have a good appetite if you go. The service is good, and the people who work there are friendly and polite. My only disappointment is that, over the years, the restaurant was unexpectedly closed a few times when I've tried to go, so I've learned to call ahead before heading over to Cordon Bleu from my hotel.
author: Tim D.

description:
The #5

San Francisco Gem
A true hole-in-the-wall find
Deserves every star

Imperial roll
Almost like a meat dessert
Satisfying crunch

Five spice roasted bird
Flavorful moist and tender
One very large piece

Country salad side
Usually not a fan
It is done right here

Thin beef shish kabob 
Almost as good as bacon
I am not kidding 

Rice and meat sauce huh?
A lot better than it sounds
A quality meal
author: Bryan C.

description: this is the place when you're looking for some delicious, filling, cheap comfort food. They're definitely not going to win any awards with the food here, but that's not the purpose. It's to fill you up without breaking the bank
author: Derrick W.

description: I don't understand the hype about this spot. I went to this place because I read great reviews. I just might be picky food critic. But actually the place was real dirty. I had a chicken vermicelli salad. The chicken didn't have much flavor. It's supposed to be a 5 spiced chicken which I have had plenty of times at other Vietnamese restaurants that had great flavor. That salad was basic. They have a basic menu chicken or pork. If the chicken wasn't special then your options are limited.
author: Princess Jasmine J.

description: This is a hole in the wall diner type vietnamese cafe lunch spot. Very low key, owners work and cook the food or I believe they do. They serve rustic homemade vietnamese food. Not your typical vietnamese food. Rice over gravy and with Pork or Chicken yumm!!!!! Their imperial or emperor rolls are good!
author: Miguel Y.

description: Happen to be in the neighborhood, and dropped in.  Good value food.  Owner Katie is nice.  The food is not cook start from finish from scratch but reheat from re-frying which is OK because she's the only cook handling all the orders and I hate raw meat.  The meat is flavorful and marinated. The imperial roll is the best I've tasted from any restaurant. Salad is very fresh.  The only low point that I can say is that the grill needs to be clean with a wire brush now and then when there's a lot of build up from the cooking,  I can see that she didn't over grill the meat but the debris of char collected from the grill diminishes the fine flavor of the food.  Aside from that this is a solid good comfort food.  This is a hearty delicious and honest Vietnamese food.
author: Mar H.

description: Still bomb! This place has been here for a while and is as good as when I went there 15 years ago !
author: Kai P.

description:
Big portions, reasonably priced, decent food and good service. 

Value
The portions were HUGE... which was just enough for me because I'm still hungry after eating at most places. It was $10 including tax for the five spice half chicken, 3 kebabs, 1 imperial roll, rice with meat sauce, and salad. 

Taste
I was expecting the chicken breast to be dry, but it was moist inside. It had enough flavor where it wasn't bland, but I wanted more flavor. It wasn't the "best chicken I've had outside of Vietnam" as advertised on the menu. The kebab was the same.  The imperial roll was battered and deep fried. The rice and meat sauce was okay, and the salad had enough flavor. It came with the fish sauce/lemon juice dipping sauce. 

Service
The service was fine. I don't expect 5 star service from a $ place. We arrived around 7pm when the place was empty and they let my family sit at the back table. It took about 30 minutes for the food to arrive, and the place was packed. 

Atmosphere
Not much to say here. It is literally a hole in the wall. The chair cushions were ripped. There were many picture frames of fireworks, and one lamp in the back that lights up the entire place besides the stove light. 

Conclusion
At first I was confused when I Yelped the place. Cordon Bleu sounds French, but the place was serving Vietnamese food... okay... They offer big portions for the price. The food is okay. There are other restaurants with more flavorful Vietnamese food that cost more. Come help support the Chinese workers.
author: Colin L.

description:
One of the best hole in the wall in the city. CASH ONLY. Located in the busy corner of California and Polk. Only street parking so it may be difficult during the peak lunch and dinner hours. More difficult is the dinner hours. Pretty much counter seating. There are 3 small tables in the back. 1 table seats 2 and the other 2 are put together to potentially seat 4.
The portions are huge especially for the price. Order the #7 half chicken with rice and meat sauce. If you like chicken, then you go here and get some chicken. The meat sauce over the rice is really tasty. Really makes for a great rice dish.
Nice lady cooking the food right in front of you.  Watch your yummy chicken get grilled right in front of you. 
Highly recommend!
author: Earl G.

description: A hole in the wall! We arrived a little after 7pm, and there were zero customers. 4 of us ordered #5 and one of us ordered the cold noodles. Slowly more and more customers arrived, so the wait of the food to arrive took a while. Pretty soon around 730pm, it was packed and phones were ringing and ringing for takeout orders. I had the #5 which consisted of grilled pork, imperial roll (ginormous), 5 spiced chicken, salad (cole slaw with vinegar), and meat sauce over rice. All for $10! worth it! Good for 2 meals! I also tried some of the cold noodles, good but not as good as #5. Definitely recommend this place if you're in the area.
author: Kylie L.

description:
(See pics) Review #1307. This place reminds me of Yamo- mostly women operated, small kitchen and hole-in-the-wall, bar seats only, poor ventilation, but delicious food! Wait time could easily be an hour during dinner time and you will be waiting either in cold outside or steam packed inside. Best would be call and do a takeout.

Fiery grill with the five spice chicken was hot tasty but the deep fried imperial roll was definitely a must have.
author: T L.

description:
Good for the buck, the chicken was very tender and the kebab was very delicious. The only thing id say is that the gravy on the rice is very "poutine" like and not quite vietnamese. 

The kind of food youd have after a long night of partying. 

Portions are huge.

Imperial roll is okay.
author: Michelle V.

description:
I actually found this place on yelp and bookmarked it, and babe saw their food pictures and has been wanting to try it. 

I got the number 1 entree, with the imperial roll, shish kebab and meat sauce on rice. Babe at the entree #5 which had the same thing I had but with the 5 spice chicken.

 I think my favorite thing would be the imperial roll, nicely deep fried lol I'm such a fatty. 
The shish kebab was pretty good too, but it also didn't seem that special to me. 
The 5 spice chicken that I tried wasn't bad either, but I don't think I had enough to give it a really good judgement. 

I think I would probably want to come back for their imperial rolls. Next time, I'll get the #2 entree with TWO imperial rolls. lol
author: Harriet W.

description: This place is amazing!! You get huge portions and it is so cheap. We got the number 5 for about $10 for two of us and we couldn't finish it. Food comes out quickly too. Great stop for a quick, cheap, and great meal.
author: Shabnam E.

description:
After walking down Van ness for a couple of blocks and not being able to choose a restaurant for dinner, my friend told me how amazing the food at this popular Vietnamese restaurant was and I have to admit that the portion sizes are huge! 

I ordered the noodle salad and it was good and flavorful. The wait for a table and the food is quite long, but if you're with good company and catching up, it's okay. 

The restaurant consists of three tables and a bar area right next to where the food is being cooked. It is super tiny and it's hard to line up inside the restaurant. 

The menu is a bit limited but that's mostly due to the fact that there are only two people cooking, one with the grill and the other with the wok. 

What surprised me the most about this place is how the dishes are washed by hand in the back, with a restaurant this popular, it must be hard to keep up with all the dirty plates and utensils. These people never seem to be able to take a break and seeing how hard they work I can't complain that I had to wait a bit for my food. They're doing the best they can! I give them props for that.
author: Maybo L.

description:
Wow! This was great. I went in with high expectations because of the reviews and it definitely did not disappoint. 

I had the noodle salad and it was one of the best I've ever had in my life. 

I will be staying in San Fran for the next 4 months and know I will be coming here often!
author: Jenn S.

description: I have enjoyed this oasis of culinary joy for the past 46 years, with same generous mound of delicious Vietnamese food. I love to bring friends there to sit at the front of the counter and watch the ladies preparing the aromatic five-spice chicken, and stirring the cauldron of tomato meat sauce for the side dish, which is poured generously over a pile of fluffy rice. Chicken salad is excellent.The place is warm and cozy, friendly, with good ambiance among the guests. Prices are modest for the amount and quality of food served. It is always an uplifting experience to be there. One couple recently flew in to SFO from South America and headed directly for Cordon Bleu, having been away for five years. The owner recognized them and interacted cordially. Cordon Bleu has long time faithful customers.
author: Carolyn D.

description:
This place is filthy. Box of cabbage on the filthy floor. Pot of chicken on the floor to be transferred to the grill for consumption. One of the workers dropped a spoon on the floor and merely rinsed it off and continued stirring the meat sauce. 
I can't even express how disgusting this place is. I don't understand the 4 star rating. 
The bathroom is the worst part if the place.
author: rebecca r.

description:
Hole in the wall. Lots of delicious delicious meat. Cash only. #5 meal. That's all you need to know!! 

28/ 30 yelp challenge
author: Sam W.

description: Cordon Bleu is one of the things I miss most about San Francisco. Every time I come, I fail to prioritize my meats. It's a struggle. I can't decide if I want the chicken (delicious), shish kebab (also delicious) or imperial roll (which is a must, I don't care how full you are). So I end up getting #5, which is ALL the meats. But that's not all. You're not here just for the meat dilemma. You're also here for the mother of all meat sauces. I kid you not, this stuff will change your life. You get this meat sauce atop a pile of white rice, and resistance is futile. If you have this for lunch, you've got the recipe for a delicious, delicious food coma. You'd better have a napping spot ready.
author: Angeline P.

description:
A hole in the wall Vietnamese diner that gives you the Street food style of Viet BBQ. With $10 you can eat like a king. The # 4 and 5 are particularly great values, and the chicken salad is also quite health conscientious.

Make no mistake, this is not fancy dining. The venue itself is small and cramped, the door hardly works, and there are only two people working at a time. Thankfully this just lends to the  restaurant's charm. 

Get the food to go (ask for meat sauce on the side, you'll thank me) and enjoy a taste of some home cooked cuisine.
author: Justin I.

description:
Huge servings, flavorful chicken, and home-run by the sweetest owners. The place is pretty small, which adds to its appeal-- the focus is solely on the food. 

We (barely) managed to finish our plates, and left feeling like champs. Cash only!
author: Angela H.

description:
So this is not a place for clean freaks or food purists. This is an awesome place for people who want a huge cheap meal.  

The number 5 is def the most popular but it's not for me, too much rice and I don't care for the meat sauce.  I do however go crazy for the noodle salad.  Totally worth spending an extra dollar to substitute chicken for shredded kebab.

It's often crowded and you can end up waiting 15-30 minutes for your food.  

Cash only. And if you're a girl go potty before you come here. Seriously. I think they spend  their time concentrating on the flavor of their food and not so much on the cleanliness..
author: Poppy C.

description: I felt like I was walking into a private Vietnamese home when I first entered, what with the grill, tight quarters and lonesome lightbulb. However, once the food fought it's way past my teeth and into my esophagus, I began to feel emotions that I've never felt before. I even invented a new word to describe them: orgsvanomous. I came close to tears of joy as I gnawed my way through the jaw-dropping feast, and became oblivious to the world until I reached the bottom of my love-encrusted noodle bowl. Don't make the mistake of missing out on this beacon of hope for the taste bud community.
author: Liam W.

description:
To summarize this place in one sentence: This is a hole-in-the-wall, Americanized decent Vietnamese restaurant that takes their time to cook/serve your large inexpensive portion of food.

Yes, you should probably order the famous number 5 which includes all things your palette should try. If you're a normal person, you likely won't finish it so expect to box it up to take home. Or, be smart and order this one dish for two people.

The two Asian women working behind the counter seemed efficient and nice. I think they were Chinese and not Vietnamese.

There are lots of good restaurants around here like Swan Oyster Depot.
author: Marlon T.

description:
I hadn't expected much because the restaurant was so tiny.
But the food, Pork chop, was so amazing!
Most tasty meat I've ever had!
I'll go there again with my friend
author: Minseon G.

description:
Huge portions, great food, and a unique experience.

I had heard about this place through the grapevine and couldn't wait to try it! The cooks make the food right behind the bar, and it has a very home-y feeling. 

I came here with a friend and our favorite part of the meal was the shish kabob (still craving it), but everything was very good. 

I'd recommend getting the #5 so you get a little bit of everything, but we also got a tofu dish that was ginormous and really good too!  

Come hungry!
author: Marilyn M.

description:
A lot of things in life let you down. Beers aren't as refreshing as they look (wait, coldness doesn't equal taste?). Kale isn't actually a superfood, in that I've yet to develop any special powers. Even things you once loved lose their luster. That shiny new Segway in your garage. The warmth of your wife's embrace. All diminishing returns. Except for Cordon Bleu. This humble hole-in-the-wall defies that modern economic theory. It never gets worse. It only gets better. Like a nice wine, or Space Jam on VHS, 60% of the time, it's good, all the time. If you're in the mood for moist, flavorful chicken, marinated shish kebab, and d*ck sized fresh fried imperial rolls prepared by old Chinese ladies, come here. If you want to sigh gloomily because the rainbow outside your window isn't as beautiful as it was last week, gtfo.

PEACE
author: Alex L.

description:
When people say "hole in the wall", they must be talking about the Cordon Bleu since I walked right past it when I was looking for it. There are two small tables in the back, and a counter with maybe 8 stools, and that's it. Totally awesome to be so close to the action. I usually have dry skin in cooler weather, but getting to sit about 5 feet from the fryers lubed me right up and I was fine. 

I went ahead and ordered the revered #5. 5 spice chicken, imperial roll,  rice with gravy, some sort of flat piece of meet, and some shredded lettuce "salad". The chicken was only ok. You can choose between a leg or a breast. Usually I'm a breast man (har har), but I went with the leg this time. Only ok. Not really that juicy or hot. Eh. The flat piece of meat was rubbery and not advised. The rice with gravy was quite good. God only knows what it is, but it certainly complimented that rice really well. The imperial roll is just a fried spring roll and this was my favorite thing on the plate. Think of your Vietnamese mother or Vietnamese friend's mother's authentic food, and that is what you'll get with that fried spring roll ("cha giau" in Viet-speak). Right on, no question. I think the next time I'll just get a couple of those with the rice and gravy for a complete meal. 

I like this place, although was whispered to by my neighbor telling me that the staff was actually Chinese. lol.

Bathroom: Tried going in the bathroom in the back and apparently someone had accidentally locked it from the inside and left. To my surprise they were trying to use a meat clever to pry the door open! :D
author: Marc M.

description:
This is hardcore-style neighborhood Vietnamese eating. I think that even Guy Fieri on "Triple D" (annoying announcer-voice implied) would pass on this place. It's a tiny dive, and not in the "cozy, quaint" kind of way, more like the "iffy, possibly shady" type of hole in the wall. 

Oddly enough, though, it's not as uncomfortable as it looks. We arrived just before the dinnertime crunch, and found spots at the counter, right in front of all the burbling cauldrons of who knows what, and chicken on the grill. It has to be hot, standing right up against all that. I don't know how the people churning this food out deal with that kind of heat all day. 

I ordered a chicken salad, and it didn't look like any "chicken salad" I'm used to seeing, I know that much. It was a heaping mound of five-spice chicken on top of rice doused in some odd red sauce, with a big egg roll. And this was well under $10....believe it or not, a ton more food than I was wanting at the time. Two people could share this and be completely OK. 

The five-spice chicken was pretty awesome, I'll give it that. But man, I just don't know about that red sauce the rice was doused in. With the rice, it came off as similar to a gumbo, texturally. It tasted like Manhattan-style clam chowder, or a Florida Keys-style tomato-based conch chowder, and that was NOT what I was expecting (or wanting, if I'm being honest) with this dish, at all. It just didn't fit, and didn't strike me as very Vietnamese. 

In fact, I enjoyed this aspect of the meal so little, I feel compelled to drop the rating a full two stars, and this might even be generous. It threw a damper on what would otherwise have been a great meal for extremely impressive value. I swear, it tasted like conch chowder. Does. Not. Compute. Was I in a Nob Hill Viet dive, or Key West? Weird.
author: Patrick L.

description: Great quality food, great portions, and friendly service. Katie makes the dining experience feel like you are at home.
author: Kate A.

description:
I found Cordon Blue after conquering the hike up California from downtown.  With hunger pangs and a lust for something unique, we walked in to this little place, which was full of delicious smells and packed wall to wall!

These are the kinds of places that attract me, with a few seats around a grill, where you can see everything being prepared in front of your eyes, and the owner making the food as if she has for her whole life.

Big portions, low prices, and everything was delicious.  We did not go for the lunch menu (though it looked great), but ended up sharing the noodle salad with shish kabob, which came with an imperial roll (omg delicious) for about 8$.  This was more than enough for two for lunch and we were the right kind of full.
author: Sean F.

description: Not very good or clean. Chicken way overrated, plenty of comparable or better 5-spice chicken options in town. Service attitude poor also, as if couldn't care less whether you're enjoying your meal. Quite disappointed.
author: Mikey L.

description:
Do not go to this place for ambiance. It literally has under 20 seats and is best only for take out or if you don't mind eating in a hole in the wall.    

I love the spicy pork chop over rice (comes with a salad) and the chicken with meat sauce. I also always get the imperial roll (fried and crunchy goodness) to share.  It's delicious and you cannot go wrong!
author: Shubhra S.

description:
After reading some of the reviews, and realizing this was about a 3 min walk from my overpriced yet tasteful apartment, I decided to eat here.

First of all, do not expect an opulent dining experience. It is a tiny place, with a white formica countertop and a few seats. When I sat down, the counter in front of me was dirty, so the woman/chef/dishwasher/proprietess, after a few promptings, picked up a dirty cloth and proceeded to wipe it "clean" for me. Ugh.

The kitchen consisted of a tiny grill, and a deep fat fryer. It is a tad questionable how often they change their oil. Probably right before the annual health inspector shows up.

OK, the food: I ordered the 1 Piece Five Spiced Roast Chicken, 1 Imperial Roll, 1 Shish Kebab, Country Salad, Meat Sauce On Rice all for about 9 bucks. Lots of food for this price. I must say, the food is tasty, and filling. If I were a homeless person and could only hustle $9 in change per day, I would spend it here. 

Other than this, I think there might be better (more authentic) vietnamese food in the city, like at Tu Lan.

Worth a stop, if you do not mind run down, seedy decor.
author: Tim N.

description:
I was not impressed with their vegetarian option. I ordered the veggie fresh rolls and the veggie noodle salad. The salad had mainly plain noodles, with very little lettuce and did not come with the veggie roll. Also the fresh rolls were not fresh. They were cooked and soggy. 
The prices online were not accurate and I was charged more than expected. I will not be returning back to this place ever again.
author: Sbeen A.

description:
This friendly hole in the wall is some of the best chicken I've had in the bay. Cordon Bleu seats about 12 people comfortably, and a majority of those seats is bar seating. If this is your first time then I'd suggest getting a combo to get a good sense of a couple items they sell. There are a handful of combo's but in my opinion there are only two real combo's. There's a combo thats mostly chicken (4-5 pieces) and then there's a combo that comes with chicken, gyro meat, and an imperial roll (kinda like a deep fried spring roll). I think the combo's I mentioned above is #5 and #6, or #4 and #5. My apologies for forgetting the combo numbers.

Overall, the pros are: great food, cheap prices, and friendly service. The cons are: limited seating, and cash only.
author: Ken C.

description:
Still love this place :)
Was having lunch here the other day and it made me smile knowing that I have a homey spot right up the street to enjoy a hot meal !

The owner knows all her customers and always makes time to chat even though she's holding down the fort!

Imperial rolls here are always on point - my favorite kind!

TIP ** Cash only :)  Wells Fargo/Chase banks on the same block.
author: Selina W.

description:
Food here is pretty good.  People aren't joking about the imperial roll.  Its definitely yummy.  This place isn't super authentic Vietnamese (hence the "meat sauce" over rice thing), but all in all, I'm happy this place is in my neighborhood.  Good comfort food when I need it.  

I think the owners are Chinese because when I tried to order in Viet, they just stared at me blankly.  I also overheard them speaking to each other in Chinese also.  No biggie... Just come here, sit at the counter and order up.
author: Vicky T.

description:
Best fresh spring rolls I've had. The springrolls are big, filled with flavor, lots of mushrooms (don't get them if you don't like mushrooms!), kinda floppy (which sounds weird, but it just makes them stand out from the rest, not stiff and kinda of dried out like others). They are simply rolls of deliciousness that are perfect by themselves, although they come with a good peanut sauce too. 

Get the springrolls. Not the imperial rolls (you can it you want), those were fried and greasy, not my cup of tea. 

The noodle salad was also very good. But the rolls are what sold me. Great prices and great service too!
author: Maleenee B.

description:
Overall: I love, love, love this place

Pros
- noodle salad
- chicken salad
- imperial roll, you must get

Sidenote
- owner is super nice
- food is grilled right in front of ya
- you can get orders to go
author: Michelle D.

description:
I stumbled on this gem with my boyfriend last weekend while viewing an apartment in the area and wooooooooowwww. 

We followed our noses in and grabbed the only small table in the corner. There is only one table, the rest is counters so don't come here with a big group. 

My boyfriend ordered the number five and I tried the noodle salad. All the meat is cooked up on the grill in front of you and the smell had us drooling. After ten or so minutes the food was plopped down in front of us. 

The number five has chicken (he always orders the leg but I think you might be able to ask for the breast if dark meat isn't your thing), marinated pork, an imperial roll, rice and a sauce that reminded me of Heinz baked beans, but in a good way. My boy did say a word until he had finished his meal. For a chatty guy, that is saying something!

The noodle salad had a delicious dressing on it and also came with the marinated pork and an imperial roll.
