The highlight is the imperial roll. Flavorful, crispy, hearty. If I could eat nothing but imperial rolls for a week, I would be a happy woman!

Unfortunately we did not get the apartment but it may be blessing in disguise for my waist line. 

Definitely stop in if you are in the area and get an extra imperial roll. Thank me later.

Bon appétit!
author: Ellen B.

description:
Here goes my first review. 

I've been coming here for the past 6 months, truly enjoy the place a lot. 

What I like:
- has a very cozy feel to it. Small "hole in the wall" family-like environment where you sit in front of the cooking area -- everything is done before you.
- food taste is out of this world, I've yet to see anyone who didn't enjoy it. Even my extremely picky-eater girlfriend really enjoyed the food. It's deceptively tasty, you will be surprised. You walk in, it's quiet, seems like an aged place, they serve you the food it looks normal, nothing amazing. Once you take the first bite you will understand the hype.
- menu is relatively simple and they limit your options. To me, this is a +. 
- the portion sizes are respectable.

What can be improved:
- my largest qualm w this place is w the attitude of the owner. While this may in part contribute to the hole in the wall feel of the restaurant, she is pretty cold, unwelcoming, almost grumpy. If you ask her for something on the wrong day she will respond w attitude and make you regret asking in the first place. That being said, she's been seen w a half-smile on occasion. 
- the rest of the staff does not speak English and is damn near clueless.
- it's very cramped inside.
- waiting times can be extremely ridiculous.

In summary:
Food: excellent.
Experience: not perfect.
author: Temur K.

description:
5 Stars for the huge portions, rich deep heavy flavors, spicy aromas, and oh-so-satisfying stomach bloat after eating here.

5 Stars for the incredibly low prices. Dinner for 2, less than $20.

1 Star for the dining room ambience & cleanliness.  If you like quiet, clean, peaceful dining rooms you will be shocked how ghetto this place is. I've visited almost all of Asia  - North, south, east & west. This place would be considered dirty even by Asian standards.

Yet Cordon Blue is one of my favorites dives in SF.
author: Tom S.

description:
I've only been here once for a late dinner, but going by first impression it was good...I got the number five, BBQ chicken plate and did not complain. 

Food- A (Check out the pic)

Service- A

Atmosphere- A

My portions were hefty, delicious, affordable and everyone there was friendly. It's like others describe, a hole-in-the-wall. So seating is limited. Being a hole-in-the-wall, it's not pretty and neither is food presentation. But you don't go here for looks, you go to get fed! I am definitely going to come back.

Oh and if you decide to dine here bring cash...
author: Mike D.

description:
We let Yelp Reviews guide us to this location and were really, really happy! It's a small "hole-in-the-wall" location that has pretty quick turnover.  The ladies who were cooking were very quick to take our order and make it.  Beware that only cash is taken but the prices are very cheap and plates are enormous.

We had a #5 combo to grab a little of everything and a ma po tofu plate. Both were awesome and either one would have been enough to convince us to go back again. Didn't finish everything but got a box to go. Was about just as good the next day!  When we got there, the bar area was filled but there were two tables in the back.  All the seats changed over while we were there. We saw a group come up and wonder whether they'd gotten to the right location (looking at their phones probably to make sure it really was the spot with the great reviews). By the time we left, people were standing around inside waiting for free seats and a line had formed outside.

Certainly a place to recommend!
author: William D.

description: I've been going here since I was in Middle and has always been my Mom's favorite spot as well. The Food is delicious & the price is right. The portion of food is a lot so be prepared with a good appetite. You will Love the Food!!!
author: Ryan M.

description:
BEST IMPERIAL ROLLS EVER..........................

OKOK onto the real review.
it's a hole in the wall place in Nob Hill, DEFINITELY stop by if you're in the area and craving for CHEAP and hearty food.

don't expect fancy shmancy seating. i think the counter seats around 10 and there are a few small tables in the back. it's not the cleanest and roomiest place but man, the food and prices make up for it!

the lady who runs this place is hella boss. lol. she's not gonna cater to you but she'll get you what you need if you ask for it, so don't be shy! it'sa typical asian place in that sense.

so I got the #5 which was $9 and comprised of:
-- a heap of rice w/ their red sauce (tastes kinda like spaghetti sauce but it's soooooo good and hits the spot..). the rice is good too b/c i noticed they used a double boiler type thing so it stays moist.
-- 5 spice chicken (it was grilled nicely but i wish it had more of the 5-spcie flavor in it.. the portion was hella big though. i've had better buuuut it was good for the price. it's really good as leftovers too =)
-- some grilled pork slices (like 2-3).. kinda charred and thin & a bit overcooked but not inedible.
-- AND THE STARRRRRRRRR: THE IMPERIAL ROLL. the #5 just comes w/ one imperial roll but i got a good 5-6 bites out of it.... omg -- you must try it for yourself. i've ordered from a bunch of places but this was BY FAR, the best here.

next time i'm here, i'm def gonna pick up a few of those, maybe the rice w/ red sauce if i'm hella hungry. those 2 items are a MUST. and i think it's totally worth driving out of your way just to try them.
author: Emily C.

description: Great legit Vietnamese food with the really competitive prices! Try the chicken meat sauce/ imperial roll number 5 special, so delicious!! :) one of the best in the area for sure
author: Sara C.

description:
Get food to-go if you can! It is very hard to get a seat during dinner time and you can expect to wait 15-20min for your food even after you get seated.

My friend and I got dinner here on a Tuesday night at around 730pm and grabbed the last 2 seats that were open. We really lucked out because the place got packed at around 830pm - people were standing all along the walls because there was no where to sit!

We both got the #5, which is their specialty. For $10, it is enough food for about 1.5 meals. However, the chicken I got was half burnt, so that was pretty disappointing. The imperial roll was probably my favorite part so I might just get that in the future.
author: Jenny M.

description: Best place to eat around Polk/nob hill. Great value and the food is he best. The chicken is simply delicious and cooked just right. More on the smoky and charred side which I love. The kebabs are amazing too. Very flavorful and crispy. For some reason I love the meat sauce with rice- very simple yet comforting. Only downfall is that it is a small hole in the wall kind of place, but that's where some of the best food comes from!
author: Fahmid K.

description:
Came here for lunch today.  Not bad.  Small old hole in the wall diner in Nob Hill.   The place probably only seat about 10 folks at the bar and 6 at the tables.  Menu is very limited. 
Pretty much you are there for the 5 spice chicken.  We ordered the plate special #5.  Seems like the popular one.  Came with one large piece of chicken (leg or breast), iceburg lettuce, giant imperial roll (pork) and white rice with meat sauce (pretty much a meat pasta sauce over the white rice).  The meat sauce over rice reminded me of HK cafe diner dish.  Very popular.
I really don't see how this place is labeled as Vietnamese food but I have to admit that five spice chicken was really good!
Great place for cheap eat!  All the plates are less than $10. Huge portions.  Good enough to share!  If you plan to share order an extra chicken.
Warning: cash only
author: Ying F.

description:
This place is amazing! 
The food is dirt cheap no matter how hungry you are you can easily get full on less than 10 dollars. It's fast, the people are nice. You should definitely check it out :)
author: Amanda M.

description:
CHICKEN
FRIED IMPERIAL ROLL
EXTRA SAUCE PLEASE

I can't even tell you how many times I've been to this restaurant.  Their number is on my speed dial and the lady knows my exact order.  This is literally a hole in the wall and compares to my mother's cooking.  It has a spectacular homemade feel and is just dripping with tasty flavor.
author: Christina K.

description:
Sigh . . . another old review mysteriously gone. Yelp, can you hire some more DBA's with your IPO proceeds?

-------------------------

Cordon Bleu is your quintessential hole-in-the-wall. They do a lot of take-out because seating is just a couple of tables or the "chef's counter" overlooking the "open kitchen" (these folks were on the cutting edge of modern restaurant design). 

I used to live on Bush St, 2 blocks away, and ate here pretty regularly because it's good and cheap. My standard order was the combo with 5-spice chicken, grilled pork, imperial roll and meat sauce over rice (#5?).

5-spice chicken is what they tout on their outside sign; this version has crispy skin and very nice flavors. The pork is also well marinated and grilled. Imperial rolls are in bubbly rice paper are in a big pre-cooked pile which they reheat with each order. It was here that I was first introduced to the rice-paper wrapped Imperial roll.

I don't think I've seen the meat sauce on rice at any other Viet joint, but I like to ask for extra. It's like a thin, but tasty spaghetti sauce or no-bean chili. OTOH, people I've come here with have been grossed out by the meat sauce so YMMV.

One plate is usually enough for 2 meals.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Delicious food! Friendly staff. Prompt
Service. Small intimate and authentic.  Definitely a must.
author: Lynn H.

description: Funny today a guy was there devouring a plate of kebab thinking it was chicken but it was pork which is against his religious beliefs. But he said it was good.
author: N A.

description:
Cordon Bleu is the most auspicious temple of the "Imperial Roll", or what I would call CHA GIO in most other Vietnamese restaurants.  However, the name, Imperial Roll, may be quite appropriate since the Cordon Bleu's version is the best I have ever  eaten, and I've been to quite a few boites that serve these ubiquitous rolls.  The Golden Deli in San Gabriel near Los Angeles comes close, but it too falls short of the greatness achieved in this very modest "dive" on California Street between Polk and Larkin.

I always pay homage to this temple whenever I make my trek up north.  This cha gio is dense, packed with thin glass noodles, rough ground, spiced pork, carrots and onions and garlic.  The Vietnamese version of the "egg roll" is superior to the Chinese ones since the wrapper is made from a thin rice "skin" which frys up ever so crisp and light.  When taken immediately out of the fryer, the fried crisp skin almost shatters in between the teeth, and the breaking open of the roll releases a garlicly, black peppery, spiced aroma that, to me, is equivalent to ambrosia of the Gods.  

I always do take out since I can then go around the corner to Common Sage on 1552 Polk St, San Francisco, CA 94109 (b/t California St & Sacramento St.) in Nob Hill to get some beer like Orion, Echigo Koshihikari, Ebisu, Ginga Ko-gen, etc. since the combination of these two elegantly concocted food and drink is positively mind-blowing to use an old, hoary expression from the late 1960's.

San Francisco has some really amazing restaurants.  Gary Danko comes to mind. But for the price, Cordon Bleu's Imperial Roll is beyond words.  You gotta put one in your mouth to know what I mean.

PS  Phone ahead so you can grab the Imperial Rolls and make a quick get away since there will probably be no parking, and you'll need to double park on California somewhere.
author: Gary I.

description: I'm such a sucker for hole in the wall restaurants, and much more of a sucker for a good classic vietnamese meal. This noodle bowl was off the hook. It's pretty big so very worth the price! Loved it. Also, there is hot tea!
author: Cherish P.

description:
Super hole in the wall restaurant. Very small dining area with a few bar stools. I want to say.. 2 tables for 4 people and maybe 6 stools? Don't come here with a big group! Nice place to eat if you're coming with one other friend. 
Good portions for the price! You would probably pay $10 out the door if you get the rice plates. It usually comes with one meat, cabbage, rice, house meat sauce, and delicious egg rolls if you pay a little extra. I brought some people here a while back and they thought it was alright.. But I absolutely love the vibe here. Quick, good home made food. Try it once if it sounds even slightly appealing to you!
author: Kev L.

description:
You're here to eat! With a small menu, they are know for their chicken - grilled to perfection right in front of you. A tiny little place and obviously been here for decades, the place seats probably 15 at max with half of those seats facing the kitchen and food is made directly in front of you. 
A meal will sit at about $10. 
Their fish sauce to go with the food is great!
author: Van-Anh N.

description:
3 stars for take out, 2 stars for dine in.

The restaurant itself is definitely not a looker. It's a hole in the wall out by Polk St. under a small, blue awning. Insider, it's just bare bones with maybe 10 seats at the bar and three small tables. Behind the bar is an open top grill exposed to the seating area.  

The service here was EXTREMELY SLOW. In total, we were sitting there for over an hour before our meal was slow. It also took about 20 mins for them to take our order. I tried to order from the first lady who brought out our utensils, but she didn't understand "Two #5s" in English. Moreover, she didn't even try to motion another wait staff to take our order. While we were waiting for our food, someone left the bathroom door open, and a putrid smell started wafting into the dining area. Some people who had already started eating looked pretty nauseated, and I'm pretty sure they lost their appetite right then. Luckily, our table hadn't started eating yet, but I know I was pretty disgusted by the smell. I also strongly urge you all to stay away from sitting in the back left corner of the restaurant!!  

I ordered Combo #5, which includes their famous five spice chicken, imperial roll, shish kebab, country salad, meat sauce, and rice. I thought everything had a pretty good flavor, and there was a hefty sized portion enough to last two meals. Note that the shish kebab was not served on a kebab stick, but is just the grilled meat. The meat was a bit too charred though, in my opinion. The meat wasn't burnt, but it was just very blackened. It was as if they hadn't cleaned their grill in a while that night, and all the residual char from the previous grilling had rubbed off onto the meat. As others have mentioned, the meat sauce is reminiscent of a light spaghetti tomato meat sauce, which was unexpected, but works with the rice and meat. 

The food was tasty here, so I wouldn't mind getting takeout next time. However, by all means, avoid the far left corner of the seating area if you want to keep your appetite!!
author: Audrey L.

description: The food really isn't Vietnamese. Ordered number 5 combo. Lots of food none of it very good. Meat sauce on the rice just wasn't  good and kabob was bland.  Chicken was the best part but nothing special.
author: Jack M.

description: The food come pretttttyyyyy slow only one lady speak english and the chicken looks good in one side and totally burnt the other side. It is still very tasty and the portion is huge!!
author: Kristin W.

description:
I ordered here today for take-out. Portion size is pretty big, but overall it was nothing fantastic.

Their five spice chicken was ok. Meat was close to dry. It's pretty hard to mess up a chicken thigh quarter, so take from that what you will. I didn't taste much spice, though the bbq grilling added a nice smokiness. One piece of chicken was a little too charred. 3star

Grilled pork was flavorful, though a little tough and chewy and sliced on the thin side, as expected when ordering grilled pork over rice from any quickie Vietnamese place. 3star

The slaw that came with, I thought was unnecessary and almost took away from the meal. It was a tangy slaw and didn't quite make sense as a component. Pass. 1star

The rice with meat sauce is great if you're wandering down memory lane (at least, for me), but other than that, it was slightly overcooked rice with a red sauce that tasted a little like a canned tomato sauce with ketchup and beef cooked in it. Tasty and filling, but nothing spectacular. 2star

Now, the imperial roll was the best. Big, crispy, crunchy, hot, greasy, and filled with ground pork and other goodies. Add some Sriracha to their dipping sauce and it is PER-FECT. 5star

And the service was ok. Now, I didn't eat in the little restaurant itself, but although the guy who took my order over the phone was not the most welcoming, he wasn't rude, and got the order right. The servers didn't crack a smile when I went in to pick up my order, and I'm pretty smiley with people (I've worked in retail!), but that's ok :P  Transaction went smoothly, and so since I'm no sourpuss.. 4star

Overall, not bad. I'd go back I guess, but certainly not for Vietnamese fine dining. (For the imperial rolls YES.)
author: Karen C.

description:
I always get my five spice chicken!! Delicious!!! Cheap!!! And big portion!!
I love this place even sometime I have to wait to get a place to sit it is so worth the wait!
The ladies who are the owner are so nice and all speak English very well. They have been in the business for years!
My favorite parts are: cheap, delicious, an huge portion.
Too bad it's cash only.
author: Ty N.

description:
I hate to sound like I'm in junior high, but I've been eating here since before Yelp existed so that makes me cooler than any of you clowns. 

I have since moved away from SF, but Cordon Bleu is always my 1st or 2nd stop every time I'm in the city (Tu Lan being the other). I'm happy to report that in the 10 or so years I've been a customer, Katie hasn't changed, nor has she changed anything on the menu. I visited with my family and brand new baby last week, and seeing Katie again made me feel like I was visiting my own family. Even though I don't know her personally, I have been there enough times to see just how she treats people, customers and non-customers alike. It doesn't take much to see just what a good human being she is. 

Everything is good here. Just eat anything and you'll be happy. I especially LOVE the simple green onion infused oil she puts on the rice for the pork chop dish. 

Tip: Katie runs this restaurant pretty much on her own, so call ahead of time just to make sure she's there. 

Bonus: After your meal, go around the corner and visit the best donut shop in SF (Bob's) for a little dessert.
author: Los Angelin O.

description:
I've figuratively described many places as "holes-in-the-wall", but Cordon Bleu Vietnamese Restaurant is LITERALLY a hole in the wall.  This eatery is probably eleven feet wide and twenty feet deep.  But don't let that size and lack of ambiance fool you.  They have a small menu as well, but the few dishes they serve - they make damn good.  For $9, I ordered combo #5 (see photo) and that entree could feed me for three meals.  THREE MEALS.  FOR NINE WHOLE DOLLARS.  INSANE.  The chicken is flavorful; the shish kebab is a thin piece of beef that has also been marinated very tastily.  And the meat sauce -- while I couldn't vouch for what kind of meat really is in that meat sauce -- is  incredible.  You could probably order that on the side since your rice will come doused in this orange sauce.  Nevertheless, I didn't complain because it was delicious!

Too bad our hotel room didn't have a fridge, so I couldn't swing the three-meal plan.  ;o)  If you're in the Nob Hill area and looking for a cheap eat in a no-frills place, definitely swing by Cordon Bleu.  And it's cash only, so come prepared!
author: Chiara P.

description:
Delicious, large portions of satisfyingly comforting food at a very low price. BYOB, too. Imperial rolls are outstanding. 

An extremely small place with few tables so not good for large groups. It's cheap eats so don't expect gourmet meats cooked to perfection; for what you pay, it's simply a terrific experience
author: Ross I.

description:
Walked by Cordon and saw it was packed. Which really isn't difficult as it is as tiny as a SF studio. Came back later in the evening to try it out. One small table available so we grabbed it. It's mostly counter seating as there are only 3 tables. I ordered a #4 and my bf ordered a #5. Both had chicken and rice with meat sauce but his also included Imperial Roll and a small teriyaki steak.
We both weren't impressed with the meat sauce. Tasted like bumped up Ragu. The steak was dry but the imperial roll was good. Now for the chicken. That was the real winner. Moist, delicious, and a large portion. Also very inexpensive.  The service was quick and efficient. 
High point: the chicken. Worth a visit
Low point: That weird meat sauce on rice
Chances we would go back? Yes, but just for the chicken and the price.
author: Mike Z.

description: Absolutely fantastic.... The owner Katie is so nice and the food is out of this world.... Inexpensive too.... A must try if you visit SF (or if you happen to live here) .... Joe from Ireland
author: Joe O.

description:
The word I'd use to describe this place is "interesting." Their food is cheap, delicious and absolutely filling, but it's not like any other Vietnamese food that I've ever had. The mister and I shared an order of rice with meat sauce and two egg rolls. The total came out to 8 dollars for the both of us, and we were absolutely stuffed. The meat sauce was a bit tomato-y and went really well with the rice. The egg rolls were huge! Great size for two people to share for lunch.

But beware, this meal is extremely heavy, the rice and the meat sauce is filling, if it's your first time, I definitely wouldn't recommend eating too much, you will feel absolutely sick by the end of the meal.
author: Mindy T.

description:
I love this place. I recently moved back to the Nob Hill area, and was craving Vietnamese food for dinner. Luckily, Yelp saved the day, and my friend and I ventured out to Cordon Bleu.

The food here is such a great deal. For $9, you get a giant imperial roll, five spice chicken, shish kabab bbq, & meat sauce over a huge serving of rice.  I had left overs, of course. The five spice chicken was my favorite.

Employees are sweet and friendly. 

Note: They only accept cash.
author: Grace C.

description:
Am I eating at the same restaurant as everyone else ? O_o I did not think this place was that great.

The chicken was Burnt and almost on the dry side. Egg roll was super oily and nothing special. The only thing that saved the dish was the meat sauce over the rice. 

Restaurant Is a hole in the wall with a lot of royal customers and nice ladies that work the kitchen. Huge portions. Long wait that I just didn't think was worth it
author: Elaine L.

description:
TIP #1: This restaurant is the quintessential hole-in-a-wall. There are maybe eight seats at the counter facing the grill, and two 3-seat tables in the back. 

TIP #2: The dishes here aren't like anything else you've ever had at a Vietnamese restaurant...

If you're looking for Asian comfort food served diner-style, look no further. Come with zero expectations and you won't be disappointed; come hungry and you will leave extremely satisfied!

"Cordon Bleu" refers to cooking of the highest class--not quite a misnomer, because the food is hearty and delicious. Most plates are assembled with the following building blocks: one or two types of meat, country salad (read: shredded cabbage), and meat sauce over white rice, plus or minus a pork-filled imperial roll. The resulting mountain of food is enough to feed a very hungry person (or two!). 

Because the space is so tiny, I could see my chicken as it was being grilled, the meat sauce bubbling in large metal pots. The two middle-aged women who were running the place were friendly and attentive. It was nearly intimate--and in some situations, it just might be. 

I'm not sure how I finished my heaping mound of food, but I look forward to tackling another plate soon!
author: A.L. H.

description:
Very surprised that my friend didn't me about this place until now since she lives so close to it and I visit her 24/7.

I opened my to-go container and asked, this is Vietnamese food?!  Grilled pork chops, five spice chicken, rice with meat sauce, and coleslaw.  My mom never made me this kind of food!  Only Vietnamese thing I actually saw was the Imperial Roll.  But ok, whatever...I was hungry and it smelled/looked delicious.  Pork chop was on par, I dislike coleslaw, and the chicken was a bit dry so it was nice that the rice was covered in meat sauce to balance the chicken out.  Imperial Roll was yummy though.  I love when spring roll wrappers are deep fried because it gives it this crunchy, yet chewy and slightly salty taste.  They should wrap it in something other than wax paper though since it can stick and take off some of that delicious wrapper.  I'd go again but it's not the best Viet food.  Nice that it's cheap and gives huge portions though.
author: Jane N.

description: This place is........AMAZING! It is not a 5 thousand diamond place, more like a 20 thousand dimoned. Everything is authentic home made food, it is like going to grandmas. I got the pork chops, superbly cooked, and very, very, and i mean..very good tasting. I recommend getting the imperial roll, it is basically a fried spring roll modified into the meat world! So go and make a friendly stop and you won't regret it.
author: Jarett S.

description:
I order out from here often, they have good food and large quantities for a relatively low price.
Actually, the dishes are typically large enough for two people to split if you also plan to get an appetizer, that's the way we typically order from here.

The restaurant itself is small (seats 20), i've eaten in a couple times, but you will either need to sit at the counter or may need to wait a while for a table.  There is only a staff of two or three, and that includes the cooks behind the counter, so don't expect spectacular service or much attention beyond someone taking your order and brining your food.

My only criticism is that the dishes come with a ton of rice (probably why they seem to large) and they have a very limited menu (4 or 5 entrees) so you might get sick of this place if you come to often.
author: Ayall S.

description: Excellent hole in the wall place with big portions, unique meat sauce and overall pleasant experience with Katie the owner. This is a no frills 12 seat restaurant with good prices. Always cooked to order. The imperial rolls are cut with scissors if that gives you any indication.
author: Aaron C.

description: Dive home cooked Vietnamese!  Simply the best and absolutely the best homemade imperial rolls I've ever had and I've traveled extensively in Asia.  Everything is good here and there is a huge loyal following, especially for the take out orders.   BYOB.
author: Matt B.

description:
I went to Cordon Bleu expecting a meal cheap and delicious. I wasn't concerned about calories, grease, MSG, borderline health inspection score -- none of that -- and still, they disappoint.

I got the grilled chicken with meat sauce over rice and "salad" (a few forkfuls of chopped cabbage). The chicken tasted good, well cooked and coated in a sweet glaze, but the breast itself was small. I guess the idea is that you get just enough meat from the chicken to justify gorging on a heaping portion of sauce-slathered rice.

The problem is that that rice is no guilty pleasure. It's soggy, overcooked white rice topped with a thin sauce. The so-called meat sauce, orange in color and water-like in consistency, tastes primarily of onion and pepper. I ate a few bites, left my money on the counter, and departed.

Some friends had told me that Cordon Bleu was a gem. Some friends...
author: Jackson G.

description:
Super bomb. Super cheap. Super filling.

For only $9, you get a fat plate of 1/2 chicken, pork slices, eggroll, meat sauce over a mound of rice. With that, you also get free tea! It basically took me two meals to finish the huge portion. I was stuffed each time and loved how each bite was so flavorful and rich.

I definitely recommend this place. Just be sure to wear clothes you don't really care about because once you walk out, you will be quick smelly.
author: Joyce M.

description:
Two words:  Meat Sauce!!!!

Make no mistake, this place is a total dive.  It's small, terrible for groups because the largest table can only seat 4, the counter is occasionally sticky, and you see all of the guts of the "kitchen" as the counter wraps around it, and it's old and crusty...both the counter and the "kitchen."

BUT, the food is fantastic!  Huge portions, gruff but friendly service, yummy chicken, super crispy imperial rolls, perfectly sticky rice, one of the best chicken salads around, and the crowning glory...the delicious orange meat sauce.  I want it on everything!  I have no idea why it's orange-ish, but I don't care.  It's SO GOOD!  And did I mention almost everything on the menu is under $10?  

You can order to pick up, and I do, even driving all the way across town to pick up dinner.  Totally worth it.  Don't even try going with a group of friends, you've been warned, they can seat a grand total of maybe 12 people in the entire place.  I suggest going alone or as a twosome only.  And ignore the decor, or lack thereof, but do go for the food.  It's not fancy, but so satisfying and homey.  I want some again just writing this.  Mmmmm.....
author: Jennifer F.

description: Eat here all the time. You should too. Get a Number 5 or Noodle Salad. Come at lunch to dodge the dinner time madhouse.
author: Joseph M.

description:
What? I haven't reviewed Cordon Bleu yet? How could that be? 

This is one of my favorite Vietnamese restaurants in SF. I will gladly hike up to California Street for their molten imperial rolls any day. We usually end up here after an evening of drinking & the food always hits the spot. I love that it's BYOB so we are able to keep the buzz going while filling our tummies with delicious 5 spice chicken vermicelli bowls. 

The place is teeny tiny & you are practically sitting right next to the stove, grill, & deep fryer. The humongous pot of bubbling meat sauce kind of scares me cuz I can imagine it knocking over & scalding half the customers. But it is interesting watching those ladies cook up food in a flash. They know their stuff. 

I go home smelling like Vietnamese food which is OK by me.
author: Erin S.

description: I had read so many reviews about this place. The staff was very friendly and the portions are huge!! All the reviews were about how amazing the chicken was. while it was tasty it was over hyped. In the end I am glad I came here. I wanted to try something different and I did!
author: Alex L.

description: I walked by and saw a crowd, and it smelled so good that I went in and had a seat at the counter.  The choices are simple: the best are some variation of pork, chicken and imperial roll. It is all super delish.  And you won't go home hungry. The portions are generous.
author: Jeff B.

description:
Tiny hole in the wall legit grilling/frying in front of you fby a chinese/vietnamese mommies.

came here with one of my classmates and got #4 (5-spice chicken, rice, meatsauce, and salad) and Pork Chop Special

Pros:
- Home cooked feel
- Good fresh/crunchy salads
- flavoful meat sauce went well with the rice
- reasonable prices
- large portions

Cons:
- Dry burnt bland pork chop
- Dry and bland five spice chicken

basically everything was not bad except the actual heart of the dish.  it's a cute place, but its only a-ok
author: Tina A.

description: 5 for value and hole in the wall experience. Order the #5 to get the best variety. Something about the portions and the meat sauce on the rice, total comfort food. Katy, the owner, puts love into this established SF staple.
author: Thomas B.

description:
We came back to Cordon Bleu, this time in the evening, and boy was it busy! There were people literally crammed inside, either eating or waiting for their takeout orders. I would definitely call ahead and place an order in advance next time so you don't have to wait as long. Got another #5 which was more than enough to satisfy both my bf and myself for dinner, and an order of the mapo tofu, which lasted me 4 meals (I'm eating the fourth as we speak).

The mapo tofu isn't the numb-spicy kind you normally get at Szechuan restaurants! I wanted to point that out for other reviewers because what I got was unexpected, though delicious by all means.

CASH ONLY!
author: Chrystal Z.

description: My fav place to go for really tasty chinese food. They are closed or on vacation like half the time though :(
author: Stephen W.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. It is so simple so amazing. The food is to serve so so so so good. Don't miss this.  And it's easy on the wallet. This is the JAMMMMMM!!! 

Love me some 5 Spice Roast Chicken. And the Shish Kebab and Imperial Roll is slamming!!!!
author: David M.

description:
First impression: Did I get transported to Asia?  You're elbow to elbow with other customers if you take on the diner seating.  If you're lucky to get one of the two tables, you will be practically sitting in another diner's lap.  Which may or may not be a good thing.  A similar situation can be found in the bathroom.  The sink is almost hanging above the toilet bowl and you're nudging the walls with your elbows.

This is a divey joint.  I came out smelling like I bathed in five spice chicken.  Expect to shower immediately upon getting home.  This is not to say that it's not clean.  When we were seated at the table, they wiped it twice, vigorously, with a wet towel then dried it with a paper napkin.  Service was fast and friendly.  

Strangely enough, the table next to us thought it would make a good date place.  Probably because they were Polk Street hobos.  Just kidding.  The couple was super lovey dovey in a we-haven't-done-the-horizontal-hokey-pokey kind of way.  I hope the guy didn't think he was going to seal the deal with this place.  Who knows, maybe five spice chicken turns her on.

I wasn't impressed with the food.  The chicken was good.  The meat sauce is reminiscent of the sauce you get with HK style baked pork chops over rice.  Basically, tomatoey sauce (to solve the mystery of the "mystery meat sauce", this would be tomato paste, chicken broth, onion, garlic, salt, sugar).  The staff are Cantonese (probably from/lived in Vietnam, which isn't uncommon).  The best thing on the menu is the imperial roll.  

I wouldn't go back and eat at the restaurant; it just wasn't comfortable, even for the price.  Takeout would be fine.
author: Erika C.

description: Heard and read a lot of reviews about this hole-in-the wall and it lived up to the hype. This small, family run restaurant served up traditional Vietnamese food with a spin.   It look like the mother and daughter had worked there for over 10 years and new their stuff. There's only room for eight people in front of the chef and another 5 scattered around the restaurant. Cash only. Service with a smile.
author: Vik M.

description:
I'm really conflicted about Cordon Blue Vietnamese Restaurant. While the sheer volume of food you get for the price is impressive and the food is solid, it's not authentic Vietnamese food, nor even homestyle Vietnamese food. 

I ordered the #5: 1/2 roasted 5-spice chicken, kebab, imperial roll, salad, and meat sauce over white rice.  All of this was piled high into one plate!

The 1/2 roasted chicken was tender and flavorful, but I could barely taste the 5-spice marinade, unlike other Vietnamese 5-spice chicken I've had. 

The "kebab" was not a kebab. Rather than chunks of meat on a skewer, you get 3-4 flat pieces of Vietnamese grilled pork. Again, the pork was tender and flavorful, but again, no discernible Vietnamese seasoning/flavor. 

The best thing about the imperial roll was the size. It was HUGE. Otherwise, I've definitely had better fried spring rolls elsewhere. 

The salad was pickled shredded cabbage. It was sweet, crunchy, and refreshing, a nice compliment to the grilled meats and rice. 

And lastly, the meat sauce over rice. LIke the imperial roll, the best thing about the meat sauce was that there was ALOT of it. It was a thick, orangey Tomato sauce, very reminiscent of Chef Boyardee pasta sauce or a sweet Bolognese sauce. I've never had this kind of sauce in a Vietnamese restaurant, and it didn't make sense to pair it with the grilled chicken, pork, and imperial roll. 

The interior of the restaurant is the definition of a "hole in the wall."  In the back, there is 1 2-top and 1 4-top. In the front, there are 7-8 counter seats. The grilling takes place about 2-3 feet away from the counter. Be prepared to come out smelling like food.

The ladies working the front counter were very nice and the portions are SUPERSIZED. If you're in the area, it's worth a stop for solid, hearty food. Butt if you're looking for authentic Vietnamese food, you won't find it here.
author: Monelle A.

description:
Judge not by the size nor decor for the food is excellent and cheap!

I followed yelp and I'm glad I did, Cordon Bleu is a tiny hole-in-the-wall of Vietnamese goodness. If you've been to Vietnam, imagine taking one of those awesome food carts on the street and transplanting it into a little restaurant. It's a little smokey, it's a little greasy but it's very cost effective and the flavors are great!

Everything is made to order and the portions are gigantic. When we arrived, we were two of three people in the small place, when we left 30 minutes later, it was packed with a line-up out the door. I ordered the #5 and my wife had the Noodle Salad, both were made in front of us, both were massive (I only ate 2/3 of mine) and they tasted amazing.

On the downside, you have to be prepared to wait if it's busy and do not go with a large group, you will get frustrated as the place is too small. Cordon Bleu is a little rundown and since the grill is the major feature, it's always smokey and greasy in there but so what, the food is the important thing and it was great!

I cannot recommend this place enough for a fast, tasty & cheap meal in the city.
author: G C.

description:
Was craving some good vietnamese food one sunday and saw this place pop up nearby. 

This place is only a 10 min walk from my place so I decided to give it a try.

I went with the most popular order and got the #5 and the spicy pork chop entree. Looks like this place has a small diner feel to it as there's only diner seating and only about 10 seats or so.

I didn't get to eat here as I was just ordering to go. Took about 20 min to get my order and the owner was very friendly and nice. The total for my order was only $21? STEAL!

Got back home and dug in with my BF. 

The imperial roll is sooo good. The #5 only comes with 1 but its enough to share with another person. Everything was delish! You taste the nice BBQ on all the meats - the pork chop, the 5 spice chicken piece, and the kebab slices. If there is not enough flavor for you just pour some of that fish sauce that comes with all the dishes. SOO Good! Also the meat sauce on the rice is a little sweet like spaghetti sauce and reminds me a lot of the sauce they use for HK style baked pork chop. So if you like that, then you'll love this sauce.

The portions are huge so do expect leftovers or go here if you are super hungry. Definitely a great spot for cheap and delicious food. Yum!
author: Christine W.

description: You can't go wrong here. Everything is so delicious.
author: Jason P.

description: Unfortunately I got sick last night after eating a number 4 combo. I suspect it was the meat sauce. The flavors were good, but clearly food safety has the potential to be off here. Sorry.
author: TravelingGirl ..

description:
Cordon bleu.  French Vietnamese?  Whose owners are not Vietnamese?  Who cares?!!!  The food is yummy and inexpensive...SCORE!

Mapo tofu, bbq chicken and fried rolls (tried to be healthy...but, hey, you only live once)

My tummy is growling already.

Suggestion:  take out (totally a hole in the wall type of place, which gets a bit stuffy for claustrophobes)
author: Hiromi N.

description: So good! Yes they get a bit overwhelmed cause it's the same 3 ladies taking orders cooking and cleaning all behind one bar. But that just makes it more like home, who's got a whole team in their kitchen? And again everything turns out SO GOOD! The number five it's a great selection cause it gives you variety, I wanted grilled meat when I first came here, and oh Lord did they deliver. But the oyster sauce with garlic tofu and mushrooms was just as good and with a generous portion of rice, I never under stand how places are skimpy with rice.
author: Jaime O.

description: I was really surprised by how much food came with our order. The chicken was beyond amazing and the service was very prompt. This place can become very busy so space can be an issue. But we were able to get a place when we came before 5:00 during the work week.
author: Casey D.

description: Good quality meat, excellent preparation, fish sauce is on point. Had the chicken salad and vegetable egg rolls, grew up with this stuff and couldn't be happier. Hard to find this in the city nowadays, anything under 5 stars for this gem of a restaurant would be ridiculous. No pretension, no disgusting meat quality, fresh ingredients.
author: Jacob J.

description:
So I got a half chicken with meat sauce over rice, cabbage, and an imperial roll. 

People were raving about how good everything was and it's so amazing. So I couldn't wait to try it.

As I wait for my food at the corner seat at the bar, I'm watching the lady cook, take orders, touch money, touch food, pick up a dirty rag to clean the grill using the same tongs she uses to flip the chicken... 
Ok, ok so the place is filthy and unsanitary but maybe the food makes up for that.

Umm.. No.. The food wasn't all that. Everything tasted kind of bland. It wasn't awful, but it wasnt delicious like everyone was saying. 

Not impressed by the food and the cleanliness.. 

Just sit at the corner seat of the bar and watch the kitchen area. I mean greasy boxes of pre cooked food near the floor? Thanks but no thanks...
author: April S.

description: Decent comfort food that is cheap and VERY plentiful. It's this hole-in-the-wall, tucked away on California St, between Larkin and Polk. The #5 is pretty much two meals: mound of sticky rice with a pork/beef tomato-based sauce, half a grilled chicken, a large imperial roll and kebab, plus a token portion of greens (slaw). But please, for those expecting the sky, go somewhere else, and take your pretentiousness with you.
author: Frank L.

description: Great food. I wouldn't say it's an authentic Vietnamese restaurant but the food is pretty good. I like how they kept it simple with a few menu items. Their thin pieces of pork that they called 'kebobs' were pretty good. I based most of my reviews on quality, quantity, and price. This is definitely a cheap place to eat so don't expect the world. Will go back again !
author: Jennie C.

description:
The #5 plate with the barbeque chicken, shish kebab (slice of bbq'd pork), country salad (coleslaw style), imperial roll (chockful of pork and a little veg) and heaping mound of rice with meat sauce is soul satisfying!

Defintely, a low-profile hole-in-the-wall, 8 seat restaurant that people in the 'hood have known and loved for many years. CB is not a place to impress a date 'cos the decor is old time brick! Also, if you'd rather not walk away with a smoky aroma from the grill, the ladies behind the counter will happily bag up your food to go.

I've eaten at the counter and enjoyed watching the ladies juggle all the orders as well as gleefully taken my food to go.

Neighborhood tip: After eating at Cordon Bleu, you can roll yourself out to watch an indie movie at the Landmark Lumiere theatre next door! Make it a night!
author: Joanna T.

description:
Keyword: five spice chicken. That's pretty much the main thing they offer here. The kebab is just a variation of the same grilled style meat (but thin sliced). Rice is topped with a very Asian definition of meat sauce. It's sweeter. I didn't mind it but my husband didn't like it. Small place so don't come with more than 2-3 people. Cash only. Food portion is very generous, for under ten bucks you get two giant chicken pieces, a mound of meat sauce rice, a little shredded lettuce, and some kebab slices. 

The chicken is grilled behind the counter and you can see it being made. It has all the nice properties of grilled meats: maximum fragrance, slightly crispy skin, and the marinade while tasty is not overpowering, just slightly savory. Overall a very good and worthy visit if you are up for some good meat.
author: Elizabeth T.

description: Had the number 5, delicious spread with a little bit of everything. Imperial roll was delicious, and everything was covered in a nice tomato based sauce. Nice cozy vibe to the place, tastes very homemade and fun to watch the cooking in action (place is mostly bar counter). The host and cook (owner?) is a warm and friendly lady. Not to mention a fine gentlemen came in to pick up dinner and covered our meal as well, so it tasted even better. Next time in town will definitely return, and hopefully that gentleman will be there too.
author: Ben O.

description:
SOMEONE'S GONNA NEED TO GO ON A DIET AFTER THIS MEAL!

This hole-in-the-wall restaurant serves up some damn good BBQ rice plates AND it's cheap too.  You also get A LOT of food, and I emphasize on the "ALOT" part.

[http://s3-media4.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/lfpxL9X3ePs834Z2drXC6w/l.jpg]
HUGE BBQ chicken thigh, imperial rolls,  [Americanized] tomatoey-meat-sauce, and salad -- all over rice. Literally, you get ALL of that and it weighs in at about 5 pounds of food for under $10. 

The only con is that it's practically a hallway with diner stools and a small table in the back and it DOES get packed during lunchtime. 

However, they redeem themselves for carrying the epic rooster hot sauce, Sriracha!
author: Albert L.

description: Got the number 5.  So much food for so little money!  Definitely a 5 star value.  Friendly staff, huge portions, and cheap prices will keep me coming back.
author: Paul W.

description:
My friends of 12+ years treated me to lunch here for my farewell/see you again lunch. 

I don't think I would have ever noticed this place since it is such a hole in the wall but it gave off the feel of a similar place that some of my friends abide by, "Vietnam" in Chinatown. Yelp it! They serve your typical Vietnamese cuisine, pho/vermicelli/sandwiches. 

When my friend and I walked in the entire bar was packed with people on their lunch break. The back table for four was free so we were pretty happy to snag it. 

They don't serve pho here but they serve ridiculously hearty amount of food for a cheap price! We all ordered the cheap lunch special for $5.75(that includes tax)

Summer Salad, Rice with sweet meat sauce, and your choice of chicken, kebab, or imperial roll - I ordered the kebab. it came with 4 big sized beef kebabs! So worth it! You get like more than 1 bowl of rice with sauce drenched over. None of us were able to finish. 

The service was a bit slow since there is only two nice Viet ladies working there. The place has no decorations nor style but the price/quantity/quality definitely won me over. I wouldn't mind coming here again!
author: Sarah C.

description:
Been here a handful of times.  Oh the bay, known for their amazing cuisines!
This place is tiny and limited seating. . .most of the time there is a wait.
But well worth it!
I'm used to the restaurants in little saigon in OC. . .i never thought vietnamese restaurants had amazing chicken. . .
this place is great! and very filling!
The servers n cooks are very friendly.
author: Remie M.

description: I love this place, it is like going to mom's house. If my mom cooked, or was well versed in Vietnamese cuisine.
author: MJ D.

description: Not only is this place right down the street from me, but the food is amazing. This place is perfect for takeout, or eating in. I love being able to sit at the bar with friends watching food being made and exchanging comments with the person sitting next to me about how amazing the food is. I have gotten the noodle salad every single time. It is so good, and lasts for two meals! The noodle salad is served with shish kebabs and a sweet fish sauce. I have also tasted other dishes with the house made gravy. Everything here is good. Considering how much food is served, the prices are amazing. Most meals are served with an imperial roll, but do yourself a favor and get an extra! They are the best part about this restaurant! Even after I move from this neighborhood, I will be coming back for noodle salad and imperial rolls.
author: Kelsey S.

description: I just love them all. Foods and people's smile. Very small place so you may not to be seated for while. but when you sit on the bar, you'll see how they make your big plate that make you smile!!
author: Ishikawa M.

description:
Good price, Great portion, So-so taste.
I was so excited when I saw the size of plate. I ordered #5. 
Crispy looking giant egg roll, a half grilled chicken, sliced pork marinated in soy-sauce, rice and cabbage with strange magical orange sauce from cauldron. 
But the sauce was taste like cheap tomato_based gravy sauce, chicken was not fully cooked so I can see the red inside. The giant egg roll was crispy, chewy which I most liked, but inside I could find normal minced pork.
Heavy eaters might like it, but picky eaters...just don't go there.
If you still want to go there, I recommend to ask them make the sauce separate. It'll be nicer than topped up the weird sauce.
author: Sukwon P.

description: I've died and gone to Shish-kabob heaven. After 10 yrs of living right by this place I finally checked it out- so good.  You kinda feel like you're in an episode of Seinfeld the first 10min you get there (ie. no soup for you) which adds to the charm and uniqueness of the experience.  The meat, rice and sauce they put on it are simple perfection - oh and the portions are insane.  I'll definitely be back.
author: Gohar J.

description:
This is a great little Vietnamese diner. How authentic is the food? I don't pretend to know, but if it is good, why speculate?  It certainly isn't what you typically get at Vietnamese places.  The meat sauce on rice was more tomato-based than I would have guessed, or preferred.  The imperial roll was a massive egg roll made complete with fish sauce to pour on.  The kebabs were also fantastically crispy. I'm sorry to say I did not get the chicken this time as the volume of food seemed pretty daunting. 

The interior is limited in seating to about a dozen seats around the counter and maybe 3 small tables in back.  This is not meant for groups over 4 people.  There is an informal line system for waiting, but the smell and sight of the food makes maintaining basic social etiquette tenuous at best.  Maybe just order to go and enjoy it back at your place.
author: Daniel A.

description:
Could someone make these ladies into saints? They are wonderful people and even nicer folks chowing down here. I went in for lunch and took a seat on a rickety bar stool picked up one of the menus and two people asked if this was my first time. I said yes and they both suggested the combination with the chicken and egg roll. I checked my pockets and found I was short a buck plus tip. So, I started to order just the chicken, well my fellow diners would not have this, they put down the extra and the ladies said not to worry about a tip. They said I would be back and make good. So, sweet!

The food was stick to your ribs and huge portions. I was very happy with the meal. The imperial roll has the most amazing chewiness under the crisp exterior, and highlights of black pepper in the meaty filling. The meat sauce is a surprise over rice and highly addictive. The chicken is grilled on this ancient two burner open grill, the marked skin is crispy and the umami comes through.

Don't expect a fine dining experience just good peeps and good food.
author: Lhm M.

description:
do you like chicken? how about sriracha sauce?
well then, you need to eat here!

well done SF! only place that has enough balls to deep fry spring rolls (they call them imperial rolls here), and they're amazing. love cordon bleu, I make sure to eat here every time i'm in town! great food and staff. AWESOME! (insert heart emoji here)
author: Sammy C.

description:
So what is Katie's secret? How do simple recipes, like meat sauce on rice or grilled chicken, pluck the strings of my heart and make me weep with joy? I'll tell you. Every morning, before driving from Fremont to work 13 hours every single day, Katie slices microscopic monolayers of marinated love and scientifically distributes them to her customers. She truly is a scientific wizard of love, food and scissors. She cuts those imperial roles right into my heart, with scissors.

Cordon Bleu, I love you!
author: Ian T.

description: If this place ever closes it will be a sad day for Nob Hill. Katie feeds Nob Hill denizens at unheard of prices. Barbecue marinated chicken on a bed of rice with a country sauce that could very well be on a plate of spaghetti. Two people can eat royally for under $20. Cash only.
author: Michael S.

description: This place is kinda small, just a counter and a few tables but it doesn't feel cramped, just cozy. The food is great! The imperial roll is tasty and definitely a must try but it's their signature five spice chicken that makes this place awesome and keeps you coming back. Also the service is good, there's always a friendly smile and a positive vibe for the customers.
author: John L.

description: This hole in the wall is one of my favorite spots in the entire San Francisco. It is like coming home after a long day, and getting home-cooked dinner from mom. Katie, who has been cooking delicious five-spiced chickens for over a decade, makes the whole experience. Recommendations: #5, noodle salad, mapo tofu.
author: Nayoung K.

description:
This place is as divey as it gets.  Everything is run down and dirty.  There's a nasty, greasy dust which covers the surfaces which are not often used.  The level of cleanliness here is very low overall.  The service isn't very good.  The family which runs the place will not be attentive to you and will often not have your order ready on time if you call it in.  The food LOOKS bad.  It's a pile of slop looking curry, with blackened chicken or pork, an unappealing looking deep fried emperor roll, a sad looking bit of cabbage salad.

That being said -- this is a true gem in Nob hill.  The food here really is fantastic.  It's got plenty of shortcomings, but that doesn't stop it from tasting great.  Authenticity -- I'm not really sure.  I feel like maybe it's truly authentic in that it's closer to what real vietnamese people would eat, but I've never visited so it's hard to say.  The menu is fairly limited, it's all variations on the same few items.  Everything I had was fantastic, though.  

This is the kind of place Anthony Bourdain would love.  It's gritty, and has this wonderful character about it.  It's run very poorly, but that doesn't stop it from being very successful and popular, because at the end of the day -- the food is great and has it's own unique style.

It's definitely not for everyone, if you managed to read this review past the first paragraph, maybe it's your type of place.  Don't expect to feel warm and welcome in this place, and definitely don't bring someone here on a first date.  It's comfort food that is somehow refreshing here in SF.
author: Yan L.

description:
A MUST READ TO ALL WHO INTEND TO DINE (and all who love it so much):

If I could sum up this place in one word: UNauthentic.

Seriously.

I've always questioned people who raved about Vietnamese restaurants in San Francisco.  Every Vietnamese/Vietnamese-American person I know who lives/has lived in SF has said that Vietnamese food is no good in the city.

I was in the area, and was looking for a quick bite on the cheap.  Saw reviews for this place and I was curious, for a variety of reasons:

1. the place was named, "Cordon Bleu" and considered a Vietnamese restaurant
2. people were raving about a "meat sauce"
3. I was hungry

I thought to myself, "meat sauce, I don't remember any Vietnamese dish having a 'meat sauce'."  Have I perhaps never come across such a dish with the 24 years of Vietnamese cuisine I've had from 2 grandmothers, 5 aunts, and my own mama??  So dine in I did, somewhat excited to try a place that so many people deemed, "a great hole in the wall," had "meat sauce," and was "Vietnamese food."  

The very first thing I saw was their menu.  Strange name I thought.  Why would a Vietnamese place have such an American name?  Maybe it's a fobby way to attract Americans.  Then, right in front of me, I saw that giant pot of meat sauce everyone was talking about (and that you'll probably see in pictures).  I asked in Vietnamese, "do la mon an gi?" (What dish is that?)

The reply I received: "don't speak Vietnamese."


I ordered a #5, which included: a 5-spice chicken, "kabobs," and an imperial roll.
Of all the Vietnamese food I've eaten either at home or in San Jose or Orange County, I have never heard of a 5-spice chicken.  I thought maybe they were talking about key ingredients/spices used in Vietnamese cuisine like garlic, thai basil, mint, lemon grass, fish sauce...(just to name a few), no, no.  I realize that THIS is what they're referencing to, 

http://www.foodandwine.com/recipes/five-spice-chicken-banh-mi-sandwiches
"Lemongrass is the classic seasoning for Vietnamese-style grilled pork or chicken, but chef Charles Phan likes to use fragrant Chinese five-spice powder instead."

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
So basically, Chinese operated (I heard them speak some dialect of Chinese) with Vietnamese-flavor influences.  

Overall, BLAND FLAVORS.  Chicken was alright, cuz you can't go wrong with BBQ chicken as long as you don't overcook it.  Imperial roll is actually the closest thing to authentic there (deep fried eggroll with rice paper instead of eggroll wrap, a Vietnamese variation on Chinese eggroll).  And oh, that staple "meat sauce;" it's an imitation of a kind of dipping sauce used for spring rolls (which usually is orangey in color and uses ground pork throughout the sauce, ground shrimp if ya wanna get real fancy). Kabobs definitely didn't look like kabobs or have a meaty texture.  



---Mystery meat sauce and mystery meat (except for the chicken).

This place DOES NOT serve Vietnamese food, 
not even Vietnamese-ish.  

More like, Vietnamese ... REFERENCED food.  I'm actually slightly offended that this is being recognized as Vietnamese food... false-advertising.  I am however, NOT OFFENDED by the food.  It's edible.  And if the chicken and the imperial roll were $1 each, maybe occasional visits from me would be possible.  I only think that they should not call it Vietnamese food.  It passes more as Vietnamese imitation grub, that's more accurate.

Still weary of trying Vietnamese food in the city.  Some restaurant from the OC should just move to SF to show the city how it's done.
author: August H.

description: This is a true neighborhood diner of the highest quality the staff are friendly and attentive. The food is delicious and delivered in ample servings. A must visit in Sam Francisco. if you really can't find it, just ask any California street cable car driver!
author: mark l.

description:
Probably 2.5 stars if we could give out demi-starlets. Paid about $8 for a pile of rice with orange meat sauce over it (too moist), and shish kabob pork slices draped over it. Weird that for all the BBQ char that it nicely had on it, flavor was lacking. Underspiced and underseasoned, it was like warmed up jerky. The country salad was a cole slaw of some sort and it was kind of nice to have a sour kick after the meat sauce oozes everything into tasting th same. The imperial roll was mighty tasty though, and almost had that same fatty thick mouthfeel like the ones from Tu Lan. 

The regulars seemed to request a separate plate for the roll, probably a good idea so it doesn't get soggy from the meat sauce.

Seating is a little strange since it's all counter and then three little tables in the back. I plopped down at one and had a woman just invite herself over to be my lunch buddy. Poppin' em personal space bubbles.
author: Kevin L.

description:
We yelped dinner in this area, and this popped up as #1, so we had to try it.
We walked into a very small narrow restaurant.  There were probably 10 or so seats along the bar (they're cooking right behind the bar).  Then there were 2 tables in the back.  We were able to find seats along the bar right away.  I would recommend this place for smaller groups, as it could be a logistical nightmare trying to get your group to sit together if the back tables are occupied.
The chicken, which is their signature dish, was delicious.  The sauce they top the rice with was amazing.  Generous portions at a reasonable price.  I think the chicken dish was $8.
You can also call in your order, which I definitely plan to do on lazy weeknights.
author: Gloria N.

description:
Came here last night with my best friend who introduced me to it and it was perfect. Got to talk to the Cantonese speaking owner and she is wonderful. They've been open for about 40 years! She says it is always busy and it is great but can't seem to do enough.

The chicken is so tender, the pork is perfect not dry at all, and the imperial roll is incredibly flavorful. I would say the best seat in the house is right next to the grill but plan for your clothes to smell like smoke.  

So if you plan to come here, plan to wait and chillax a bit, and when the food comes, it is so worth it!
author: Cindy C.

description: First time I tried to go here, the woman rudely told me they were closed. It was 8:30. Second time I tried to go here, they were simply closed at 7:30pm with the doors locked. I don't care how famous your imperial rolls and chicken are - you have horrible service and I haven't even gotten a chance to eat your food.
author: Samuel S.

description:
Wife and Matt were deciding, "Where to eat for dinner along the busy intersection of Polk and California?" And we decided to check this place out for dinner. 

With a recent review and another inspiring choice from a couple of Yelpers, in Matt's mind saying, "Matt, you must eat @ Cordon Blue!"

Accepting the advice, we ate here for dinner, and surprisingly a couple has just finished their meal and left the counter, in which we had no choice to take from this extremely small restaurant. 

Although it's not a large menu, Matt had the Combo Special #4. The $7.30 hefty meal had a piece of Five-Spice Vietnamese Style leg and Thigh, 2 thinly-sliced steak kebab, 1 crispy egg-roll, and a big scoop of rice blanketed with their specialty meat-sauce. The Chicken was very tasty, although he wanted to eat the leg/thigh piece like a barbarian, but couldn't with the busy patrons dining and glancing at the hottest couple of this tiny restaurant. That is "Us"!

She had the Cold-salad w/ sliced chicken pieces. The $6.25 cold noodle-bowl had sliced chicken meats, assorted slice vegetables, 1 crispy egg-roll and covered with Cold Vermicelli noodles. 

Our respected meals were very tasty and largely immense. And our soothing warm tea was very comforting. We also chatted with the Cantonese-speaking workers and owners there, including one, who was looking at Matt's uniform. "Damn, Matt wishes he was single!"

This tiny restaurant has won numerous coveted awards, including the Bay-Guardian voted the restaurant as "Best Hole-in-the-Wall" restaurant for 2003 & 2004. 

Considering the busy location, this eatery is not a "Hole in the wall" establishment by all means. 

A very good restaurant .
author: Matt G.

description: Five tasty stars! I have been coming here for years and love this hole-in-the-wall. Everyone is super friendly and I really feel like I get treated like family here. I think I tried everything on the menu. If you are really hungry, you should order the #5 combo plate which has a bit of everything. Rice, meat sauce (tomato base with little bits of meat), pickled cabbage salad, shish kebab (thinly sliced and grilled), chicken breast/or thigh, and imperial roll. Or you can order the pork chop rice plate. It comes with a freshly made salad (lettuce, cucumber, nuts, dressing), rice with pan fried scallions topped with grilled pork chops. It's amazing! And if you are vegetarian, try the tofu with rice. It's a version of mapo tofu except 10x better with bits of mushrooms and oh so delicious. You can order this with meat also.
author: Missy X.

description:
This is a true hole in the wall that serves good, cheap food. At first, I was thrown off that there was no pho on the menu, and most items are pork. Unless stated (for the noodle salad), you cannot switch a pork item for chicken or vegetarian. Keep that in mind if you don't eat pork like me.

Anyway, the chicken is proclaimed 'best outside of Vietnam.' I've never been to Vietnam but it's freaking good chicken. The #4 special comes with half a roasted chicken with 5 spice--SO good and so filling. The spring rolls are good too; the imperial rolls have pork. 

The portions are very large and excellent for take-out meals. No comment necessary on the decor because that's not the priority. I can definitely see myself grabbing to-go orders here frequently....but mostly of that chicken.
author: Emilia S.

description:
I love this place. It's just a hole-in-the-wall, but ignore the decor. The food is delicious, consistent, and inexpensive. The #5 plate has a little bit of everything (like the "Best of the Menu") and is such a deal at around $10.

It's a family-run business - the mom & pop were behind the counter for years, now it's the next generation, and they're always there, churning out this great food.

I'm not near Russian Hill very often, but whenever I'm in the area, I make sure to stop & get a #5 to go.
author: judah m.

description: Yummy, Yum...YUM!!! Incredibly Delicious Everything! I am already trying to find an excuse to take a trip to SanFramcisco again just for a taste of something else on the menu! Awesome hole in the wall with a guarantee to feel satisfied your meal. A must try AND a must Re-Do!
author: Wendy E.

description:
Cute mom and pop place. it's very tiny and you can sit at the bar and watch them cook your food. I had the meat combo which had the chicken leg, pork slices and egg rolls. Everything was good and super cheap!! The rice dish is covered with a meat sauce that reminds me of bolognese. haha. 

I kept looking at the people next to me cause they had a noodle dish with egg rolls and pork. I wanna try that next time!

Huge portions for the price. Can't ask for anything more.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
Small place so you have to come at the right time to avoid the crowd. They serve all their rice plates with meat sauce so thats is awesome. I tried everything except their five spice chicken which is supposedly their featured dish. What I like most about their meal is the imperial roll. Its basically those fried Vietnamese spring roll supersized! 

You must be confuse if I'm raving about the food. Why am I only giving it 3 stars. Because as good as it was. It doesn't leave me a distinctive impression. I feel like I could find something similar somewhere else. I guess it lacks originality.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Number five is amazing. Omfg. The food is amazing. They grill the meat right in front of you and the portions are huge. 
The chicken is very flavorful. The pork is the right amount of sweet and salty. And the eggroll is a real eggroll. It is meaty, flavorful, crunch, and big. I recommend this place to all starving students who want to get their moneys worth and have left overs for another meal! I love this place
author: Reiko n.

description:
LOVED their combo plate! Huge portions, small space but we got to sit in the back side of the restaurant which is one of the only two tables in here. The rest seats are all counters. 
Tip: just because the name of the place is fancy doesnt mean the inside is...I suggest no fancy date here. :p But the food is AWESOME!
author: Rio S.

description:
after having a massage nearby, we were hungry and i didnt want to go anywhere that wasnt walking distance 

ordered
-#5: 5 spice roast chicken, imperial roll, shish kebab, country salad, meat sauce on rice.. everything was good

-spicy pork chops: this was ok

-ma po tofu: pretty good

so much for 2 that we had leftovers for the next day

notes:
-tiny place! 
-cheap and big portions
author: Raquel T.

description: I might have to give this place another shot. I thought it had charm- it's a small hole in the wall with friendly owners and about 8(?) bar stool seats at the counter by the grill. For $6.25, I got the #1 lunch special with the imperial roll, meat sauce on rice and salad. The imperial roll was pretty darn delicious. It's a fried roll with meat and veggies inside. The meat sauce is literally just... sauce... on rice. I was expecting a little more something. At first i thought the price was a steal! And then realized I wasn't getting much. But hey i got a lot of rice, i guess? I saw a bunch of others get grilled chicken on top of the salad... might have to get that next time. Otherwise the food was decent but not as incredible as I had hoped.
author: Stef S.

description:
Fine, call me a snob if you like.  Not a fan.

The pinkish mystery meat sauce over rice?  Kind of grossed me out.  And the famed five spice chicken...so blackened  that it was mostly carcinogenic.  Imperial rolls tasted like the kind I can get from Ranch 99 and fry up myself.

I'm all for cheap eats and I have nothing against hole-in-the-wall joints, but at very least, the food has to be good!
author: Joanne G.

description:
I came here after reading the Yelp reviews. I might rate this great if I ate here when I was a starving student eating 1 meal/day. The quantity of food is good for the price. The meat was OK, the fried spring roll was typical deep fried mystery food taste, but the "meat sauce" was really the worst part. Some people say the sauce is what helps the rice go down, but that would be like soy sauce on rice (which I do NOT like).
Other than being cheap, I don't understand the 5-star ratings, but I guess one has to try it to judge for themself.
author: MT Y.

description:
FOOD:
1.) Chicken rice plate - so much food. My friend who brought me here really really likes it. I'm not too sure about it, but I think the appeal is how much a comfort dish it is. Plus lotta meat.


SERVICE:
Good

ATMOSPHERE
Tiny place, mostly a small bar seating around the small open kitchen
author: Angela L.

description:
This is a great, small hole-in-the-wall place to get food in Nob Hill. The portions are asian mom big and the prices can make any fast-food joint quake in their boots. However, I think the ladies are Chinese and the menu makes me think this is more of a Chinese restaurant than a Vietnamese place. Ma Po Tofu? Five-Spice Chicken? Regardless, the chicken is perfection and like others, you may want to ask for the meat sauce on the side. Always order extra imperial rolls. You will not regret it.

One note, this place is probably better to-go than dine-in. It only seats about 12 people and we sat at some tables next to the wash sink (not the best ambiance). But for a $8 dinner, that leaves you stuffed, how can you complain?
author: Daisy Z.

description:
I lived in the area for two weeks and kept walking past. The idea of everything slathered in meat sauce was enough to bring me in.

I will admit, the 5 spice chicken was tasty but the kabob meat takes the tops. Although the beef is not in cubes like you would skewer, it is very flavorful and full of char; I  would go for full on kabob next time. The spring roll deep fried and you really cannot get any more meaty. Finally, meat sauce turned out to be something to try, kind of gimmicky.

For a meal that will fill you for a day and a half and on the cheap (for SF), not bad at all.
author: Vince E.

description: This place is great. I've been going to Cordon Bleu for over 33 years, and there's a reason for that. It's got some of the best Thai food I've ever had outside of Thailand. The place is tiny and usually packed. Occasionally there's a line out the door. But let me tell you , The wait is well worth it, and it's a great value for your money. I can't recommend Cordon Bleu enough!  My usual is the number five, no meat sauce, lots of chicken sauce Bon appétit
author: TJPHX T.

description:
It is every bit the hole-in-the-wall.  In fact, it seems to be little more than a hole, with 4 staff members all cramming around a hot stove and grill, churning our Vietnamese plates at a rapid pace (I am filled with both pity, envy, and awe thta they manage to work with more efficiency than a German car factory).  Space is limited and there is pretty much just counter service, plus a handful of teensy tables shoved into the back.  The place is always packed, and if you eat in you do run the risk of sitting next to the overzealous foodie who will spend an hour boring you with his every culinary adventure since the age of 5. 
    Immeditaely they thrust menus at you with a minimal selection of options.  hHe portions are gargantuan, and all the plates are under $10.  In fact, you could probably just order one plate for two people and still both leave feeling so full you don't want to eat again for another 12 hours.  I went with the noodle bowl, which came with kebabs and a Vietnamese Imperial Roll, although I also had the option of upgrading the kebab to chicken for a measly $1 extra.  I discovered pretty quickly with a fast glance at the grill that the chicken wasn't really my thing (it was a huge leg or breast of meat on the bone, with far too many visible tendons and too much dark meat for my liking).  Accordingly, I did not choose the option to upgrade, and instead went with the kebab which turned out to be thin slices of grilled pork meat.
   Waiting for the food took a lot longer than I expected, but I can't really blame them with such limited space, they actually were constantly working as it stood.  However, in the future I might just call ahead and wait the 20 minutes for takeout.  When it was pushed in front of me the bowl was stuffed with a mountain of noodles, a roll that was kind of charred and stuffed with shredded veggies and cabbage (kind of chewy and utterly addictive), about 5 slabs of the grilled pork (not what I expected from a kebab but it was so good I didn't actually care), and a light broth at the bottom that required a bit of digging.  I was pleasantly impressed with the combination, and I wolfed as much as I could manage down pretty rapidly.  My dining partner went with the 5 spice chicken, and he seemed far less happy with his choice.  He kept insisting the sauce (which doused a pile of white rice and a large hunk of chicken) tasted like a red conch chowder.  While I didn't really get that from my sample, I can say I didn't really think it was as spicy as I had expected, and I did vastly prefer my own selection that evening.  I personally thought it was more of a bland tomato sauce used for spaghetti kind of thing, but either way kind of meh.  Also, I did see someone else's tofu plate which I would be tempted to order next time.
    I wouldn't call it fine dining by any stretch of the imagination, but it is definitely a cool spot to get your Vietnamese fix. For what you get, knowing it is a quick and inexpensive option, it is decent.  However, you can see everything being cooked in front of you, so if you're squeamish and want an immaculate kitchen this probably is not the place for you.  It is cluttered and possibly has questionable health code ethics.  Also Cordon Bleu (an odd name for Vietnamese) is cash only, so make sure to swing by an ATM on your way over.  Cheap eats, huge portions, it is definitely worth checking out that night you're feeling too lazy to cook or for when you 're craving some Asian comfort food.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Another a pig in the mud kind of shit.

Combo #5, Five Spiced Chicken, Imperial Roll, Shish Kebab, Country Salad, Meat Sauce & Rice. $8.65

The strange looking Meat Sauce always makes me vomit a little before start eating.
True, isn't it?
Oh Shit, it looks So bad.
It's So Bad, but the taste surprisingly Good every time.
It's a Good Shit indeed.
Really Good.

We became a regular because it's our standard routine dinner after movie at Lumiere Theatre.

Tonight show is "Five Spiced Chicken"?
It looks exactly like that when you are at north east corner of Polk Street and California Street looking at the theatre, no matter what is really showing. 

The portion is big.
Take home if you can't finish.
You'll be surprise that the 5 Spiced Chicken is surprisingly still good in next day.
author: Nobu K.

description: This place is amazing. If Vietnam had American diners this is what the restaurant would be like. Place seats about 12 people and the food is cooked right in front of you on the grill. The meat sauce is incredible over rice and the chicken is great. Highly recommend getting an imperial roll. They're the bees knees.
author: John G.

description: Awful. Poor quality Chinese food labeled as Vietnamese. Non-existent service. Sketchy kitchen protocols. Regrettable meal.
author: John W.

description:
this is my favorite place in the entire city to eat.
really wonderful service too
author: Jacob D.

description: I love this place...yes, it is a dumpy dive...but the food is so tasty.  I first went there with a friend who told me it was her favorite restaurant in SF...that was over 20 years ago.  I have never been unhappy...the service is not in your face friendly...but as you what them work when sitting at the counter...they work really hard and you just get a warm feeling and can tell they are nice.  The 5 spice chicken and the imperial rolls are my favorites...
author: grant t.

description: I love this place! Super friendly neighborhood vietnamese diner. A place where the regular customers actually help clean off the tables for newcomers as it gets packed quickly. Their meat plates are huge and the owner (Aunty) is super generous! 3 pork chops on one plate. The 5 spiced chicken is amazing. Salivating just thinking about it!
author: Juliana L.
