description: 3 stars means A-OK: I would come here again. The #5 (chicken, flat kebab meat pieces, shredded lettuce with a vinegar sauce, rice with tomato-based meat sauce, 2 fried imperial rolls) is $11.35 and is a heaping ton of food. Pretty tasty, too.
author: Miguel C.

description: This place is funky, small and packs a punch when it comes to portions and taste!  My friend and I had  the Noodle Salad bowl with Chicken.  The chicken was tender and grilled right in front of us.  There are no secrets in this place, everything is laid out right there.  I would definitely go back next time I go to get my nails done at Silk down the street!
author: Meli B.

description:
It took a while to find this place, but I am glad that after some walking around, we finally did. When my friend Jenn and I first entered, all we saw were happy customers, most of which were standing and waiting for their take out orders to be completed. Due to our limited time, I wish we had thought of doing that because we did not have enough time to really sit down and enjoy the food.

Due to our limited time, we decided to share an order rather than each order our own plate. A lady waiting told us their chicken was a must-try and since the menu said it was world famous, we figured we had to so we got the #4. The meat sauce on the rice was hecka good and I could definitely see myself eating a whole meal of just that. The chicken was good too but don't know if I can see how it's world famous. While we were frantically eating to get to our event on time, the cook kindly gave us each a piece of the kabob so we could at least taste it. Now the Kabob was truly AMAZING. That is something I could see being world famous more so than the chicken.

Despite our limited time to eat here, I really enjoyed the food and will definitely be back again. We did try to come back after the event to order the Imperial Rolls but it looked packed again so we decided to save that for another time. But someday, we will come back and take our time to sit down and enjoy the good eats.
author: Gajan K.

description:
Came here on a whim looking for some quick good food in the area. We got quick GREAT food. 

Truly a hidden gem that reminds you why SF is so amazing. Huge quantities of food that is all delicious. My friend and I both got the #5's and were both fully satiated and satisfied. I highly recommend for the local and traveler alike.

Oh, and for that price. $9 / each. Ridiculous.
author: Milan T.

description:
The chicken, I must admit, could be a bit dry at times.  But their garlicky tofu with mushrooms is the bomb!  :)  

The waitresses are always friendly.  Great service, cheap price, plus you get to watch them cook from right across the counter.  Ideal place for a satisfying meal sans the ambiance.
author: Kristen S.

description:
This place epitomizes the very definition of "hole in the wall." It's literally a small storefront in the middle of f*cksville with approximately 7 counter seats and a couple of very small rickety tables.

This place was recommended to us by the owner of Rockin' Tacos in Chicago, who originally hails from San Francisco and spoke so highly of this place that I knew we had to try it. Of course, he also made us promise to bring him some Imperial Rolls back to Chicago for him.

He warned us ahead of time that it was divey; not that it was a problem, but with a name like Cordon Bleu, one expects something a little fancier.

This was our last meal in SF and the trip definitely ended on a high note.

Since we knew ahead of time it was tiny, we got there right when it opened so we wouldn't have to wait. We got two seats at the counter and watched the magic happen.

Chickens were grilling, egg rolls were frying, and meat sauce was simmering away on the tiny stove. The stove is so old that the knobs are no longer there and pliers were used to turn it off/on.

The owner came by and took our order and she asked us how we heard about the place and we told her about our connection in Chicago and she smiled. Cordon Bleu has been there since 1967, which I find astonishing. 

We ordered the much-heralded Imperial Rolls, vegetarian rolls, a combination plate and a chicken salad.

The Imperial Rolls have earned praise for a reason. Crispy, but not greasy, bursting with meat and vegetables. Egg roll bliss. The vegetarian ones were quite tasty as well, with bean thread and mushrooms inside.

The chicken salad was indescribably delicious. A bed of cabbage, mint, basil, carrots and bean sprouts with a pile of five-spice chicken on top that the owner took off the grill seconds earlier and shredded right in front of me. It was dressed with some type of vinaigrette that accented the salad perfectly. This salad was bursting with fresh ingredients; it made me feel good eating it.

My boyfriend got the combo plate of half a grilled five-spice chicken and rice with meat sauce. He devoured it.

We talked with some of the regulars which this place has in spades and everyone proclaimed it the best Vietnamese food in the city.

We placed our order for Imperial rolls to take back with us, got the bill (seriously cheap), paid and left, knowing full well we will be back one day.

Cordon Bleu was our own little celebration marking the 35th anniversary of the end of the Vietnam War.
author: Melanie S.

description:
Great grilled meats, and the imperial rolls have the right flavor and texture, though they're a bit big. 

Minus two stars, as I can't recommend the vermicelli bowl -- it's more like plain rice noodles than the bouncy texture of bún that you usually get at Vietnamese places. 

Add one star back for the huge amount of delicious grilled meat you get for your money! I think I'll try the signature dish next time.
author: June K.

description: One of my favorite places in San Francisco. I've never found anything else like it. Love everything they make there, plus portions are huge and inexpensive.
author: E K.

description:
O Cordon Bleu, I'm such a sucker for you. I must've gained a few pounds just from visiting this place so often. 

First, their chicken - I'm not a fan of bone in chicken but man, their grilled chicken is on point. So tender and tasty! Second, their rice and "meat" sauce - I'm not sure what's in that sauce but it is absolutely delicious. It goes so perfectly with the grilled chicken. Finally, the imperial rolls - holy hell, this just brings the meal to a full circle. They are so crispy and amazing so just go ahead and get three more.

Great hole in the wall restaurant that is inexpensive and tasty! I might have to kidnap the lady if I ever move out of the neighborhood.
author: Roopa A.

description: Since 1972, when I was an 18 year old actor at San Francisco's The American Conservatory Theatre, I have been relishing this perfect oasis of savory flavors and beautiful owner, Karen's familial hospitality.  You will love the food and the spirit of the owner and her team. The No. 5 on the menu is almost the full treatment and still under $10. In 1972, for # was, I think, $2.50 - an hour's wage for me, at the time also working as a busboy. I now live 1,000 miles from the Cordon Bleu, but I will answer its call, as I must, soon, again. I am like a pilgrim for the food and the atmosphere. The tiny space encourages a feeling of a dinner party, with strangers often happily striking up enthusiastic conversation about how great the food is, and exchanges of stories about how long you have been coming there. Nothing more fun for the devotees than to watch the expression on the face of a first-timer!  Rapture and never anything less. Extraordinary in every way.  Of course, more must be open than one's mouth. For the ultimate experience, enter the Cordon Bleu with an open heart, for you will fall in love with this place, and come back for more. Tell Karen "Hi" from Ron!
author: Ronald L.

description:
I love the 5 spiced chicken salad! Everything's fresh from the cold cabbage, mint, basil, chopped peanuts served with sweet and sour vinaigrette and topped off with a heaping portion of their delicious Shredded 5-spiced chicken!

And for those of you with an appetite for destruction, the # 5! It pretty much comes with everything on their menu that's not vegetarian.
author: Jorge P.

description: Place was really good and the atmosphere is fun. Small dining area and the "kitchen" is right in the middle of it. Definitely recommend the #5
author: Todd S.

description: This place is bomb. Good food at a great price. Get #5 if you're hungry or the chicken salad if you want something lighter.
author: Dave S.

description:
It's a lot of sloppy food that is oddly satisfying yet doesn't cost a lot but I'm still undecided as to whether I really like Cordon Bleu or not. 

I've heard so much about the 5 spice chicken. Perhaps I should have ordered that instead but I needed forkable food since I was on the run so I ordered the #1 - kebabs, imperial roll, served with rice and mystery meatsauce plus a cabbage slaw. 

I have to admit I'm a little confused by said mystery meat sauce. It definitely doesn't feel very Vietnamese ... and definitely not French. But the kebabs were nicely grilled and had a nice sweet BBQ flavor. I also loved the super delicious and crispy imperial roll. In fact, I will gladly do away with the rice and sauce and just snack on Imperial rolls all day long. 

You get a lot of food on your plate for the price you pay. My takeout box lasted me two meals. Don't think I'll crave it ever though but I might come back to try the chicken that everyone seems to rave about.
author: Jon L.

description:
(more of a 3.5)

Lived in the area for a while, always glanced over this place until the following on here intrigued me to try it.  Is it all that and a bag of chips?

The chicken - not bad, not great. 
The "shish kebab" - really just your usual grilled Vietnamese pork.
Meat sauce - tastes a lot like what I remember spaghetti-o sauce tastes like (haven't had that in over a decade).  I mean this in a good homey way, not "ugh, canned food".  Goes really well with the rice, and totally hit the spot when it's cold outside.
Imperial roll - really hefty and meaty - practically a lunch in itself.

Conclusion:  nice comfort food.
author: T C.

description: Amazing and cheap food! If your looking for something to fill you up and your on a budget I definitely recommend this place!!!
author: Erin M.

description:
This is definitely a hidden gem in SF!

I loved the chicken salad! Small place but incredible service and incredible food!! Also, try their imperial roll and #5!

FYI: No reservations, so get there early or call in for pick up!
author: Vee A.

description:
I love coming here. This place is no frills, straight to the point, down right good food.

If you don't know where this restaurant is, you'll very well pass it. It's a hole in the wall. Upon walking through the doorway, it's almost shocking how small it is. And that's the beauty of it. This place really is only for people who get lucky and find a free seat or people who understand that the food is worth the wait.

The menu is very limited, but just about everything is delicious. The eggrolls are unlike any I've ever had. They're big and (I think) cooked twice to make them extra crispy. I have yet to find another restaurant that makes their eggrolls that look and taste like this - trust me, I'm Asian! And the meat sauce, oh, the meat sauce! It's doused over your rice. To me, it tastes more like a tomato base with bits of meat. However it's made, it's freakin' good! The portions are huge and cheap. I once came here with intense munchies and I still only ate about 2/3 of my plate and felt like I was going to burst.

I think what I love most about Cordon Bleu is I feel like I'm sitting in an aunt's kitchen. The cook (who I'm assuming is the owner) is a nice and accommodating lady. She'll make conversation with you when she can - she's usually busy focusing on cooking since it seems like the restaurant is constantly brimming with diners.

This is definitely a hidden gem in San Francisco.
author: Napier B.

description: So disappointed! The bbq'd meat was so dry and charred. Service was so slow and poorly coordinated. Worst of all, anyone noticed the chef uses the same tongs for raw meats, cooked meats and imperial eggrolls? X - contamination!
author: Ames L.

description: Very limited menu, but what you get is pretty good. This is a great value for lunch or an easy dinner, but the food itself isn't special. There are perhaps a dozen seats for dining in. Most of their business appears to be takeout. Cash-only.
author: Chris K.

description: The imperial rolls are delicious. The grilled 5-spiced chicken is very tasty. Everything else was ordinary or sub par. Refrigerator-cold vermicelli noodles, watery Campbell soup meat sauce, chewy frozen pork pieces, slow service, grill/smoky hole-in-the-wall. There are much better Vietnamese places than this.
author: Susan D.

description:
you wouldn't think of this place as a Vietnamese restaurant, and in fact its not really authentic vietnamese by any means.  I'm not even sure what Cordon Bleu has anything to do with the food they serve.  

All I can say is that it's a small dive place for good grilled meat whether its for their five spiced chicken or pork chops.  Their imperial rolls are nice and hot and their meat sauce over rice is something to try.  I wouldn't rate the food amazing but good to very good.

The area has diner stool seating a few tables, most people get food to go since its tiny inside.  The family that operates this place are very nice and work real hard.  

cheap eats, good food, try it!
author: Kevin W.

description:
Whoa, this place is AMAZING! How did I not know about this hidden little gem for all this time??!! 

Hubby's auntie took us here for some family bonding - it's her favorite place, and I understand why!

Michael M. said it best..."you walk in and will hit the back wall" - this place is TINY! People are lined up just for a chance to have a seat at the tiny lunch counter or their 3(!!!!) tables in the back.

Order the #5 - you'll get a sampling of their five spice chicken, rice with meat gravy, cabbage and carrot 'slaw' and bbq beef - Not to mention a roll of their CRACK-INFUSED imperial rolls. 

Seriously people, these imperial rolls are flippin' out of this world...the best I have ever had! I'm dreaming of them now....mmmmmmm!

Nothing is over $9.00 - yeah, that's not a typo...$9.00! It's so much food that you'll feel like you've won the Vietnamese jackpot!!

A helpful hint: don't go wearing nice clothing or before a night on the town - this place is so tiny that you will walk out smelling like the grill your food was cooked on. BUT, it's so worth it!

They do some crazy to-go business too!
author: Christy L.

description:
These ladies, Katie and her crew, are masters of the Vietnamese comfort dish. It's a tiny and typically packed countertop restaurant and you can watch these ladies in action frying and serving up delicious 5 spice chicken, savory and tasty Imperial rolls, delicious cabbage and sweet vinegar dressing. I really don't know a thing about traditional Vietnamese fare or the proper title of any of these dishes, but I know it's good and comforting and perfect for the city full of grown up children missing their mommy's. 

Check it out. Great prices and tasty grub. That red meat sauce over the rice even makes my vegetarian sister and her girlfriend temporarily break their no-meat vow every now and then. 

Thanks Katie! She knows we love her.
author: Marina M.

description:
This is a great little hole in the wall.  Big portions, affordable, friendly service, and a great atmosphere if you are into dive-y places.

The meat sauce is really, really great and both the chicken and beef were cooked very well and had good flavor.  The country salad was really good when mixed in with the rice and meat sauce.  

Will definitely be going back many times in the future.
author: Malcolm A.

description:
My favorite hangover food. Mounds of rice with meat sauce, imperial roll, and thinly marinated pork does its justice. The lightly pickled cabbage is a great texture adder too!

Been going here since I moved to Nob Hill several years ago. Katie is very friendly!
author: Ronnie T.

description: Get #5. Chicken, delicious shish kabob, imperial roll, meat sauce and rice. All cooked right in front of you after you order. Great value for money.
author: Kunal K.

description: Excellent hole in the wall! Particularly good for takeout, as the place is tiny and there are only three tables (?) and mostly counterspace sitting. Five spice chicken is fantastic, and their noodle salad rocks.  Portions are huge, the food is yummy, and the price is unbeatable. How do they do it? :-)
author: candide o.

description: Favorite restaurant in all of the city! My family and I even make the 45min drive over whenever we're craving it!
author: Jamie J.

description: Hole in the wall delicious-ness. Had the #1 and it was great. My girlfriend got the chicken salad and will definitely come back.
author: Steve C.

description:
Hole in the wall go to.

Been coming here since the 80's.

Would long since have been out of business if it weren't any good.
author: P G.

description: No--wait. No! Never going back, and this place needs a through inspection by the Health Department. Gross, just gross.
author: Jake M.

description:
Recently we moved into the neighborhood and were excited to see (& smell) a Vietnamese restaurant within walking distance. Also, word of mouth said that this was the go to place. One day when too lazy to cook we decided to try this place, getting our food to go. Drum roll please........

DISAPPOINTED does not even begin to cover our feelings. 
We had the 5 spice chicken, advertised right on their awning.  The chicken basically looked and tasted like the bad bbq chicken that someone burns after they've had 8 beers manning the grill. I'm part Filipino so I know good rice and their rice was over cooked. No one enjoys mushy rice unless its in a desert. The rice was also covered in some sort of mystery sauce that was simply bland and unnecessary. The mushy rice and odd sauce was too much, I took a total of three bites and threw my plate away. I attempted to try the Imperial rolls that we loved at another place but that too was oily and inedible. 

End result? DON'T BELIEVE THE HYPE. Ever.

**Recommendation?
Try the Vietnam Restaurant in North Beach. I've never eaten anything there I didn't love and come back for. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz/vietnam-restaurant-san-francisco
author: Jenise B.

description: Love it. Great cheap, hole in the wall. My favorite type of place.
author: chad w.

description:
I don't know why everyone was harsh about the decor and the place. I liked it, it's got a little diner experience with seats around a counter and a small table in the back. 

The portions are huge, like I couldn't finish it huge, which is saying something since I can shovel away food pretty well.

The meat sauce over rice was good but nothing to write home about. The imperial roll was delicious, fried and good meat inside. The chicken was great but I really didn't like trying to get everything off the bone all the time with my knife and fork, I wish they tore it away from the bone but that's just my laziness.

The price was good, I only paid $11 for everything, though I wouldn't recommend getting the sides separately, they are expensive when they aren't part of that combination.
author: Rohan D.

description:
Woohoo! As good as it gets!

Formula: 
Call. 
Order a # 5. 
Wait 20 Minutes. 
Pay Cash. 
Devour.
author: AJ G.

description:
This place is definitely overrated on Yelp. Seems to be a neighborhood thing as it was also recommended to me by a local, outside Yelp.

The place feels a bit dirty, with liquids boiling out of the pan in front of you. The grill was dirty and my grilled pork chops came full of that nasty black stuff from the grill.

The pieces without black grill waste tasted good, though. And the price is reasonable. But I'm not coming back.
author: Nilson S.

description:
The upsides: holy god that food. The menu has about four things on it, which is great, because they do them all beautifully. The shish kebab (which is actually just pork) is moist and flavourful. The imperial roll made me want to kill myself because I knew I would never experience flavour like that again. And the oyster/tofu/pork dish was amazing. Texture, flavour, good smells - oh yes, this food had it all. On top of all that, we each only paid $8 for that gloriousness - and it was enough food to last each of us two or three meals!

The downside is that my friend and I walked in here on a Sunday evening and sat at the bar, then had to wait about 15 minutes before we could even catch someone's attention enough to get a menu. Once we had looked it over, it was another trick giving the woman our order. We then proceeded to wait AN HOUR for our food. I can appreciate that this place is eensy and that the three employees are overwhelmed with everyone jammed in there on top of the phone/to-go orders that keep piling in, but it was a little insane. However, the food was worth the wait.

Just know that there most likely WILL be a wait.
author: Lia S.

description: Great hole-in-the-wall with consistently well spiced food for a great price in the city. If you're still hungry afterwards head to Bob's donuts a block or so away!
author: Keivan Z.

description:
Not sure what's the fuzz about this place.
Small place with a smokey BBQ. Chicken, rice and some sauce. Meh. Not a big deal.
author: Fernando C.

description:
Big portions, yummy, savory, and memorable.

Fried Egg should be optional for all rice plates. It's a must.
author: Ken C.

description: Had the best chicken salad here, was a bit skeptical about the way the food was sitting out ready to be cooked but it tasted amazing!
author: Alice W.

description:
I love the grilled meats here, I love the people, and I LOVE THAT FREAKING MEAT SAUCE.

Now this isn't some sketchy, $1.99 chinese food 'meat sauce' where you can't tell what meat it is. (Actually, I can't, but it doesn't matter in this case.) It's a textured, flavored, savory sauce that makes you want to put it on everything you can find on your plate just to see how good everything is with it.

The owners are Canto-Viet and very nice. It's a very "at home" atmosphere that I can't describe in words. If I were far away from my home (I'm not), I would be drawn to eat here on a very regular basis. Even though the tastes aren't what I grew up with, you can tell it's all served with love.

The seating is minimal and you're encouraged to be brave and ask people to retetris themselves to allow the maximum number of people to be efficiently seated in the place. (Some people are just grumps, though. "No, we may only be two people but we don't really want to sit at the counter to let your four people sit, sorry.)

There's no question, I am coming back. It's just a little far from my place in SoMa. :(
author: Josh K.

description: Real small place, cash only, they make the food in front of you on a small grill. Got the number 5, pork,chicken, imperial eggroll, and rice and 'meat' sauce. good amount of food 10.50$ cash only. Next time try out the vermecelli.
author: K T.

description: This is place is fantastic if you want really really good, no-frills Vietnamese food (and if you like grilled meat). The owner is very nice and a great cook. I had a wonderful experience eating there by myself at the counter talking to a Vietnamese man who goes there whenever he is in the city. The portions are enormous and the food is very tasty and just where to go when you want something simple, delicious, authentic and cheap.
author: Ros S.

description: This was such a welcome find! Thanks yelp.  The spicy pork chops were delicious and I could not believe how big the portions are...oh and the lady who owns this place could not be nicer.
author: Todd F.

description:
Ordered from here on a Tuesday night. 

Even though everyone recommends getting the Imperial Roll, we opted for the Fresh Spring Roll instead because we weren't feeling something that was deep fried. The Fresh Spring Roll was delicious - very flavorful and tasted fresh. Highly recommended.

We also got a veggie noodle salad. It was okay but not great. It was lacking in vegetables and was pretty much just noodles.
author: Alden Q.

description:
If you haven't been you need to go.

Guideline to a good eating experience:

1.  Just sit down and if there's no spots available, wait outside.
2.  Pretend your Vietnamese aunt is just cooking a good meal and you happened upon her kitchen.
3.  Tip well

It's a ton of food, so go stoned.
author: Nick C.

description:
Get Item #5, it is just a combo of all the good stuff they got.  Done and Done.  No menu required.  5 spice chicken, pork slices, HUGE deep fried imperial roll, rice covered in beef stew like sauce, and small cabbage salad.

Huge portions!

Very small spot, be ready to wait.  I would advise ordering take-out around peak hours.

BYOB

Great service.
author: Steven F.

description: Ridiculously good chicken, ridiculously big portions, ridiculously cheap prices. No room to sit so carry that ish out! You're not a local if you haven't tried this spot.
author: Anne A.

description: We ordered the number 5 and the noodle salad, both were very delicious! Feels like you're eating in someone's kitchen, the place is super small and intimate. Highly recommend!
author: Leah R.

description:
Wonderful family-run, establishment.  They do just a handful of things and they execute them perfectly and with welcoming cheer.

The portions are big enough to destroy me (almost six and a half feet tall) and they cap out at $10.

Come and treat them equally well.
author: James R.

description:
Ever since I moved to San Francisco, I have missed Vietnamese food like crazy. I have found a few "fine" places. Most get the job done without having to drive to San Jose. But of course nothing beats homemade Vietnamese food from my parents. 

Stopped by on the way home and ordered the #5 combo because everyone says it's a must. I ate the hell out of the imperial roll, well half of the meat inside and the entire outter chewy deep fried wrapper. 

The chicken was moist and charred perfectly. That Asian woman who was cooking has the art of charring and cutting with scissors down to a science. The pork was dry. A bit disappointing. But edible. 

The meat sauce. It was fine. Tasted a bit like tomato paste. I thought the sauce would be spicy, but no. Next time I'll get the sauce on the side. 

Overall another "fine" Vietnamese place to add to the list.
author: Chen D.

description:
This restaurant is a block away from Van Ness Ave. so it's easily accessible by public transportation.  

The restaurant itself is very small, probably only able to seat 15 people max.  The waitress are very friendly and you get to watch them cook up your food as the grill and deep fryer are in the middle of the tiny restaurant.  

I tried #4 on the menu which came with five spice chicken, rice with meat sauce and country salad which was more like a pickled slaw.  The five spice chicken was more carcinogenic than I hoped because it was over-charred, however, the chicken was still quite moist.  The chicken didn't have the best five spice flavor but I received a large portion, both dark and white meat.  I sadly was not a fan of the meat sauce as it seemed just thickened with corn starch.  I did enjoy the crunch and tang of the slaw.  I was able to sample the shish kebab and imperial roll, both of which were delicious!
author: Maya S.

description: A small hole in the wall. Pretty good but the vermicelli noodle with pork + eggroll dish already has the sauce on the bottom! I didn't know ahead of time so I added more sauce and it was way too much. Also, I heard this place was super good but coming from San Jose, I've had better Vietnamese food down south.
author: Leslie C.

description:
This is the kind of place you write home about. Huge portions, great prices, and they cook it all right in front of you. 

Anyone who gives this place less than 5 stars should probably be sipping thousand dollar bottles of wine on their yacht while their maid feeds them grapes. With the limited seating in the place, I'm fine with them staying on their yacht. Stick to your upper echelon lifestyle and quit writing yelp reviews.

You can't go wrong here. Only thing to note is that it is cash only so come prepared. Servers are very polite and the kind of people you don't mind giving your money to.
author: Tom B.

description: Small and bar seating, but the food was delicious. The House Special Chicken Salad was refreshing and an excellent combination of flavors, the imperial roll was delicious, and the shish kabab was tender and tasty. The prices were good for the amount of food and the service was friendly. One thing to note, it's a cash only place but don't let that deter you!
author: Meagan S.

description:
Mmm hole in the wall. A skinny little restaurant with the cooks behind a counter and a couple of small tables in the back. Love it! 2 stuffed people for under $20: perfect!

This so called Vietnamese place (run by Chinese, but uses fish sauce?) has yummy combos of grilled pork, chicken or kebabs (beef, not on a skewer like you might think), with this "meat sauce", which is a tomato based sauce with some ground meat in it. Also comes with a huge, deeelish egg roll and some cabbage salad. Drizzle the rice and meat sauce with some soy sauce and eat with the meat, dip the egg roll in the fish sauce, and enjoy! A good, filling, reasonably priced, complete meal.

P.S. The ladies that work here are so nice and friendly! Free piece of meat while eating at the counter? Sure!
author: Christine L.

description: I love this place!  Tiny, unpretentious, in bad need of some updates, but the food is great.  The five-spice chicken and pork kebabs are tasty, as is the meat sauce that is poured over the rice.  Huge portions - always satisfying.  Inexpensive too.
author: Eric C.

description: Bomb imperial rolls. Lots of food for decent price. Order to go cause its super small inside and your clothes will smell.
author: Eugene H.

description:
To me, Cordon Bleu is the standard for cheap, homey and comfy Asian cooking. This is the stuff I grew up on and I am so glad that there is something like that to remind me of home here in Nob Hill.

Good things
- #5 Combo: For those who love variety, this combo meal is the way to go. It comes with two pieces of their five spice chicken (either white or dark meat) and it's really actually good, if you can look beyond the charred skin. It has a few pieces of (dry) marinated grilled pork, which they call shish kabob. The cole slaw is tasty and the tomato meat sauce over the rice is really really filling (though lukewarm the two times I've gotten it). The highlight for me is the imperial roll. It's huge and so delicious, except it is also totally overfried.
- Noodle salad: A lighter, seemingly healthier alternative to fried stuff. It's also pretty big, like everything else here, but that's never a bad thing :)

Not so good things
- Cleanliness: I know this is a hole in the wall, and I totally can appreciate that, but this place is so dim that I seriously think the two ladies and man that work here refuse to install lights because the dirtiness of the establishment would dissuade restaurant-goers from coming back.

I can look beyond the dirtiness and the assumption that my food probably isn't cooked in the most sanitary conditions because the stuff is just that good. Vietnamese comfort food, I am so grateful for you!
author: Shira C.

description:
#5 for $10 . 5 spice chicken, imperial roll, Shish kebab country salad with meat sauce on rice!

The restaurant is small and can probably sit about 8-10 people. I ordered take out and it took about 30mins before the food was done. If you sit inside and wait, you can expect to smell like BBQ food.  You get seated at the bar and see the woman cook and grill the food. I recommend calling in ahead of time. The place is located right next to the chase ATM machine, you have to find street parking.  I've seen a lot of people park right infront and just pick up.  Park at your own risk?! Portions are humango and can be shared by two, def worth the price paid. I've never had gravy over rice and that made it extra juicy. The chicken was moist and the eggroll was meaty. Def recommend coming here for a cheap budget lunch/dinner.
author: Chanel L.

description:
Great food. Loved the meat sauce!
We (group of four) brought our own wine and they were cool with it. The plastic cups they gave us for wine and water had gotten a little moldy on the outside from being damp and stacked inside one another on the counter. It was fine but next time I will bring beer and my own bottle of water.
author: Janell H.

description:
THIS PLACE IS ABSOLUTELY DELICIOUS. It's a hole-in-the-wall restaurant. I don't know how authenticly Vietnamese the food is, but all I know is that it is delicious. I got the special with everything (I think it may have been #5). It comes with a huge portion of rice topped with meat sauce (its more like a gravy), grilled chicken, beef shish kebobs, and a huge imperial roll. Maybe I was just hungry, but everything tasted SO delicious. I definitely preferred the chicken to the beef, because it was more tender. The portion is SO huge (for only $10), that I had enough to eat for 2 days. 

My friend and I also shared an order of the "spring rolls," which isn't your quintessential spring roll. It's a warm spring roll with sauteed veggies and glass noodles inside, served with a side of peanut sauce. The peanut sauce was where the money was for me. It was very sweet and the consistency was thick. I would go back just for these rolls.
author: Lillian K.

description:
Worth it to call ahead - if you are on time, she's pretty good about saving a spot or two at the counter for you. Ordering to-go is also an option. 

Jesus, mary and joseph. I haven't had anything here that's bad. And I've ordered everything on the menu. 

Perhaps some of the best tofu dishes I've ever had. Garlicky tofu, tofu noodle salad, fresh spring rolls, and one more i'm forgetting. 

As for non veggie, the chicken is out of this world, meat sauce is more of a tomato based flavor on the rice, the grilled pork that comes with the #4 is so delicious. The imperial rolls are lip smacking good also. Just make sure your entree doesn't already come with them.

Two people eating here should not be more than 12$ a person (if ordering apps). 

BYOB - just pleeeease be discrete about it. No need to get them in trouble for anything.
author: David N.

description: Super tasty and worth a visit. Noodle bowl with chicken hit the spot.  Chicken was moist and imperial roll was piping hot. Grilled chicken plate did not disappoint.  Coming back for more on the next visit to the city.
author: Fiat L.

description: Really wanted to try it out until we made the walk and realized it is small ally like room filled with waiting guests to be seated. We could have give it a shot had it not been so small and so crowded.
author: Jag M.

description:
I love discovering great, hole in the wall places, and man, this is the definition of a hole in the wall. It literally is the size of my bathroom, with the flat top grill, counter seating and 2 small tables squeezed in the corner. Sadly, the counter was full so my boyfriend and I had to sit at the table, but it wasn't unbearable. We just kinda felt like we were sitting in time-out or something. :( 

After we ordered, it took a while to get our grub, it was constantly busy with dine in customers and to-go orders, but it was so worth the wait. Both of us got the #5, as all Yelpers recommended it. SO GOOD. The meats were juicy and tender (the beef "skewers" were chard on the edges and that taste was heaven), and the imperial roll was GINORMOUS and satisfying: crunchy, chewy and meaty. The serving of rice and meat sauce covers the entire plate, and no lie, I ate it all.

I was admiring the woman who ran the joint, and it was quite comical, the cash register doesn't work, I'm positive,  as it merely serves as a box to stash all the cash. She does all the math in her head too for change. 

I think our bill was like $25, if that. Pretty sure the garlic fries and 2 bottled waters we got at the Giants game were more expensive.
author: Courtney C.

description: Ordered the number 5. Bomb! Small place and kind of hard to find a place to sit. But once you do, you will be surprised by just how good the food is!
author: Drew L.

description: Best hole in the wall food in the area by far. The food is delicious and made with care. I got the veggie spring roll - best spring roll I have had in the city. And the chicken salad is great too. You can't go wrong here. Cheap prices too!
author: Harmony P.

description:
I went there today. Horrible!!! This place not only dirty, the food is terrible. 

I totally agree with "Alex D" who commented earlier(see below)

10/26/2013
Alex D.
18 friends 14 reviews
Terrible!!! In short the food was over cooked and lacked flavor. However the portions were huge. 

I ordered the #5 combo plate on a friends recommendation (5 spice chicken, rice with meat sauce, imperial roll, shish kebab and cabbage salad). The quarter chicken was dry and flavorless. The rice and meat sauce tasted like chef boyardee on mushy rice. The imperial roll were fine but far from the best I've ever had. The Shish kebab was more like beef jerky, dry, flavorless strips of poorly marinated beef grilled to a burnt crisp. The salad was just undressed shredded cabbage. 

Cordon Bleu is a quantity over quality place. I would hardly even call the food Vietnamese.  It's a combo plate Asian food cafeteria for hungry 20 somethings who need to load up on bad cheap food before slamming tons of bud lights at mcteagues.
author: Sam J.

description:
Came here in Dec 2012 after the wait for House of Prime Rib proved to be too long. Definitely not a good place to go for large groups as our party of 7 were squeezed in their only table they had. I'm not complaining about it, just merely pointing it out. 

The food was delicious, and as all the yelpers said, the meat sauce and the imperial rolls are gooooood. I don't know how they make those imperial rolls so huge and packed with meat.
author: Jeffrey C.

description:
I really rate this place, super divey whole in the wall Vietnamese!

Majority of seats are counter, with 1 or 2 very small tables at the end. Quite often you will need to wait to dine, or order take-out

Portions are insane, I normally order the special, chicken, beef, rice and a spring roll at super cheap price! You can eat until you hurt and have enough left for lunch the next day.

Service is great, with typical hole in the wall you are served and pay the same lady who cooks the food and washes the dishes :)

Go, give it a try, you won't be disappointed!!

Oh by the way it is BYOB!!
author: Chris M.

description: This place is awesome. Expect to leave super full!! The imperial rolls are amazing and so is everything else. The owner is also very nice!! They cook everything homemade style right in front of your face
author: Megan C.

description: I am so grateful to the lovely proprietress at Cordon Bleu for taking me in right at closing and serving up some of the most delicious food I've had in a long time. It's truly a neighborhood gem and can't be beat for tasty bites at the right price.
author: Paul A.

description:
Not a restaurant for the squeamish: The cushions on the chairs are all ripped and hotel pans full of cooked or uncooked chicken were placed practically at our feet multiple times.

The Five Spice Roast chicken has marvelous skin and is mostly moist (some of the white breast was a little dry.) Service was slow, not taking our order for 20 minutes and not letting us pay for another 5 even as we stood by the register and a line snaked out the door.

But the food is good, if a little simple, even if the ambiance and kitchen prep are a little "is that sanitary?" street food-ish.

FYI: They speak both Cantonese and Vietnamese, so if you want to bust out your multilingual skills, you have some extra choices.
author: Alexander J.

description:
Yum Yum!!
There is nothing better than cheap to-go food to enjoy in the comfort of your own home! The five spice chicken was delicious and generous in portion with loads of other goodies to keep you happy. When you're too lazy to cook, swing by for a quick meal and a great start to a lazy pj evening!
author: Christina L.

description:
Their imperial rolls are delicious, but their meats were a bit too charred and their rice/tofu dishes had a texture that you can eat without teeth. 

Everything WAS tasty though, and affordable. And the cooks/waitresses are super sweet!
author: Cindy M.

description:
I love it when I find a hidden treasure in the city. The food is amazing, the imperial rolls are no doubt a must-get. 

Portions are really big. You're definitely getting the bang for your buck! 

The only thing is that this place is small, so go with a small party.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
3.5 stars.

Two of us went at 8.30 on Thursday night, and there was only one empty seat. We were waved at to wait, but 15 minutes later, no progress so we got takeout.

I ordered #5 to sample everything; everything was tasty. The imperial roll is a crispy (rice?) shell wrapped around what's basically a kebab. Yum. The spiced chicken is delicious (they drizzle something on it from a tea pot), the shish kebab is tough but flavorful.

Everyone here raves about the meat sauce, but honestly it's only pretty good. It's creamy and flavorful (probably full of fat) and the rice is large and glutinous.
author: Justin M.

description:
We had been there many years ago, maybe 15? And my husband had been there as a kid, 30 some years ago. Hasn't changed much, apart from ownership! 

Good stuff. Very nice Imperial Rolls. Tasty five spice chicken and kebabs and of course the rice and gravy. Not something you find at every Vietnamese place. 

Having just taken a food safety course I had a few times when I just had to look away but overall, not awful. I figure the very high heat from the grill will get anything bad. Would recommend they invest in a separate knife for cutting the chicken pieces on the grill though, and maybe a couple more tongs. But really, if we were in Vietnam, would there be isolated tongs for picking up the cooked meat? Hmm. 

Many regulars. People are not getting sick here, I'm guessing.
author: Penelope B.

description:
Not entirely Viet cooking, but pretty darn good for what it's worth. 

Order the #5, bring cash and the only question to ask is how long (when ordering to go).
author: Ryan L.

description:
Seriously do not know why this place is 4 stars.

The venue looks like a run-down diner like ones you find in Chinatown. Most people sit at the bar and if you're lucky enough you sit at 1 of 2 tables in the back.. The grill is right next to the bar so be prepared for meat cologne.

The service: there are 2 ladies working during peak time dinner hour. One takes orders, grills the food, and closes the check while the other bus tables and help set up food plates and to-go orders. Basically way too much to do for 2 people so everything takes forever and you get very little attention.

The food could make up for all the above but it failed. They have a very simple menu but don't execute well. The plates of meat are all overcooked and dry. The five spice chicken had no spice. The only thing they do well are the fried spring rolls. People think their meals are a great value but it really is just a lot of white rice covered with a few pieces of grilled meat. Don't be fooled. 

I would suggest going to any other Vietnamese restaurant where you can get the same exact dishes at the same price and WAY faster.
author: Ed L.

description:
You wanna get PHAT? THIS IS THE PLACE TO BE. SMOTHER ON THAT SAUCE, AND ILL SMOTHER IT ON YOU. LETS GET DOWN TO BUSINESS.

This place is some fine dinin, can't go wrong here. And the two vietnamese women know how to cook. Its cheap, its tasty. All y'all haters can get a big WAD OF MEAT SAUCE in your face. Eat it up WHELPERS!
author: Sina A.

description:
A great little dive on California Street. Just a grill area and a counter you sit at. Nothing pretentious, always the same lady cooking. She's really nice and can strike up a conversation with you and it's never annoying or anything. She's awesome.

As for food, I'm not sure if I would describe it as "typical" Vietnamese, or at least typical in my world. A distinctive feature the Cordon Bleu is the fatty ground-pork gravy that is doused on your mountain of white rice. Throughout the day, there is fatty ground pork being mixed with some tomato-based sauce in a big vat on the stove. It's kind of like a bolognese sauce. Either way, it's pretty damn good.

I have a bad habit of getting the biggest thing on the menu, especially at a place I don't eat at too often. So far, my go-to "being a fat ass" meal is the number 5, which is a mountain of food for $9. Piece of chicken, some shish kebab, the aformentioned mountain of rice with pork gravy, fried imperial roll and some country salad I normally wouldn't care about, but it's a bit tart which helps balance out the richness of this meal. The chicken is good, the pork shish kebab is a little sweet, the imperial roll is crunchy hot goodness and the rice and gravy is overkill, but good!

Since it's December, I'll stop in a bit more. The #5 is perfect for the winter. 

Real affordable, great, rib-sticking comfort food. I'm a fan. The only thing you might not like is having your clothes smelling like the food afterward.
author: Miguel G.

description:
Get the combo #5 and the chicken salad and then worship at the Shrine of Katie.  If you tell her Enzo sent you, you'll be very glad you did.  

At our repeated request, Cordon is now open through the afternoons.  I can't rave any more about this place than has already been done.
author: Enzo L.

description:
One of those little hole-in-the-wall places that you would miss if you didn't pay attention while walking by. It's a tiny little place where it is all counter seating, but can watch them cook in front of you (it's just like Yamo in the Mission). Of course, the food is good and cheap! Get a hearty amount of food for $7!

- 5 Spice Chicken: a must try! the mystery meat sauce over the rice looks questionable, but its good! chicken was good and juicy with a little burnt smoky flavor on the outside. egg roll was your typical fried imperial roll.
author: Linda C.

description:
Tiny hole in the wall that was PACKED, non-stop.

Not sure if this is really Vietnamese food....it reminded me of Filipino food more because of the sheer amount of meat in every dish.... but the food was great so I'm happy.  I love the Vietnamese noodle salad dish, and that's what I ordered.  The portion was HUGE, and the grilled meat was delish.  It also came with an eggroll, which was alright...wasn't that impressive, but the overall dish was a 4-star plate.  I tried my friend's Pork Chop special and that was soooo good.  The meat could have been a little more tender, but it was spiced/marinated so well, I loved it.  

We also noticed that everyone was getting #5, with the reddish looking sauce over their rice, so I asked to try a sample of that, and their "meat sauce" was GREAT! It seemed like a tomato-based veggie+meat sauce, and I definitely want to come back and try that #5 dish that everyone gets!
author: Liz W.

description: Anything with their meat sauce over rice is GOOOOOD.  Imperial Rolls = SO GOOD.  The Asian lady who cooks the food likes it when you eat everything on your plate.  It's like you're her son and she's so happy you ate all of your food.  Very small place so getting seats close together for a group of friends is rare.  Don't go with more than 3 or 4 friends if you want to sit together.
author: Durty D.

description:
Simple menu, but good food. It's grilled meat (chicken or pork) on top of meat sauce covered rice, with a side of pickled cabbage. Combo #4 comes with 2 pieces of chicken, while Combo #5 is chicken, pork, and imperial rolls. Oh yeah, those rolls are simply awesome. Crispy skin on the outside, and meaty filling on the inside. All combos are just under $10.

I highly recommend getting the food to go. There's hardly any space to dine and you are literally sitting a few feet away from the grill. I walked in there for only 3 minutes to grab my food and I left smelling like a chimney.
author: Jun W.

description:
I came to this place with my friends one night after drinking in the area.

My first impression was, this is "a hole in the wall".  There is a cooking area with 6 or 7 chairs around it and one table.  We came pretty late (~9ish) on a Sunday night and still had to wait.  I imagine if we came during a more popular dinner time, it would take a long time to get seated, which would be the only drawback of this place.  

The food is awesome.  It tastes GREAT (and portion size was huge).  I think I got there special which is like beef over rice with their sauce and their spring roll.  Because we were there almost until closing, they also gave us free food (this meant I got to taste the chicken and I actually liked that even more).  

The owners (I believe they were anyways) were really nice and started chatting with us.  They started showing us pictures of their grand-niece and they started asking us how we knew each other and all.

Overall the food was tasty and it gave off a very home-y feeling...kind of like I was eating over at a relative's house.
author: Carrie L.

description: I am not sure how I feel about their orange-y mystery meat sauce, but they do have the most amazing grilled chicken (I always ask for dark meat), and I am also a fan of their vegetarian spring roll with peanut sauce.
author: C J.

description:
Walked by this place many times, and finally went for lunch today with the lady.

Upon walking in I noticed how small the place was! About 7-8 seats at the bar area, and two tables at the back that will sit about a party of 4 or 5.

We ordered a Number 4 and 5. Both delicious! The meat sauce reminded me of home. It tasted like a version of 'Taiwanese pasta sauce' my mom would make, growing up. Meaning that it's like a very sweet bolognese.

Definitely try their imperial roll! Meaty and crunchy goodness.

A plate, plus a side order is definitely enough to feed two!!
author: Susie L.

description: This place has about 10-12 seats, so expect a wait if you visit during dining hours. The menu is very short and simple and everything on there is delicious. I had the number five special, comes with kabab, chicken and imperial roll. Then it comes with steam rice that is slimmered with a special meat sauce to throw in a nice kick. the portions here is very generous so one order can feed two people, depending on your appetite. I would recommend this place. Very friendly family owned business.
author: Thomas M.

description:
Been coming to this place for a long-time, and it is really as good as it gets. Best bang for your buck lunch or dinner. Friendly service, simple easy to choose menu, large portions, hole-in-the-wall atmosphere.

Highly Recommended!!
author: Robby A.

description: I give them 3.5 stars I think everyone hyped the meat sauce up for me, it was good but nothing amazing! Big portions, real good eggrolls, they are huge. If you like Tu-lan's eggrolls these are the same! but the cool part was the owner was very nice. I could come back if I'm the area craving saucy rice
author: Karen T.

description: Just get the noodle salad. Don't over think it, just do it and thank me. SO GOOD.
author: Joel D.

description:
PROS:
- You get a ton of food for the price
- Hole-in-the-wall restaurant with a communal feel
- The acclaimed #5 is solid

CONS:
- The food is good, but not great
- The service is very slow, so don't come here if you're in a rush
- You're seated close to the grill, and the aroma of a Vietnamese BBQ will cling to your shirt
- Cash only

BOTTOM LINE:
If you're looking for amazingly delicious and cheap food from a foreign hole-in-the-wall restaurant, walk two blocks down from Cordon Bleu to Shalimar (Polk/Pine).
author: Charlie H.

description:
Very small restaurant with limited seating, only two tables and counter seats. Yet my friends still recommended that I try this restaurant out and I'm so glad I did. I wouldn't call this "authentic" Vietnamese food by any means and they have a very simple menu, however they execute their short menu very well. As far as entrees go the choices are from numbers 1-5 depending on what items you want on your plate. I tried the #5 and felt that was a good choice.

Grilled Pork was absolutely fantastic and cooked to perfection.
Imperial Rolls were decent but nothing mind-blowing to me.
Spiced chicken was awesome and quite tasty.
Meat Sauce & Rice was a nice touch to the meal.

I really enjoyed this home-cooked style meal, in fact eating at the counter felt like I was a part of their kitchen in a way. The people working there are so generous and nice, it's fairly easy to start a conversation with them. I couldn't finish my #5 entree so I got a to-go box and I'm eating it right now!
author: Jeffrey C.

description:
Ah... where to start with this shame of a hole in the wall. 

Don't get me wrong. I like hole in the walls. I love them, I yearn - yes yearn - for them. But this one was a shock. 

First, let's talk cleanliness. I know hole in the walls aren't known for their hygiene but this is the first time I've felt uncomfortable eating somewhere because I'm scared of food poisoning. This is from someone who has just lived in Korea for the last 3 years, and most hole in the walls there don't understand what a health code is. But this is the first time I've experienced a place where I felt like they're deliberately being dirty. The sauces and pots and crusted over and the food is all unrefrigerated and pre-cooked with flies swarming around them. Cooked and recooked and left to cool and then cooked again. That's the best way to explain what they serve. 

Second, food quality. The driest food I've had so far. Their kebobs are simply Korean style pork steak. Their "spices" on the chicken is undetectable. Their rolls are overpriced overly greasy on the border of rotting pieces of flour and meat. Their sauces are quick mixtures of frozen condensed sauce which for some reason doesn't even have the flavor associated with such greasy food. Their "meat sauce" which is really just a watery version of Asian curry was the worst I've had so far. 

Third, their service. Ok... so they were nice enough. I guess. But it took 30 mins to make my food when there was only one order ahead of mine. Took their sweet time to even put the meat on the grill. 

Fourth, price. The price wasn't that cheap. It's a hole in the wall. So I expected a lot of food for a low price but the only reason that it was filling was all the white rice they give you. Not enough of their "meat sauce" or Asian curry as I would call it to cover the portion of rice and a very small amount of real meat. I would forgo the rolls and focus only on the chicken if I wanted my money's worth. 

I wouldn't go as far as to say, "Don't ever go here" but I would definitely not go there if there were other options available or someone else wanted it.
author: Dominic C.

description:
I read all the great reviews and since I LOVED Vietnamese food, I was hoping this was going to be a good meal.

The meat sauce was weird, tasted like the sauce came out of a can with some grounded meat thrown in.  The rice was also gross, it was mushy under all that meat sauce.

The 5 spice chicken was ok. And the chicken wasn't freshly grilled because when she pulled it out, it was already cooked, she was just warming it up.   The lady burnt parts of the edges and I saw her cut the crispy black pieces off while it was on the grill- seriously, I'm watching!  

Not a place I'd go back in for superb Vietnamese food when there's so many other great venues a hop skip away.
author: Sfcitygirl M.

description: Easy to order and delicious to eat! This hole in the wall has a small menu of various specialty chicken dishes, meat sauce on rice and salads. I've tried a few things on the menu including chicken salad and imperial rolls. The chicken salad is a delicious mix of cabbage, shredded chicken, carrots & mint. The dressing is has a sweet but hot taste that brings out the best flavor in all the ingredients. The imperial roll is crispy and full of flavor dipped with a great side sauce. I'm excited to go back and try more meals from here!
author: Josefine M.

description: Vermicelli noodle bowl with chicken had a ton of fresh hot chicken in it. Delish! Glad I yelped this place b/c it's definitely somewhere I might not have gone in otherwise (read: dive).
author: michele v.

description:
Man this place is good. I've been here a couple times and enjoyed the 5 spice chicken lunch special.

Today I was especially hungry and got the entree (which really means an extra piece of chicken).

Simply delicious from start to finish.

I used the bathroom today for the first time, and while it was the smallest room I've ever peed in, it was clean. so thumbs up.
author: james m.

description:
First of all, I'm so surprised that I don't yet have a review for my beloved "chicken place," since I've been there 20+ times.  I was planning on doing a review update, but I guess I'll be writing my first review!

I found this place when I first moved to San Francisco after seeing a movie at Lumiere.  The ambiance is not so nice, but the woman working the evening shift behind the counter is so sweet and friendly and the food is to die for. I actually prefer the laid back atmosphere. I've even been on two dates here (I recommended it of course).  

I always, ALWAYS get the #4 with all white meat chicken, extra meat sauce, and an imperial roll.  This is enough food for two days (or two meals) for $10.  Pretty cheap!  It's also BYO, so feel free to bring in some beers or a bottle of wine.  Usually, everything is so well prepared.  The only not excellent meal I received was on Saturday.  Yes, I was in hangover hell and really needed my beloved chicken place to pull through, but they didn't.  My chicken arrives and I open up the box to find on one piece of chicken (they always give you two) over the usual white rice, without EXTRA meat sauce and the meat sauce was bland! I was soooo distraught, like all day. I'm serious.

So, I guess I'm going to have to give Cordon Bleu four stars instead of five, just b/c of this experience. Next time, impress me again and I'll change my rating to five. I still love you Cordon Bleu, I'm just sad.
author: Jenny W.

description:
The five spice chicken and country salad are the only things worth getting here. The meat sauce is an awful spaghetti sauce-like concoction that they drown your rice in. Opt out. The "shish kebab" is overly char-grilled slabs of meat (not cubes). Opt out. The imperial roll is simply awful - enormous and tastes funky (maybe kept frozen too long?). Opt out. 

Hubby and I split the #5 (about $8) and it was still too much food because half of it was less tasty than Chef Boyardee. You will stink like the grill by the time you leave. Definitely a hole in the wall. Nice staff so I'm sorry to leave so few stars.
author: Marina N.

description:
Man, Vietnamese comfort food at its best.  While there really are only 5 options on the menu, maybe 12 seats in the restaurant with barely any walking room, and seating at the bar being 2 feets away from the grill, the food speaks for itself here.  Tons of rice with some sort of mysterious crack gravy, spiced chicken that's straight off the grill, and huge imperial rolls that will make my mouth water for days.  Oh, all for about $10 too.

My only gripe and reason why this isn't a 5 star place for me is that I felt that the chicken could have had a tiiiiiiiiny bit more taste and juiciness.
author: Jeff N.

description: Amazing vietnamese combo plates (get the 5!) for a great price. Cash only. Tiny place so get there early.  Plenty of food to fill you up or take home as leftovers.
author: Detoxreto X.

description:
This yelp is about the karma of tipping. And five-spice roasted chicken.

I don't have a standard policy when it comes to tipping when getting takeout. If the service is great and/or the person helping me does something a little extra, like swapping a side or being very accommodating with my requests, I usually tip. But if it's nothing special and I've saved them the trouble of waiting on me and doing dishes and all that, I often don't. All depends.

This afternoon at Cordon Bleu, I was faced with a tipping dilemma. The lady helping me wasn't exactly friendly, more indifferent, but she was giving off a warm smile to customers she seemed to know well. Maybe you have to be a repeat visitor to get her smile. Her tip jar was full, and since I wasn't charged tax, figured why not, let's get some karma points.

I'm so glad I did. Because I got home and discovered that my five-spice roasted chicken was not one but two massive pieces of outstanding goodness. Seriously enough for two meals, unless you're like me and are too tempted by the smell and taste and decide to eat some right away. So good.

Had I not tipped I might have gone back to correct my mistake. And maybe on that second visit I would have gotten a smile. I think one day I'll go find out.
author: Jason B.

description:
This place is a serious hole-in-the wall joint, and I love it! There is bar seating, and probably 2 tables in the back, so be prepared to wait if you go during peak hours.

Not only is it inexpensive, the plates are good. Kind of reminds me of a home cooked meal, where everything is piled on to a plate. This is some serious Vietnamese comfort food. I usually get the Garlicky tofu which is really good for all you vegetarians out there. The chicken and pork dishes are tender and juicy. Not dry at all.

The owner is very nice, and is a great multi-tasker. You see her cooking, then handling the cash register, then cleaning up... I have always walked out of this place with a happy tummy :)
author: Nadia M.

description:
Yay we got a table when we came!  Counter was all full.. awkward standing behind people @ the bar.  But, YAY we got a table!

People at counter got served before me and they arrived later than I did..  Got the COMBO #5 w/5 spice chicken, shish kebab, an imperial roll and rice w/ meat sauce. 

The chicken was delicious, tender and juicy and I actually ate the skin.  The shish kebab, also delicious.  I remember the imperial roll to be much better about 10 years ago.  Oh well.  Did not care for the meat sauce at all but the bf seemed to really enjoy it.  

Bf got a noodle dish, traditional vietnamese fo sho.  He said it was good.  I was still put-off by the meat sauce so I couldn't tell.

I remember this place to be a 5 star many years ago and I guess after many years, many things change.  Too bad!  Bf liked it though!
author: Kimiko Q.

description:
Bring cash and don't wear anything you aren't planning to launder in short order. You'll smell like your dinner long after it's finished but the meat sauce over rice alone is worth the stench!

If you're claustrophobic, don't eat meat or require a side of ambiance at every meal, DO NOT come here.

However, if you now and again appreciate cheap, tasty BBQ (especially 5 spice chicken) and don't mind bellying up to a crowded counter to get it, COME HERE!
author: Miriam W.

description: Gotta love hole-in-the-wall restaurants with a large following! I happened to walk by Cordon Bleu while on my way to Wreck Room. It smelled awesome. I knew what I was having for dinner that night! And what better food to have after a few drinks!?! Although the wait was a little long, the food was well worth it! Great food, good price, friendly service. 5-stars well deserved!
author: Stephen Y.

description:
First of all I want to clear something up. This restaurant is NOT Vietnamese. They don't even speak the language. Just because there are rice, 5 spice seasoning, egg rolls, and fish sauce does not mean vietnamese, but more like Asian cuisine.  

We had a craving for Vietnamese food and since this place had such great reviews, we decided to give it a try. I agree the portions are massive but really no great taste. Chicken burnt and can't really taste the 5 spice seasoning. Ladies are nice, place is tiny, portions are large, but that's about it.
author: Ilikefood N.

description: Cathy is it when it come to good food and customer service. I have been going to her for about 30 years. Great price . It has been the same after all these years. It is served in generous portions and with love. You can taste the love and care that comes with its preparation. Sorry no photo this time . I was so hungry , I ate the evidence. I have since moved to Las Vegas and I make sure I go there every time I'm in town.
author: Jolens V.

description: I used to frequent a similar establishment in North Beach, but I have to admit, Cordon Bleu is just better on all accounts. The noodle salad is great and honestly enough for two meals (for me at least). It's your typical vietnamese noodle salad with the bbq pork, noodles, veggies, fish sauce, and imperial rolls. However, these rolls are some of the best I've ever had. The service is nice and friendly and the space is a lot cleaner than what I'm used to from my former haunt. If you want no frills Vietnamese food, this is the spot...
author: Nicolas H.

description:
So I'm giving this place three stars because the Cordon Bleu has a soft spot in my heart.  When I first visited San Francisco, my cousin (who had been there for 25 years) took me here, told me this was one of the first places he had eaten at when he moved there.  I was impressed.  Their five-spice chicken was tasty (not spicy, but definitely flavorful and not gamey like chicken can get), and I had an imperial roll that was pretty good.  You can get a meat sauce accompaniment but I never remember there being "meat" in it (it could just be chicken or beef based, but I don't ask, they don't tell ha ha).  OK fast forward a few years later.  This time they have "combos" with the chicken, rice, meat sauce, roll and shish kebab.  I have to say, I really like their shish kebab.  I'm not a kebab fan normally but it was tasty. The chicken is what I remember.  The service, eh, you get what you pay for, which is very little (my husband and I can get FOUR meals out of the two we order what we pay for around $20).  

Here's the kicker though: in NYC they've started this "grading" initiative where local restaurants and food establishments have to hang their sanitary department grades in their window.  Needless to say, they have strict standards and if you "failed" you will be a) shut down until you pass and b) if you have a C chances are, you don't want to advertise that.  The last time we were there, my husband and I got a little skeeved about their sanitary practices.  Using the same scissors over and over to cut the chicken, cut the shish kebabs and cut the imperial rolls.  They don't have sinks up front to clean them at the ready.  we were amused though, because after a while, my husband said, "Would this place last in NY?" I said, "No they'd be shut down in 20 seconds!"  

I'm over the Cordon Bleu, I've made it a point to go there the last few times I was in town.  But I may have to put it aside, until SF gets all NYC on them and makes them clean up their act.
author: Taryn C.

description:
The grilled meat dishes were really well made.  The deliciously marinated chicken/beef/pork were grilled to perfection right before your eyes.  The red/tomato with pepper sauce they put on top of the meat and rice reminded me the sauces of the Hong-Kong-ness restaurants. Menu was small comparing with the usual vietnamese/pho restaurant.  

Keep in mind that this place is very smoky.  Some has mentioned that this place felt like you were eating in a kitchen.  That was literally true!  The grills was set in the dinning room and despite seemingly good ventilation system, we smelt like grilled meat on our way out.  The place was quite "romantic" because of the strong smoke added to the "mystique".   Basically, do not wear your "dry clean only" clothes here unless you plan to wash them anyway.

Service was slow and the service people intentionally avoid eye contact when the place got really busy.   I think the people who ordered take out were pretty smart.
author: Ka P.

description:
This is a major whole in the wall. I just wonder if the health dept. has inspected this place lately.  The food storage is not so cool.  Food on the floor with open containers, roaches flying all over.  So don't expect excellent decor and it is dirty. They need to wash the walls and ceiling from all the grease that has accumulated there.  I have eaten there twice and I did not get sick, I just felt bloated from the excessive portions of food.

)  Small seating about  16  ( a few small table plus the counter).
2)  Whole in the wall that need a renovation
3)  Hefty Portions especially the rice
3)  Gppd spicy chicken but is not consistent.
4)  The Kitchen is open and you can view the food being prepared.  It is not a pretty sight.  They don't use stand sanitation with the cooking utensils and such.  
5)  Not a lot of ventilation so you smell when you leave.
6)  The bathroom has a lot to be desired.  Yuck.  Go to the restroom if you decide to you go there and take your chances on the health element of your food..  
7)  Food is cheap most is under $10, plus the tip.

I wonder about food storage and cooking preparation.  It really scary.  I won't go back there ever.  Two time was enough especially after the second time when I saw roaches in there.
author: Vanilla C.

description:
Since Cordon Bleu is relatively close to my place, I passed it a few times and noticed it was always packed=good sign #1. A sign outside touting 5 spice chicken=good sign #2. And yet, I left mildly dissatisfied. I wish I knew who advised them to put the "Best Chicken outside of Vietnam" on the menu. I enjoy heat and am known for my seasoning skills so I expected some serious flavor here but I didn't get it. 

Maybe I built it up in my mind, but my chicken, rice with meat sauce (blech) and imperial roll (tasty but its fried so it better be) was really disappointing. I came home looking forward to being "bleun" away.

With that said, since its close and the cute guy waiting for his food at the counter suggested a few other tasty things on the menu, so I'll try those out before I write CB off totally.
author: Lesly S.

description: I was really pleased with both my meal and the portions of said meal. The chicken was great but I'd pass on the pork and opt for another one of their delicious egg rolls instead.
author: Misha T.

description:
This place Cordon Bleu my mind!

I never would have expected it from the outside. This place looks like a dump from both the inside and outside, like a ghost of a short order diner from the 60s. A handful of stools are around the counter, and two tables in the back by the door to the clean, closet-sized restroom. Meat is grilled before your eyes, and surplus grilled chicken rests in trays just an inch or two above the floor behind the counter. Not too sanitary looking.

But the food is cheap, delicious, and served in bountiful portions. Good, hot tea served in diner mugs.

My group ordered two of the lunch specials (imperial roll and chicken) and a chicken salad. The chicken was freshly grilled and succulent. It was served over a mountain of rice that had been slathered on a mild orange meat sauce. Pickled cabbage was on the side. The imperial rolls were crispy and served with a small bowl of vinegar sauce. My friend's chicken salad looked delicious: a big bed of cabbage, diced chicken, crumbled peanuts, mint (or cilantro?), and a tangy sauce.

Everyone seems to recommend lunch combo 5 which includes both grilled chicken and imperial rolls. But it's a ton of food. Come hungry and leave obese if you go this route.
author: Nik D.

description: This place was suggested to me by a coworker and this was one great suggestion.  This place serves large portions but besides the portions, the food taste excellent and made-to-order.  All the people inside are friendly and even the customers seem to be regulars which is what I will become now that i got put on to this place.  Thanks for always preparing a "home cooked" meal for me.
author: Eric L.

description:
Sure, there are better places in San Francisco to eat, but on the value equation this place deserves 100 stars. 

For about $12 you get a full meal and imperial roll that will either feed the following: 
1 really hungry man
4 skinny girls
or 
My boyfriend & I

Takeout is great or if there's a game nearby it's not as packed. 

What do I love about it? The meat sauce (on the rice)....yeah the meat sauce!
author: Melissa M.

description:
Some of the best non-pho Vietnamese food I've ever had! A true San Francisco experience - hole-in-the-wall counter seating, cooks right in front of you and cheap!

Chicken here is really good, but I'm sure everything is. That mystery meat sauce is disgustingly delicious. $5 can get you really full here.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
Lot's of food for great prices. I got the raved about number five because it comes with everything and everything was great. It comes with an imperial role, a piece of five spice chicken, some steak, and rice with meat sauce. My wife got the chicken salad which was also good. Entres were around $8 a piece. It's a ton of food so next time I'll split the number 5 with my wife.

It's a small place with not much seating so it's probably better to grab it to go. If you do eat there though you can byob.
author: G S.

description:
What a great find!  From the moment you see it, it has signs of great promise.  It is a hole in the wall (like, if you had to dig a hole in the wall, it would not take you too long to dig one this big) that's almost overflowing with people, and they're all not more than 15 feet away from the big grill that is constantly turning out delicious chicken and other things.

The menu tells you this will be quite possibly the best chicken outside Vietnam, haha.  Ok!

I got the chicken salad.  It was the same delicious, flavorful, juicy chicken that's in the other dishes, prepared right in front of you, served over cabbage salad, and sprinkled with peanuts and fish sauce.  Crunchy delicious tasty, but next time I will probably go for one of the other chicken dishes.

Only thing is that it wasn't as quick as I thought it would be.  However, since it's got very limited seats, the woman running the place is happy to take phone orders.

Great food, cheaper than most things nearby.
author: David W.

description:
Testament:  When I'm mad at the boyfriend, he knows that a trip to Cordon Bleu will almost always make me forgive and forget any transgession we were bickering about.

How can I not?!  I only wish I could learn how to simultaneously breathe while I scarf down the goodness that is the #5.
author: Clarissa P.

description:
I was disappointed not to see a single cockroach on my visit -- lord know that's what you'd expect if you took some of the silly reviews here seriously from people who are confused about the distinction between fine dining and fine food.  

Well, the Cordon Bleu has fine food rather than fine dining.  It's BYOMD -- or Bring Your Own Matre'D, and don't bother signalling for the sommelier.  He won't come.  So order a vermicelli bowl, and enjoy your meal!
author: Laurence W.

description: The food here is quite tasty. My sister was around the area and ordered take out back to the office. Thanks to Yelpers I ended up getting the #5 combo which included eggrolls, grilled pork, chicken and rice with meat sauce. The pork looked kind of dry in the beginning but after taking a bite it wasnt that bad! The portions were huge- we ended up sharing.
author: M W.

description: Excellent. I would leave a one word review if yelp would let me, but they won't. Cordon bleu is quite possibly the most delicious dining option in nob hill...definitely my favorite. The imperial rolls and kebabs are an experience unlike any other...but that meat sauce tho...what a treat.
author: Alex K.

description:
I would like to give more stars! I love 5 spice chicken, but this isn't 5 spice...in fact, I didn't taste ANY spice at all. This was just average grilled chicken. Not terrible, just not 5 spice. Also, seems like the chicken is already cooked and is just heated up on the grill. I had dark meat, so it wasn't too dry. The "meat sauce" has a processed food taste and the rice gets drowned in this sauce, which I didn't like. Too soupy. The average "country salad" is basically cole slaw without the mayo. 

I think I prefer more authentic Vietnamese food. 

There are only two tables and a counter with 7 or 8 seats. Very tiny place. The service was fine.
author: James B.

description: Wow! Great portions for your money! The chicken has soooo much flavor & the Imperial Rolls are YUMMY!! The rice & gravy just make it divine...I have to come back and try the pork chops, actually I have to come back and try everything on the menu. It's a little hole in the wall & you might have to wait a bit for the food, but worth it!
author: Monica C.

description:
Talk about a hole in the wall. As you know, those places are usually the BEST or...just nasty. Good thing is place was up to par with the 4 star review. When you come in, you find that there is NO place to sit! Either be prepared to wait or be smart like those SFers who called in for a take-out (which you may have to wait a bit as well). There's maybe 10 counter seats and 6 at tables. 

They have their grill at the counter so you can watch them cook! Everything looked so good. We tried the famous chicken, which was surprisingly tender and very flavorful with spices. The kebob meat was SOOOO GOOD! We didnt have time to wait for an order of it but she kindly gave us a piece to try and it was MMMM MMMMM GOOD!!!!
The rice with meat sauce was also delicious!! Just the right amount of meat with their sauce because sometimes too much meat just makes it too heavy or too...meaty. They serve their plates with pickled cabbage which is a great balance.

I really want to go back to try their imperial rolls! Everyone around us who ate it made it look like it was heavenly. Also their Asian cuisine dishes like Cha-siu (pork) noodle looked SOOOOO FREAKIN' GOOD!

Anyway, will come back again to try more. The price is decent, around $6.50-8.00. I just like how Cantonese people are heading up this great Vietnamese place. Oh you Chinese people...

Cordon Bleu into mi heart...
author: Jennifer C.

description: The pricing and amount of food were great.  The meat was good but the gravy sauce was a bit lackluster.  Still, I like the ladies that run the place and the ambiance so I would come back.
author: Kurosh H.

description:
THIS PLACE BLEU ME AWAY.

I was torn between giving it four stars or five stars.  I ordered the number 5, five spice chicken with shish kebab and imperial roll, "country salad" and meat sauce over rice.
