It was a heaping plate of delicious food for something like $8/$8.50ish.  Imperial roll was hot and crisp and stayed hot the whole meal (I give it a 5).  The chicken was a half chicken, and deliciously seasoned (I give it a 5).  The kabab wasn't as moist and flavorful as I wanted, but still very tasty (I give it a 4).  The meat sauce over rice...well, it's good but kinda weird.  I felt like I was eating canned soup poured over rice.  Don't get me wrong, it was tasty, but in that I'm-not-100%-sure-what-I'm eating sort of way.  (I give it a 3).

This place is a true "hole in the wall", not much for atmosphere.  A lunch counter with about 9 to 10 seats, plus two small tables in the back.  There were a LOT of regulars there, eating and and taking out, so clearly this place has a following.

The menu has some vegetarian items on it, but not many - I'd say it's veggie-doable, but not necessarily veggie-friendly.

I will go back, for sure, and I won't hesitate to bring friends.
author: Dave M.

description:
Not sure if I can say 'Meh, I've experienced better' of exactly what's served here, but as far as hole-in-the-wall homecooked Asian fare of some variety, yes, MEH.  

Everything falls under bland, dry or both. Exception: Imperial roll was nice & greasy & packed with stuff.  Chicken & kebab & cabbage salad are in the very bland, very dry territory.  Rice & gravy are very bland, though given it's gravy, gets a pass on the dry.

See a lot of responses that it's so much food for $10 on the combo plates.  Going to disagree here, unless you want 3 meals of rice & sauce, which you could certainly eek out of the styrofoam plate.  As far as protein goes, your good for one helping.

The place was clean, not too busy & staff was friendly.  Good mix of local characters.  Really unclear what desensitized palate thinks this is good eats?
author: Talia R.

description:
Oh the "Gordon Blue".  Definitely the best hole-in-wall Vietnamese place I have been to in San Francisco yet.

Their 5-spice grilled chicken is just so special.  Hard to define why, but so good!  I've had it most times (usually split a plate with a dining companion).

In fact, it is definitely a "bring a friend" place as you'll want to try more than one dish.  Take, for example, the Imperial Egg Roll the size of a junk.

And the meat sauce on rice is just delicious.

A great place at a great price.
author: Francis U.

description:
What's not to like about this place? 

This place has tasty food, friendly service, giant proportions and all at a good price.

Definitely coming back here time and time again.
author: Kevin O.

description:
The chicken was extremely good and nicely grilled to perfection. The seasonings (which honestly you could probably purchase at any Asian grocery store, 5-spice seasoning) were just the right amount and with everything chargrilled to perfection, it's just too hard to say no.

My biggest complaint, too much water in the rice. The mushy stuff tasted like school cafeteria rice, it really doesn't need to be that jook-like man. I also would've liked their cha gio more if it was less thick on the wrapper.

I would just supercede the process of figuring it out and order extra meat sauce immediately. I have no idea what in the world that stuff is but do you really ever ask when you're in an Asian hole in the wall? There are 4 tables and maybe 8 seats across the bar. I would suggest getting it to go or be extremely patient. It is just down the street from Bob's donuts so it is a viable option. Dessert before dinner? Why not!? It is the new year =)

So enjoy, don't expect crazy much, but it's price to portion to quality ratio is superb! Large amount of food, decent quality, and $6?!

Remember, get extra meat sauce!
author: Winè C.

description: I've been eating at Le Cordon Bleu since the early 1970s -- its longevity a testament to the wonderful food, and as a Taurus I stick with what I like!  The original owners sold it to Katie a few years back and gave her their secret recipes, and she has maintained the quality and added an extra warm dimension with her personality!  The 5-spice chicken is the BEST in the city (and beyond), the salad (cabbage, carrots, mint, onion and peanuts) is super fresh and refreshing, the imperial and spring rolls are sooooo yummy, and if you're on a tight budget there's nothing better than the rice with meat sauce ... all at prices that are hard to believe in this day and age!!  My only reservation in recommending it is that is already too popular!!!
author: Kathleen M.

description:
One of my favorite hole in the wall type restaurants. Aren't those type of restaurants always the best?! LOL. I always love those places that only San Franciscan diners would know about. 

Anyway... on the food. #6 combo is definitely worth a try. Very hearty, filling and you get the most for what you pay for. The chicken is *sigh* heaven. Tender & juicy... not at all dry. Just how I like my chicken! The meat sauce over rice is also what I think makes this plate so tasty! Also comes with a slab of meat, imperial roll and slaw. The slaw is great. Gives such a hearty meaty meal some balance and a bit of freshness. 

will be bringing my friends that are visiting out of town here for a real San Francisican dining experience =O)
author: Crystal S.

description:
The place is small and not the cleanest place. I came here the other day to try something new. There were 8 counter spots and 3 small tables in the back. The counter, tables and even the utensils were not very clean.

The food tasted nothing like what one would think with the name Cordon Bleu. The food tasted more like stuff out of a Vietnamese home. They have one grill for their meats and one wok for everything else, so food is kind of slow. Even the tap water that they gave us tasted funny. The portions were the only good part of the place. The portions are huge.
author: M C.

description:
Some restaurants arent for everyone. There's nothing wrong with that. This may be a prime example.

The place is tiny, counter service with a grill behind it. Great to look at but your clothes will come out smelling of bbq smoke.

The food, well, the portions are generous, tasty, a bit on the heavy side. The entrees are under $10. The meat sauce is very tasty but the roll tasted like a breaded condom.

If you like hole-in-the wall type places with limited menus than give it a try. If you like more traditional type restaurants then id say skip it. Everyones happy!
author: Ash S.

description: This is one of my favorite Bay Area restaurant. I got #5 which had everything: chicken, imperial roll, pork, meat sauce and everything was delicious. The meal was so big that I was able to split it among two people and as a result my pants were a snug. Every time when I am around the area I think about this place and how i miss the chicken and imperial rolls. The place is very tiny, sorta like an old diner where you just sit at the counter top to eat. There's two asian mamas who does all the cooking. I wish I could take one home so they can cook for me all day long.
author: Victoria C.

description:
THE BEST KABOB. I love the meat sauce. I go here every week. 

The salad is good also!

The chicken is a bit dry tho.

I love that they give a lot of portions. I end up stuffing my face so fast, I don't finish. But I love taking it home and eating like a fat ass later!
author: John P.

description: Tiny hole in the wall in Polk Gulch with recipes perfected long ago. Belly up and get comfortable. Simple menu. Everything on the menu is very affordable (under $10), especially lunch specials. Enough food in dishes for two meals. Excellent chicken. Meat sauce compliments rice and meats nicely. Food prepared within feet of your seat, no secrets here. Nice, friendly owner who genuinely wants to see you leave pleased and come back again.
author: Kill P.

description:
JB, you'd be proud of my cave man diet after an 8.5 mile run! The chicken salad hit the spot. The chicken skin is delicious and full of flavor. And the fish sauce used for the salad made even lettuce acceptable. (I hate lettuce salads...) 

The take out of shredded chicken on a bed of lettuce took 20+ minutes, minus one.
author: Dee Y.

description: Homestyle food. Huge portions. A bit like a tiny cafeteria - but welcoming and warm. Had the #1 combo plate and it was great :)
author: Tara K.

description: Real Vietnamese Home Cooking -relieved my tough day. I'm not one that really likes holes in the wall because I typically found they're  not as good as people say and you're stuck with a lousy atmosphere. This is the exception to the rule.  I was skeptical both on the neighborhood and look, and the menu didn't seem to shout out anything interesting, but the food and love with which it was prepared prove me wrong.   It was like having a Vietnamese "Jewish mother". Most of these reviews are about the special chicken plate, but I opted for the Ma Po Tofu and it was the best I've ever had. The portions are in enormous . I was staying in a hotel so I couldn't take on the following night dinner. Even the Tea was wonderful. As soon as the tea was poured my tension relaxed and I sat down and enjoy the meal I'm still thinking about. Go!
author: Joanne R.

description:
food's good, but i just realized that the special sauce is strained canned pork and beans, intriguing ... 
Remember, its a cash-only joint and it's pretty small, be prepared to go elbow to elbow with your fellow diner.
author: Alex C.

description: I love this place. It has a lot of character, Katy the owner is very friendly. The food is very good, I always have the chicken salad which has always been a delight. I do recommend Cordon Bleu highly.
author: Guido W.

description: This is the best meal in town!!!  This little hole in the wall spot is as good as it gets - delicious, cheap & Katie is the most adorable cook/owner you could hope for. If you're in the mood for a dive style restaurant and a big meal.. this hits the spot
author: Siiana A.

description: The #5 is great - chicken is so tender, great flavor too.  The imperial roll tastes like deep fried meatloaf, in a delicious sort of way.  I was a bit apprehensive about the rice from Yelp photos, but it's just white rice with a tomato-based sauce, definitely good stuff.
author: Bryce T.

description:
When you first walk into this place you might be a little suspect, trust me don't be.

THIS IS BY FAR THE BEST MEAL IN SAN FRAN!  Order the #5 and sit back and watch the lady behind the counter do magic.  The Chicken was moist and as good of chicken as I've ever had! The price was very cheap, and I plan on going back veryyy veryyy soon!
author: John F.

description:
Pros:
-Cheap
-Tasty
-Friendly staff
-large portions

Cons:
-SMALL menu
-not much seating inside
-you leave smelling like old food

Next time I'll head up Polk to Miller's.
author: Jessica L.

description: Asian home cooking at an affordable price in a clean, homey hole in the wall. Seemed very popular for takeout, but we sat down at the bar and had a nice meal.
author: Ryo C.

description: Okay... Parking sucks but this place is awesome!!!  It is super small in there so don't expect to be able to sit in there.  Their egg rolls are deeeeelicious!  The meat sauce on the rice is soo good!!  It is weird that they pull the marinated chicken out of a bucket thats sitting beneath a counter but hey....tastes great!!
author: Sherry M.

description: I love this place.  Cheap, huge portions and yummers.  It's a hole in the wall with limited seating so you may want to consider going early or late or calling in and picking up.  Menu is limited, but it's not like you need the options.  Just get the chicken with rice and meat sauce and start shoveling.
author: Sharon W.

description: So I just moved to SF and stumble upon this gem and fell in love with it!!  Its a small run operation by Katie the owner who is an absolutely awesome! the food is great, you  can get a #5 which is 3 pieces of pork and a piece of either white or dark meat chicken, the best imperial rolls in town, and a mountain of rice with her secret recipe meat sauce! Warning it is ALOT! but taste great as leftovers the next day as well! they do not sale beer here but Katie is cool with you doing a BYOB run to the liquor store in the corner and knocking a couple down while you eat! if you like a good homemade food like your grandma would make for you and not paying a crazy amount of money for it this is the place to be!
author: David L.

description: If you want home cooking, great prices, yummy yummy food, and the most wonderful owner, Katie, you must must must must try this.  Visually your will go "huh" but once you eat her grilled meat and imperial rolls, you come back a lot !!!  Thank you Katie for keeping it good and simple!
author: Cindy S.

description: LOVE this place! We drive from San Mateo just to dine here! Small hole in the wall kinda place with excellent flavorful food! Generous portions to top it off! Highly recommend!
author: Dave T.

description:
I live pretty close to this place, and it always smells amazing so I finally decided to check it out. I ordered the #5 so that I could see what this place is all about. It came with Chicken (pick a breast or leg), Beef Strips (Shish Kebob) and an Imperial Roll and Rice smothered in their Meat Sauce.

The cool part is that they cook everything up right in front of you. Or, it kind of looks like they grill it up in front of you, but it was previously roasted or something. Either way, it's going to be fresh. I noticed that the cook was snipping off some of the gristle (burnt stuff) from my chicken with a pair of scissors. I love me some tasty gristle, so I was a little disappointed and wanted to ask her not to do that. It turns out she was only cutting off a few small pieces of extra black gristle, so it was okay... i guess. 

I opened up the massive plate when I got home and started with the chicken. It was pretty good but the chicken wasn't that big so it left me wanting more. I guess this isn't the restaurant's fault, but I really like big portions. The beef strips were tender, juicy and grilled well - pretty delicious and probably the best part of the meal. 

The imperial roll.... I've never really been a huge fan of egg rolls because they're greasy and make me feel disgusting. This was no exception - it's HUGE! Hard to say, since I'm not a fan of egg rolls in general, but I took one bite and left it alone.

I'm also not a huge fan of the meat sauce drowning my rice to death. I'm somewhat of a purist when it comes to my rice, but I thought I'd give it a try since it was my first time. I'd definitely ask for WAY less meat sauce next time, get it on the side or even ask for none altogether. It was nothing for me to get excited about. 

I got my order to go, but the service was pretty good from what I could tell. Overall, the food was good, but I still don't know how it can smell that DELICIOUS and just be "pretty good" food. I'd probably give this place an extra star if I went back and only got the Chicken and Beef and Rice without meat sauce.
author: Matthew L.

description:
vegetarian noodle salad
vegetarian rolls
#4 - two five spiced chicken

i love them. the best chicken ever. just thinking about it makes me happy.

who cares if the place is dumpy - if that makes those "ionlyeatataplacethatispretty" away - i am all for it.
author: Dot K.

description:
I haven't eaten at Cordon Bleu for years -- usually because it has been too crowded when I thought about eating there -- but I always remembered it as a place where you can get a really BIG and tasty meal for cheap.  Nothing has changed on that front. 

My favorite Chinese restaurant on Polk St. (Sam's Cafe) was closed for a week and I was trying to figure out where else to eat.  I was hungry and in the mood for roast chicken. So, I walked down to the tiny restaurant at California and Polk next to the Lumiere movie house and took a seat at the counter.  

CB is definitely a 'dive" and almost always crowded because there are only 9 seats at the counter and only one table for 2 and another for 4 in the "back."   The grill and stove are so close you could just reach over the counter and touch them if you wanted to.    

As with most popular small restaurants -- like CB & Swan's around the corner -- the best strategy for getting a seat is to go early or late.  Otherwise, you're likely to have to stand in line before you can be seated. I happened to walk in late in the afternoon after the lunch crowd had already left and there were only 2 other customers at the counter.  So, getting a seat was not a problem.  

Parking is another matter because it's all metered (along and w/in a block of Polk)  and most spaces are taken, but you can usually find a space on the opposite side of California St between Larkin and Polk or on Sacramento or Clay between Polk and Larkin.  If you're going for lunch and make it quick, you can also try parking for FREE in the garage below the Wells Fargo on California St near Van Ness, which has an attendant -- who's there mainly to assist cars leaving the garage and as far as I know doesn't keep tabs on how long you're parked there or whether you actually go into the bank.

I briefly looked over the menu but I already knew what I wanted and ordered Combo #4 -- which really isn't a combo -- which offers half a chicken on rice w/their rough cut cole slaw for $7.95.  They precook the chicken and the waitress/cook (owner?) grabbed 2 big pieces of chicken -- breast/wing  and thigh/drumstick -- out of a container under the counter and plopped then down on the grill and when they were done laid them on top of a HUGE pile of rice laced w/their signature  tomato based "meat" flavored sauce that they put on everything along w/the cole slaw.

i'd forgotten how generous they were w/the servings and was wondering if "d be able to finish it all.  No problem there!.  The chicken was GREAT -- hot, tender and juicy. Didn't really taste any "five spice" seasoning on it -- at least no hint of anise -- but whatever the seasoning was was very tasty and I finished off the entire 1/2 bird right down to the bones.   I then cleaned my plate of all of the rice and slaw.   Yum!!

I can't say I'm a "fan" of CB because I seldom eat here, but it's definitely A-Ok and if you're in the mood for some roast chicken -- as i was ---head straight to CB  for a cheap, tasty and filling meal!
author: Martin C.

description:
Wonderful surprise.  This place is your proverbial hole in the wall.  The lunch counter seats 8 -10 people and there are two additional tables in the back.  There were two ladies behind the counter cooking away, one on a large grill for the meat, the other one cooking the rice and sauces and helping out.  


We were looking for some fare on the lighter side and we loved it,  I had the chicken salad and my hubby had the mixed meat plate (#5 I think) and our meals were just delicious.  

The meats were cooked on the oversize grill.  The salad was served with chicken and a phenomenal Asian salad dressing. Hubby loved the meats (beef, pork, a fried roll )served over rice with a sauce).  The pork was sliced thinly and seasoned really well.  I was not a fan of the sauce, the plate could have stood just as well over white rice.

We had a yummy lunch all for under $25.
author: Maria S.

description:
I'd heard so much about this place and I finally got the chance to go...

It was good...

Since I wasn't sure if I'd get the chance to come back again I got #5, the menu selection with the following items:

-Imperial Roll
-Meat Kebab (Beef)
-5-Spice Chicken (Leg and Thigh)
-Meat Sauce (?)
-Rice

The imperial roll was fantastic - cooked just right and full of flavor; the meat kebab were thin slices of grilled beef, which were pretty good; the chicken was a decent portion and was cooked all the way through (thankfully!) and did have some decent flavor; the meat sauce...sorry, I really didn't like this - it doesn't have a lot flavor and I'm kinda scared to know what's in it...

Overall, this place was good, but not great.  I'd suggest coming here if you happen to be in the area and want a big portion of low-priced Vietnamese food.  It's tiny so it's not good for groups, but they cook everything right in front of you and it's nice to see the process of making a meal.

The service is fantastic - the cook/waitress/server was so nice and sweet!
author: Ken G.

description:
I still totally love this place.  

I was meeting an out of town houseguest for her farewell dinner and she chose Cordon Bleu based on my review.  I warned her, hole in the wall, but terrific food.  We agreed to meet at 5 right whe the doors opened.  I got there about 10 minutes prior and she was, naturally late.  So there I stood, outside the open door inhaling the most delictable and ravenous hunger inducing grilled meat scents.  My tummy was seriously growling, it was absolute torture.  I also suffered watching the counter spaces filling up as I waited for my friend.  Augh, would she never arrive?  20 minutes later, she did and we got the last 2 seats in front of the grill.  Thank God!

I already knew what I would order, vermicelli noodle salad.  New (to me) item on the menu and it in no way dissapointed.  It was everything a vietnamese noodles salad should be, filled with noodles, cool and crisp veggies, basil, mint, chopped peanuts and heavenly grilled pork and an imperial roll.  It was a LOT of food in that bowl.  She must have put on 6 pieces of the shish-kebab meat.  

My out of town friend ordered a Number 5 so she got a taste of everything.  She ate the entire plate of food!  She declared everything delicious but was especially enamored of the five-spice chicken, and wjho wouldn't be?  You'd have to be dead or your tatsebuds would have to be dead not to enjoy this place.  

I tasted the meat sauce and thought it not as flavor intense as I remembered from many moons ago. This is not to say it's not good, but I get a very intense black pepper from it.  There is also a cornstarch consistency that I do not remember from before.  

The imperial rolls are still SO fabulous.  So are the grilled meats.  I'm going to pay many return visits to try the new items on the menu (and the old favorites).
author: Donna H.

description: Hefty servings and nicely grilled meats.  The space is pretty small so prepared to wait around in line (or come off hours).  The only issue I have with the place is how they put marinated chicken meats and cha gio on the floor behind the counter.  So don't sit close to the window side if you don't want to witness where your food have been sitting.
author: Koalie W.

description:
I remember vividly how I first discovered this gem of a hole in the wall.

Long ago, it was a few days before prom. Two of my girlfriends and I just finished doing our nails on Polk and we were starving. One of them suggested going to Cordon Bleu and I'm like, "Uhh, the school?!" Then she said, "You'll see..." With a name like that, I expected a really nice ritzy french place. As we walked over to Cali street and into a small ass restaurant, I was like, "Oh hells no" and she was like "Ohhhh yeaah." We ordered food, I fell in love, and the rest is history.

The owner is really nice and also the main cook, or BBQ-er. I remembered (on my first day of discovery) that a homeless man came in with some change and she gave him a BIG heaping of rice and meat sauce. Wow, points for her! I always order the shish kebobs/ imperial rolls and meat sauce with rice. Whatever you order here, it's a full hearty meal that you won't forget, because your clothes will smell like BBQ even after a few washes. Doh!
author: Anita W.

description:
So my girlfriend and I met a few of our friends here the other night. Place looked decent from the outside, kind of like Chez Mama in Potrero, how there is a bar and two small tables. Before my friends arrive I look at the menu to check out the deal before we order. 

Here is where the histeria begins:

1) Mabo Tofu: is not a vietnamese dish, but appears... interesting.
2) "Imperial Roll": is 2.60... interesting.

So, maybe its really good... My girlfriend is japanese, so she eggs me on to ask if they give you two or one per order... so I call the cook/waitress over and ask her... (in vietnamese...) OH! Lo and behold, she doesn't speak vietnamese...

No one, speaks vietnamese here...

Oh, and by the way, its one roll per order... ONE.

We order two... maybe its good, I got to give these Chinese people the benefit of the doubt, maybe they're from N.Vietnam, and are really good at cooking... how do i know?

So in comes my friends, and as they sit, they begin to rave about the 5 Spice Chicken...  We order, 5 spice chicken for everyone with the "meat sauce over rice."

Food arrives...

HIsteria Part 2 begins...

1) Chicken is over cooked, CHARRED.
2) Chicken + "Meat Sauce" = bland, needs salt, needs FISH SAUCE.
3) "Fish Sauce" for Imperial Roll... tastes SWEET... like not FISH SAUCE.

And so I ask for SALT, and they give me soy sauce... I ask for rice, and the woman doesn't speak english...

I ask for FISH SAUCE, and they give me... dipping sauce...

So, I don't really know what everyone else is thinking or what they must be ordering. If you're looking for Vietnamese food, please dear god go back down the street, and get your ass into a Vietnamese restaurant. These chinese people don't have a clue as to what the hell it is to make VIETNAMESE FOOD. 

If you like this place, god help you, and thank god you're not filling the places I frequent for my cuisine.

Oh, and yes, I am Vietnamese.

*boomshakalaka* if I could give this place Negative Stars, oh I would... Oh hell yes, I WOULD.
author: Christopher L.

description: This place is so damn good. You will be completely satisfied with the large amount of food for such a low price. The number 5 killed it with chicken, beef, rice covered in meat sauce and imperial rolls. Mmm
author: Josh Y.

description:
What in God's name are all you people talking about?  This is one of the worst restaurants I've ever been to in my life.  Five spices on the chicken, true.  Four of them are carcinogens, but the other one was quite tasty.

I got a seat when I walked in here and still waited 20 minutes for my food.  The main reason I waited that long is that the women working the grill was absolutely MURDERING the meat.  It was blackened and burnt to a crisp by the time it reached my plate.  It was served on a pile of rice that could feed an entire Vietnamese family, and drenched in a red sauce that had absolutely no taste except for black pepper.

The Chicken was scorched beyond reason, and needless to say was tough.  The shish kebab was also scorched and tough.  The spring rolls were ok I guess.  I watched as she deep fried them, then took them out of the oil, then deep fried them again, then took them out, then deep friend them again.

Beyond that, my lord is this place dirty.  I got a good look behind the counter at the conditions they were cooking in, and it reminded me of the dirtiest street food stalls I ever encountered in Asia.  Maybe you could call it a little too authentic.

I would pay NOT to go here again.  Can't believe people wait in line for this place.  Then again, almost all of them are drunk.
author: Tom R.

description: It can be a bit of an experience dining in - tiny restaurant and the three cooks seem like the Fates, but is recommend more for take out. Service is really slow, but the food is great.  Prices are really reasonable.
author: Justin N.

description:
holy mother of god jumping down the street on a pogo stick this place is good.

miss u cordon bleu!!!
author: dkw ..

description: a cool, tiny old spot with tasty giant portions for cheap. Your meal is cooked right in front of you and the staff is very friendly.
author: Ryan W.

description: Props to the owners here, they make awesome food here. They chicken is good and they offer white meat for an extra dollar for those that are trying to stay lean or on a diet. I've been here twice and only get the 5 spice chicken dish with white meat. The chicken comes with rice, which is a bit on the moist side, meat sauce, which is awesome, and a bit of salad on the side. HUGE PORTIONS. GREAT CUSTOMER SERVICE.
author: John Z.

description:
We decided to come here for lunch today and it was a good lunch.  Bf and I shared Menu Item #5:
1 piece 5 spices chicken
Imperial roll
Shish kebob (2 pieces of meat)
Meat sauce over rice
Side of salad/coleslaw style
for $8.95.

Good deal, was enough for both of us and definitely a nice little cosy restaurant. The two girls spoke Cantonese so I was able to converse with them and I overheard them telling a patron that they have been there for 10+ yrs. How did I know abt this place when it's just a few blocks away? Will be back to try other items on the menu.
author: Yan M.

description:
I would totally give 5/5 if this place is bigger and spacier T-T, and if they accept credit card (just more convenient for me). This sucks for those who want to eat here, but the space is limited.

As for the food, awesome! #5 is the best! They give you a generous amount of bbq meat, rice, salad, and sauce + a huge imperial roll. They taste good too, especially the meat sauce over rice.

The owner cook right in front of you, so you know its authentic and it is. 

I'm so glad that I live so close by Cordon Bleu. Will definitely visit again.
author: May K.

description:
This place is in my neighborhood and while I remember loving the food, somehow it's been a year or more since I've been in.  Finding some company, we ventured in - I already knew I was ordering the 5 Spices Chicken Salad and only hoped it was as yummy as I'd remembered.  It was!  (and now I'm left wondering why I'm not hitting up Cordon Bleu every week).

Big plate of lettuce, cabbage & mint (and maybe basil) - and freshly bbq'd chicken (which you will wait for, because it's cooked when you order your salad), topped with chopped peanuts and a mouth-watering, sweet - yet sharp - vinaigrette of some sort.  It doesn't sound like anything fancy but it's as perfect as a salad can get.

So I mentioned the bbq.  There may have been some some thin strips of pork on the bbq, which turned out to be shishkebab, which turned out to be too enticing to not order (and at $3 for an a la carte order, why the hell wouldn't you?!)  As one might expect, this also turned out to be more than one could finish, when coupled with a giant chicken salad.  But I tried!  And I liked it.  (and I'll do it again, dammit!)  There was a mild teriyaki-ness to the marinade and it was DELISH.  I had to remind myself to use my fork and act like a lady.  Delish.

The only reason I can't give it 5 stars is that the space itself is due for some paint...and probably a little bleach.  But when you're sitting 2.5 feet from a 500 degree grill...and watching dozens upon dozens of pieces of bbq'd delicacies get shuffled around to perfection...you forget about the bleach.  In fact, you just kinda wonder, "which piece is mine?"
author: MJ P.

description:
I can eat about 50 of their imperial rolls!

#5 huge portions
++ 5 Spice chicken: flavorful, juicy, crispy where is should be
++ Imperial rolls: fairly large, filled with GOOD substance (not just usless filler), fried to perfection
+ Shish kabab: thin sliced well marinated meat
+ meat sauce: asian concoction of some sort of meat, tomato, onion... THAT's home cookin' to me :)
+ service: SUPER kind, the owner was checking in and chatting with regulars :)
+ price: talk about getting a bang for your buck!

Only about 8 stools around the bar and a small table in the back.

I will most DEF be back!
author: Angel L.

description: Why isn't "Chinese" listed on its categories? There are definitely Chinese items on their menu...a super tiny menu for a super tiny restaurant. The spot can be easily missed, but don't miss it! The food is sloppily prepared, but who cares how it looks when it tastes that good? Portions are hefty and prices are a bargain! They have a fancy name for a Vietnamese joint, but there's nothing fancy here. Sloppy, yummy, hearty cooking, that's it. I'd give more stars if there were more menu options...and Pho. I seem to always expect Pho when I see "Vietnamese." That's just me.
author: Helen L.

description:
I am not a fan of charred food. So you if like that burnt taste and the carcinogens that are associated with it, be my guest. My eggroll was as black as night.

Cheap, big portions, but at least a quarter of the plate was black and inedible. 

Ladies at the grill were nice. The food took too long.
author: William H.

description:
Hole in the wall deliciousness alert!

Forewarning: this is not a place where you go to enjoy dinner, catch up with friends, or eat and decided to linger over a beer or two. This place is literally the size of a hallway and how they manage to fit a kitchen and a counter-top table there is a mystery. You may however just bring yourself and your appetite to feast on some tasty food.

The portions are huge, and the variety of food you get on your plate can be kind of overwhelming. A combo meal will come with salad, two huge pieces of grilled chicken, an egg roll, and a bed of rice covered in their home special meat sauce--WOW I needed to take a breather just writing that. I kid you not, you cannot go home hungry when you have this much food. I think the 5 spice chicken was good, but parts of it were a little too charred for my own liking yet it wasn't overdone either. It probably has to do with the heat the chicken is cooking at.

I'm assuming this place is really popular for to-go, and I can tell this restaurant has attracted loyal customers since a lot of people who came by to pick up their to-go orders made casual conversation with the cook/owner there like they were old buddies. That's usually a good  indicator of how a restaurant is.

Anyways, the menu is limited but I definitely recommend the combo meals as they were fulfilling and delicious and allow you to kind of get a taste of everything. Parking can be a pain since it IS San Francisco and it's in a busy part of the city. If anything you should probably grab this food on the go. Also, this place only accepts cash if I remember correctly, so make sure you have some on hand before arriving!
author: Winnie T.

description:
Bring a little cash money ($10) and prepare to become addicted. This place really is spot on every time. They boast the best Vietnamese chicken in the city, and yes, I think it is. I have to say the best thing about Cordon is the homey taste of their food -and I am speaking mainly about the meat sauce. Everyone I've brought here gets obsessed. Check out T I don't mind -I've been through my own. Not to say that it isn't good now and that I don't want some, but you know, you can't just stay stuck on the same thing for forever. 

Bottom line: try it, like it, bring a friend, and have fun on the ride!

I'll check the boxes below, but note here: not good for groups, closed Mondays, cash only, minimalistic, sort of greasy -since you sit at or near a counter behind which the sole cook and owner, grills/fries it up before you.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I like to eat my Vietnamese grilled meat drowned in meat sauce!!!!!

Actually I get the combo with everything and get the sauce on the side then I can choose what I put the meat sauce on.  Its a Vietnamese plate lunch!

When I lived in the TL a very nice woman ran the joint, but she is not there any more. Dont worry the staff there is still very nice and efficient.

BYOB too!!!!!!!!!

Best chicken.  If you like grilled meats and a hearty meal at a good price come here.
author: Richard N.

description:
Just found out about this place. Went there last night, got the #5. Had multiple dreams of the chicken, rice drenched w/meat sauce, and of course, the imperial rolls.

Woke up this morning at 5am wondering if they'd be open....was literally that good.

It's now 8:20am and I can't stop thinking about the imperial rolls. It's negatively impacting my work performance.

I live three blocks from Cordon Bleu. I'm F'd.
author: Farbod D.

description:
I take everyone here. If we're friends and I havent taken you here, well...

Love this place. They basically have 5 things on the menu and all the dishes are combinations of those five. The big thing is the five spice chicken but, and I'm going to say it, I like the shish kebab and imperial rolls over the chicken. Yeah. So I normally get the Noodle salad or the Number 1 (shish kebab and imperial roll rice plate). Number 5 (shish kebab, imperial roll and five spice chicken rice plate)  is the dish everyone goes all ape over, but I saw through the BS and I just stick with the Number 1, baby.

I've written five and 5 quite a bit in that paragraph.

The best part about the place is the owner. Katie is super friendly and will chat up just about anyone if its not too busy. I was once there during a lunch break when a customer who came in, said he hadn't been there for 10+ years and asked if Katie remembered him. Not only did she remember but then she asked him about his daughter and remembered her approximate age. Since that day I've been going in for a late lunch (when the place is slower) and trying to become a regular so she'll remember me. I'm not kidding. Seems weird? Well we'll see in 10 years when I'm remembered and you're not!
author: Erich S.

description: Affordable and delicious.  They don't have much in the way of ambiance if you eat there, but the food more than makes up for it.  I usually get one of the combination plates, which come with that hearty meat sauce over rice.  The chicken and the imperial rolls are my favorites.  They give you a lot of food for the price you pay, which heats up well as leftovers.
author: Karen W.

description: Great food. Very small place but that makes it very interesting.
author: Heather W.

description:
3.5 stars, rounded up for the nice ladies that work there. My boyfriend and I came in for a late late lunch (read 4:30) today and we were the second party there. Boyfriend ordered the number four: rice, meat sauce, cabbage salad, five spiced chicken with an imperial roll on the side. I had the noodle bowl with imperial rolls and chicken. 

Imperials rolls were the bomb.com. Chicken was finished on the grill, soo good. Boyfriend had his left on the bone, mine were hand shredded in front of me.

The meat sauce was mild and not overpowering, good not amazing. We probably would prefer fish sauce next time.

As we ate lunch,  the place had more and more patrons come in. Regulars and newbs alike.
A great, comforting lunch. Would definitely come back.
author: Ellen H.

description:
This place most definitely cheered me up as I was not in a good mood and freezing cold in the city on an early morning. It's really a hole-in-the-wall which means it must be good! My friend and I sat on the counter on stools facing the small area where two ladies cook right in front of us. I could not wait to eat as I watched the chicken and pork I ordered grilled right in front of my very eyes. The salad is what I expected with chopped peanuts and mint in a tangy fish sauce. 

What i noticed was that they cook rice in clay pots instead of normal rice cookers which, in my opinion, makes the rice taste much better. Favorite part: the meat sauce of course! This place does get pretty crowded but it's worth the wait!
author: Jamie T.

description:
MEAT MEAT MEAT !!!!! My haven to flee to to not having to deal with preachy, pretentious, holier than though Vegetarians and Vegans. 

I have been a patron here for more than twenty years. Once upon a time they were five stars, they changed their recipe a bit and while it is still great, it is not the nirvana it once was. 

This a tiny hole in the wall next to the Lumiere theater. There about ten stools for the bar and three two top tables in the back. I believe the entire square footage of the place is 16. The menu consists of Five spice chicken, Shish kebab( just filets of beef on a skewer), Imperial rolls and a Pork chop. YOu can get any combination of this along side the most supreme rice with meat sauce. The base meat is beef in the sauce and I always get extra. I tend to just get the Number 4 which is half a chicken with the rice. Whilst I enjoy the Imperial rolls and Shish Kebabs, they are not as delicious as the chicken. Yes it is Flame broiled, so the skin gets burnt, which is also DELICIOUS! Flame broiling it retains its moistness and flavor. 

   The staff is all Vietnamese, Katie is very friendly, the rest of the staff can be a bit curt, but your at a counter, service is not really my goal here. Cleanliness? Again, it is a hole, I have never gotten sick, I am not a germaphobe, so therefore I have no complaints here. Trust me I have worked at places far worse where the customers can not see the filth. I guess ignorance is bliss and a big picture understanding is a rare thing for Americans. Turnover is swift so you will never have to wait more than ten minutes Prices are good and food is awesome. Vegetarians stay away!!!!!!
author: Christopher N.

description: Great and cheap hole in the wall type of place. The prices were extremely affordable and the portions were plentiful. The only downside to this restaurant was that it was cash only.
author: Marc S.

description:
Cordon Blue is your basic hole in the wall, it also serve excellent Vietnamese Food at a great price. Staying at a nearby hotel I did a Yelp search, I really had no idea what I wanted. Anyway I found Cordon Blue, it sounded good getting a rating of 4 stars. 4 Stars is just about right. I had the #5 which came grilled chicken, sate, white rice covered with gravy and a spring roll. The gravy and chicken were delicious. It was a huge amount of food for $9. When I was there it seemed to have mostly regulars, not touristy in the least.  In fact I suspect the most visitors to San Fran would turn their noses up at it. That's too bad, they'll be hard pressed to find a better value in one of the most expensive cities in the country. 

Seating is very limited, I counted only 16 seats. There is no kids menu; the menu is also very limited.  Service was friendly; food was cooked only a couple feet away and served quickly.  Highly recommended.

FYI - no check or credit cards
author: Dave J.

description:
With a mouthful of leftover imperial role, I am here to pay respect.   I am sitting home alone on a Friday night eating leftover Cordon Bleu, and as sad as that may sound, I'm really really happy because the food tastes even better the next day!

Very simple menu:

Kebob (thinly grilled pork slices, not skewers) 

or

Five-spice chicken (choice of white or dark, grilled to tender perfection) 

or, if you're like me..

BOTH.  all plates come with a heap of rice smothered with tomato meat sauce. and many of the combo plates come with the giant imperial roll.  it's delish!  also included is a pile of slaw that I find much tastier hot. ie. microwaved =)  the rice and meat sauce bakes together in the microwave too.  oh the simple pleasures in life. 

Large portions of Asian comfort food all for $7-9 a plate. TAX INCLUDED.  There is something incredibly satisfying about paying exactly what you see.

The place is small, with a counter facing the kitchen and a few small tables on the side so not the best for large groups.  Perfect, however, for a chill night with a few new friends. =)
author: Beatrice T.

description: Meat gravy madness. Order the #5, and expect to wait for a seat at the counter. It is so worth it. Viet comfort food on a scale I have not experienced before. No booze and cash only so bring a bottle of wine, and not much cash -$20 feeds 2 hungry folks. Hole in the wall ambiance and parking is a bitch. Neither detract from the experience. The self absorbed hipsters who frequent the place do however. Plan accordingly.
author: Aly H.

description: Really really sayisfying. Grilled chicken has that aromatic grill taste, perfect with the light meat sauce and fresh slaw.
author: Sarah L.

description: AHHHH, this place is amazzzzzing!!! I can't get enough of the imperial rolls, they are soo yummy. My first try I got the ultimate combo plate that includes everything they offer just to know what is the best thing there. My go to now is the noodle bowl which comes with a huge serving of the imperial roll. MUST KNOWS: this place is small (10 seats small), everything is made to order (be patient!!), cash is preferred and come starving portions are huge!
author: Donna H.

description: the servings are large and the price is cheap.  You get what you pay for.   Personally, I like typical Pho restaurants that have Rice dishes with BBQ pork chop and some greens on the side.   Those places don't serve as much food, but the quality is better.
author: Mark T.

description: We ordered the #4 five spice roasted chicken combo and the #5 five spice roast chicken plus shish kebab and imperial roll. I am not so impressed by the chicken, but like the meat sauce on the rice a lot! Limited seating inside, more suitable for take out.
author: Emmy P.

description:
This place is freaking awesome!!! 

Noodle Salad 4 Life! BBQ meat (cooked right in front of you)  topped with peanuts, but laying over vermicelli, salad and a so totally YUM dressing...and under 8 bux. Oh and a big phat tasty imperial roll chopped up over it all.  The imperial roll seemed to have mystery ingredients and I didnt even care...which is so unlike me.  

This was a yelpless visit but I'm not surprised to see over 300 reviews. Twas a total hole in the wall and we were lucky to score two seats at the counter at noon. The place only seats about 15 and soon we were surrounded by people either picking up or mean mugging us to hurry it up. Can't wait to go back one day!
author: Virgo M.

description: I used to frequent this "hole-in-the-wall" when I was a park intern with very little money.  It's a fantastic value - I always stuck with the #4 special - a cabbage salad, meat sauce on top of rice, and a generous portion of what they say on the menu is "possibly the best chicken you'll ever get outside of Vietnam."  Well I don't know about that, but it IS finger lickin good -- SO GOOD that perhaps that's what motivated one of the other customers (a complete stranger) to one day shamelessly ask me for the skin!
author: Connie H.

description:
I stopped in to Cordon Bleu tonight for the first time, and came away very impressed. Dont let the name deceive - the place is a hole-in-the-wall Vietnamese restaurant, with about 8 or 10 seats at the counter, and another two tables in the back. The cook (and owner? It seemed to be more-or-less a one-woman operation) took care of all the orders on a flaming grill behind the counter.

When I arrived, the place was crowded, but many of the diners soon left. There's quick turnover, and many people seem to be picking up to-go orders.

The menu is short, featuring a few meats (I ordered chicken and "shish kebab", which turns out to be a sort of pork steak), and everything seemed to be served with either a huge helping of noodles, or rice & meat sauce, with a large Vietnamese spring roll on the side. The food is satisfying, and very, very plentiful. I had difficulty finishing - struggled quite a bit at the end.

But I left hugely satisfied -- the meal was good, the place feels friendly and homely (almost like a family kitchen) and at $12.00 for meal + drink (a coke) and a good tip, it's a great deal!
author: donal c.

description:
Yum! My new favorite hole-in-the-wall neighborhood restaurant. 

Don't let the long line deter you, the food is worth the wait. I stood in line for about 20 minutes before securing the table right near the swinging kitchen door. With a bit of maneuvering, I managed not to get hit by the door by wedging myself beneath the calendar. 

Ordered the Number 1 and Number 4 combos. The chicken was perfect, the kababs are not kababs (no skewers, more like the chargrilled beef you see on most Vietnamese bun), and the imperial rolls are deep fried. And the meat sauce was delicious! 

Less than $9 per plate and definitely good value!
author: Madeline N.

description:
This is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco for meat craving. That meatsauce rice is my psychic confirmation I'm in San Francisco. I CRAVE those flavors and the 1/2 chicken amplifies my salivory gush-to.

I don't mind the tinyness, sure, it's smoky, it's a BBQ! 

I love bringing it home, heating it up old-school.
author: mike p.

description:
It was cheap.  It was very good.  Go there.  

:-)

The fresh flowers are a nice touch.
author: Sofia H.

description: One of my favorite places. Good food, low prices, and friendly eat-at-the-counter service.
author: Dave G.

description:
This is one of the few Vietnamese restaurants that have such a small yet specialized menu without the normal soup and noodle bowls. 

I thought the menu was simple but the food came out kinda overcooked for me. The chicken was too burnt for me and the rice with the sauce was tasty but sloppily spilled onto everything else including my imperial roll... Overall, for the price I think it was worth it. After a movie or looking for a late fill-me-up dinner, this would be an option. I would suggest To-Go orders.

Three stars. Like the other yelpers, this place is more like a hole in the wall type of restaurant. Not good for big groups, or a nice occasion. The food is alright and the service is pretty fast for fresh BBQ chicken.
author: Jen L.

description:
I am obsessed with this place. Seriously, I think I'm going to start going once per week. 

The highlights: food is cheap, tasty. Service is awesome. Crowd eclectic.

I was recommended this place by a colleague whose opinion I really trust because he's an absolute grinder. Fresh out of college and fresh of the east coast, I asked Tom for a rec for a cheap, solid, place to grab a bite. Tom came through.

I rounded up a couple of buddies, and we went for it. We were pretty confused when we walked in--asking ourselves questions like "why is this vietnamese place called Le Cordon Bleu?" We sat down at the bar which encloses an open-kitchen. Place is packed. Finally, these saintly little Vietnamese women serve us, and we begin watching our food cook in front of us. Never had a more agonizing experience in my entire life. I think I was foaming at the mouth by the time we got our food (not a bad wait though). I got the #5 per Tom's rec--a ton of grilled chicken, 2 pieces of this thin steak-like meat all on top of this rice under a nice flavorful meat sauce. Oh and they go ahead and tack on this mega egg roll that's just delicious. Meggroll? Whatever. There was so much freaking food, I don't think my two friends even made it to halftime. Really shameful performance. I'm known to eat, and even I couldn't finish everything.

Not only did I have amazing food for like 9 bucks, but I had a phenomenal overall experience--great food, great people, good conversation, a few laughs. Seriously, this place may have changed my life. 

To the nay sayers: If you're complaining about the service or something about the ambiance you should probably consider the fact that everything on the menu is under 8.50... I think the last big mac meal I bought cost 8.50---wasn't exactly dazzled by the ambiance there either. Of course, this place was about 1000x better than Mac Does. Did I mention the service was phenomenal? Those women are going straight to heaven.
author: Colin F.

description:
Five-spiced Chicken, Mapo Tofu are the dishes to be had here. 

Five-spiced chicken is really tasty and the meal is filling. They give you big portions of rice and their meat sauce. I don't know what's in that meat sauce (get your mind out of the gutter) but it is to die for. The salad is whatev.

The mapo tofu is surprisingly hearty with minced pork and big pieces of mushroom.. mmm.. 

This place may not be extravagant but it is comfort food. Great for take-out. Call ahead.
author: Brandon O.

description:
Holy moles. Hands-down one of my favorite places in San Francisco. 

It opened my eyes to a whole new facet of Vietnamese cuisine that I was not familiar with... and which I now know I love! 

Get the #5. Seriously. Just don't even think about it. The smell alone will knock you off your chair. 

The cherry on the cake: it's a LOT of food, so you're bound to have leftovers (I have a big appetite, so I don't think I'm exaggerating here), which you'll be very happy about the next day.

The down-sides... 

The service: they pretty much ignore you for as long as they can and, although it doesn't seem malicious or intentional, it can get pretty frustrating if you're hungry or in a rush (read: catching a flick at Lumiere next-door). 

Cash-only policy: I mean, I'd be willing to drop serious mula here and stock up on meals for the entire week, but I don't like to carry much cash around, so it requires some planning ahead. 

Little seating: We got lucky when we went and scored a table, but it's often crowded and just generally unpredictable, so it's not super convenient for eating there... and it's definitely not good for groups. 

Man, my mouth just waters thinking about it!
author: G. J.

description:
Cordon Bleu has only a handful of menu items, but they sure do it well! I keep coming back for their chicken, but their other items are decent to good as well. The price/portion ratio is outstanding!

The only thing that keeps me away sometimes is the fact that it gets crowded and the service is slow as a result (not to be confused with bad service).

For added fun, poll your friends to see what they think is in the "meat sauce"
author: Ryan V.

description: I'm not sure what it is about the meat sauce they put on their rice, but it feels and tastes like home to me and I just can't get enough. (Did I just inadvertently reference two Depeche Mode songs? You bet I did!) In the same vein as classic divey joints like Yamo and Art's Cafe, where you can barely fit more than 10 people in the restaurant, Cordon Bleu provides huge portions for a great price. On my most recent I ordered the pork chops and there were literally four huge grilled pork chops on a mound of rice... They had to bring the side salad on a separate plate! Be prepared to turn a blind eye to cleanliness, obviously this isn't a white tablecloth type of establishment. But I love it and I'm sticking to it!
author: Andrey C.

description: Having lived so close for 20 years I must've given this up as a veggie. Now I understand and there is tofu life here! Just ask and you'll be pleased because this place is amazing
author: Smelly S.

description:
From what Ashley H. writes, she sounds like one of those chicks I went on a date with and left her with the bill.  What's wrong with you?  Do you watch the Hills for inspiration on your dialog?  If the validity of each restaurant lies upon the language spoken by the chefs, every damn restaurant in SF would be Mexican...stupid.

Cordon Bleu experience is awesome; you come here when you're happy, sad, hungry, hung over, distraught, enthused; the food is personable and the service is homey.  You're not getting white tie service here and honestly, no one credible desire it.  The lady will hand you a couple menus, put her elbows on the table in front of you and ask you how you're doing before you order.  You want tea, you'll get tea.  You want water, you'll get water.  You want life advice, she may give you a few.  You'll feel like you're sitting at home while your mom's giving you the mothering food experience.  If you had a horrible upbringing, I suggest  you come here for the therapeutic experience.

Imperial rolls here are huge and delicious; whatever you order you have to get something with it.  If you're a monster, order the #5, it has every animal split and grilled over a huge mound of meat sauce and rice.  Put some of that hot sauce on it and you're pretty damn close to some Biblical paradise that doesn't even exist, so throw those stupid ass books away and come here and eat some real food.  

PS it's BYOB here, so bring your favorite alcoholic beverage!  But don't bring your precious lil bottle of Chateau Mouton-Rothschild cuz the food is bold and undaunted.  Plus if the flavors don't hit you in the face, then I will.
author: Nico M.

description:
A little stand-offish at first going in to this little hole-in-the-wall.  

Get ready to eat becasue they serve you a LOT of food.  Even the "smaller" lunch special could feed two people (six in Africa).  

The meat sauce served over the rive looks and tastes questionnable until the third bite; pretty damn good.  

Small menu, easy choices, and cheap!  Give it shot.
author: Jimmie L.

description:
Bring your appetite and your patience. Amazingly large portion sizes at very reasonable prices. 
The kebab plate is thin sliced and grilled to a slight crispy char and  is served with a mountain of rice smothered with a good but rather bland meat sauce and a yummy vinegar based shredded cabbage. If its your first time try the sauce on the side. It also comes with an large crispy imperial roll. 
They are also famous for their 5 chicken plates served the same way. The chicken is perfectly seasoned and grilled the same way.
Now with that goodness comes the patience part.....there is very limited seating. The counter seats 8 and there are 2 small tables in the back. When its busy you could be waiting for quite a long time to sit. If you like divey hole in the wall places this should qualify....if you don't then togo is probably a good idea. It is very intimate and all food is prepared in front of you on a small gas grill and stove. Its great food super cheap but be prepared to wait.
author: Landon T.

description: Finest hole in the wall joint west of the Andromeda Galaxy. Katie is a sweet person and a magnificent maker of kebabs and the like. Even the little garden salad on the side is remarkable. There is truly nothing wrong with this place.
author: Gustavo O.

description: Interesting food. I have never eaten similar vietnamese offerings. Very inexpensive and a great place for takeout. Make sure you are hungry because portions are humongous!
author: Greg B.

description: One of the best deals in San Francisco.  Probably the best imperial rolls in San Francisco.  This place is pretty small and there can be a long wait sometimes.  With people ordering takeout, things can get a little crazy.  I wouldn't suggest this place if you're in a rush.  One other tip is that you can bring your own wine/beer.  I always get the Number 1 combo with no meat sauce.  Yum!
author: Daniel M.

description:
So this place isn't a place you go to to get FANTASTIC OUT-OF-THIS-WORLD food, BUTTTT you do go here when you're craving it (because it's that good).

So although it may not be the gourmet life-changing meal, you do start craving this stuff after you've had it for the first time.

I went on a Friday afternoon, ran in for a LATEEE afternoon lunch and got the Chicken lunch special to go. The chicken was a bit charred but sooo tender and marinated yummily, that I had every piece of meat on the bone that wasn't charred. 

Additionally, the red special sauce mixed with the rice and cole slaw was definitely an insane combination. I was sooo full after eating maybe 1/3 of my to-go lunch special but because it was SOO good, I had to keep on going. I ended up eating the ENTIRE thing and feeling like a beached whale afterwards, but sooo goood.

At the price they sell, although the place may seem a bit janky, the food is so comforting and definitely something I'm craving when I want a down and dirty, almost southern-style home-cooked meal. Since the southern-style home-cooked 'square' meals are hard to find in this city, I think the Vietnamese versions will do wonderfully.

Can't wait to go back to try the pork chops and the imperial rolls, although I've limited myself to going to this place only 1-2 times a month because it is such a heavy meal and I don't know how to stop myself  from eating the entire plate :)

Cash only, VERY Filling, VERY cheap, VERY warm/small/stuffy (inside, I encourage to do take-out)
author: Jung-Ah Y.

description: Friendly service, wonderful food! This place gives you a lot of "bang for your buck." The food is not only delicious & cheap, but there's so much of it! This is the place to come if you're hungry!
author: Kate B.

description: Cordon Bleu - Still delicious. My favorite is now the noodle salad with shish kebab -- cold noodles and salad offset by the hot-off-the-grill shish meat PLUS an imperial roll. Are you kidding me? Heaven. I told my husband, on my death bed, I want an imperial roll included in my last meal.
author: Emily B.

description: Miss this place! I used to live around the corner and this place rocks! Cheap prices and by far the best 5 spice chicken Ive had. Open late to! It's a small place with no more than a dozen seats, so it's good for takeout! Incredibly cheap prices too!
author: Brandon W.

description:
hole in the wall run in amazingly cramped quarters by homies (cantonese speakers) who sink well below anything a la cordon bleu straddling the low and lower echelons of cuisinedom only to deliver yet oh so satisfying punches to the gut in the form of mystery meat sauce, monster size imperial rolls and flavorful bbq 5 spice chicken.

barring the occasional hardness of the possibly twice cooked rice, this is inexplicable comfort food that brings smiles to all. hell, someone even managed to cram a birthday party in there.
author: Henry Y.

description:
I had the pork chop... Big portion, good tasty food, and very good price... The place is really small, but I left pleasantly surprised.. It was very home-style cooking... 

Give it a try..
author: James F.

description: great place, small low budge modest divey style vietnamese  restaurant.  They cook it over open flame right before you.  Prices are great, food is good!  come here and try it out.  The book is sometimes much better than ithe cover portreys  :D  this to me is a little sleeper hidden gem.   Nice place, me likey!
author: Jae L.

description:
This place is the definition of a hole in the wall but the food is great and the prices are low.

Most entrees are $6-$8 and come with a generous helping of rice with "meat sauce" and slaw. The five spice chicken is delicious and the imperial rolls are some of the best that I've had.

Cramped counter seating along with a couple of small tables means that you may have to wait if you go during busy times but with such good food and low prices, it's worth a visit.

P.S. Beware that since it's such a tiny space, the BBQ smoke gets everywhere and your clothes will be smelling of BBQ for a long time afterward.
author: Charles M.

description:
I absolutely love this place, although its a bit slow, its worth the wait. and the amount of food you get is worth every penny! I stumble upon this place during work hours for me, I was so excited to get some cordon bleu, haha boy was I mistaken, but in a good way.

Until I came here, Vietnamese food was never impressive to me, pho, grilled bbq with tangy sauces. But this place changed my mind, how awesome is the Grilled chicken here? Awesome to the 5th power! How awesome is the kabob? More awesomer! I've had the great pleasure of tasting everything on the menu, and have come to the conclusion that the noodle salad is the best thing to get, the best bang for your buck and easily it will fill your tum tum. 

Say hi, smile to the lady cooking your food. Theyre nice. its cozy in there so dont expect to bring your crew of 50. at most this place will sit 15 people TOTAL. and the biggest group you can bring in is probably 3~4. 

Its not nice inside at all, but that is its 'hole in the wall' charm. be patient for your food, the one person thats usually on the grill is a nice lady. this is definitely a textbook hole in the wall. 

the whole experience is about the amount of food you get and the quality of the food you get. in this case it is 5 stars. 

oh, dont bring a date here unless she/he is a foody with no regard for atmosphere.
author: todd p.

description:
You walk in and will hit the back wall.  My friend and I had time to kill before picking up her son from work. She has fond memories of this place working near by.  Super cheap, no meal is over $9.00

I have to admit I was skeptical of the "meat sauce on rice".  I'm not anymore.  I don't know what is in there, but it's pretty good.  It comes covered on all the dishes.

The chicken, "possibly the best outside of Vietnam", was very good too.  Everything is grilled fresh, but of course the chicken is previously cooked and given a good heating on the grill.

The Imperial Rolls are some of the best I've had in SF.  You won't get it with lettuce to wrap it in like Out the Door, but they are very good.

Seems to be veg friendly, but if you get the Veg Imperial Rolls, I think they are cooked in the same oil as the meat ones.  Better to have the Spring Rolls, which I don't think are fried.

Great service, and everybody loves the lady behind the counter.  Maybe she's related to the Saigon Sandwich lady??  Expect to wait for your order, and there's not much seating.  Cash only.
author: Michael M.

description:
I have to laugh at the bad reviews because I can understand and respect their opinion about this place.  

This restaurant has a fancy name for a hole-in-the-wall, so that can be deceiving.  

As far as the food, I've tried the chicken, beef, pork chop and egg roll (all in different visits, of course!) and I've liked it all.  I've taken, at least, 6 people there.  1 of the 6 didn't like it, because of the mystery sauce, which it a peanut butter meat sauce.  Being Filipino, and cooking the same sauce in a different dish, I get it.  BUT, I can see how others do not.  

Everyone's taste buds are different.  I think you should just try it.  If you're suspicious about the sauce, ask for it on the side or not at all.  Simple solution!
author: Leslie C.

description: Love this place.  It's tiny, very friendly (especially the neighborhood guy who stops in and helps out -- Justin?) and the food is AMAZING.
author: Tasha D.

description:
There's so many damn Chinese fast food joints in San Francisco, and luckily my girlfriend's family picked this one. It's a real cozy little hole in the wall dump. 
They could really use some more space. I swear it was like military chow hall lines trying to squeeze in there. 
The wait was reeeeeally long.. About 2 hours (NO LIE).. Once we got our food, all our worries went away. The salad/cole slaw wasn't the greatest but the egg rolls were yuuuuuummy.. If you're in the area I would recommend this place to anyone.. I had a gay day in San Francisco
author: Alex C.

description:
I never had to wait very long.
Parking is not too much of a challenge.
CHEAP
TASTY

Number one please...no country salad and a pepsi...thank you.
BBQ pork, imperial roll and a bed of rice with mystery meat sauce.

*drool*

The only one bad thing...I burp throughout the day....and relive every bite.  YEP not fun but it is sooooo worth it.  This joint gives me gas but worth every bite and burp.

PLEASE note that this is a dive joint.  If you like frou frou places and joints that score high on the restaurant cards....don't come here.  Save a seat for the people who don't mind.

NOW I need to convince my bf to go here tonight though we are going to japan town tonight.  It's a little backwards but I think I can manage to pull this....*keeping fingers crossed*
author: Elisa O.

description:
This is a cute hole in the wall. Bar seating with maybe two tables in the back. They're are usually two ladies cooking in the kitchen, warm and welcoming.

You get a whole lotta food for little money so that's what draws you in. I had the kebob (grilled marined pork) and it's piled on top of a HUGE bed of rice topped with a tomato based sauce. They top it off with a cabbage slaw and a imperial roll (I ordered a vegetarian spring roll instead). All in all, it's a homely type place and the chef lady said to me once, "I don't have kids but I feel like I have so many with all the people  I feed."  Awww.
author: Jane C.

description:
We were so excited about finally eating here, we decided to celebrate with large amounts of BYOB.  I barely recall walking out of this place, but I do recall how freaking bomb-tastic this food was.

I am no conosseur of Vietnamese food, but I do know good food.  

I had the Chicken Salad- probably some of the best chicken I've ever had- the flavor was out of this world (and i could taste it over the copious amounts of alcohol i had imbibed), 2 large boys i was with had #1, #3- about 5 lbs of white rices topped with yummy meat sauce and all sorts of meat + delicious spring rolls.

All I can say is $22 later, we walked out drunk, full, and oh so satisfied.
author: Gabrielle J.

description:
Although the newest SAT format has dropped analogies, let's do one for fun!

Yamo : Mission :: Cordon Bleu : Nob Hill

This hole-in-the-wall reminds me of a classier Yamo. Though not nearly as dive-y, it too has limited counter seating and Chinese ladies working the (cleaner) kitchen. They bicker less, which kinda lessens the experience...

The entrees are definitely the way to go. In particular, the Number 5 has one of everything - five spiced roast chicken, imperial roll, shish kebab, country salad, and meat sauce on rice - a great way to sample all the best dishes Cordon Bleu has to offer! Two standouts are the imperial rolls and the shish kebab (marinated grilled beef slices). The imperial rolls are made to order so they're always crispy and piping hot. Both are seasoned perfectly and are so flavourful! Dip them in the fish sauce and they're even better. I found the chicken a little dry though and the country salad is basically just shredded cabbage.

And their meat sauce on rice... to die for! It's a Chinese-style western dish (kinda like Chinese-style Russian borscht, which I totally prefer over Russian-Russian borscht!) The tomato-base sauce is less hearty than an Italian meat sauce and the spices and flavours are different, but both in the best ways possible.

The noodle salad's really good too. It's your typical Vietnamese bún dish - douse it with fish sauce and magic happens! I wasn't a fan of the ma po tofu though as it left a weird taste in my mouth.
author: Steph L.

description: Not the cleanest Kitchen, But best value for the meal at a dive restaurant award. its just a counter with very few seats where you can watch one cook actually cooking your food right next to you. The chicken is amazing! I think its the best grilled chicken in town! The menu is very limited but, I love the number 4 or 5.  the meat sauce on the rice is like this amazing meaty almost tomato like gravy and the imperial rolls are flavorful and CRUNCHY!  But its a must try even just for the amazing chicken. Best option get it to go and pig out in front of the t.v!
author: Michelle A.

description:
Poor, and hungry? Come to Cordon Bleu!
They give you a lot of warm, cozy food. Eating the meat sauce on rice is like eating a dish prepared by the grandmother you never had. The lady who made our food was super nice and hospitable, I want her to be my grandma. 
It's really small but warm and fun for a quick, wholesome bite to eat, when the money is low. 
I have a feeling, from the other customers that were there, that she has a lot of regulars that simply can't cook for themselves and need a filling, friendly place to go feel like they have a home. It's not depressing, it's cute.
author: Shanna H.

description:
I got the rumbling in my tummy, walked into this joint and stayed there eating for a good 2 hours. The food here is pretty darn good. you can tell when food has been marinated and cooked properly unlike some other places. 

Atmosphere: 
very hole in the wall family mom and pop shop diner style, with 8-9 stools for seating. Other than that, you can squat outside and eat your food if you like. The kitchen is right in front of you and on a cold day, it thaws you out. On a hot day, get some ice water because you'll be sizzling as you gobble up your food. 

Service: 
Pretty homely and friendly people. please leave a decent tip, they ain't a hole in the wall place for nothing cuz those big fast food chains are right down the street too. the owner/cook/waiter will give you some life tips if you need it. 

Food:
they don't serve alcohol, so BYOBB (BRING YOUR OWN BOOZE BUDDY). they provide all the water you can drink and perhaps soda too. i usually bring a bottle of pear cider from bevmo since it goes well with any chicken and sauce dish. the imperial rolls are HUGE! they look sexier and 3x bigger than the imperial rolls you see at a chinese restaurant that charges the same price.
author: Jason C. J.

description: 5 stars for one reason and for one reason only --- vegetarian spring roll.  I've got this place on speed dial, the veggie spring roll takes 15 minutes, call it in, thank me later, cash only.
author: Hanah L.

description:
5 spice chicken!!!  Imperial rolls!!!  Thanks to my good friend Dave who introduced me to this little institution in 1999.  This is a fantastic dive restaurant in San Francisco.  Next door is the Lumiere Theater if you want to catch a movie after dinner.  Polk street also provides a variety of entertainment options.

Go hungry.  The food is cheap and the portions are large.  If you go back every night of the week, your food will be prepared by the same sweet woman and her family.  Everything is very consistent, and you can phone in your order to go if you don't want to sit and eat.  Get the #5 if you want to try it all on one plate for less than $10.

Be sure to take cash as they do not accept credit or checks.  Don't go with a big group because the place is tiny.  Don't go on Mondays because they are closed.  Parking is a bit of a challenge in this neighborhood, but not if you don't mind walking a few blocks.  Sometimes, I get lucky and find parking right on Polk.
author: Ryan W.

description:
i got #5 and it was ok. the meat sauce scared me.. wayyy too much food/rice but the chicken was basically to die for. I think it was a good meal for the price.  fyi. they get the chicken from a tub stored on the ground (next to where they serve people)

20 bucks plus tip for 2 people!
author: David C.

description:
In terms of sheer bang-for-the-buck, this place rivals Saigon Sandwich further down Polk.

Food is good, plentiful, and cheap.  It is a tiny place, however, so I wouldn't be surprised if you have to wait during peak times.

If I ever have to clamp down on the budget, I'm coming here more often.
author: Dave N.

description:
Ah cordon bleu.  So chill.  I went there last night cause I was drinking corona's on an empty stomach.  "Can I order some food to go?" 

Lady behind the grill:
 "Sure what would you like."

Me:
"Umm, I like those egg rolls."

Lady:
"You need the number two."

Me:
"Okay I'll take the number two then."

Cordon Bleu has a great simple menu and fresh grilled vietnamese food to go, or to eat on their simple bar stool counter.  I went there last night at 10:05pm and they close at 10pm.  But she nicely waved me in to come sit down, no problem.  

Lady:
Would you like some tea while you wait. 

Me:  Tea, yes..please.  Umm, This is some good tea, its Jasmine?

"Yes Jasmine, you should drink tea. It has some bitters that help calm your spirit." The sweet lady behind the grill says.

"Yes, I do need to learn more about tea." I quietly respond. Thank you Cordon Bleu for the fresh meat over rice, two extra large egg rolls and sirarcha and sweet and sour sauces to go. Now that hit the spot.  I promise to drink more Jasmine tea to calm my spirit.  Good night.  See you soon.
author: Georgio N.

description: Amazing amount of good food. Love their roles! Cooked to eat on the spot!
author: Shawn O.

description: The food here is good, cheap and served in large portions. I don't recall what I ordered but I spent 10 dollars ws happy and had leftovers for the next days dinner and I can eat. This place isn't fancy but it gets the job done and it does it well.
author: Christina S.

description: Not the most authentic Vietnamese restaurant in town but it is delicious. The menu is simple and I would recommend getting the pork and the imperial roll. Cheap, fast service, and delicious food. What more can a tourist ask for?
author: Tam V.

description:
I found this place on Yelp-- so I'm going to pay it forward.

YUM YUM YUM! I disagree with places that call Cordon Bleu a 'hole-in-the-wall'.  It's small, yes. But it's clean and adorable.  You sit at a counter surrounding an open kitchen, as Vietnamese mothers cook up a delicious storm.  It's friendly and affordable, and you should definitely eat here!
author: Zuzzi E.

description: Despite being a "Vietnamese" restaurant, the entire place is staffed by Chinese speakers.  Two ladies scurry around the grill where "possibly the best chicken you'll ever taste outside of Vietnam" is cooked.  I've never been to Vietnam, but they've got me nearly convinced that I need to move there.  The chicken.  Is.  Delicious.
author: Carlin E.

description: I was so looking forward for this meal. We came in about 15 minutes before they opened. Practically we were the first customer. Lucky for us since this place only has a few seating. We can watch the lady cooking our meal. I was looking into the very interesting meatsauce and thought that looks like Chinese style spaghetti sauce. Someone came in an just order rice and meat sauce, and we thought Great, they like it, must be good. Came to our turn, the portion was huge. I ordered the special roast chicken and rice, and my bunny ordered the combo that came with chicken, meat and egg roll. The rice tasted al dente. I thought this was odd since rice should be fully cooked, you know, not like spaghetti. The meatsauce was the worst thing on that plate. There were some faint weird taste on that sauce. Wait...what was the taste? Oh yeah, taste like chlorine to me. I couldn't finish my meal :( The chicken as well... Not so great. The thigh part was ok but the breast was dried. Maybe not their best day? I dunno. The price was very cheap, though, especially to think that one plate can be shared for 2. The lady was nice too.
author: fenny g.

description:
It's not authentic Vietnamese food, but it tastes good and is a great value.  You get A LOT off food for your money.  The food is good and the lady is nice.  Do I crave the food and think about going back?  Maybe once every 8 months or so.  

I just think there are better places to go for Vietnamese food.  But it is a great value for your money.

Things to note- very small place- I think it's a ten seat or so counter and maybe 3 tables in the back.  Also, they cook the food at the counter so you will smell like food.  It also gets a little stuffy there as well since the space is so small.  But it's nice.
author: Rose T.

description:
Let me give it to you straight. This place is all about value. 

If you tried to get me to pay $50 for a Justice concert. I would say, hell no! Justice sucks!

But if you told me you had $15 pre sale tickets and I was your boy, I would be like man, that Justice is some slick poppin!

This place is like seeing Justice for $15. Good value.
author: Richard S.
