description: Suckered again...i can't get a break in SF....I can only attest that ppl who've reviewed this, just have never been to NYC to experience true delicious dive food.....This is the weirdest fast food viet joint ever, they mainly only serve the bbq chicken and pork and than a deep fried imperial roll....with a nasty tomato based meat sauce. I wanted to like it, i really did, but I nearly fell into a 3 hour coma after I ate only half of this and it's only worth 2 stars, cause you really should only be eating this if it's 2AM and you're stupid drunk.
author: Monster E.

description: I tried very hard to find the gold in this gem.  I left full with cheap eats, but not in the orgiastic coma I assumed I would be in.  I went for the five-spice chicken, rice with meat sauce and country salad.  The chicken was moist beyond all belief and I dug the five-spice seasoning.  However, this was not the best chicken I have ever had.  The rice was plentiful, but the meat sauce tasted like Chef Boyardee.  The country salad had no dressing and was just dress greens.  My words may seem harsh because my expectations were way too high.  The people running this place are quite nice and are not skimpy with their portions.  They open at 11:30, but are not ready to serve food until 12.  Be warned.
author: Jeremy G.

description: The garlicky tofu over rice should not be overlooked.  You may think it's all about the chicken, but that tofu hits the spot.  Remember to be patient when dining in, the food is cooked fresh so everything takes awhile to make except for the meat sauce which is pre-made in a giant pot.  Don't sleep on Cordon Bleu!  You already kno what it iZzzzz
author: Law C.

description:
Yeah, its 5 stars.

But wait.... why 5 stars? You've read the other reviews. Its small, the service isn't excellent, blah blah blah. Listen, small places, especially built like this one, make it difficult to serve everyone promptly, especially with the numerous amounts of take out orders they go through in an evening. 

The food is awesome. It reminds me of my favorite place in Sacramento, BoBo's Cafe. I know you haven't been there, but I don't care. If you're too antsy to sit and wait, just get it to go. Its extremely good either way. The noodle salad and imperial rolls are my favorite.

I also have a special place in my heart for Cordon Bleu because I ate there with my now fiancee, for the first time, the night we got engaged. It even inspires romance people!

FYI, it does end up in your clothing, but if you like it as much as I do, you can just smell your clothes for fun... Don't judge me.
author: Aaron S.

description:
Ma Po Tofu is not something normally found on the menu as a special.  Especially if the menu lists only 5 things.  I like the addition of garlic and shitake mushrooms, it makes the dish savory yet unique.  It tastes as good as homemade but it is different enough that I can like them both.
We came here with Jen and Eric.  We found rock star parking.  We sat at the counter.  They ordered noodle salad and it was served in the customary huge bowls.  I was not surprised, but the BF is not so multi-cultrually inclined.  
The imperial rolls were fried before my very eyes.  It was like watching marshmallows being toasted.  Mesmerizing.  
I've heard that the rice and sauce is good.  I'll have to come back for that.  
The portions are SO BIG that the leftovers themselves were 3 distinct meals.
I love vietnamese food.  Slurp.  Filling.  Sigh.
author: Christina C.

description:
Amazing food at killer prices
always always always a good meal.....i take out of towners here every trip
author: Chris D.

description: Delicious and so cheap! Service is non-existent because they're too busy cooking in front of the bar (where you sit unless you can nab one of the two tiny tables). The menu is very limited, but it seems like you can't go wrong with anything on it. I loved everything that came with the #5 (5 spice chicken, coleslaw-like salad, deep fried Imperial Rolls, and rice with the amazing red sauce) and the Noodle Salad (more Imperial Rolls, beef slices ("shishkebab"), and rice noodles). I split these 2 entrees with 2 other people and was still stuffed. And in the end I only shelled out $7!
author: Amy X.

description:
I came here the other night at around 9pm (around closing time) and there were still a ton of people! This was a great sign. I ordered the chicken combo with eggroll, rice, and meat sauce, and the spicy pork chops. Man was I impressed. The portions were HUGE and everything is around $10. I would highly recommend the spicy pork chops because they're not too spicy, were tender, and cooked perfectly. All the meat is grilled right in front of you. 

Not a good place for groups, not a good place if you're trying to impress a date. I'll probably order food to-go next time as the restaurant is tiny.
author: Bobby D.

description:
Wow! This place is so delicious! 

Their imperial rolls remind me of the garlicy goodness from Tu Lan but bigger and better! 

I ordered the # 1 with the grilled pork and imperial roll over rice with their special sauce and a side of picked cabbage salad. Something about their sauce! So onion-y and sweet, I would get it on the side next time, but sooooo yummy.

Pricing is just right too. 

Can't wait to try their pork chop!
author: Ema I.

description:
Don't know what I can add to what fellow yelpers have already said, so the bullet points are: 

1) It's not like eating in somebodies house, its more like eating in somebodies hallway. 

2) The menu doesn't exactly seem vietnamese to me, but the food sure it tasty and the meat sauce is more than yummy, and I still get the vietnamese food burp after I eat here. (so it must be authentic) 

3) People are nice enough. (My wife doesn't feel accosted like the restaurants in little saigon) 

4) Cheap. 

Great place if you can get a seat and just want to each good chicken.
author: David M.

description:
I'm a fan.  My god, their imperial rolls!

For entrees, the meat sauce they slather over the rice before placing your selection on top is real onion-y.  (I'm a rice purist and ask for 'no meat sauce'.)

Takeout is where it is at, but the counter seating can be amusing, if a seat opens up.
author: Pineapples D.

description: Affordable and delicious. I've never been even slightly disappointed with my food. The owner is sweet and fun to talk with. I stop by to say hi even when I don't plan to dine.
author: Erin S.

description:
Its always the simplest things that are the best.  Cordon Bleu's rice with meat sauce is no exception.  No idea what they put in it, but its best described as a lighter, sweeter spaghetti meat sauce.  I had their #5 which is the 5 Spice Chicken accompanied by rice with meat sauce, shish kabob (really just grilled pork/bbq pork), egg roll, and salad (cabbage).  The chicken was a little plain to me, but everything else was excellent.  The rice with meat sauce is definitely what makes this place stand out.  

I think they speak Chinese, but not  sure about Vietnamese. The place is very small and the run by 2-3 people so service is a bit slow.
author: Bert N.

description:
While I believe this place is most well known for their chicken, I would have to say the Meat Sauce is really the best part of this place. 

Very limited seating since its really small restaurant so you may want to consider taking it to go 

yay for meat sauce =)
author: Jasper L.

description:
I loved this place.... in the 80's.

I ate at Cordon Bleu many times back in the 80's when my boyfriend at the time worked next door at the Lumiere. The chicken was always moist and had a delicious flavor from the five-spice seasoning.

I went back this week as I was in the area and was really hungry.

Oog, not good. Not good at all.

I had a number five as I loved those in the past. The only good thing about it was the crispy imperial roll, the rest was garbage. The chicken breast was overcooked and tasted not of five-spice, but of an off, chemical-like flavor. 

The rice was so mushy that you couldn't identify individual grains- it was more like a uniform paste.

The meat sauce was orange, and watery, and completely tasteless.

Don't order anything with their "shish kabob" on it. Their version is hard, thin disks of meat that are wandering into beef jerky territory. It's really awful.

Yuck. It was bad.

I'm saddened that I'll never go back. 

P.S.- Don't watch how the cook handles the raw and cooked chicken with the same tongs.
author: Cara N.

description:
Great food but service is hit or miss. Sometimes it's very fast, and sometimes it can be quite slow. If you call in an order during normal hours, wait at least 30 minutes until you head out - even then, you might need to wait 10-15 minutes.

The misc meat sauce they put over the rice is yummy and mysterious... The fried summer roll is very crunchy and oily, so eat at your own risk. The chicken is tender and moist. I always get #5, which means you get a little bit of everything yummy here. Good comfort food.
author: Amy W.

description:
Really?? I'm not sure what all the fuss is about. 

The 5 spice chicken is tender, but really not that flavourful. It's MUCH more tasty at Golden Star in Chinatown, and even Pho Vietnam nearby on Polk does a slightly better version.

Imperial rolls taste like they do at any other Vietnamese place. 

Shish kebab (aka Thit Nuong) again was just average.

It was reasonably cheap, but the price/quality ratio is not good enough to make me want to return. My search for good cheap options within walking distance of my apartment continues *sigh*
author: Jeremy H.

description: I live around the corner! And I love this place! Portions are huge taste amazing and the little lady cooking everything to order is pretty awesome in my book. Not good for big groups. Oh and it's cheap like really cheap! Dinner for 3 was $25 Love!
author: Barbara V.

description:
Come here and get the number #5 meal. It is great, something different. The place says its Vietnamese BBQ but it is really Chinese. The ladies here was speaking Chinese and the only thing about this place that is Vietnamese is the nuc mam sauce (fish sauce). 

My plate was super full, i got the #5 meal. It came with a side of cabbage, rice with meatsauce all over it. A piece of chicken and 3 pieces of steak, marinated very nicely. And one piece of their imperial roll. Everything was really tasty, the meatsauce was something of a surprise to me, i never had that on rice before. Alot of people get just the rice and meatsauce alone. I believe it is only $4.07 with tax. When i was sitting there i think i seen about 4 people get that only. My meal with a soda was about $10 dollars. That is pretty cheap for the amount of food you get. I'm a pretty big guy and it got me stuffed. 

4 Stars for Cordon Bleu in SF
author: Lux K.

description:
Okay, so I've given Cordon Bleu two tries to wow me, and so far I've come away with decent meals at a reasonable price, but nothing that will cause cravings come tomorrow or next week.  I know some people *love* their meat sauce, but I found it kind of bland.  The BBQ chicken was good, but I think it was also a bit under seasoned.  Imperial rolls are a highlight if you like crispy, pork goodness... So Cordon Blue is 3 stars (for me, at least).

I do want to try one of the tofu dishes and maybe the BBQ pork to see if I can find something that grabs me...
author: David S.

description: Always love this place! Tiny, usually a wait, and cash only. The chef, Katie, is so sweet! My bf loves the #5 and I'm all about the noodle bowl. This place is a neighborhood gem.
author: Eli W.

description:
Here's another one of those "what were you expecting?" moments.  

I'm reading other reviews and I gotta say, I'm amused by the ever-so-gently snarky comments.  People will find something to complain about, won't they?

For instance, little frowny harrumphs about Cordon Bleu not being authentically Vietnamese.  Someone came to this admittedly homely, dozen-seat hole in the wall expecting the full authentic panoply of the complex cuisine of a very large country like Vietnam?  Really?  I came for the pork chops.  

Or the straight-faced, slightly furrowed-brow observation that the food is perhaps, well, Americanized.  Well, yeah.  They have to buy the chicken, the pork, the cabbage, the water, and for all I know the 5-spice powder here in, yes, America.  They're serving cheap, tasty, filling meals to--yeah, Americans, mostly.  Americans with Chinese, Vietnamese, Russian, Korean, Chinese, Polish, Italian, German, English, Samoan, Indian, Pinoy, Japanese, and Dutch surnames, and occasionally, palettes.  Have you had Chinese food in Italy?  Newsflash:  It's Italianized.  I haven't found any Vietnamese food in Italy (yet) but I am guessing it will be Italianized too.  You mean western food in China isn't, well, Chinatized?  As far as I know, western food in Vietnam is definitely Vietnamized.  That's kind of the point of Vietnamese food, isn't it?

What the hell are we talking about here people?  A place like Cordon Bleu isn't supposed to be a laboratory to transport you through the time-space continuum to a lunch counter in Ho Chi Minh City!  Such a culinary feat only happens on rare occasions (see my review of Divino) and really, shouldn't be attempted, much less expected.

The only culinary feat that should be evaluated here is:  How was your pork chop?   What did you think of that chicken?  Wasn't that Imperial Roll good?

My pork chops, both carryout and hot on the plate, effing rocked my tastebuds.  My chicken fell off the bone and slathered my tongue with unctuous flavor and made me want to moan like a cheap porn star.  My little beef strips have me calculating my next opportunity to eat them again.

That's all that should count here, people.  That, and the fact that the hardworking staff here are sweet, funny, sassy, kind, and produce some kickass flavors.

If it's too Westernized for you, or not authentically Vietnamese enough for you, my sincere apologies.  I'll just slide into your seat.  I have pork chops to eat.
author: Kevin S.

description:
This restaurant should be in Guy Fieri's Diners ,Drive ins and Dives.   

I think this restaurant only holds up to 20ppl max and I think I am talking about the servers and the cook as well.  It is amazing to see one lady do so much.  She cooks,cleans, clear tables, answers phone calls, she does it all.

Chinese lady serving Vietnamese/Chinese soul food!!!  This by itself , should prompt you to try it.  The set up is very similar to Vietnam on Broadway st.  A whole in a wall with great food.

The menu is very simple.  They serve imperial rolls, pork, five spice chicken, cole slaw salad, meat sauce over rice.   I think you can even have all of that on one plate.  They  serve the best Asian comfort food in the city and at a very reasonable price.  Don't expect to be wined and dined here.  You are here to eat and get your grub on and nothing else.

Gotta love these mom and pop restaurants!!!!
author: jason g.

description:
My dining companion told me this epitomizes Asian comfort food, and I whole-heartedly agree.

The #5 

Massive pile of steamed rice topped with tomato-based meat gravy, one imperial roll, one half roasted 5 spice chicken breast or thigh, a 4 oz piece of flank steak and country salad (which is just cabbage slaw marinated in a rice wine vinegar dressing).

Not bad for $8.95. 
It's enough food for 2 full meals.
author: May T.

description:
So what if she's picking up the towel that she wiped the grill with using the same tongs that she's picking up the food with...? After which is placed on the side of the grill, where who knows what lives? I have a strong stomach. And I haven't seen many reviews of anyone getting sick, so that's a good sign.

The food was tasty. Mystery meat sauce? I'm a total fan. I can ignore that first paragraph up top and return to this place for the meat sauce! The owner tells me it's traditional Vietnamese meat sauce. Whether it really is or not, I like it.

A nice stop if you're going to watch a movie at the Lumiere next door! Go here if you want a LOT of food!
author: Tinna H.

description:
craving sweets in napa? YOU HAFTA check my next review!!!

***

WOOHOO! it's as good as it gets!!! 

this is SERIOUSLY GOOOOD STUFF !!! 

i'm SOOO bad ... SOOO SOOO bad ... i'm supposed to be doing my school paper since it's due in less than 24 hrs, but of course, i dread it to the VERY LAST minute that i end up going for a pilates session in the morning, then to cordon bleu for a grubbity dub... =D *burp* now, i must go for my personal training session in a few ... mairin, i'm dreading class ... =D see you in a few girly~~~*

cordon bleu IS SERIOUSLY AS DINGY AS IT GETS but I LOVEEEEEEEEE IT ... cozy, warm, friendly, and good food!!! it's seriously as if your mom was making you that homemade cooking... you can ACTUALLY WATCH the folks cook right in front of you... 

who says people from beverly hills can't appreciate hole the walls? lol.

screw you~

this place probably seats up to 10 ppl max, and the restroom is as good as it gets ... you can barely hover, and at the same time, wonder whether someone's going to knock your head down as you try to aim ... lol but anyways ... the food was SUPER good and i shit you not, the owner will spoil you ... my friend has been coming here for YEARS and the only difference is? the price. this is possibly the VERY best chicken you will probably have OUTSIDE of VIETNAM!

lots to choose from ... lunch specials from $5 and up ... you can even pick and choose a la carte from $2 and up ... there's 5 special platters but i have to say, i HIGHLY* suggest #5. you get a piece of spicy roasted chicken, 1 FAT imperial roll, 1 shish kebab (bomb!) and a side of country salad with meat sauce on top of your rice ... that gravy was supppper...  they even have several house specials,such as spicy pork chop, noodle/chicken salad, mapo tofu, $7 and up..

SUPER SUPER CHEAP and with the amount they give you, you will be pleased ... TRUST ME, i EAT aLOT ... 

for you vegetarian lovers, they have a stuff for you too~!!!

tip: closed on mondays ... & CASH only ...
author: Jennifer S.

description: best. chicken. ever.
author: Carlos A.

description:
Don't knock it till you try it.

It's really not that bad, I like the number five with the 5 spice chicken. At first, I was terrified by the location and dining area, but the food was the real deal. I don't think I would come here regularly but it's worth a visit if you never been. I might if someone suggest it. Definitely worth a bite after drinking.
author: Stanley K.

description:
So I believe the best way to eat your way around SF is to ask the locals, and in our case those happened to be our good friends who have lived there for a few years now. My Husband & I started our reunion evening off with a little wine tasting and on to a couple other bars, and  naturally after a few pops we started getting hungry. My friend asked us if we liked Asain food and we said yes, next thing we know we are sitting at the counter of Cordon Bleu. Many things were running through my head when I first sat down, including the tiny size of the place, the one little lady cooking like crazy behind the counter and of course the mouth watering smell of the food she was grilling up. My friend turned to me at this point and said "Dont be scared, this is really good". To be honest, I needed a little reassurance!! This isn't exactly a fine dining establishment. But I was brave and buzzed and ready to eat whatever that delicious smell was.
Man was he right. Some of the best food we have had in a while actually. My Husband and I shared the grilled chicken breast with "meat sauce" and a couple spring rolls. All of which were exploding with flavor and down-home asain cooking. The meat was fall off the bone tender and seasoned with seriously delicious asain spices. The "meat sauce" was so unique, I guess I would describe it as an Asain gravy. The spring rolls were lightly fried and packed with veggies.The best way I can describe it would be that it was like Katie, the Cook/Owner had invited us to a backyard BBQ at her house. 
The atmosphere was warm, inviting and friendly and the food was nothing short of awesome. I have been craving it ever since and I cannot wait to go back. Seriously, so good!! Thank you SF friends!!
author: Cristy N.

description: I love this place!  Delizz chicken and imperial roll, large portion, and good service.  During rush hours for dinner especially, the wait can be long.  I usually come to Cordon Bleu once a week during lunch, and order a 1/2 chicken and roll to go.  The owner lady is always nice and she grills the chicken crispy (per my request).  Yummy!
author: Meiko S.

description:
The barbecue chicken, shish kabob, and imperial roll combination is delicious.

The food comes on top of a plate of rice with meat sauce.  The meat sauce is cooked in a large stock pot and they continue to reduce it in smaller sauce pans before pouring it generously over the rice.

The imperial rolls have this great crunch and even though they're deep fried, they don't have that greasy taste.

The chicken is tender and moist even though the outside looks crisp.

The shish kabob meat is also tender and flavorful.

They've got a pretty good selection of other foods, but #5 should be your first choice
author: Jason K.

description: I came here after reading many rave reviews for their five spiced chicken. So, this past week I had a chance one afternoon to come for lunch and try it. Maybe it's just my taste buds or something but, though it was good, it wasn't excellent in flavor. On the other hand, ordering it as a rice plate totaling around $6.75 after tax and it including pork beans and a small salad, it was a very good deal. Also, as a small restaurant with one person doing all the cooking in full view and one helper, I have to give them an extra star for that.
author: H K.

description: I got the dish that came with meat sauce over rice, BBQ beef, fried imperial roll, pickled cabbage, and fish sauce on the side. The combination of flavor and quality among all those ingredients made this an awesome dish. The meat was smokey, imperial crispy, and cabbage a refreshing complement to both. On top of all that, it's a mountain of food that you can't help, but devour and become overly full since it's so good. It's a tiny place with a lot of food cooking, so your clothes will surely smell after, but it's well worth it.
author: Andrew N.

description:
Wow.....with the dollar falling so fast, we could be using it for toilet paper soon.  before that happens, drop by this place & enjoy.  a small family operation that gives really good food, huge portions for a cheap price.  

a very small dining area so come for a early dinner.  the imperial rolls are so good that you won't care about your diet.  the grilled kebabs are very flavorful.. thin cut good beef with a rich flavor that comes from some secret family concoction.  they do a mouth watering 5 spice chicken that is so good that i just ate the left overs for breakfast.. the rice comes with this sauce that has changed thru the years.  original Vietnamese to this tomatoe/beef sauce similiar to  spaghetti sauce. still good 

do tell them not to over cook items or you will have beef or chicken jerky.
parking can be difficult so avoid peak dinner hours. no parking lot but plenty of street parking.  service is good.  usually your waving like mad before anyone thinks you need service .

 i thought i would have to do a table dance to get attention for extra napkins or water refill. this was not the case.  
i loss out at having some dollar bills stuffed down my undies.  boo hoo hoo.  water & extra napkins refilled/replaced, take out orders not stacked to the height of the leaning tower of New Pisa, etc...

a good experience so check it out.
author: Dan W.

description:
Gather round, ladies, I'm about to divulge a huge secret:  I'm a lightweight.  Yup, manly Phil H. gets buzzed at the whiff of alcohol. So if you ever want to get me drunk and take advantage of me it wouldn't cost you much money. On that note, after three pints of Guinness at John Barleycorn I needed food stat. Luckily Cordon Bleu and their world famous Five Spice Chicken was right around the corner.  I ordered the #5 and a few minutes later was greeted with a huge plate full of food. The chicken was fantastic but I swear I'm tasting at least three of the five spices this morning.  
Four stars for good, cheap food served in a bare bones setting by a friendly staff.
author: phil h.

description:
Cordon Bleu is quite ordinary at first glance. It's a ten seat counter with faux Vietnamese food served for Polk Gulch scenesters on a budget. 80% of the menu is served in "meat sauce". As best as I can tell, it's definitely "meat", but the rest of the ingredients remain a mystery to me. I'd rather not ask to be completely honest.

What makes Cordon Bleu remarkable is the amazingly efficient staff. One woman, who happens to be the owner, cooks your meal on a stove about 2 feet from the counter. She will also take to-go orders, work the cash register, hand out menus, appease drunk diners, visit with "regulars", tell John T he is a nice singer. There is also another woman who preps the meat and rice in the back room, and one dishwasher guy who well...washes dishes.

The owner manages to handle all these responsibilities while operating in a work place about 50 square feet. AMAZING. She is my hero.

Tomorrow, when I'm writing C# code in my cubicle, I'm going to multi-task too. Maybe drink coffee AND tea in two different cups. Maybe. 4 stars.
author: John T.

description:
Eat here only if you enjoy that surprising crunchiness in random bites.  

Because you are chomping on a cockroach.  (What, you didn't know that "cordon bleu" means "cockroach" in Vietnamese?!)

A friend had brought take-out to the office and shared, and the chicken was yummy , so thought to give this place a whirl.  

There was a roach on the chair, two on the table, and I saw one inching its way toward my purse.  

One was too much.  But to see four!  I think I now need to commit hari kari!  

Where is the SF Board of Health?  They need a new inspection.
author: Bevy M.

description:
I was struck with a craving so bad that I ignored the two star reviews for this restaurant.  Of course, I was mentally stuck in a time warp from back in the late 70's when I first discovered this place.  Back then, it was hard to ignore the line of people waiting to get in every night.  The food was pure deliciousness.  Flash forward to today.  The original owners gone, along with their delicious food.  The meat sauce is a bland tomatoey sauce.  There is more salt than flavor in the shish kebab.  The imperial roll may be big but that's different too.  It was lighter and crispier.  
The only thing that is the same is the fish sauce.  People will still like this food.   It's cheap and filling.  But I wish I hadn't eaten it.  I would still have the lasting  memory of what it used to be
author: R L.

description:
The best. Dirt cheap - $8.25 for a whole heap of food. Amazing deep fried Imperial Rolls. Best chicken I've had since spring break in Jamaica. Also, some Nob Hill crazy dramatically graced us with his presence at one point and started serenading the guy sitting to the right of me. 

It was awesome. The bum was shirtless and musically incorrigible, a remarkable combination. He and the owner engaged in quite the conversation which can be neatly summed up by imagining a small Vietnamese women screaming 'Leave!' and a rather ragged-looking, shirtless intruder singing about the days of yore when he was a young buck in Hollywood. 

If I ever become a script writer, I will include this scene in every movie I write, no matter how out of place it is. I will stubbornly demand that Jeremy Piven continuously reprise his role as the bum. Eventually directors and producers will become furious with my refusal to omit this scene, I will go broke, return to San Francisco and barge shirtless, broken and poor into Cordon Bleu singing about my days of yore in Hollywood. Oh, life comes full circle.

Additionally, to all the sissies out there who say something akin to 'The food is excellent, but it's just soooo dirty,' I have two words: Grow Up and Stop nitpicking (as you are now, no doubt, because I've overrun my 2 word limit).
author: Tom C.

description:
Look for the tacky sign over the hole in the wall that reads "5 SPICE CHICKEN".

As it turns out, the chicken is great.
author: slayerela b.

description:
The stars are for the food (this is a mom and pop hole in the wall).  The grilled chicken on rice with meat sauce is a mixture of great flavors and textures.  The meat sauce over rice is amazing.  Just a word of warning, their serving sizes are large so be prepared to come starving or plan on leaving with leftovers.

Things I love at Cordon Bleu in order of passion:

Meat sauce over rice
5 Spice Chicken
Imperial Rolls
Pork Chop

Everything else is decent but not swoon-inducing.  Vegetarians will be sadly.  

Your clothes will smell a bit as they grill in front of you.
author: MJ C.

description: Hahahah this place is awesome. Super tiny and ridiculously homey. Cheap with huge portions. Menu is crazy simple - gigantic Imperial roll, flat pork meat or chicken in various combinations. It's all good. Tasty and cheap!
author: Joe G.

description:
Everyone raves about Cordon Bleu's chicken,  but I have two alternate words for your consideration:

1) Garlic (n) - a European allium (Allium sativum) widely cultivated for its pungent compound bulbs much used in cookery

2) Tofu (n) - a soft food product prepared by treating soybean milk with coagulants (as magnesium chloride or diluted acids) --called also bean curd 

String these two everyday words together at Cordon Bleu, and you get their legendary Garlic Tofu - so good it can't really be defined in mere verbal superlatives. How can such heavenly fare be available for under ten bucks?
author: Leela S.

description: Just like eating in a street restaurant in Vietnam.  Small, dirty, but what great flavor and food. Just sit up at the counter and watch the food cooked about 3 ft from your seat.  The meat gravy they put over the rice is wonderful.  Order the #5 for a large sample of everything.  And only $9 for enough food for two.
author: Don D.

description:
HEAPS of food.  I, for one, DO NOT really like the meat sauce.  It makes the rice even heavier than it already is.  The chicken is really great and the deep fried egg rolls are SUPER crispy.  

We also like the noodle salad - a 'bun' approximation.

It's not authentic Vietnamese, it's fusion.  And I mean that in the literal, not trendy, sense.
author: Calvin N.

description:
I used to live live about three blocks from this place... In that whole three-year period of time, I NEVER set foot in the place... There are only two reasons for this...

1. I saw the name "Cordon Bleu" and assumed it was an expensive French place...

2. I'm an idiot.

...well, thanks to Kristina R.'s suggestion, I finally made it over...

I'm happy to report that it was worth the wait (even if I was too dim to know that I was, in fact, "waiting")... 

It's a little, hole in the wall place... two tables, I believe, and counter seats all around... the menu claims it has the "Best Chicken outside of Viet Nam"... I've been to Viet Nam (they do have excellent chicken there)... and the chicken salad I had was fantastic.... the price was right... and the other dishes I saw people ordering and eating also looked uniformly good... The woman behind the counter was friendly: "You want hot tea?" ...umm... I guess so.. "Good, because it's right here, so I don't have to go way over there..."

... Be prepared to be stared at by the people waiting in line to get seats... I think I picked up my fork (with the final piece of chicken) and brought it to my mouth about five times, only to put it back down and continue a conversation... I didn't look behind me, but I could feel the eyes burning a hole in my back... that stunt should have got me arrested... (sorry about that.)
author: John M.

description:
The chicken is amazing, the sauce is amazing, the noodles are amazing, the spices are amazing. 

I get the noodle salad every time I come here and I love it. I brought my friends here after B2B and it really hit the spot! It literally is a hole in the wall with a bar setting that seats maybe 10 and a small table in the back. The woman that cooks is super nice and really takes care of you! 

Cheap and amazing, could you really ask for more in life? :)
author: Jessica R.

description:
Alright these guys dont get 5 stars cuz there's only 1 cook and she's busy doing everything including taking orders and the cashier.

This place gets 4 stars cuz the food was good, the service was friendly and we were all stuffed.

We ordered meat sauce over rice i was hungry so i was liking it
the egg rolls were crispy and gude
the chicken was grilled and was nice and tender

i was not to big of a fan for the pork though, however she was so nice she gave us some to try for free.

bottom line i will bring some friends to try, it was priced well 4 people 45 bucks or so.
author: DOM d.

description:
After living just a block away from this joint for nearly 4 years the BF and I decided to give it a shot. 

It's little, maybe seats 15 people and has mostly counter seating. The menu is pretty basic. Meat and rice and a couple variations, but the most expensive thing I saw was $8.50. I knew immediately I'd like this place. 

I should however start at the beginning. We did not make reservations, I'm not sure that you can, so we showed up at about 8 p.m. Saturday night. Every seat was taken, but there wasn't a line. We went inside, expressed our desire to be seated, and were told "just a few minutes" and in an effort to not be rude to other customers, we went outside.  About 5 minutes later, a group of 4 occupying two of the three actual tables left and we sat ourselves down. 

I ordered the #5...which if memory serves included the spiced chicken, rice, meat kabob, salad, and imperial roll. My companion ordered the Pork Chop meal, and a chicken combo...he was very hungry and indecisive. In the downtime, we discuss how very quite the place is for being so small, low conversations and the grill are the only sources of noise, there's no music and no cooks shouting orders. 

Our canned cokes were delivered promptly, and the BF's plain salad (but the dressing was good) but wait, didn't my meal include a salad too? Maybe, i don't remember. Or maybe they're bring it, I'll just wait. 

A few minutes later the waitress brings a heaping plate of chicken, rice and cabbage. The BF receives a heaping plate of rice and pork chops. The lady says to the BF "I'll be right back with one more pork chop" a few minutes later she delivers one with her tongs fresh from the grill. Amazing. 

So, everything seems to be in order, but wait, didn't ! order a meal with a roll of some sort and a kabob? And didn't the BF get some chicken too? Well either something was lost in translation or we misread the menu. But, I'm not too concerned cause the food was amazing. and I was very satisfied after eating about 1/4 of what was on my plate. 

The best part: we left full with ample leftovers for a midnight snack, all for $25. 

We'll definitely be back, but we'll be careful to communicate our orders more clearly. 

And bring cash, they don't' take anything else.
author: Lara L.

description:
stopped here before the opera for a quick bite.  the place is teeny tiny and you are literally sitting two feet in front of the stove.  charming.  i love grease on my face.

the food was alright.  the meat sauce that covers the rice was odd...it tasted like watered down ketchup with mystery minced meat in it.  i ate it anyway.  the chicken was unremarkable, except burnt.

i do have to say it was cheap....but oh wait, as i was leaving, the owner was going through the menu with a customer/friend and will raise prices.  so go soon!
author: Sally T.

description:
I don't know why I have never reviewed this old "stand by." I have lived within a few blocks for 15 years and I used to go here ALL THE TIME. Then, suddenly for no reason I stopped going. Maybe I got burnt out. I don't know. I went last week again and was blown away by how good it was. So, naturally, I went again last night and was equally impressed. Addiction is back on.
There's a lot not to like about this place admittedtly (it's too small and a dive) but I go for the food, as do most others. It does also have a great ambience with the staff and clientel, who appear to be regulars. I may soon join the ranks again.
I love the spicy pork chops. I remember when they first started serving them. I got them every time for a while, but I'm back to "Number 5" these days - chicken, kebab and imperial roll.
Chicken is juicy and charred to perfection. I don't know how they get it so tasty, it just appears like regular chicken but taste is divine. The kebab is also quite tasty, a liittle chewy but nice. The imperial rolls totally rock. They cook them slowly in an electric fryer and they come out piping hot and freakin awesome. All this piled up around a huge mound of rice and their famous "meat sauce" with some cabbage salad to boot and you've got one of the tastier meals in the 'hood, on the cheap at that.
I may just incorporate this place into my weekly routine again. If you're looiking for quaint, this ain't it. Authentic, probably not. I hate to say it, but "slap yo mamma awesome?" - CHECK!
author: Matt H.

description:
Chicken, pork, pork-meat sauce-
Small, just as small as you'd think,
but cleaner, brighter, with flowers
Cheap, packed, filling
author: Jake H.

description: Wow trippy scene. Lady literally cooking in front if you. If you're squimish about cross contamination, stay home. If however you want the best fried spring rolls and chicken    Noodle salad, this is the place. Have your anxiety eraser of choice prior to arriving, it'll make it easier to handle.
author: Eric C.

description:
I wanted to like this place so bad.  The woman behind the counter is really sweet and friendly.  The food portions are huge.  Yeah, the place definitely needs a good wash and scrubbing, but this rarely bothers me.

It's just that this place has such mediocre food!  Nothing tastes bad, but there's just nothing to write home about.  The "infamous" marinated chicken...is just marinated chicken.  I had expected more vietnamese influenced flavors.  And the meat sauce?  Wish I didn't have any.  Oh, and the rice was mushy, which annoys me more than anything in an asian restaurant.   I enjoyed my imperial roll...but I have a weakness for anything deep fried. 

It makes me sad thinking about all the great meals I could have had elsewhere, for the same (ungodly) amount of calories.
author: Cathy S.

description: Continuing the new obsession with Vietnamese, we continued on the quest to Cordon Bleu. You can catch all of the grill top action right at the counter, and the food lives up to its reputation. Tasty spring rolls on top of noodles? Yes, please. My meat-eating companions enjoyed the chicken and pork, and my veggies were great.
author: Jessica R.

description:
Ouch, I went to this place with friends before catching a movie next door.

Decor - felt depressing, 2 guys who looked down on their luck eating alone. Short counter, felt like I didn't have enough space from the person next to me. The place felt pretty dirty, and if you look at what's happening in the kitchen behind the counter, it's not a pretty sight. The chicken was stored about 3 inches off the floor on a shelf, close to where the staff is walking. Also noticed that their SF cleanliness score which was hanging on the wall was an 80 or so, that's the LOWEST score I have ever seen. I decided to keep an open mind while they were cooking up my #1 - which is kebab (some sort of marinated beef), with a huge plate of rice with 'country meat sauce' and some cabbage.

When the food arrived, I felt like I was serving time in a prison and this is what I'd be eating for my crimes.  The country meat sauce was a tasteless watery mess, the meat was overcooked and dry, and the cabbage had no flavoring that I could detect.

No bueno on any measure.
author: Spoon G.

description: Loved it! The garlicky kebob was amazing and magical. The ambiance was epic. Limited menu of meatly savories. Cheap, delish, but no Pho. Lovely owner cooks in front of you -- no Marxist commidity fetishism there. No complaints.
author: Andrew K.

description: Love Katy's food.  My first time was last night thanks to my boyfriend who has lived in the city for about 30yrs plus.  He knows all the great local spots in SF.  Thank you for taking me honey.
author: Scheryl W.

description:
True story...
I was walking around town and out of the blue "wo xiang mapo dofu" enters my brain.  But where does one get mapo dofu?  So I walk down to Chinatown.  Not being familiar with the area I can't find any good cheap  Sichuan restaurants to fit the bill.  After a dissapointing walk down Stockton I return back down California.  Then I happen up on this sign for Cordon Bleu Vietnamese.  And luck be a lady that I find some mapo tofu on the short menu.  

A couple of teas, a plate full of spicy tofu and some pork from the grill (compliments of the cook) and I was a happy man.  

Everyone else (and I mean everyone) was coming in for the chicken.  I gotta get back to try.
author: Jason R.

description:
Favorite takeout spot! 

I've never actually eaten here but we get take out every two weeks. It was 1-2 times a week for a little while there, but we've chilled out a bit since then. 

The #5 is the way to go. Ultimate comfort food in every way.
author: Francesca Z.

description:
Cordon Bleu is the kind of place that could only work in an urban setting. Luckily, here we are!

The food is, well, strange. Everything is oddly sweet, but it's a flavor that grows on you.

When ordering, the combos are where it's at. They all include rice with "meat sauce." They don't specify the type of meat; I couldn't tell, and no, I wasn't asking.

The chicken, described on the menu as "possibly the best chicken you will ever have outside of Vietnam," is pretty tasty but far from the best I've had, even in San Francisco.

None-the-less, Cordon Bleu deserves four stars. It's a dining experience you can only have right here at California & Polk and it's an incredible value. Most of the combos are about $7 and include more food than you can possibly eat.

The place is tiny, so show up with just one good friend to make getting a seat easier. With dinner, I recommend a big glass of water to prepare your falsetto for when you're belting out "More Than A Feeling" at Encore, next door, after dinner.

You know the one! "Its more than a feeling, when I hear that old song they used to play..."
author: Brad L.

description:
A tiny little place that you can accidentally walk right by even when you are looking for it. The chow is pretty good and the portions are plentiful, so you won't walk away feeling cheated. Most of the stuff is cooked on a small grill out front, which is also where the pots full of meat sauce are simmering.  The meat sauce is ladled over a healthy portion of rice with most of the dishes, but there are some dishes (such as the pork chops) that come with rice and some chopped green onions.  

Which reminds me, the menu isn't all that useful.  You can get "meat with rice and meat sauce" or "chicken with rice and meat sauce" or ...  Umh, is that barbequed chicken, fried chicken, boiled chicken, raw chicken (hey, its popular in Japan)?  Well, you get the idea, but don't get put off by this.  If it won't fall through the grill, it's probably bbq'd.  Just order, you'll be happy.   The other shortcoming is the beverage menu is limited -- no beer.

All in all, the food is tasty, the portions are more than sufficient, and the price is right.  Check it out if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Tom Y.

description:
OMG. I have been hearing about this place for so long now, and always forget to visit. Finally, tonight i brought a friend of mine there. Well we ordered the #5..... DELISH! Super filling, tasty... and cheap! They say their chicken is the best, and they were right. 
Oh... and they dont serve any alcohol.... BUT you can bring your own drinks in. BYOB. Love it.
author: Cameron H.

description:
Hmmm...
I'm not feeling the excitement of some other yelpers, I gotta say.  The chicken is good, and the shish kebab is yum.  The cabbage salad is surprisingly good -- love that tart dressing.  But, back to the chicken -- it was definitely good, but didn't revolutionize my life or anything.  It was good chicken, well flavored, cooked on a grill.  The meat sauce was kinda meh to my taste, but when I added some spicy sauce and mixed it in, it was pretty special.
I wouldn't recommend, personally, going out of your way to go here, but if I was in the area and craving chicken, it would definitely be the place to go.
author: Smog R.

description:
With a name like Cordon Bleu, I was thinking that this place was going to be some fancy, bland, over-priced vietnamese food..but when I got there, it was the complete opposite.  Wow!  This has got to be the smallest establishment that I've EVER eaten in!  I wanna say that they can only seat about 12 people at a time...so...if you're REALLY hungry...I hope you're also patient!  

Love the ladies that work here!  They must've asked if my food was ok about 5 times (...maybe it was because they knew that i was from san jose...where the majority of authentic vietnamese restaurants stand!  ....or...maybe they just knew that i was a part of their people)!  awww...they remind me of the sweet lil' ol' grandma that I've never had!  

I'd have to say that this has got to be my favorite vietnamese food joint in the city!  ...now, if only they delivered!
author: Nancy T.

description:
We slammed this teeny place with 8 people in one fell swoop on an early Saturday evening.  This didn't take into account the steady stream of other patrons who called or walked in for to-go orders.  I braced myself for stressed-out 2+hour service that might yield really fantastic 5-spice chicken.

And wonder of wonders -- the gracious and friendly staff performed some sort of magic ballet behind the counter and we were all eating that wonderful grilled chicken in about 45 minutes!

I was actually a bit amazed at the number of workers that staffed this place -- at first it seemed there were 2 only proprietors, but by the end of the evening I counted at least 5 people sharing the various duties of grilling, salad-making, drink-serving, counter-cleaning and supplies-schlepping.

And yes, I couldn't bring myself to touch the meat sauce that evening, but yes on the generous chicken portions; yes on the simple, refreshing country salad, and yes on the delicious imperial rolls.  And YES for the ridiculously low amounts of $6-7 per entree!
author: Claudine C.

description:
The owner is such a nice lady.

The place is literally a big kitchen with a counter and some stools. 

Menu was simple and the food was delicious. Very afforable also. 

The gravy they put on the rice is liquid crack.

Very divey, very neighborhood-y feel. Very my kind of joint.

Apparently has been open for 40 odd years.

Will be back for sure.
author: Rocky K.

description:
Wow, this place just barely passed the food safety inspection. I'm sure of it. But these type of places (dirty, grimy, barely passed food safety) always make for the best restaurants. Funny and ironic how things work out.

This place just surpassed Tu-Lan as my favorite cheap eats.

The lady working the grill is super nice and awesome. If she were a man, and I was a woman, I would have her babies. I overheard her speaking mandarin and Cantonese. Is she even Vietnamese? WTF?! No matter, I'd still have her babies.

There is only 1 menu item you need concern yourself with here, and that is Combo #5. Do not worry about ordering anything else because #5 is the most bang for your buck (yes, key word here... VALUE... a reoccurring theme for me because I am a cheap bastard.) Combo #5 is about $8.65 or so, and that comes with 3 scrumptious items. You get.... (1) the imperial roll (2) 3 slices of marinated grilled meat. I think it's pork. (3) the 5 spice chicken. All this is served with salad and rice topped with "meat sauce". Seriously, that is what it says on the menu... "meat sauce".......

To be honest, the chicken is not as awesome as they advertise. It was good, but not great. Could have been more flavorful and a bit more juicy. But the marinated meats were great. The meat sauce must be some grade D quality ground meat of some type. Perhaps dog? I hear the Vietnamese get down like that. The GF is Vietnamese, I should know. But whatever, it doesn't matter what meat is used because it's really great regardless.
author: Jay W.

description:
Amazing food, great prices.
Be prepared for a tiny place with little seating and AMAZING BBQ!  I've been going here for over 20 years and It's my favorite hole in the wall in all of SF.
If it's too crowded, just order take-out.  It'll be worth it!
author: Steph J.

description:
So My girlfriends trendy hipster brother insists this is the place.

Maybe for pathetic scenester clones. 

The foods same ole homestyle fare. Nothing special, another geedunk of the bay area. Tasty inexpensive no frills.
we were stuck next to some deteriorating yuppies babbling about real estate. ( Kinda when coked out Metal guitarists babble about getting their band back together.) 

So its, Ho hum for the food.
The customers are as neurotic as all hell
But everyone needs their place in the sun.
That place just isn't for me.
2 stars and thats pushing it.
author: vinnie g.

description: The meat sauce taste so similar to the HK baked pork chop dishes in LA cafés. Because of that I'm giving this place 4 stars! Ultimate comfort food.
author: Jenny J.

description:
I hate to say it, but i've seen a walk-in closet bigger than this place. If ur claustrophobic, i don't recommend eating in here; Just order ur food to go like i did.
The food, however, is very good. I ordered entree #5 (the five spiced roast chix) It's very pleasing to the palate and it certainly filled me up. Lemmie tell u, it got its own authentic taste. I'm definetely coming back here.
author: Rick B.

description:
As a native and resident of SF that grew up in this approximate neighborhood, I'm almost ashamed that it took me over 25 years to initially find this spot! 

The only time I do stop in here (every couple of years) is if I happen to be driving by, am hungry, totally slumming AND there is a parking space I can immediately see and snag. And I always get it to go. 

Grilled chicken is basically already cooked and re-heated on the grill once you order it. Rice with "meat sauce"...well, I didn't actually ask what kind of meat it is, but it's palatable. I think it's better that way...not knowing, that is. Garden salad? Pretty pathetic: maybe if I was a rabbit...

Haven't bothered to try anything else on the limited menu. 

Bottom line:

It IS what it is.
author: J C.

description:
The food is delicious! I got a #1 and the friends got #5's.  HUGE portions...totally worth the moolah!  I would normally give it 5 stars cause its so damn good...but man...

i ended up sitting at a back table where i was fully exposed to what goes on behind the bar dining area.  Pleasure with my sense of taste...not so much with my eyes =(.  I'll be back more, but only as a take out lady...the place is pretty small so i wouldnt come here with more than 2+ people.

...everything was damn good...had to take some home cuase there was way too much for a little woman...and it still tasted great at 2am!
author: Gladys D.

description:
Out of all the "Hole in the Wall" places in the bay area, I would have to say this is one of the best for the money. Five Stars for taste, portion size and cost!

The name of the restaurant is a little misleading. It really isn't a vietnamese restaurant. Rather, it's more of an "asian comfort food" place.

The thinly sliced grilled beef filets (called shish kabobs) plus large imperial roll combined with a special meat sauce all over a generous portion of rice and side of chopped cabbage (Combo #1) is something wonderful that is not duplicated anywhere else in the bay area.

The decor reminds me of a small old style diner complete with small counter area and a couple of small tables. Its really a no frills "Hole in the Wall", however the chinese woman that operates the business is very friendly! 

I have been enjoying this place since the early 1980s. The menu is limited and It hasn't changed much over the years, however, why change a good thing? The food has been consistently great for the value. 

Eating by the counter on a warm fall evening and watching the tourist ride by on the cable car is truly a "local" San Francisco experience.
author: Donavan T.

description: What's there not to love? Love the tomato sauce, love the imperial roll, love the portion, love the price!
author: Phuc N.

description: Cheap, fast, and yummy! Great hole in the wall Vietnamese food. Open late for hungries and those who do not want to wait in the line.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
Savor the delicious spices in the grilled chicken and "shish kebab."  This is some real comfort food, that sticky rice with meat sauce is great on a rainy day.  

Expect to wait for a seat at the small counter or single table, great service from the owner/chef/waitress, and to pay only chump change for a big plate of food.  

Don't expect anything fancy, or to be thrilled by the SFDPH rating.  They're cooking the marinated meat from that bucket on the floor so fast, nothing really has a chance to jump in there first.  I hope.
author: Ken B.

description: Incredible chicken, pork, and meat sauce. If you're planning on drunk karaoke at encore, stop off here on the way and fill your belly with goodness.
author: Tom W.

description:
Meals are all under $10. But you'll be surprised of how filling and yummy they are!!!!!

Pick a bar seat and go for meal No4. Enjoy the BBQ presentation and the delicious dishes!!!
author: Chiqui H.

description:
I don't really get what the fuss is about with this place. Yeah it's a hole in the wall, but so what? Does it really assuage your corporate guilt or make you feel that much cooler to come here? 

The food's alright if you need something cheap, substantial and fast, but it doesn't really stretch beyond that. Five spice chicken ($5.75) was two huge pieces of grilled chicken, the skin all blackened and crispy and with a slight hint of the spice flavor but nothing distinctive. Because the pieces were so big, this flavor couldn't really seep into the white meat inside which tasted fairly bland.

The shish kebab ($2.60) was more disappointing. It's not really a shish kebab - skewered chunks of meet - more thin strips of pork streaked with black lines from the grill. It had reasonably smoky flavor but again nothing all that special. 

In the menu set this came with an Imperial roll which I changed to a fresh Vietnamese spring roll. This was vegetarian with some tofu inside. It didn't taste bad, but the things inside seemed a little bland and it didn't really have that crispness of fresh vegetables which the best Vietnamese spring rolls can give. It came with a thick peanut sauce akin to peanut butter.

In the sets we had (numbers 1 and 4), both these dished were plonked on a pile of white rice that had been covered in meat sauce. This sauce has hints of tomato ketchup about it and little pieces of pork. It gave the rice some flavor but really didn't do much more. The 'country salad' which accompanies is really just a small heap of shredded cabbage.  

People will probably keep coming here for that 'mom and pop' feel. But there are definitely better places within walking distance for around the same price. If you're looking for Vietnamese then brave the crazies of the Tenderloin and head down Larkin Street. If you want kebabs, hit Myconos Greek restaurant, or De Afghanan Kabob House, which are both nearby on Polk.   

We had food to take away, calling over the phone first. The food was ready when I arrived to pick it up.
author: Nick O.

description: What a great little hidden gem!  I am not sure if I would have ever found this place without knowing about it beforehand.  It definitely has a dive look, but I wasn't going there for the scenery, it was all about food, food, food.  The chicken was juicy and the portions were large, but the prices were low.  Also, liked that the chef/owner was carrying a cookbook around with her.  I liked that she seemed to be so invested in cooking the best food possible.  Yum!
author: Kate J.

description: love this little hole in the wall. 5 spice chicken, imperial roles, meat sauce over rice, and byob. so delicious!
author: erik l.

description: This restaurant is definitely a hole in the wall. I've been coming here since I was a child and man, does this place still have it. The food is delicious, the meat sauce is to die for. I always get the #1, the kebab and imperial roll on top of a bed of rice and meat sauce. So good. And although the place is super small, and the decor is almost non-existent the staff is really friendly and the food is good and cheap.
author: Mellani L.

description:
I just moved into a tiny one-bedroom apartment in Nob Hill/Tenderlion -Ajacent neighborhood.

I am sad to leave my cute colorful two-bedroom in the much more inviting neighborhhod of Hayes Valley but I am consolued by having Cordon Blue only two blocks away.

The #4 and #5 are the only things I would recommend ordinaring because they are so amazing.

I also recommend that the first few times you eat this delicious five spiced food you eat in the diner an the counter. You must do this until you can recall from memory the master skills in which these ladies BBQ the chicken and pork.
author: Sara K.

description: This place is a very good place to go if you like inexpensive food and not looking for anything fancy. Great big portions and the meat sauce is addictive!! Chicken is tender with good flavor. Go for any of the combos and you will get your monies worth!
author: Wolfy W.

description:
The best treasures are kept hidden.  Needless to say, Cordon Bleu is a hole in the wall Vietnames restaurant that no one ever talks about.  But the food is absolutely delicious.

BBQ Chicken or Pork rice plates is their specialty.  You might have been to other Viet restaurants in the city, but nothing like this one though.  Check this out.  Ever had spaghetti meat sauce on top of your rice?  How bout a Vietnamese egg roll on top of that?  Some coleslaw?  You think it's wierd now, just wait until you try it.  Some of the best comfort food there is. 

I wish this place was opened at 2AM after the club!
author: Roland L.

description:
There is nothing better than a deep fried Imperial Roll that burns the living hell out of your tongue, inner cheek,lips, and that possible cavity on your left back tooth. 
The meat sauce on the rice is so super yummy...they do not specify what animal the meat sauce comes from...but I like to think of it as when my dad would give us some random pot of stew and tell us it was chicken. 
Well thank you dad, because now I do not even flinch when a waitstaff says, "Well, yes ma'am, that IS guinea pig you have eaten."
Anyways...the food is yummy and freshly made, and it is enough food for at least a midnight snack.  
Don't expect matching silverwear, plates, or disposable napkins for that matter.  Nothing matches, the menu is a old worn down green sheet of paper, and its really really small.  Super yummy though.  You guys definately need to try it.
author: Janet R.

description:
Wow! What a great spot! Ignoring the name.... I dig everything about this place. It's has everything I was looking for in a Vietnamese restaurant. I felt like I was in Vietnam, visiting someones home for dinner. No bells, no whistles. Just awesome food at a great price. 

They don't have a huge confusing menu, very basic, and they do it right. I had a half chicken bbq'd with rice, meat sauce and a spring roll. My girlfriend had the noodle salad... both were delicious. Quick side note... there is an absence of pho on the menu... which at first I didn't understand, but this place doesn't need it, if you want Pho, go somewhere else...

If I lived closer to this place, I would probably go on a weekly basis... I would recommend it to anyone... go now!!
author: Blake W.

description:
What can you say about a cheap, delish, and a charming hole in the wall restaurant such as Cordon Bleu? Well to begin, the workers there are so adorable and have a deer-in-the-headlights kind of feel to them, but that doesn't detract from the greatness of their food. A good place for lunch, but never take more than a friend or two. CB tends to fill up fast and it is a "hole-in-the-wall" restaurant, so seating is limited. 

          A very simple menu, and with feeding their customers in mind, dont think you'll be eating a the French Laundry kind of place- a local eatery. Most of their dishes are branches of each other and are simple Viet-Chinese dishes. Very cheap and a good place to stop by for lunch. Not exactly the cleanest place, but thats probably the last thing on your mind when you are scarfing down a #1 Kebab-rice combo.

Food 5/5
Atmosphere 3/5
Price 5/5
author: Jimmy K.

description:
Culinary Theorem 102 states that some of the best food comes in the tiniest of venues.  Cordon Bleu, a blink-and-you-miss it sliver in the wall along the California Cable Car line, situated (in)conspicuously right next to the Lumiere Movie House, offers some of the best-made food in San Francisco.

This is a place where I would take the Coen Brothers... should I ever befriend them.  This is a place where I would take mom, a snazzy date, or my boss without hesitation.  

Cordon Bleu has a core menu that is easy to peruse, with friendly & fast service... and serves food fit for the most demanding patron, Gripman, or Nob Hill foodie bar none.
author: Jim W.

description:
Woe!  Solid food.  Tasty tasty.  A gem of a place.  If you want some get-down-and-dirty (and don't mind the dirty part) grinds, you gotta try this place.  

The people who ate here seemed like regulars, and huge fans at that.  Not here to chit chat or bullshit, just get some ono grinds.  Sorry, I had to throw that one in.  

The lady behind the bar is working her ass off, deep frying some imperial rolls, grilling some meat and chicken.  So, the menu is pretty tight, not too many choices.  They do have vegetarian options.  But who eats that here is what I want to know?  Not I.  Yes, I was brave, and ventured out of my "comfort zone" and ordered meat.  Actually the #1 which had an imperial roll, skewer (meat with no stick, and it tasted like bulgogi), and meat with rice.  All mixed together.  Can I tell you how delicious it was?  Sometimes I can be a pretty picky eater, pushing things this way and that.  But not at Cordon Bleu.  I mean, sure, I was tipsy when I went... but it was still good.

Since I don't eat meat, I woke up with a sore stomach.  But that's my fault / issues, not the restaurant's.  Oh, and they only accept cash.
author: Sarah F.

description: Yes, the food is good and that mysterious meat sauce is damn tasty. BUT one thing will definitely keep me from ever coming back: ROACHES! I saw three crawling on the wall! That's just one too many -- Yikes!
author: Lisa R.

description:
Meat sauce on rice.

Most entrees come with meat sauce on rice and cole slaw. I quite like the pork and imperial roll because it compliments the MEAT SAUCE ON RICE. Yeah, I thought it was strange too.


The food can be a wait sometimes because they absolutely COOK THE SHIT out of everything. I know this because there are only 2 tables and most of the seats are at the counter.You can watch the kitchen which is comprised of a grill, a home sized refrigerator and a 4 burner stove which is usually full of pots of MEAT SAUCE. This place is tiny so you might want call ahead and take it out.

I like it in a kind of trashy way. The way I like acid wash Daisy Dukes.
author: Josua P.

description:
Wow, this is definitely one of  the best hole-in-the-wall joints ever! The place obviously channels all of its efforts on creating delicious traditional Vietnamese dishes...and nothing else! I had the #4: chicken, meat sauce over rice and some salad. All of this on a huge plate for only $7! 

The place is tiny and fills up quickly and easily--and by filling up, I mean 20 people max. You walk in and immediately see the kitchen and bar seating surrounding it. Interesting set-up. Our group was large so we sat at one of the few tables in the back. Everyone is so nice here; it's definitely  a neighborhood restaurant. They even let us bring our own wine since they don't serve alcohol here. Great place to go if you're running on an empty stomach and an almost empty wallet!
author: Natalie T.

description:
Tiny place, like the size of a walk in closet (okay, maybe slightly bigger). They only had two tables and the rest was counter seating. 

Good portions. I got the #5 and was nauseatingly full.  I think the meat sauce was overkill. Next time, I'm going to ask them to leave it out. 

BBQ chicken and shish kebab were decent. The imperial roll not so much. Too crispy.

We ordered 2 #5's and 2 cokes. It came out to $21 something (not including tip). 

FYI: Prices on the menu aren't accurate. I think everything went up to at least a dollar. There is a menu with updated prices taped to the register.
author: Dorothy N.

description:
I really wanted to like this place with all my might, but maybe because I am Vietnamese I know some good Vietnamese food and this was not all that to me. Don't get me wrong it's good and all, but I can go to T.L. and get better. Very NICE & friendly staff. Too bad I couldn't give them more stars, I wish I could.

1/5/07 UPDATE I have now had their chicken and it was goood. So +1 star to that. No more of the vermicelli stale noodles no more. Chicken all the way!
author: Christina B.

description:
Solid.  Finally hopped down to this joint tonight for some comfort food and wasn't disapointed.  I ordered the Spicy Pork Chops -- so good.  They come with green onion rice and some cucumber/tomato salad.

It's all served by 3 or 4 ladies milling about w/ various mystery sauces and BBQing.  It's great, won't dissapoint.  They also serve some great looking 5 spice chicken and sping rolls...I didn't have the opportunity to try, but they looked great.
author: John R.

description:
MEAT PILE!

Yup, that's what we call it, infamously dubbed by my friend, the bike queen. It's literally meat on top of meat on top of meat on top of rice. Then to top it all off, there's meat sauce all over that son of a gun. It's practically meat heaven! 

My heart of attack of choice is the #1. A little bit of imperial roll and kebab. It's a great combo. And when I feel especially hungry, I order the mammoth behemoth, the #5, a chicken breast, kebab and imperial roll. 

Lemme tell you, you have to try the imperial roll. It's darn tasty. 

And when you feel for something lighter, I recommend the noodle salad with the imperial roll. That's good too. 

Oooh, I almost forgot, the ma po tofu is good too!

There's a lot of good stuff here... they rock!
author: Lester L.

description:
Based on the glowing reviews here, we tried this place for dinner tonight. I'd give the food 2-3 stars, but the overall experience is a 1 at best. Yes, the 5 star chicken was good, but having to stare at a tray of the mysterious "meat" that goes into the "meat sauce" sitting out on the counter (who knows how long it had been there!) while trying to eat was nothing short of disgusting.  Was the meat sauce on rice good? Yes. However, what on earth are you actually eating??!!  I didn't spot any of the roaches mentioned in other reviews, but its easy to imagine them scurrying around in the corners. This restaurant is simply not clean AT ALL. I'm not sure this restaurant paints an accurate picture of the beautiful country that Vietnam actually is.

The owners are incredibly nice. They try really hard. However, if they would invest in adequate refrigeration and ventilation, they might be on to something. I am positive we will not return.
author: Megan L.

description:
CB is not a dive.  And I wish people would stop insinuating that it is dirty.  Surfaces don't have to be brand new to be clean.   And I've never-ever-never seen a cockroach there.  

But if you want sterile:  eat in an operating room, or get a bubble-boy dome.  

Like others, I fell like I have to stick up for Cordon Bleu.  Cordon Bleu is unpretentious.  Its not claiming to be anything more than it is:   Its' a little hole in the wall that serves really good food at low prices.  As for 'authentic' it doesn't matter to me.  It is what it is.  Really Yummy Grilled Stuff.  

As a matter of fact, whenever I don't feel good and need comfort food, I go here.  Katie makes me tea, I get a hot meal, and I go home feeling better AND full.  I wish she was my mother.
author: purple z.

description:
The combo with the kabob, imperial roll, and rice with meat sauce is just perfect.  They really pile on the rice and sauce, which has this addictive flavor.  It's like eating Swisher Sweets.  The kabob is nice and thin, so charring it doesn't make it too tough.  The Imperial Roll?  God...the Imperial Roll.  I've burnt the living spit out of my tongue diving too quickly into this heavenly little log.  Crispy, chewy, packed with fillings, sticks in your teeth kind of goodness.  
The chicken is good, yes, but for the price and quantity, that combo is just unbeatable.
I don't understand people who knock this place for its lack of seating, greasy walls, and the occasional roach.  It's the Tendernob, people!  If you're that concerned about your gourmet accomodations, what are you doing in that neighborhood in the first place?  A dive is a dive, and this is one tasty dive.
author: Billy C.

description: For what it is, 5 stars. (espec when you look at the index of quality/price - ranks super hi).  Amazing.  #5 is the default for newbies.  I really enjoy the noodle salad with beef (some of the combos, well, don't have a imperial role, which is a travesty).  Highly recommend.  Food is delicious
author: Daniel W.

description: Meat and rice with meat sauce. The chicken was moist, imperial roll as big as a baby's arm, meat sauce I'd drink with a boba straw.  Definitely a once in a while place and a treat. Portions are out of control, cheap and good. I wish I oculd give it 4.5 stars.
author: Krystle A.

description:
Everytime I pass by this place it is packed!  I finally tried it out tonight and it was tasty and reasonably priced.

We sat right at the bar, so we smelled of smoke and food afterwards.  =) But the best places always make you smell of it long after you've left the restaurant.

The portions are huge, but it was so good that I ate almost all of it! The meats are tender and seasoned good. =p

Cash only!
author: Aiko T.

description:
I embarrassed myself by greeting a woman who was clearly Chinese in Vietnamese. Luckily, my companion has eaten at her restaurant about a thousand times, so I was saved. My apologies.

Billing its cuisine as Vietnamese comfort food, Cordon Bleu serves up grilled meats, cabbage slaw, and a pile of rice covered with meat sauce on a plate the size of my head for pennies. The imperial roll was excellent, but the rest of the food was a bit too simple (though it certainly satisfied my craving for sweet, salty, and umami). Also, because most of the seating is at a counter that curves around the kitchen, the smell of mops and bleach mingles unpleasantly with the aroma of the food.

Still, this is a good place for a quick, cheap, filling lunch. The ladies that work here are lovely, and the restaurant is proud of its dive status. Need proof? Just look for the plaques along the window.
author: Brianne C.

description:
Excellent vegetarian menu if somewhat limited. I had the cold noodle salad with four small veggie springrolls on top. Very good and I could barely finish the thing. (They also have a tofu/mushroom dish I didn't try, but sounded good.) We also shared a fresh veggie spring roll which was full of mushroms and was different from the typical fresh spring roll you'd find in most Vietnamese or Thai restaurants, but was equally good. The wife and kid shared a beef/tofu/mushroom dish which they said was 4 1/2 stars. 

The drink menu was basically soda, so we just got water. The place is small and a bit grimy but you leave very full and satisfied without paying an arm and a leg.
author: Chris S.

description: The food is delish.  Just a few menu options make it easy to order, and the hearty portions leave me completely satiated, along with leftovers for lunch the next day.  My favorite is the chicken salad, but any chicken dish is great. Tiny place with just a few seats, so prepare for close quarters and possibly a wait for a seat, or just get takeout. They are closed Mondays.
author: Brooke N.

description: I went here on one of my walks around San Francisco. I ordered one of their combo meals with the different kinds of meats and an egg roll.  The price is extremely cheap considering the quality and portion this place offers.  The lady who seems to be the owner and also the cook of the place was very nice.  She said she had just lost her i-phone and so if anyone knows where it is then please return it to her.  Will definitely return.
author: Anh W.

description: Really interesting Vietnamese food. What is meat sauce? I have no idea, but it's good! Best chicken? Meh. I remember liking it, but I don't remember LOVING it. It's a good deal though, and if, by chance, you're drinking up on a saturday afternoon along California, this place is a great place to eat.
author: Camille T.

description: CBV would clear 6 stars if it was an option. This place is as phenomenal as all of the reviews paint it. My only complaint is that Cordon Bleu isn't open every single time the craving for their noodle salad or emperial roll hits me... although, to be fair, that would require their being open at all ours of the night. Not a bad thing on the menu, friendly and efficient service, counter-top seating so you can bond with all the other CBV junkies. Favorite mid-week dinner and a movie at the Lumiere next door date place.
author: Amanda W.

description:
Huge portions, got the #5 lunch combo with the imperial roll/ beef (shishkebab)/chicken.  Was unable to finish the plate.  
Imperial roll was crispy and delicious
Beef was thin, spiced well, and tasty even though a bit dry.
Chicken was delicious and juicy.
Even the salad was yummy.
Looking forward to trying the vermicelli bowl/imperial roll combo or the Mapo Tofu next time.
author: Barnaby G.

description:
Really a 3.5 stars rating.  I've been coming here since I was a kid, before the current proprietress took over ownership of this place.  (Back in the day, the "shish kebobs" actually came on wooden skewers.)

I feel the food has slipped a bit in the past few years, but I still love the imperial rolls.
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description:
The tastiest brown meat sauce over rice you'll find!  Disclaimer, I haven't tried every other restaurant that serves tasty brown meat sauce over rice.  

Sampled the shish kebabs (which aren't kebabs at all, they're basically sliced beef grilled on an open grill), five spice chicken, imperial rolls, all fantastic.  I love the Vietnamese imperial roll approach.  My personal theory is that they've taken some kind of pork fat and used it to wrap the roll innards pre-frying.

But what I really loved is the mysterious brown meat sauce over the rice.

You'll walk out smelling a bit like the grill, but it's worth it.  Pretty cheap, good food, and a location near the Lumiere for indie movie satisfaction thereafter.
author: Walter K.

description:
Come here and order the #5 for a plate of meat (chicken, pork and imperial egg rolls) with rice. The secret to the special plate is the meat sauce they pour all over the rice. How can I get my hands on this recipe?!

Don't come with a large group b/c it is a very small establishment.
author: Katie K.

description: Really tender chicken, tasty shish kebob.
author: Dan F.

description: Best Imperial Roll in SF, hands down.  Years ago I worked nearby and ate there about once a week.  Always good.  I haven't been there for years, but the missus goes fairly often and is friendly with the owner.  A couple weeks ago she came home with a leftover Imperial Roll, and I had a bite, and since then I've been craving one.  It is the perfect combination of ingredients with a slightly gummy/chewy wrapping.
author: Hal M.

description:
Don't come here thinking that you will get a white table cloth dining experience because you won't.  Do come here with simplicity in mind and an empty stomach - The portions were so ginormous that my sister and I split our order!  I love their simple menu of either chicken, kebab, imperial roll, or tofu served either over rice (with meat sauce) or vermicelli noodles.  The atmosphere is unpretentious and warm as you cozy yourself up by the booth in front of the open kitchen.  

I've been to several Vietnamese restaurants, and I have to admit that I've never been to one quite like this. Their cuisine has a totally different concept.  They have a sort of East meets Southern Comfort food thing-y going on.  In all honesty, I think it's the meat sauce over rice that makes it unique.  Otherwise it would just be like any other Vietnamese joint.  

This is a perfect place for a quick & decent grub under $10, and possibly $6 bucks for lunch.  I don't recommend this place for a 1st date  otherwise your date might think you're cheap.
author: Nancy G.

description: This is the best "hole in the wall" restaurant in SF! The gravy over the pork chop/BBQ chicken was just so delicious, I could just lick the whole plate! I make a point to go there every time I venture into SF. The price is so good and you get a huge portion.
author: Patti S.

description:
Even though I'm only giving this place 3 stars...i love this restaurant.  On a budget back in college I would have been eating here every single day. For less then 10 bucks TWO of you can be full. I'm only docking them because I don't want people to show up and thinking it is anything resembling an upscale establishment. 
The people who run this place are great and they know how to make great tasting food.  On the other hand, I'm positive they use ingredients that are not organic etc....but you gotta cut corners somewhere when you serve such large portions at such a low price.  

Also, seating is limited so dont' bring groups of more than 4 if you can help it. I also believe it is byob which is nice.
author: Tristan S.

description:
Very yummy. Very cheap. They even do to-go.
I went with a friend, and sat at the counter. The ladies working there were really friendly. A hole in the wall restaurant at it's best!

From where I was sitting, I could see the pre-rolled imperial rolls and the marinated chickens just sitting underneath the counter. I'm pretty sure it's clean and not harmful, but that wasn't appealing. -1 star.
author: Seaweed F.

description:
