One day on the way home, my roommate and I are discussing what to get for dinner:

Me: Oh, I'm not sure...I guess I might get Golden Horse, as usual
Her: I think I'm going to get Cordon Bleu
Me: OOOOOOH. Me too then!
Her: Okay! Let's look at the menu
Me: ::types in yelp.com, finds cordon bleu, and looks at the menu via yelp photos::
*we make our selections*
*I dial the number*
after 10 seconds...no response...
Me: Are they not open Mondays? ::checks yelp and confirms bad news::
Both: Noooooooooooooooooooooooooo. 

Anyhow, as everyone before me has said, this place is really good value. lots and lots of food, and I am a big fan of the meat sauce over rice. I want some now!!! 
Just a word of advice, because the lady cooks right behind the counter, expect to smell like everything if you eat there. I've always gotten it to go.
author: Emily H.

description:
For hot days. . .
Imperial roll, grilled pork topped noodle salad.
For the cold days . . .
Imperial roll, grilled pork and meat sauce.

It's that simple at Cordon Bleu.  Brilliant.
A cheap, good eats staple in  theCity.
author: M E.

description:
This place is the best diner style meal in the Nob Hill area. It's small and a little dirty, but the staff is incredibly nice, and the food is tasty and doled out in huge portions. There might be some be better Vietnamese in the Tenderloin, but meals here will leave most people just as satisfied as anywhere.

I recommend the bun (noodle bowls) if you want something you can finish in one sitting.
author: Lorenzo M.

description:
This is one of my favorite places to eat in San Francisco.  It's a tiny hole in the wall that can seat around a dozen people.  My boyfriend and I always order two spring rolls and split a #5 for dinner, and both of us leave feeling pretty full for less than $20.    The food is pretty delicious.  The spring rolls and are the best I have ever had, and I always go back simply because I have a spring roll craving.  The imperial rolls are my second favorite.  The #5 plate is pretty great.  You get half a spiced chicken, an imperial roll, beef shish kebobs, and some rice with meat gravy on it.  It's all delicious, and the portions are very large.  

If you go:  cash only, hard to find parking in the area, and I would recommend wearing clothes that you don't mind smelling like grilled spiced chicken when you leave.  Despite all that, this place is very worth going to.
author: Jamie S.

description: BYOB, delicious chicken (I got the #5). This place is great if you love hole in the walls. There will probably be a wait, and it's not the cleanest looking place, but this place hits the spot.
author: Mark W.

description:
A neighborhood constant for years!  The #5 is possibly the greatest combo of quantity and quality for under $10 in all of San Francisco.  

I have been baptised in meat-sauce.
author: John H.

description: I had their lunch special with chicken, which came with salad, meat sauce over rice and one piece of their 5-spiced chicken (leg or breast of your choice - i chose leg). The owner is very friendly and the service was good. The chicken was marinated, steamed, then grilled on the surface. It's overall tasty, juicy and tender, although I would prefer the surface to be a bit less burnt. The portion of salad was rather small but it's quite fresh. The meat sauce was just ok - I'm not a fan. What I really didn't like was the rice - it was soft and soggy, and the fact that it was served with meat sauce made it worse. Had I ordered the 5-spiced chicken salad or something with rice noodles, instead of the rice plate, I might have enjoyed my meal better.
author: s c.

description: I think this place deserves 2.50 stars but profoundly not 3. I thought the food was decently prepared but somewhat lacking in flavor. The Mapo Tofu is way better at a place like Mission Chinese. As for the half chicken the sauce for the chicken was good but not enough to moisten the otherwise somewhat dry chicken.  The imperial rolls were also nothing to write home about. On the whole, I came away feeling that this place is WAY overrated and that one can do far better in the mission.
author: George E.

description:
Entertaining. Delicious. Ridiculous.

It's a common misconception that all hole -in -the walls serve satisfying, delicious meals.  Well, Cordon BLeu is more than a hole in the wall - in fact you'd probably believe me  if you told me it used to be a public restroom. But the food is sure to knock your socks off.

The most entertaining/questionable meal I've ever had:
1. Girl is waiting for good 15 minutes for order she called in
2. Angry boyfriend walks in - demands to know where food is
3. Lady tells him they're out of the chicken
4. Guy gets angrier - "JUST HEAR ME OUT A'IGHT?! YOU CAN'T TELL ME YOU DON'T HAVE CHICKEN WHEN YOU SAID MY ORDER WOULD BE READY 30 MINUTES AGO!"  **storms off**
 **re-enter girlfriend**
5. All the employees get flustered , except for the queen bee (she's hardcore)
6. Queen Bee turns around to get order for girl- runs into co-worker, drops order on ground- **REPLATES!...hesitates to give to girl**
7. Ok, two rice plates (they ordered two chicken dinners) Charges girl.
The End

Ridiculous wait. Ridiculous scenes. Ridiculously good food.  

All for a fairly cheap price and great entertainment and company.  You COULD go during slow hours (if there is such a thing) but go during the rush and sip on a bottle o' Chuck while you sit back and enjoy the chaos.  It's a great time.

Know Before You GO:
1. no corkage and byob ok!
2. the wait for chicken dinner is around 30 minutes
3. they tend to run out of chicken sometime around 7:30pm
4. you can order ahead....but it don't guarantee you nuttin
5. cash only!!!
6. *not for romantic purposes.*
author: Jane L.

description: LOOOOOOVE this hole in the wall restaurant. They cook your delicious food in front of you and it is totally reasonable.
author: Lindsay D.

description: Amazing 5 spice chicken over rice and then smothered in a tomato/meat type sauce...ridiculous!  Small whole in the wall that is a must try.
author: Andy S.

description: combo #5 big yummy portions of chicken, rice drenched in meat sauce, and pork. flavorful and tender. great prices!
author: Lily Z.

description:
Awesome.
Cheap, fast, friendly, filling and damn tasty.
Perfect for a pre-movie bite to eat before hitting up the Lumiere.
Can't say its true "vietnamese" food but hey, who's going to argue with an $8 meal. 

The mapo tofu and roast chicken are great!
author: Jonny Bobby G.

description:
total hole in the wall small family owned restaurant. it probably fits less than 20 ppl inside and their menu is small but for the price its not bad. based on the yelp reviews i got the 5 spice chicken. apparently there is a lunch sized dish, which is a bit smaller sized and perfect for a girl. i got the regular plate and it was huge! i couldnt finish it. the chicken was good. the sauce over the rice was delicious! 

CASH ONLY!
author: Jen S.

description:
I never want to solve the mystery of the meat sauce laddled on the rice here.  

No matter how often I come in, and they do recognize me now, and say sweetly "light on the rice, heavy on the sauce" I have yet to acheive that perfect balance, so I will endeavor to perfect and report when I get it right.  The owners/workers are stunning the way they flip and turn and laugh and pour tea.

The BBQd to a crisp meat makes me drool.  Now I want it for breakfast.
The imperial roll sticks to your mouth roof.  I have food texture lust for this.  I always leave smelling of meat smoke and with a fish sauce soaked tongue.

Is it wrong to make people drool at the Lumiere when you sneak some 5 spice chicken into a movie?

It's all made better for the incredibly low price.  The broke must try it because it can easily be a double meal.  The veggie stuff is very good but I don't know that you won't have it touch meat at some point.
author: ChubbyBunny I.

description:
Hole in the wall restaurant run by non-vietnamese people? 
Of course I'll TRY IT!

The food is decent. I got the spring rolls. Don't recommend those. They were very sad looking and tasting. The vegetarian egg rolls on the other hand, I do recommend. 

Since I don't eat meat, there was very little for me to order  - basically only ONE DISH, which was the spicy tofu with mushrooms. To my surprise the order was quite plentiful and made my taste buds happy. 

Didn't love the place, but would come back again.
author: MJ T.

description:
a tiny, tinyyy restuarant, but the food is so delicious!

i got the porkchops with rice (around 8-9$).

PROS:
-the portion was huge! there were 3 slabs of grilled porkchops on top a bed of rice. it also tasted delicious! the porkchops were tender and you really didnt need anything else but rice :)
-cucumber salad that came before it was also good with lots of cilantro and a sweet&sour dressing (it reminded me of the dressing that you put on top of vermicelli dishes at pho places)
-hot tea 

CONS:
-really..really small restaurant! but they do to-go's!
-even smaller bathroom
author: Joy K.

description:
I eat chicken in the morning, chicken in the evening, chicken in the afternoon.  I love chicken.  The 5 Spice Chicken in my #5 was very bland and was not impressed with the slash in my chicken made by them.  For a place that turns out that much chicken, they should know whether the chicken is done or not by just looking at it, not by cutting my piece open.  

I noticed that the color of my chicken was different from others. It lacked the marinade or something and might have been a fluke.  But a restaurant should not make mistakes like this because I'm down $8 with some tasteless chicken.

The meat sauce was actually better than most Asian cafe spaghetti sauce, but watch out for them calories.  I had to ask them to put the sauce on the side before they add the 400 additional calories to my plate.

The imperial rolls were delicious.  The skin was nice and crisp, filled with perfectly cooked vermicelli and pork. However, for you big vermicelli eaters, do yourself a favor and research Asian vermicelli in the news - it's not too good =(  It's up there with the fake eggs, soy sauce practices, and eel farms coming from China.

4 stars for the Rolls
2 stars for the meat sauce
-5 stars for the chicken that I had, might have been a fluke, but its what  I had on my plate

If you think this chicken is that good, my chicken would be orgasmic.  PM me and I'll invite you to my next bbq and you can yelp my bomb@$$ chicken from the grill.

stinky tofu
author: StinkyTofu S.

description:
Voted the best dive bar in SF for 2006, this hole in the wall joint located in the heart of Polk Gulch is a great place for classic vietnamese cuisine. The menu doesn't offer a great length of options but certainly delivers quality in the selected items. I usually go for the five spice chicken which is a half a chicken over rice with this yummy sauce drizzled over it. I decided to try out the #5 which features a little bit of everything - five spice chicken, pork shish kebab, rice, and an imperial roll. For $8, it was a steal. 

The place is really small with only about 8 counter seats. If you dine in, be prepared to watch them cook your food in front of you. They also offer to go which is always a great option. If you're in the mood for some tender and flavorful meat, check out Cordon Bleu.
author: Josephine H.

description: Great value meal that is very tasty. The food here is a bit different than other Vietnamese restaurants. For instance you won't find Pho here. It is a great hole in the wall with hearty home-style cooking for a great value.
author: David J.

description:
SNOB ALERT!

got it?
yeah just kind of scary looking around the oven area. you know, the place where they are cooking my food. I kept straining to see what the health code rating was, trying not to let my dining partner notice. as if the score makes a hill of beans.

chicken was fine. until I kept getting a mouth full of skin. and to think I was sober. tofu plate. good in a sloppy kind of way. you know, like one of the good menu days around the corner at the soup kitchen. 

but the crowd. ah here's where its good. the crazy Russian lady who wouldn't stop talking even when her fixated audience of one,  the managercashiercookhostessbusserwaitress, had walked into the kitchen. her husband had obviously glazed over hours prior. or the guy on his third day of (but the drugs have just been so good lately!)
or the guy doing morse code on the front door. when he finally burst in: "your phone has been off the hook for like the last, uh FIVE MINUTES!" were the first words out of his mouth. (i guess our morse translation was a little rusty.)  "hmmm..." was about all the everyjob lady said. and in no time he had rustled up a stool and began remarking on how fortunate for her that he had come in (all those togo orders she might have missed) and how VTech phones suck (I'm stickin to verizon.)

the crowd is worth every yellowed square inch of those three stars.
author: Jeremi M.

description: yum!  the combinations come piled with LOTS of food and are definitely large enough to split.  i always love counter seating...and of course friendly service and cheap prices.
author: Christy C.

description: This place does offer a meal at a good price.  Ordering the number 5, you get a big piece of chicken, some kebab meat, an imperial roll, enough rice for 2 - 3 people and some slaw.  The chicken was ok.  Nothing special and you dont taste any spices.  The kebab meat was actually not bad.  The rice with meat sauce was fine, but just not too my liking.  The imperial roll was awful.  So deeply fried/something else that I took one bite and that was it.  The slaw was fine, but I am not a slaw man.  I gave the place 3 stars because for the price, you do get value, but not top quality.  With some many good truck meals and other $ places in SF, I dont plan on returning, which is the real test of how good a place is.
author: Markus S.

description:
LOVE THIS PLACE!!!

I haven't had Vietnamese BBQ like this before :)
Their meat sauce for their rice is to die for and their egg rolls are big and delicious.

I took 1 star off because this place is VERY SMALL, i say it can fit about 20 or less and it usually gets packed around meal times (lunch,dinner) and it might not seem as sanitary as you may think, but the food is great.

YOU SHOULD DEFINITELY TRY THIS PLACE OUT IF YOU ARE AROUND THE NEIGHBORHOOD, ITS SOMETHING DIFFERENT I'LL TELL YOU.
author: Virginia L.

description:
I LOVE this place. Found it on yelp and have been going here ever since and that was over a year ago. The woman that cooks the food is so sweet and such a hard worker. They really do put "love" into their food. My fav is the #5 and the noodle dish. Have had everything on the menu and have not been disappointed. To quote another yelper "2 stuffed people for under $20: perfect!" cuz that is exactly how it is!

Not a good place to go w/ more than 4 people. Even that is a lot. Ideal for 1 or 2. Counter seating is the best to me. I like to watch her cook all the food and it just smells so yummy (mouth watering just thinking about it). Get there early and never be shocked if there is a wait. I suggest you wait if there is one cuz it will be wroth it!
author: Kae w.

description:
YUM-MY!
Hole-in-the-wall... tasty deliciousness... Great food at Fantastic prices?!?! Just my style of a place :D 

I had the spicy pork when my friend took us there after a hike. It was so tasty. The portions were huge and I ended up having the rest for lunch the next day. I definitely need to go back for the other items on the menu :)

This place is all about the meats on grill and delicious broth to flavor your rice. Don't come here expecting fresh veggies and pho :)
author: Alice C.

description: Have not been by here for many months ... nothing really changes, which in this case is acceptable.  I order the "five spice chicken" dinner pretty much always, and usually to go ... sure, sometimes it tastes like 4 spice chicken but that marinade they use on the chicken is just kind of dead on good.  Or maybe "good on dead (chicken)."  Not appetizing description ... yah, what's up with that tomatoey meat sauce that they liberally douse the rice with?  Darn good in any case.  Well made rice btw.  Tasty goodness ... consistent comfort food ... this place has been around for a long time ... deservedly so ... one of my late night working standbys ... throw a piece of chicken at anh v.
author: Terry A.

description:
Like a little birdie would say, "Cheap! Cheap!" 

This place is fantastic: generous portions, low prices, and delicious food. The only drawback is how tiny it is. I recommend getting food to go, especially because it's always so busy. 

I used to come here while I was growing up a few blocks away (I'm 26 now). My family still refers to it as "THE Vietnamese place." I had the pleasure of coming back for the first time in 8 years recently to find that the food was exactly the same as I remembered it. I'll be back again soon; the drive up from LA is actually worth it. Sure, I have friends in the area, but they aren't as important as the imperial roll. ;) 

Mmm. 

Now I'm hungry, dammit.
author: Cat W.

description: So good & so cheap, can't go wrong. Love the pork chops!
author: Jade D.

description: Their menu says they have the best chicken outside of Vietnam.  Well I didn't eat very much chicken when I was in VN, but I can say Cordon Bleu's chicken is some of the best I've had EVER... of any type of cuisine.  They first roast the chicken in a braising liquid then finish it off on the grill to order.  Anyone who cooks knows this is the only way to keep chicken moist and give it a crispy finish.  I don't consider the Vietnamese to be the best chicken cooks (including my family), but Cordon Bleu's given me some hope (even if they're all Chinese over there).
author: Mimi L.

description: you get a lot for your money. big portions, but food is just average. fish sauce lacks kick and flavor for a vietnamese place. a lot of people seem to like the meat sauce but i didn't think it was anything special.
author: Judy k.

description:
What can I say that others haven't?

-It's small
-Best to go alone so you can get a seat, or go early
-The Ma Po is amazing
-It's filling and delicious
-Worth the cramped space
author: Pouria Y.

description: Their chicken is so good, yes, they know their chicken.
author: Yoko S.

description: After watching Planet B-Boy at the Lumiere theatre, my friend suggested we eat dinner at this very hole in the wall joint. We waited about 10 minutes for a table, and knew right away what we wanted to order. Get number 5 w/ white meat! It's the gravy! And totally inexpensive for dinner. Friendly service.
author: Thomas L.

description:
The food here is incredible!!  The price is right for less than $10 for a gourmet tasting entree, I could say it's good and cheap - just like my ex-boyfriend but that's another story.

I usually get the #5.  Portion size is big, enough for leftovers-dinner later or lunch the next day.  You get half 5-spice chicken on top of their special tomato meat sauce over jasmine rice, lightly vinegar dressed cole slaw (Asian style) and an a crispy tasty Imperial roll with a dipping sauce.  It's so delicious.

On days I don't feel like eating too much meat I get the Ma Po which is the Tofu with Ground Pork over Jasmine Rice.  It's so simple but it's bursting with incredible flavor.  You can get it spicy if you ask for it!!

The ladies who work there are nice and friendly!  Once I even walked in at 10pm ...they were just about to close and I was willing to walk away so they didn't have to stay there late but they insisted I come in and they'd make me a plate.  Now that was cool cause I was hungry!
author: Sarah V.

description:
LOVE YOU!

Thank you hubby for showing me this place. This is seriously hole in the wall. With a max seating of (like other yelpers said) 15-20ish people (tight squeeze), be prepared to wait at least an hour for food. In fact, just call in an hour early and grab a drink before you attempt to get near your food. 

This is good food. I will wait. and wait. and wait. 


Large portions, cheap cheap cheap. I got Order #5 just because the guy sitting in the stool next to me had it and I nearly drooled on his arm staring at it. I think I was full just looking. YUM YUM.



I'm coming back...and bringing 20 friends. Too bad suckas.
author: tammy m.

description:
This place was SO GOOD! 

It was this little hole in the wall place (literally) without many seats but man was the food tasty. I've been to Vietnam and although this wasn't that close to actual Vietnamese food, WHO CARES! IT WAS GOOD!

It's also super cheap and in huge portions, I don't think I've fully finished a meal there yet. Every time I go there I end up getting the same meat dish. Why? Because it's too good for me to try anything else.
author: Mina G.

description:
Bartender at the John Barleycorn pub recommended this place, specifically the 5-spice chicken (2 pieces of spicy grilled chicken with rice covered in meat sauce and salad--combo #4). Great meal that could have fed 2 but it was good and I was being a little food monster. Also ordered the deep fried egg roll which I think I'll skip next time so I don't clog an artery due the saturated oil factor. 

For a great but reasonably priced date, I suggest catching a movie at the theatre next door, ordering some 5-spice chicken to go (space is small and resembles a Jersey all-night diner) and eating it at the John Barleycorn pub (while it's still in existence) with a couple pints of Carlsberg. Your date will admire your awesomeness in culture and flavor.
author: Kelly R.

description: Awesome spot for cheap food if you like hole in the wall authentic restaurants.  The garlic tofu dish with mushroom is out of this world - even my meat loving boyfriend who is not so into tofu loved it.  The owner cooks everything right in front of you with the other workers and you get massive portions for the price.  The place is small without much seating but I have never had a problem. The chicken is unbelievable from what I've heard.  Must try if you're looking for delicious, cheap, vietnamese and you're sick of pho and healthy spring rolls.
author: Kimberly J.

description:
Word, 

This place is killer and is the sparkling definition of the "Hole-in-the-wall-with-awesome-food" type place. It's run by three Vietnamese women in a place that probably was a broom closet before becoming a restaurant. 

What makes this place great is the simplicity of it. The decor is simple, the atmosphere is simple/casual and the food is simple. They only serve four things. Grilled pork, grilled chicken, imperial roll, and noodle salad. That's it! It's kinda like how In-N-Out only has burger, cheeseburger and double burger (yes, I know there are the "secret codes," but I just mean on the basic menu). But with simplicity comes perfection. Everything is tasty and is ridcockulously cheap and with large proportions, and they have combos that combine the items.

I've spent time considerable time in Vietnam and the noodle salad is very similar to the type of noodles you'll get from a pho stall in Ha Noi or Pho Tho.  So its very authentic. 

Fellas, this is a great place to go on a date to show her you are hip and know all the cool hide away type places. I myself have gone here for four or five different dates and the ladies have always raved how great the food is. They think you cool and in-the-know, and the meal will cost less than $20.

Yups
author: david h.

description: It's small.  It's simple.  It's good.  Now you know how to interact with owner/chef.
author: Simons C.

description:
I heard sooo many great reviews from friends & fellow yelpers,.... however even tho' it was very affordable, but I wasnt impressed.  I had the Number 4 with half chick, cabbage, & meat on rice.  The flavor was ok.  Much more bland than expected. The meal presentation was satisfactory.  The restaurant atmosphere was a so-so diner style hole-in-the-wall.  

In closing I feel the need to imitate the annoyingly nasal words from the Nanny character (Fran Drescher):  "Eh".
author: McCracken C.

description:
I wish this place were bigger, but waiting 10 minutes for a table (probably) never killed anyone.

What's not to love? Cheap, relatively fast, and tasty. I genuinely enjoyed the experience (including overhearing other people's conversations and watching Katie cook).
author: Erika B.

description:
These guys are on my list of  "hole in the wall" places that are worth a visit.

Food's cooked as you order.  The ladies behind the counter are efficient and no nonsense.  Not that they're rude, but they don't waste time chitchatting with you.

Overall, good food.  Love their five spice chicken and the Imperial rolls.  The shishkabab is tasty, but it's strange ... I would have thought it would come on a stick ... but no stick.  Mystery sauce over rice ... yum.
author: Winnie C.

description:
Hey....I love this one. 
It's good and it's clean enough. The only critiques from me was, not enough choices though. But, definitely recommended.
author: Mara B.

description: The. best. Vietnamese. food. in. San. Francisco. period.  I've been going here for eight years and I've never had a bad meal here.  The owner is the sweetest lady you'll ever meet, and this place is the best value you can get anywhere in the city.  Do yourself a favor and stop in for an amazing meal!
author: Tyler D.

description:
Amazing.  The variety of reviews astonishes me.
I honestly can't find anything wrong with this place.
Sure, it's small, but that is part of the charm.  Individuals who've never met before all strike up conversation with eachother.  The staff, only one of whom really appears to speak English, will recognize you and learn you order.  And they all smile, genuinely.
Sure, their standards for cleanliness and ingredient quality might be lower than other restaurants, but it isn't dirty, and their ingredients aren't bad.
Actually, the place is pretty clean - it has to be, there are hardly any seats.  Also, they cook their meats so well, and season their vegetables so nicely, that you will forget what organic means.
This is a restaurant worht taking people to.
author: Jeffrey R.

description:
If you want bang for your buck, this is one of the best places to go.  For under $10 you can get enough food for at least two meals -- unless you have been fasting for a month and are extremely hungry.  Each time I go I tell myself I will try something new, but each time I hear myself mutter, "#5, please."  Granted, you are eating a sampling of almost everything they have to offer with the 5-spice chicken, shish kebab, spring roll, rice with meat sauce, and cabbage salad all piled onto one delicious plate.  The 5-spice chicken is so tender and juicy and flavorful -- YUM! The shish kebab has a great marinade -- YUM! The meat sauce is sort of like a marinara and is not overkill -- as some others have noted -- YUM! The spring rolls are all right.  They are pretty greasy and chewy, but not the worst I have ever had.  I do still eat it, so what am I complaining about? ;-)

Mind you, if you are looking for a nice, clean, pretty restaurant, be warned that this place looks a little sketchy.  There is an old, ratty counter where people perch and watch as the Vietnamese ladies slave away at the grill/fryer/stove.  But, what they lack in atmosphere they definitely make up for in food.

Highly recommended for those with a budget and those that want an interesting dining experience!!! One of my favorites!

Note: They only take cash and are closed on Mondays.
author: Katie M.

description:
A great date night for me is dinner at Cordon Bleu and a movie at Lumiere.  I always get the number 1 or the noodle salad, which is basically the number one on top of a cold noodle salad.

I don't know what they put in their meat sauce that goes over the rice but it is addictive.  As are their imperial rolls and beef.  If you a weirded out by watching your food getting grilled and cut with scissor and raw beef coming out of Tupperware under the counter, this may not be the place for you.

But if you love tiny hole in the wall secret and delicious spots then hit up Cordon Bleu.
author: Katie M.

description:
I remember when my friend Jeff asked me " are you feeling blue (bleu) today?" Not having no idea what the hell he was talking about, I inquire WTF  he was getting at.  No he wasn't asking me if I was feeling sad, he was asking if I wanted to go to his favorite hole in the wall, Cordon Bleu.

The first time I came here, we sat in the back.  Geez this place is a real hole in a wall.  It felt like I was sitting in someone's small kitchen waiting for their mom to bring out the food.  The place is incredibly small.  I had that not that very clean feeling about that place but hey it gave it that genuine mom and pop small eatery feeling which I enjoy so much.  I just try to stay ignorant with these types of joints regarding health code violations because I'm sure they had a handful in the kitchen.

The portion were pretty large for the price. I don't recall what I ordered but all I vaguely remember was big pieces of meat smoothered in gravy along with spring rolls.  It was pretty damn good and everyone enjoyed their meal.  Came back here again and it was still a great  meal.  I've been aching to come back but haven't had the chance.

Parking here kinda sucks so try to park at the Whole Foods up the block if you have no other choice.  While you're at it, go catch a flick at the Lumiere which is next door.
author: Jason Y.

description:
Hole in a Wall: Love it!
Family Owned: Love it!

BUT for the food, I'd say I'm okay with it.  While it's spring rolls are fantastic it's grilled chicken dish is not exactly Vietnamese.  Moreover, they try to add more flavors to their meals by pouring gravy over the rice since the flavor of the grilled chicken is very ordinary.

Having said that, I would not mind eating here again once every 2 months or so.
author: Alan T.

description:
Very yummy if you can over look the gritty almost dirty surroundings and then I noticed their heath department inspection score: 86. Thats low. Then I noticed the chicken in a big pan ON THE FLOOR behind the counter. Then I saw someone bring out a huge tray of those amazing imperial rolls freshly made....raw not cooked yet and she put them on a shelf behind the counter....hmmmm all this food just sitting out with no refrigeration made me nervous....but we were already eating. It was delish but I could not get over the score and the food just lying around.
That said the food was good, the rice with tomato sauce was yummy the chicken and kebob were also mmm. Three stars for cheap and funky....guess we took our chances here but honestly is was tasty.
author: James S.

description:
I've heard a lot of positive things about this restaurant, so I had to try it especially since it's in my neighborhood.  Frankly, I wasn't that impressed.  I had their chicken (Their specialty) and beef meal.  The chicken was good, but the beef was well overcooked and charred which was disappointing.  The rice and sauce accompaniments were decent.

The people were friendly and the small yet cozy place had a good feel to it, but my meal just didn't delight me.
author: Lemar H.

description:
Update: These folks continue to rock my world - definitely one of the best meals in town, in my humble opinion...yum yum yum!

I used to come here many moons ago and now that I'm back in the neighborhood sort of, I dropped here for lunch today. It still rocks!  I loved the whole experience -- sitting at the corner, virtually inside the kitchen, where I happily inhaled and absorbed the grill smell into my clothes, and sat serenely, waiting for my food. This is the real deal and my bun with chicken was amazing -- super fresh, tasty and filling...the portions here are not for the light-hearted. Several shall-we-say-sturdy men walked out with leftovers and although I was starving when I came in, I barely rolled out after finishing the whole thing. When you order chicken, they don't kid around -- they are talking about a quarter to a half chicken. And the two little ladies hack it onto the grill while you watch. 

Also, where else can you get meat sauce?   Nowhere.
author: Melissa G.

description:
So it seems like most we were walking down the street wondering what to eat, pizza/no, chinese/no, italian/no... etc you know the conversation...
and somehow out of nowhere cordon bleu was there.
i have walked passed this place supposedly 100's of times.
i say supposedly cause i have not seen it before and i am SURE it is in some magical time continueum thing that only allows you to see it when you need it.

anyway

service - gold
food - greasy, spoon cafeteria at it's best
portions - huge
price - cheap
bench - fun

all in all - this is now our little secret.  we havent told anyone and when we need to get away we will hide in our time continueum - next to the cool theatre from the 1940's.
author: Nathan H.

description:
Cordon Bleu wins the award for the quintessential hole-in-the-wall restaurant. The cuisine is closer to comfort food than what you'd normally expect from Vietnamese, but I have no complaints about it.

It's easy to think of Cordon Bleu as dirty, but beyond the old plastic cups and chairs with ripped cushions, the place is squeaky-clean.

Don't expect service to come to you. Ordering involves flagging down the cook at the grill. This isn't difficult, I just had to readjust my expectations. 

I've eaten at Cordon Bleu at least five times and every visit has been consistently enjoyable. Portions are never an issue, the never-changing menu has no need to be changed, and I walk away knowing I got a phenomenal deal for 8 bucks plus tip.
author: Greg S.

description:
They should just change their name to "Best Hole in the Wall Vietnamese Diner in San Francisco".

Large portions, small selection, cramped seating, things are cooked before you on fire-darkened stoves, fryers, and pots, and you come out smelling like the place. The food tends on the heavy side: they pour a meat sauce on top of the mountain of white rice that comes with your food. And they do not scrimp on grilling foods. So I come here when I'm in the mood for a lot of food and am not terribly worried about the quality of what I'm consuming. What can I say: Regardless of what I order I always clean my plate. 

CASH ONLY. Most entrees (maybe all?) are priced under $10.
author: Louise L.

description:
yelpers, pls don't throw pieces of chicken at me.

i love hole in the walls.  and i really wanted to love this place.
i like.  i like.  but love - maybe not this first time round.  maybe i need some more warming up.

cordon what?  who related cordon bleu with vietnamese cooking?
and since the sweet old ladies were chinese, this was a baffling mix.

but the crowd which all seemed like regulars were happily chatting and munching away.

i ordered the #4 : 5 spice chicken - two giant pieces of hen.  one was juicy and falling off the bone.  one was sadly so dry, i could burn wood.  i chewed for hours.

the rice drenched in a tomato meat sauce was tasty tasty.  gotta love the italian meats, i mean...meets chinese food.  i mean, vietnamese.  you know what i mean.

the cabbage salad was two thumbs up!!!  i'll have to try out the imperial rolls next time.  and hopefully, some juicy chicken.
author: Anh V.

description: What a gem! I have lived close by for a long time, but this is definitely a "blink and you miss it" kind of a place. But please do go - the food is wonderful and uber cheap. While as a vegetarian, I was unable to partake in the meatfest, I thought the garlic tofu with vermicelli salad was pretty tasty. Tofu was soft, but good. And, if you ask for "spicy", Katie and the gang will definitely pile on the jalapenos!
author: sar h.

description: MEAT SAUCE! I don't know if you can call this authentic vietnamese food. But it is definetely the place to go. Huge proportions for under $10. It is literally a hole in the wall.
author: Linda N.

description: Good portions for the price. The food is tasty. All I've had though is the chicken, rice and meat sauce, salad, and imperial roll and all are very good. The chicken has been dry a couple times, but still overall a very tasty meal for a reasonable price. I like how they cook in front of you too.
author: Joy H.

description:
Delicious! Great portions! Great prices!
I got a number 5 and it was great.  The meat sauce over the rice was pretty...pretty...pretty good.  They cook the food right in front of you so it has a very intimate feeling, like being in someone's kitchen.  Cash only!
author: Andrew R.

description:
I'm from new york city. Over the last 30 years, I used to visit SF very regularly, much less so now. I first found this place sometime in the early 80's , and it's still one of my regular stops if i was some quick cheap eats when I visit.

The 5 spice chicken is great - nice taste and that grilly charry flavor, and the meat sauce on rice is so comfy yummy. Honestly, i dont think i've ever had the pork chop or anything else - if I lived here in SF i would explore the menu (limited that it is) but it's such a rare treat for me and those are the dishes I'm coming for.

If I want fine dining I'll head to gary danko or something.

but there are times when this is exactly what i need t feed me
author: matthew h.

description:
Seriously good grub.

5 spice chicken is great, so are the imperial rolls.
author: Matt V.

description: We don't eat meat and we still love this food. It's mostly a meat friendly menu but we got both veggie items on the menu and loved it. Best food, best night!
author: Yolanda F.

description:
#5 - chicken, kebab, fried roll, rice and meat sauce = ambrosia 
did i mention a huge portion for only $6 ... do yourself a favor and at lest try this place out once ...:)
author: Anthony S.

description: Good and cheap food. They really give you a lot of goodies on the plate. I got the combo 5, which is the biggest plate they have with 3 pieces of grilled pork, chicken leg and thigh, springroll, rice with meat sauce, and pickled cabbage slaw. Really small place with maybe 20 seats if that.
author: David L.

description:
For me this place is home. Comfort food for the Viet diaspora oft unparalled in this coastal metropolis. One usually will not want of more generous servings then plated here. Don't overlook the chicken salad. Almost as good as my dear 'ol mom's. Damn, that's good eats for sure! Beware. This isn't a hip diner by any means, irregardless of its proximity to an arthouse theater. The last star is reserved  because of their limited hours. Props to the ladies! 
ENJOY!
author: Ian H.

description:
I have heard wonderful things about their five spice chicken, but I'm not really a chicken girl. 
I like rice with gravy.  As an added bonus they will give you some charred meat and a fried imperial roll.  Comfort food, innit.
Its greasy in there, but you can also get food to go, either way, delicious.
author: Flemm F.

description:
Best hole-in-the-wall in the city, hands down. It's all about the Five Spice BBQ Chicken with meat sauce over rice. mmmmmmm chicken... In fact, most of my friends just call it "five spice chicken" and nobody can ever remember it's real name. 

The food is just messy, charred, and awesome. The place is a total dive - a little on the dirty side, but just ignore that ;) Seats around 10, max. People come in to chat at the counter and get a bite on their way home or out for the evening. I've seen people bring in their own wine and even ice cream before. The family that runs it is super friendly and efficient with their service.  

Come with an open mind, leave with a full stomach :)
author: Jon W.

description:
This is where I go after some music at Grace cathedral. Its my warm up to enter society again. The staff are kind, attentive, and cook in front of you. 

Just order the ma po tofu extra spicy, an egg roll, and a coke.

Be nice and enjoy.
author: maxwell c.

description: My favorite in the City. Cannot beat the price. Gotta get the kebab and the chicken combo. It is unbeatable.
author: Nick C.

description:
So people like this place, "Best bun in the city!" I hear.  "Such a great deal!" they say.  

Not really though.  It's not bad, cute dinner seating, big portions, but I found the bun to be far too noodley, lacking in variety (cucumbers, peanuts, pickled carrots, green onion, salad stuff rather sparse) and the beef & rolls on top, while freshly made and inoffensive, weren't the best.  The rolls lacked a bit of flavor, and the beef was a bit too gristly for my taste.

Don't get me wrong, it's a fine Pho shop, and while it's not the culinary miracle others may claim, it is the best Vietnamese food in the immediate area.  The cooked while you watch bit is good, plus the employees/owners seem nice, and the prices aren't unreasonable by any means.
author: Gustie L.

description:
I've been going to Cordon Bleu for 10 years now.  I even remember when they got the new grill and hood in (that was about 6 years ago).

The ladies who work there are always nice.  The servings are enormous.  I usually order an extra side of shish kebab to go with the leftover rice I have for another meal.  

I usually recommend the combo which has everything: shish kebab, imperial roll, and chicken for those who've never been to CB, but I always get the shish kebab/imperial roll combo.  I wasn't a big meat eater back then, but when I tried their shish kebab I was hooked.

The menu used to be one page in a super large font with 4 combos and an ala carte menu, but has changed a lot since then.  It now has salads, a tofu dish, daily special, and one vegetarian meal. 

CB is tiny it seats 7 or 8 at the counter and has three 2-seat tables in the back.  It definitely fits the description of hole in the wall.

I do not recommend this place for vegetarians, but for all you meat eaters go hog wild!
author: J H.

description:
IT'S NOT FRENCH!

Whaaaaat?

How this place escaped me for years, i don't know, i even lived in the tenderloin and it still escaped my radar.

The place is very small, but the food is cheap, fast, and most importantly good. But watch your step, I almost took an unexpected trip. Another plus, is you can brown bag a beer if you so desire...

You're a vegetarian? Eat before you come here!
author: wayne s.

description: Best French Vietnamese food by Chinese owners. No joke. For $7 the grilled pork, rice w/ meat sauce, fried spring roll, and shredded cabbage will make you wonder why you don't eat here more often. Don't expect Subway-speed service, but the mild wait is worth it, or just phone in your order and pick it up 15 minutes in advance. Cash only.
author: Rocky S.

description: Yum!!  I like #5.  The imperial roll is amazing!  I loved watching it fry up, and served immediately.  A+
author: Goshen F.

description: When it comes to divey, hole in the wall, cheap, greasy, huge-portioned Vietnamese restaurants, I'm still partial to Tu Lan. However, Cordon Bleu has better imperial rolls. Great hearty comforting food, especially on a rainy SF day. If only they would add Vietnamese drinks....
author: Mark A.

description:
i've been going for years...
great place, great food, consistent, nice people.
go!
author: Ingrid Y.

description: Friendly service but the slightly over-priced tofu dish was bland. This was the only veggie option. :(
author: Jack N.

description: I've been here a couple of times with my dad and usually we sit at the bar because this place is as big as Harry Potter's under the stairs room. I usually order the #5 because that's what people come here for. I mean the plate has chicken, imperial rolls and rice with that gravy sauce. It's the total package! I love sitting at the bar because it allows you to see how they cook their food and that's always a fun part of the eating experience. My favorite thing would have to be the imperial rolls, so crunchy! Like a concert in my mouth. I have no idea what is in their sauce and I don't really want to know, just let me savor the mysteriousness of it all. Their portions can definitely fill you up, but it's cheap eats. Do not take a girl out on a date to this restaurant. If you do, there's a good chance you're never going to see her again. Unless she is me.
author: Lauren L.

description: Really friendly and unique hole in a wall place. Food is good, but a bit too much meat for my taste. Portion is very generous and price is very reasonable. Its definitely worth checking out.
author: vincent c.

description: I think that people should just stop being pansies and give this place all the credit they can get. I mean for the price of their plates you get so much and it is so goooood! Everything on the menu is awesome! 5 stars to the hard working people that make this place happen. Only in San Francisco.
author: Kayla G.

description: I think people really use the 5 star button too easily. Yes this place is cheap and yes the food is OK but not sure about the fantastic button. What is that stuff on the rice anyway? Not thinking it's meat. The imperial rolls were good. Rice and weird sauce were average. Kebab flat meat - average. Thinking maybe I should have gone for the chicken. Tiny so be patient. Don't go out of your way - just OK
author: Doreen D.

description: Loved this place! If you are in a group of more than 3 or in a hurry, not the place for you!  Looks like they do take out.  I loved the Noodle Salad with the 5 spice chicken.  Service is not friendly, but not rude, just working hard and no time for that, I think.  Cheap and yummy food, can't beat it.  Oh, did I mention... BYOB!
author: Kelli G.

description:
So... you enter, sometimes waiting a couple of minutes for a spot at the counter, and then be ready to grub.

I like it when people and places don't pretend to be something they're not. This place is for eating, that's it. It's cheap, it's good, and it fills you up. The food is as no-nonsense as the staff that works there. 30 minutes and $7.70 gets you fed and outta there.
author: Sean W.

description:
I'd give it a 2.5 if I could.  The food tastes great, in a comfort food kind of way.  Grilled pork chops, if done right, are awesome in my book.  The salad and imperial rolls that came along with it were great.  Tiny hole in the wall place, gotta love it.  Maybe 15 seats total.

The reason this doesn't get a better review is that the place is unsanitary.  Food is kept at the floor in uncovered containers.  Contamination by toe jam or creepy crawlies is a real possibility.

Order stuff well cooked.  This is actually as close as I've found in San Francisco to a yakitori restaurant (even though it calls itself Vietnamese and serves no beer), but just be careful.
author: Frank M.

description:
Character, this place has it.

Katie behind the counter grilling and memorizing everyones order is the friendliest person you will meet.  This place is small and you can't help but talk to Katie as she grills behind the counter.  You are looking at 13 seats with only three table and the rest counter space.  Stand in line or order it to go.  If you do order to go you might be looking at 15 minutes of waiting if there is a line.

What to order:
#5 -  a taste of everything, even the infamous meat sauce on the rice
Chicken Salad
What are you hungry for?

I went here two days in a row.  That is is how good this place is.
author: Po L.

description: Came here today for dinner and it was ok. It was definitely something new, I've never had Vietnamese style rice dishes with the meat sauce on it before (and I'm from Westminster aka Little Saigon). My cousin and I ordered the #1 and #5. The portions were huge and price reasonably but I think I like Vietnamese rice dishes with the fish sauce better.
author: Alison L.

description: I have only had a few items on the menu, but I keep ordering them because they are fresh and delicious. And the delivery is prompt and courteous! Great place!
author: Christie S.

description: The number 5 is the way to go.  It is a lot of food, it all works together, and is at a great price.  The food is bomb.  Highly recommend.
author: Chris D.

description: This place is magic. The price is EXTREMELY right and the food is super flavorful with big portions and the vibe is welcoming. I will CERTAINLY be back. The food has a very down home feel, look, and taste. I was going to The Lumiere and needed a quick meal in less than a half hour and took a chance. I'm glad that I did.
author: W. Kamau B.

description:
This is what a good cheap eats place should be. Cheap. Tasty. Cheap. Filling. Cheap. And what would a cheap place be without counter seating and potential health code violations?

Admittedly, I'm not a big fan of their mystery meat sauce. Although it is oddly interesting to watch them make it.

Want to stray from the traditional? Try their noodle salad or the chicken cabbage salad. Don't forget to add the sriracha!
author: Mobile B.

description: This place is AMAZING! The food has so much flavor. I have been going here for a few months now and I can't get enough. I recommend the number 5. Good bang for your buck so make sure you are hungry. A huge plate of food ranges from 6-8 dollars.
author: Jonathan M.

description: wonderful, crispy, juicy bbq at rock bottom prices.  if you don't have your own bar-b-q grill this is the place to go.  its small inside but the atmosphere is super friendly.
author: Amy C.

description: My friend and I were lucky that when we walked in we grabbed the last two seats at the counter. We both ordered the #5, roasted chicken, rice with meat sauce, and imperial roll. Everything about the dish was very very savory.  It tastes just like a classic motherly meal should taste like; a meal that can sooth the soul.  I am definitely coming back.
author: Marco M.

description: Top 5 cheap eat in the city. The #5 is amazing and enough food for two days. Couple that own it are VERY friendly.
author: Ben T.

description: Really good, greasy food, large portions and a very good price. I usually get the number five, which is a good place to start if it's your first time. I love the crispy beef strips and the imperial rolls are so good, but so bad for you! The meat sauce in the rice goes really well with the cabbage slaw. It's fun to sit at the counter and watch the woman work the ancient equipment!
author: jen w.

description:
Make a circle with your index finger and thumb. 

Go ahead, do it now. I'll wait. 

Okay good. That circle you just made is the size of Cordon Bleu's tiny establishment. But as guys with small penises like to say, size doesn't matter! 

They're right. 

Because Cordon Bleu is my favorite Vietnamese hole-in-the-wall dive restaurant. Very large portions for very little money. Add a super-addictive meat sauce and prepare for your boat to be rocked like a hurricane.

If you're a vegetarian, you'll be allergic to this place. But to all you lovers of tasty meats, this is your oasis.
author: Chanpory R.

description:
All I have to say is pour that COUNTRY GRAVY on my white rice!

I notice a lot of reviewers into the "authenticity" debate.  To them I say mixing traditions and adaptation are found in all third world cuisine. Accusing CB of not being "authentic" is like claiming a Vietnamese Sandwich isn't really Vietnamese because it uses a french baguette.  

The food is warm, tasty and the portions are large. This is a great value restaurant meat eater or vegetarian alike. You can enjoy your food more because you see all of the work that is laboring to create it, pots overflow a foot away from where you dine. My favorite hole in the wall joint next to one of my favorite theaters, the Lumiere.
author: roselia i.

description: Super good and super cheap. Loved the imperial rolls, 5 spice chicken, and meat sauce.
author: m t.

description: I am a SoCal kind of gal, so I'm use to the traditional type of Vietnamese food. I thought I'd  try this place because of the ratings on yelp. This place is super tiny, but the food was delicious! I loved their beef and rice with the red sauce. I would definitely go back if I visit SF in the future.
author: Mandy C.

description: I'm not a Vietnamese restaurant regular, but Cordon Bleu might turn me into one! The #4 didn't disappoint.  The leg/thigh portion was a bit difficult to navigate but tasty nonetheless.  The breast was flavorful, moist and delicious.  Wish I'd paid the extra dollar to get all white meat.  Tasted my husbands imperial roll and was impressed with how packed it was and full of flavor!  Friendly helpful service.  Read some reviews that criticized sitting in the back but we were comfortable and didn't notice any off-putting odors.  Well worth the $8-9 per plate.
author: Ms F.

description:
Come Meet Katie. She'll tell you what's the word on the street!

NO really. This restaurant can duo as both a social lounge and a eatery. It's a small quaint place so be ready to say "hello" to your next door neighbor's elbows. It's as big as an average home's kitchen but it's got a heart of gold. There's only one long counter so many people wait in line outside the restaurant to get a seat. Katie is the owner and you'll see her behind the counter almost everyday. If you can get past looking at what a real restaurant kitchen looks like, then you can really enjoy the food here. If not, then perhaps this might not be your spot.

Why is this place so charming? Because you feel at HOME in this place. It's not much when you walk in. A typical mom and pop of SF. The real charm is the mojo of this place. Katie knows her customers well and has a charisma like no other. She listens to you and boy is she funny. All of the cooking is done in front of you so you know there's no funny business. The menu is small and not super vegetarian friendly but that's okay. Tell Katie and she makes magic happen. 

My coworker and I ordered the garlic tofu/veggie combo plate. One would expect the typical fare that most Asian restaurants; a small entree plate with a side of rice. Here, you have to wear your sun glasses because what you get will blow you away. Katie loads up your whole plate with rice and then drapes your entree on it like if it were velvet on your skin. She uses a whole box of tofu just for you and boy is the tofu tasty. The garlic sauce she makes (which can be made without oyster sauce) coats your tongue and although it can make you a fire breathing dragon, its soo warm and tasty. 

In addition to the entree, we got the imperial roll. MAN o MAN is this a bad boy. SO bad. I kinda wanted to take this in the corner and show it how bad it was but hic! sorry this is not the right channel for that! The imperial roll is a large spring roll but it has something imperial about it. I say it has something imperial about it because I REALLY have no idea what's in it. I do know that its the BEST roll i've ever had and that says a lot. Especially since I'm vegetarian. It's got portabella mushrooms in it and the noodles are marinated in some sauce which gives it a black tinge. This alone can serve as your lunch or dinner but I bet you that this won't be it... My coworker always says that her stomach button malfunctions in here. It's like your stomach doesn't turn off. You just want to keep eating and eating. The food makes you super full and when no one is looking (which is hard in this place) you yearn to release the top button of your pants. 

Had enough food? Then have some tea with Katie. Tell her your problems. If you're having issues with finding someone to date, she'll suggest you some passerby's. She knows her regulars and she's a pretty good judge of character. I think the best part of this place is that if you're new to the city, you have the opportunity to make an instant friend. Everyone at the counter (whether they are naturally friendly or not) interacts with one another. I dunno what makes this happen but I suspect it's this: MAGIC. Okay, okay. Not a kid anymore BUT, it is magic to see all walks of life both young and old laugh with one another over warm, home style food. Yum.

Okay, so lets do a recap. 2 garlic tofu/veggie entrees. Check. One large Imperial roll. Check. 2 small egg rolls (which Katie threw in for free because I was curious).  Double Check. 2 Jasmine Teas. Check. Total: $21 bucks. REALLY? COME ON. You can not beat that. Tip her well and show her the love she showed you.

I'll tell you another thing. If you pass a homeless guy on California street and they see you holding these left overs, they ARE going to ask for it. True story and yes, they got the left overs but boy do you wanna kick yourself for being a good Samaritan. Damn you angelic conscience! 

This is a gem of a place so keep your eyes peeled for it. It's easy to miss because it is a small place but if you find it, you won't be disappointed. Katie is a hard worker and you'll see all the love she puts into her food. Oh I miss you Imperial rolls and I'll be back someday!
author: Lakshmi R.

description: I got the kabob, meat sauce on rice and salad thingy. It was really good and for the price, it was great! It came out to $7.50 and I left w/plenty of leftovers for the next day! Decent food for the price you pay. I would definitely go back!
author: A M.

description: I was here when I was on a group trip with a friends while visiting SF.  We hopped off the street car and ordered a few dinner after seeing Alcatraz.  I forgot what I ordered exactly, but I do remember ordering the 5 spice chicken.  I was impressed, however, I would not describe it as the "best chicken outside of Vietnam."
author: Chau L.

description: Great Food. Fantastic Price. I'd say 6 or 7 counter seats, and a few tables. Great Value.
author: Nicholas P.

description: I was avoiding reviewing this place in fear of letting the cat out of the bag on one of the greatest cheap-eats place in SF, but since there are already 20 people who squealed, I'll elaborate on why this is one of my all-time faves.  GOD, their 5-spice chicken is so good.  So good, I can't stand it.  They must dip it in something illegal to make it taste this yummy.  Yeah, this place is pretty gross to eat in.  But still, that country salad is killer.  I also like that lava-hot meat sauce they ladle over rice.  If you're not into the chicken, order the noodle salad, which is big and fresh.  Don't get the spring rolls, though.  If you've ever eaten the rolls at Minh Tri, everyone else's taste sub-par.
author: Kristina R.

description: Any place that has only a few things on the menu and even fewer places to sit down better have perfected their recipes.  And let me tell you this place most definitely has.  Don't come here if you are a vegetarian that is for sure. But any one else will  enjoy their bbq chicken drowned in more meat sauce.  Don't waste time wondering what type of meat is used in the sauce or how many calories just enjoy it. And leave room for the best imperial rolls you may ever have.  Of course not a place to go to for a romantic date, though I would be quit happy to go here on a date ;)
author: Trista L.

description: Oh my god, the food here was so good! My family came here based on reviews and I'm glad we did. The place itself is very small and looks sketchy. My mom and sister didn't like the way the place looked but I didn't care. When I read the description as a Vietnamese restaurant, I was expecting pho. When I got there, the menu was small and lacked pho but was priced very cheap. I ordered the 5 spice chicken and my mom and sister got a tofu dish. The chicken tasted so awesome and the sauce it came with was spectacular. The sheer amount of food was also ridiculously huge as I could barely finish it all. The tofu dish was a bit too salty but the chicken was perfect. I want to move to San Francisco just to eat this stuff everyday!
author: Kevin K.

description: If you are looking for cheap and quick, tasty food then Cordon Bleu will fit the bill!  Service is pretty slow & inattentive unfortunately but hey it's still a good value and the food is solid.  I like the no frills aspect and even though it's a 3-star I definitely will be going again when I want something cheap, filling and chill.
author: Gene X.

description:
i don't have a problem with this place as my wife does. so i guess i'm going to go back on my own. i'm hoping this isn't the start of separate lives. you know it starts with separate dinners then before you know it it is separate beds, vacations, etc...

a little MSG now and then is just part of eating some tasty asian grinds. i had the combo that included an imperial roll, chicken, and grilled pork. it comes on a mound of rice with this meat sauce that could feed the homeless population outside the place. i like the carcinogen causing burnt crispy edges that accompany the chicken. (i drink lots of red wine at home in hopes of killing the little cancer buggers.) anyway i ate it all except the pile of rice and was happy. i don't think i puffed up from the MSG. i'm always a little puffy so maybe i just wear it better. 

writing this makes me want to hit the place again soon. i like it just fine. oh yea it is cheap.
author: roger b.

description:
I've been visiting SF on business frequently over the last decade, I've taken the most high-flutent clients to the best places, the priciest, the most impressive, the best value, the loudest, blah blah, and when folks ask about my fave restaurants, it always boils down to three places - Dottie's True Blue Cafe, Slanted Door and this - each residing in their own distinct galaxy in SF's gastronomic landscape, which I've seen plenty...

The Bleu (my co-producer "yelps" the name - The Bleuuuuuuuuu - everytime we land at SFO or Oakland coming in from LA) is a mecca-like voyage, a staggering advance towards sustenance, the broom closet with but if you blink, you'll miss the feast with my name on it, #5 with a Diet Coke (I think I'll name my next child that), you need say nothing more...the meat sauce, the imperial rolls, the succulent chicken, the satay beef, the elbow-to-elbow, dna-slam dancing confines, seating maybe 12, that blackened pot of simmering meat sauce (mmmmm, with corroded effects dating back to the Summer of Love, but who's counting), the Vietnamese family proprietors slinging the fare like yum-bearing mercenaries, the meat scissors brought out on occasion to clip the slightly charred edges of the satay beef to ensure palate-worthiness...I'm dying to fly up there right now just to get a taste...so worth the wait if you have to line up outside...On that 100 or so list of things to do before you die that you have tucked away somewhere, add "Dinner at The Bleu", you'll expire happy.
author: Mitch S.

description: Awesome little hole in the wall with the staples: grill meats (chicken, pork), AMAZING meat sauce over rice cooked the old school way over a gas stove, country style salad (really just lightly vinegared shredded cabbage and carrots) and these ginormous imperial rolls (i think mini burritos whenever I see them). I always order #4: nothing beats the 1/2 grilled chicken, mountains for rice with heaps of meat sauce, and the salad.  I wish they sold the meat sauce in jars so that I can take it home and just use the sauce over rice. THAT would be the ideal comfort food.  I never finish the entire plate, because it can feed 2 people. The owner gave me more rice and like 2 inches worth of sauce  in my to go box. So much sauce that she had to separately pack my remaining chicken. She must have heard me say that I wanted to take jars of sauce home.
author: Annie Y.

description: I've been going to Cordon Bleu since the mid 80's.  It is the most amazing "hole in the wall" that I have ever found.  It's one of those places where someone has to take you the first time and I guarantee you that you will be back.  I highly reccommend the #5 which is grilled chicken, cole slaw, a mountain of rice with a delicious meat sauce, a spring roll and a shish kabob...all for less than $10.  Go...NOW!
author: A. P.

description: Great deal for the price, and the owner couldn't be nicer. The 5-Spice Chicken, Ma-Po Tofu, and Imperial Rolls are all winners, as are the generous portions of rice smothered in meat sauce. The wait can be lengthy, however, and getting one's order in (and getting the check) can take some effort it it's busy.
author: James P.

description: 5-spice chicken is the best bbq chicken outside of 'nam!  A giant plate of chicken, meatsauce, fried crispy imperial rolls, seasoned and shredded cabbage will cost you a piddling sum of $8.  The chicken was savory, had the perfect crispiness to the skin, and tender inside-- well marinated, well cooked.  A true hole in the wall, acommodations were limited to a counter that seats about 9/10 and 2 or 3 small tables.  Will come here again and again-- hits the spot for a pre-drinking-binge dinner.
author: Marjorie B.

description:
The food is tasty but the method of cooking does not conform to any health regulations recognized in this hemisphere.  Marinated raw meat is kept at room temperature in open containers.  Cooked meat is kept in metal bins on the floor.  The cook uses tongs to put raw meat on the grill then immediately uses the same tongs to put cooked meat on a serving plate.  Half-cooked egg rolls are left in the open air indefinitely and then resubmerged for a minute before service.  There is only one rag in the kitchen, and it is used for any purpose.

They should change the motto to "Possibly the best-tasting case of food poisoning you will get outside of Vietnam."
author: Jeff B.

description: Good food, for super cheep. It is a hole-in-the-wall for sure. All food is cooked to order off of their tiny menu. However, the portions are HUGE!! I can only eat half of the plate before I am stuffed. The two of us eat there for under $20. There are very few seats but, you can just wait a few minutes and grab a seat at the counter in no time. It is worth a visit, I'm hooked!! Sauces are great, meat is fresh and cut perfectly, the 5 spice chicken is sooo yummy, the rice is great and the meat sauce they make on it is just delicious. Good tea and such nice people that work and cook there. Just  go!!!! I gave it 5 stars!!
author: Heather L.

description:
The grilled pork and chicken was very yummy.  The "imperial rolls" wasn't very tasty to me... just tasted fried... not much flavor or texture.  Our meals came with more rice than was needed.  The tomato sauce thing over the rice was a bit strange to me.  I've eaten at many Vietnamese restaurants and never seen anything like that... or in any Asian cuisine...  Although this place is run by Chinese people so it's understandable that it's unlike any Vietnamese restaurant I've been to.  Overall the food was tasty and reasonable.  

Their bathroom was very clean...  which surprised me... considering they grilled the food on the floor.
author: Kelly C.

description:
There's some kind of Opiate in her food. I'm not kidding. I'm a hedonist. I get around, I search out deliciousness. I can't help but make yummy sounds when eating something divine, but I have never had my mouth water with the thought of a restaurant. There, It's doing it right now. God damn it. I am not driving across the bridge and looking for parking just so I can satiate that craving for number 5. GOD DAMN IT. 
Here's the thing about this place: It is a true hole in the wall. A counter with 8 stools, 2 ladies jocking for position behind the counter serving up 5 different combinations of what they have.   It is not a clean, pretty, spacious restaurant. If you were raised by parents who shun things like dirt and germs, are afraid of things unknown, or have an idea of how things "should" be, you will be uncomfortable. If not, get your rump over here and sit down. Order a number 5. Just do it. Don't ask why, just order it. 5 spiced chicken, thin strips of beef, country slaw, Deep fired eggroll, and oh yes, MEAT SAUCE over rice. Ask for extra meat sauce. Then ask for some more once you eat the meat sauce but there is still some rice left on your plate. They're used to it and will gladly serve you up some more free of charge. No, there is no such thing as coutnry slaw or this kind of meat sauce in Vietnam. Who Cares!?! It's freaking awesome. Oh, and CHEAP. Dinner for 2, 2 sodas, Meat Sauce to go for $20.
author: Jared H.

description: I haven't been here for years and I miss it so much! This is a place where u'll never forget how closely you're rubbing elbows with the guys sitting next to your stool, slurpping up the most delicious meat sauce on steamed white rice. MMM! It's Vietnamese cuisine, mainly grilled/bbq items. It's affordable and gives you a large rice plate portion. Gosh, you've gotta just try it once. Five stars cuz the food is so satisfying and delicious and different.
author: Margherita S.

description:
i was a pescatarian for a while and then inexplicably started CRAVING meat. this place satiated me completely. there is meat in/on everything. the menu is small (like the spot itself), but everything is good. not too delicate of flavors, but hearty BBQed goodness. they trim everything that is too blackened. those small details count for me. 

to be totally honest, a little grunge doesnt freak me out. the grill that they use at this place is hot enough to kill any germs. someone said they were put off by the rag (you'll know what i mean if you go there) but seriously, if you manned a grill before you will understand that its better to clean it off than to leave the charred stuff on your food.
author: Ligaya T.

description: An unbelievable amount of tasty chicken and rice with just enough spice for only $7.50: this is the #4 at Cordon Bleu. You get to watch it being cooked so you'll be good and hungry by the time it's ready (Takes about 15 minutes), and you'll know it was fresh. The pork and other items on the menu are good too, but I'd highly recommend the 5 spice chicken first. Probably the best hole in the wall restaurant I've found in SF so far.
author: David K.

description: Upon entering, if you like what you smell, you will enjoy your meal...no matter what you order.  Everything pretty much tastes more of the *five spices* than its animal or vegetable of origin..I like it, but I have to really be in the mood for it because there is nothing subtle about these eats...and, as mentioned in earlier reviews, beware the blistering hot imperial roll!
author: L W.

description: This restaurant is great! It is a small place, but the vibe of sitting right next to people and watching your food get cooked makes for a really neat dining experience.  The first time I attended cordon bleu there was a group of guys who brought a cake for the owner.  It was really a neat night because the entire place sang to her while the service did not miss a beat.  The food is amazing and my friend and I are totally addicted now.  I think there is crack in the meat sauce...I NEED MORE!  The chicken salad is huge and you don't leave feeling like you need a tow truck to get you home.  I highly recommend this place for a unique dining experience and...they let you bring in your own wine!
author: Tracy R.

description: The chicken dinner is enough for 2 meals unless you're feeling gluttonous. Perfectly grilled & never dry. This is what i eat when i need comfort food.
author: Sarah L.

description: I've traveled the world, and appreciate good food.  When in SFO I always go to Cordon Blue, limited menu, limited seating only about 18 people max, simple and not  attractive to look at, but the food is outstanding, and you get a LOT of it.  Enough for two meals.  The chicken and meat sauce are excellent, like nothing I've ever eaten.  The owner is so nice and she and her limited staff work very hard to prepare their homemade, cooked to order recipies. If there is a line up, it's definitely worth the wait. I only gave it a 4 star because of the ambience.   I cant wait to go back again!
author: Dawn M.

description:
i had combo #5. both the shish kebab and chicken leg was absolutely delicious. i thought the meat gravy was okay but wasn't loving it as much as others.

it is a bit pricey for a dive but the food is damn good.

looking around i noticed 2 things: 1) best dive in 2006 for sf weekly 2) health inspection score of 89 in sept. 2007

these were both reassuring especially after reading some of the other reviews. i also did a quick scan for roaches/rats and was satisfied. i've decided to go with the "what i don't know won't hurt me" philosopy as i really want to come back and try the ma pa tofu. =D
author: Princess Pompom Patootie W.

description: Yummy 5 spice chicken - we split an order with some tea and still headed next door to the movies full on a rainy Sunday evening. 5 stars for the 5 spices, 5 stars for a fairly clean hole in the wall open kitchen, 5 stars for pretty good food at a beats Boston Market price! But it's a 4 for two reasons: snippy waitress/cashier who puts the family dysfunction into a mom and pop op, and look, I know I grew up in WI, but if I wanted to be cold, I would have stayed there. Close the back door - I'm huddling over my tea cup to compensate for the draft! Still, I will go back when I'm in the neighborhood (though I will also wait until it's warmer).
author: Keri B.

description: Love this place.  The imperial roles are fantastic.  The place is very small, but the food is fantastic especially for the price. Yes, you do have to wait a bit to get service, but there is only like 4 people working.  This place is so worth the wait...Please note there is a limited menu...love the salad...
author: Y S.

description: Best five-spice chicken (ga nhu vi) in SF. And what a steal. For $7.95 or so you get a lot of food, usually rice, cabbage salad, and the chicken. Right next to the Lumiere Theatre, this is great for before or after a film. Yeah, it's tiny, and not the best decor, but who cares when it's this good?! I could frankly care less. Order the combos with the chicken, but not the meat sauce. It's totally unnnecessary and overkill. A blue ribbon prizewinner indeed!
author: Hao L.

description: Food here is YUMMY! It is a complete hole in the wall, so don't expect some high end ambiance.  There's probably only seating for 15 people max in the space. The plates are big and pretty darn cheap. The egg rolls, chicken, shish kabob beef and meat over rice are all very tasty!
author: Eva L.

description: I found this place when I first moved to SF because every night when I walked by it on my way home from work, there was a huge line. I had to know what the hype was over this hole-in-the-wall teeny-tiny place, so I finally went. Let me tell you, I GET IT!! This little lady can cook up a storm, and you get obscene amounts of delicious food for nothing! All of the dishes are basically a combination of either 5-spice chicken, shish-kebab, meat sauce over white rice, cabbage, and either a spring roll or an emperial roll (which is like a meat-filled spring roll.) All of this food is roughly anywhere from $6-$8, and is some of the best things you'll ever taste. Plus, it's a hole-in-the-wall, so it's cool . . .
author: Jamie C.

description: Great hole-in-the-wall 5-spice chicken. Grungy atmosphere. Loved the food but when I woke up the next morning my whole face was puffy which can only mean one thing: loaded with msg. Sad but probably wouldn't go back.
author: margot b.

description:
Came for: trying out a dive-y experience
Will come back for: bang-for-your-buck hearty food (yummy chicken, beef, and imperial rolls) to take to-go

It was my fortune that I stumbled across this great find of a dive before I'd heard/read anything about it (this review is a few years overdue).  As it happens to be on my commute, I decided to stop by and peak in.  The area is tight and consists only of one main bar table and two (?) small tables off to the sides.  Despite the limited space, it's crowded with eager folks who've already placed their orders or those onlookers waiting for a table.  I opted to order the combo plate of 5-spice chicken, meat slices, and imperial rolls with meat sauce over rice to-go.  
And when I finally opened it up back at home -- it was so very good.  The chicken was moist and the meat just fell right off the bones.  The marinade of the meat was done so well that it made me forget about having waited the extra 10 minutes for it.  The imperial roll was crispy and flavored well w/o being too salty.  And the meat sauce?  Although it seemed kinda ghetto, it was...  hearty and good.
Cordon Bleu?  It has my vote and I'm glad it's an easy access for me.
I highly highly recommend picking it up as a to-go!
author: Carol K.

description: I popped into this tiny hole in the wall for lunch the other day and walked away very pleased, very full and slightly less hung-over than when I had entered.  For five bucks I got a giant piece of 5-spice chicken, country salad (a fancy-pants name for coleslaw), and meat sauce over rice.  The menu claims that the 5-spice chicken is "Possibly the best chicken you will ever have outside of Vietnam" and while I may not necessarily agree (I've never been to Vietnam), it is damn good.  For me though, the real kicker was the meat sauce.  The only way I could properly describe it is, fortifying.  I think that shit could cure cancer.
author: Broke-Ass Stuart S.

description:
One of my favorite places over the decades. Yes, it has been around that long.

Simply flavorful, delicious, ample, juicy food. And incredibly cheap.

I always get the combo with everything, including the meat sauce. 

Don't pass up the imperial rolls. Cordon Bleu is about the only place that knows how to make them properly these days.

The owner works hard and is fun to talk to. But keep in mind that this is a real hole-in-the-wall, with very little seating. If you go at busy times, she's not likely to be in a chatting mode because she is cook, cashier, and maitre d'.
author: Greg T.

description:
clunk!  that's the sound of me plunking down my coors light tall boy on the counter while my friend and i wait for the nice lady to fry us up a couple of imperial rolls.  no judgment here, just crispy, crazy delicious, totally hot imperial rolls.

i go temporarily crazy when i'm in here and start thinking i should order at least 2 meals to go, even though i would have to drag them around for 5 hours, at least 3 bars, and a hour-long BART ride home.
author: Holly B.

description:
Tiny little hole in the wall and not a little grimy but they are so friendly and the food is fast and cheap and believe it or not, you CAN get a healthy meal!!! I always get the chicken salad which is lovely raw cabbage ( low calorie) and fresh herbs tossed with white meat chicken and I ask for the vinegar dressing on the side so I can control how much, even though its not oily or heavy.  Nate always gets the rice, 5 spice chicken, pork and roll plate and I get to have a bite of the fatty goodness without making a meal of it and feeling all heavy.  
We actually call this place  "The Goodness".
Admittedly though we have not been coming here often as it is small and just a counter to sit at and you come out smelling like you were marinated in the 5 spice and grilled...so don't wear your Sunday best and wash your hair so you don't smell up your pillows like a BBQ.
Its worth it though, very yummy.
author: Nilu r.

description: This place is awesome! The chicken is perfect and the portions are huge- especially for the price.
