I ordered the number 4 (chicken, rice and salad) and my boyfriend ordered the number 5 (chicken, shish kebab, rice, salad and imperial roll). Both orders were delicious and I think one number 5 would be sufficient for two people- meaning you could go out to eat for under 10 bucks!
author: Kristen L.

description:
tender, hearty meats, and five stars for the juicy five-spice chicken. the rice is even cooked in a pot rather than a rice cooker. i love their flavorful egg rolls and i'm not even really into egg rolls. it's a pretty quiet place, no music, and everyone is busy eating:) limited bar seating. the women who work there are lovely. 

this is one of my favorite spots in the city. it's like, less than 8 bucks for half a chicken, rice, meat sauce, and a large, homemade imperial egg roll. ridiculously cheap and amazingly good food. as good as barbecue can get without my own grill. i feel like it's always 3/4 hungry males eating in there when i go:) cash only! (but there is a wamu next door and a wells fargo and bofa very close by).
author: Jean H.

description: This place deserves 6 stars.  It's one of a kind.  I lived right up the street, and I didn't go nearly enough.  It's small, actually tiny, and their hours seem really quirky, but the food is to die for.  It is unbelievable, really.  And it's cheap, maybe 7 bucks for a huge meal.  I believe I would normally get the 5 spice chicken, sauce, and all the fixings, and everything I ate there, from the meat to the poultry to the rolls to the sides was heavenly.  I miss this place.
author: Jim D.

description: This place only serves bbq pork (which looks like beef) and 5 spice chicken. Both come covered with some pork meat sauce. I don't eat pork so I can only eat ONE THING at this restaurant. ONE thing and I can't even eat the sauce that's supposed to be on it. I'm still giving it 5 stars because the chicken is that good and it's cheap. I think this might be the cheapest meal you can get in San Francisco and it's really good. I can usually get two meals out of it.
author: mazzy s.

description: If you are expecting Slanted Door or some other fu-fu vietnamese place, you would be sadly mistaken and clutching your pearls as you entered this place.  This is a extremely small place with counter service.  I think this is the first vietnamese restaurant in the city so it is probably very Americanized ( I have never seen gravy over rice at another vietnamese restaurant).  However, the food is great and filling.  There is a trio of extremely hard working people that work here and they do a great job in providing a very hearty meal.  If you have visitors from the mid-west who you think might not try vietnamese food, they would probably like this version of it.
author: Travis H.

description: Meat sauce is go! Extremely filling and quite cheap, and tasty. Not something you'd want to do everyday. Once or twice a year is probably perfect. Very friendly, good value.
author: Jonny A.

description:
So I have walked by this place many times and I decided to try this place out. The funniest thing was that right before I left there was a white guy and an asian girl that left and paid for their bill. My gf (who is asian) and I (the white boy) sat down in the same spot. The owner asked if I wanted change and I said no it's the people before us. And in disbelief she said really? and I said yes. Then she made a comment that caught me and the people next to me offguard and said "all you people look alike". Ofcourse I was shocked but laughed. Ofcourse if it would have been the other way around it would have been very offensive and the place would have probably shut down.
Regardless I definitely like the place and will definitely come back. You get a lot for your buck. I only brought $20 and ran back home to get a few more $$ for tip. I know if I wouldn't she would be the type of lady that would remember me as the cheap white boy so i had to do what I had to do. :)
author: Nir B.

description: Whole-in-the-Wall Place ... but Rice with Meat sauce is the "Real" San Francisco Treat.  Get their House Special Combo Plate (to go ... if you can't stand to eat in the place).  Imperial roll,  Five spice chicken and grilled Viet. pork.  Comfort Food in the comfort of your home.  Check for Business Hours sometimes they're closed.
author: Jerz Z.

description: I lucked out when I moved to the TenderNob 11 years ago and ended up living 4 blocks from Cordon Bleu.  The #5 is like a little to-go container of heaven, smothered in a meat sauce that rivals the ambrosia of the gods.  The food alone is worth the trip but if you stay and eat there...if you sit at the warm counter watching your food being cooked in front of you, listening to the cable cars rumble by, sharing the moment with no more than a dozen other people...you also get one of those true, intimate, slice of San Francisco experiences.
author: Jon B.

description: i love this place. awesome food cheap! i think i have taken every guy i've ever dated here! :)
author: Timothy M.

description: It made me want to go back to being a vegetarian. I was excited about this place, my friend raved about it and told me "Get the chicken and meat sauce!" Which i did and I guess I shouldn't have watched how they make their food. Umm gross! They have stock piled under their counter their uncooked chickens and rolls and meat, exposed with no covers! They used a rag over and over and over to clean the grill and made my dinner friends lose their appetite. Although the imperial roll did not burn my mouth, and the veggie noodle salad was really fresh, I wont go back.
author: Alyssa C.

description: Ok, noodle salads with meat and imperial rolls and yummy sauce are pretty much my favorite thing and having it so close to my house is truly amazing. The fact that I've lived here 4 years and never went in is a crime I may never be able to rectify.  So incredibly good- and its BYOB- which is great because they bring you tumblers to drink wine in, which is awesome.
author: Noelle Q.

description: The first time I went to 5 Spice I saw the cook drop a chicken on the floor and put it back on the grill!!!  I've eaten here several times since and have never gotten sick.  So, five stars for good food, BYOB, and a "dive-y", hole-in-the-wall experience that doesn't give you e coli.
author: Nora G.

description:
So a foodie friend of mine with discerning taste recommended Cordon Bleu for their 5 spice chicken. It took me awhile to check it out myself because I'm not too into 5 spice, but when I finally tried it it was fabulous. I ended up getting the noodle salad which came with really tasty pork and delicious eggroll. By calling it noodle salad, rather than the Vietnamese Vermicelli noodles with pork, I was thinking it might taste more like a Chinese dish rather than Vietnamese dish as it states. It really was delicious and sooooo much better than the Viet version at Minh Tri's. My husband ordered the #5 and he got that meat sauce...I tried a tiny bit of it but it just didn't look appealing to me so I didn't grub off his plate as much as I thought I would. I do agree that they should use different tongs for the raw vs cooked meats, but other than that...food was great and I didn't have high expectations for ambiance so no complaints on that front. Great hole in the wall place, limited menu makes for easy ordering. Also, I think this restaurant is more Vietnamese/Chinese than Vietnamese. 

There was only 1 young waitress and another woman (the cook). The waitress really cracked me up...she didn't seem to speak much English...If you order straight from the menu as-is, then she's fine with taking the order...Any special requests can get confusing for her and the customer trying to communicate with her, which may cause her to walk away and giggle with her hand covering her mouth - at which point the cook comes in to translate and take the order. Cute :).
author: Mellie D.

description: I love this hole in the wall, it's the place I go when I'm craving greasy and meaty deliciousness. First, they have the best Imperial rolls and five spice chicken I've tasted in the city so far. I also love the noodle salad, they don't shy away from giving you lots of meat.
author: Kelly L.

description: I enjoyed the food as much as watching the 3 Chinese women run the business. They have a small menu with different combinations. They are honest, if you order the ma po tofu, and they are too busy to make it, "Too busy today, I will make it for you some other day. Order something else." That's classic. :) Definitely super good value for hot home cook food. I always end up eating 200% more then what I am suppose to.
author: Ervinna L.

description: Probably one of the best hole in the wall places I've ever been to. The place is tiny and really needs remodelling. Only the brave food fanatic would actually eat here. I personally just always get my food to go. The combination dishes are simply amazing. From the imperial rolls, grilled beef or chicken OR just order the big combo that has all of them...you'll feel like you're in hog heaven (in a very delicious way). This place is cheap especially considering you can feed an army---ok, maybe a little bit of exaggeration there---with the amount of food they give you. Definitely worth a try if you're not a food snob and have to have your food in an immaculately clean place because this will not be the place for you if so. If you're adventurous and ready to have an explosion of flavors happen in your mouth on the other hand, then Cordon Bleu is perfect for you.
author: Vincent L.

description: I am big fan of this place. It's a small hole in the wall kind of place...six or seven counter seats and three tables. I had the noodle salad...and it was good! The imperial rolls were definietely and a favorite of mine. I also tried their five spice chicken...which was also very good. Overall, good prices and good food.
author: Brandon U.

description: While not for the table linen and crystal crowd I highly recommend Cordon Bleu! I have been a customer for thirty years after having stumbled upon them while out for a walk. The food is wonderful and I love the show in the kitchen!
author: Maggie M.

description:
rice, meat sauce, topped with fried goodness and more meat!

i give it only 4 stars just because i think the portions have gotten a little smaller of late.
author: Joanne L.

description: Went here on the night before Thanksgiving and they were open late.  Ordered a chicken plate with an Imperial Roll.  Came with rice and a salad.  Simple, yet authentic, filling and very low priced.  Katie or Kate treated my cousin, her friend and I, like her own kids.  She kept cooking more food and Imperial Rolls and putting them on our plates as we were eating and she never charged us extra.  Very hole in the wall, and I love the fact they cook your food in front of you.
author: Nezza F.

description: this place ROCKS!!! the shish kabob (lamb) is to die for, perfectly grilled right in front of you. I always get the lamb and noodle dish, it comes with an imperial role and is mighty yumyum. The chicken salad is also a nice treat. Beer goes really good with this food but its byob. This is one of my fall back places... it always hits the spot. never more than $10.
author: C. G.

description:
you like imperial rolls?
you like *grilled beef? 
you like MEAT SAUCE?

then cordon bleu is your best friend!

as for the vegetarians, i saw a lady picking at some gloopy tofu slop that she obviously didn't like, so i'm not sure the "best hole in the wall vietnanese '06" is for you.

*I'm not sure why they insist on calling little squares of grilled beef "shish kebabs" on the menu; so if you're expecting a skewer, look out!
author: amber c.

description: When you sit at the diner-like bar in a Vietnamese restaurant with a French name, you feel the collision of cultures.  Similarly, you see a collision of foods in the bowl/plate of whatever you order.  I like their style...What's the point of separating them all, if the spices can happily mingle with eachother and it all ends up in the same place?  This is a great place to "round-out" on Nob Hill and there are some spectacular neighborhood bars in the area if you need something to wash down the sheer quantities afterwards.
author: ellyk E.

description: I think I ordered the wrong thing!! I know their chicken is their specialty, but I was craving spring rolls, so I ordered that instead. I was expecting vietnamese fresh, veggie spring rolls with peanut sauce. Instead I got fake spring rolls with a saucy cooked veggie mixture!!! NOT what I expected. Plus, the peanut sauce was nasty!!! It was watery and not good at all! I was SO disappointed! Don't order rolls here for sure!! It's a totally hole in the wall and I'm not sure if I would really go back.
author: Denise L.

description: One of the best hole-in-the-wall places I have been to so far. I like that they prepare the food in front of you. Space is limited so to beat the rush, get there a little before noon. Make sure you feed your meter because the meter-maids are out in full force on California and Polk during the lunch hour. You cant go wrong with the #5. The 5 spice chicken is savory but it's the meat sauce over rice which made me a repeat customer.
author: Gabriel C.

description: It's already an amazing feat to cook meals for around 10 people at a time in a place the size of my living room.  Heck, you should see me when it's udon night at home - food splattering all around the kitchen.  Noah suggested that I get the sampler platter... it was a LOT of food - and I can eat big.  In the end, it was pretty outrageous, but I wished I had ordered the chicken and rice noodle salad instead of the meat plate with extra meat sauce. My stomach wanted to start all over.  We went back for the salad and it was good!  This place makes the cheap eats list.
author: Shelley T.

description:
oh
my
god
(becky, look at her butt...)

so cheap, so delicious.

i came back to seattle and tried to make my own meat sauce. someone PLEASE tell me how to make the meat sauce...
author: mandy m.

description: I ate here for the first time today. I got number 5.. the 5 spice chicken with other stuff entree. It was pretty good. The servings was big and the food was cooked fresh. But it was costing like 10$ after tax. I would come back and try it again.. Oh and also, there is room for like only 12 people in there.
author: Dao C.

description: Hidden little hole in the wall. The ambiance is miserable, but the food is very fresh and tasty. Go for the chicken, pasta, and/or rice with meat sauce.
author: Brad C.

description: I am a fan for giving 4 stars.  I like that this place is so close to me.  I got the #5 I think, basically the plate with everything and it was under $10 which was nice.  The rice with the meat sauce was alright.  The shish kabob beef was pretty good.  The 5 spice chicken was delicious.  I also liked the cabbage that tied everything in.  The egg roll was good too.  If you like fried food, then this is the place to go because everything seemed oily even though it was grilled, but still an overall place to go to when you're hungry and don't have a lot of money.  More bang for your buck!
author: Limzer L.

description:
an old hippie from nyc said he started going to this place around 1975 when the Lumiere had great French films and would get an incredible meal for about $3.25 and loved the meat sauce over rice because it reminded him of a kind of Italian marinara sauce but more meat, less tomato.

sooo...i went to check it out...have to admit to loving LOVING the grilled meat on a stick...totally bad for you, but it is something I'm not about to eat everyday, nor take the time out to cook by myself. the place was packed the night I went to sit at a grungy place for about 14 people to sit either at the bar, whilst watching the Vietnamese lady grill up the meat. Cost about $8...a bargain for all the yummy imperial roll w. sauce, rice, meat sauce, and bbq'ed meat.

not a place for a date is right...unless he is a cheapo meattyman.
author: miriam b.

description: The meat sauce was really, really good. Everything else was kinda average. If you eat there, you and your clothes will reek of food and grease. Prepare to do laundry (or go to the cleaners) the day after. I'd suggest showering afterwards, too, but that's up to you.
author: Steve C.

description: While I can't say that it doesn't taste good, and that it isn't a great deal, I am always skeptical of places that keep partially cooked meats underneath the counter in a bucket.  Is this O.K.?  Eat at your own risk, but if you go I highly recommend the 5 spice roast chicken, the rice with meat sauce and the imperial roll.  Actually, especially the imperial roll b/c it is deep fried, thus ensuring any bacteria perishes in a vat of boiling oil.
author: Jon M.

description: I had fond memories of my first meal here in '78 after the movies at the Lumiere when I was a kid (The Thief of Baghdad with Hardware Wars as a short).  I've been back many times since.  It's an awesome hole in the wall.  The food is delish, super cheap, and the scene is great.  I frequently end up in conversations with my neighbors.  No liquor licence, but you can bring your own.
author: Stefan A.

description: Yes it's Vietnamese, and yes, it called Cordon Bleu, and no, it's not for vegetarians, maybe not even for anyone who knows a vegetarian.  This place is all about the MEAT - big, greasy pieces of meat.  As if BBQ pork strips, 5-spice chicken, huge deep-fried egg rolls, and spicy pork chops aren't enough, they have pork meat sauce (read: Vietnamese Sloppy Joe) and rice that everything is served over.  Next time somebody asks me what my favorite BBQ in the city is I get to say, "Cordon Bleu... it's Vietnamese."
author: Trevor F.

description: Great little diner that serves up a wicked 5 spice chicken over rice and beans.  Not sure how Cordon Bleu fits into the whole scheme of things but I figured the folks running the joint are Vietnamese.  This is a uber cool spot to go to for something a little different but not extreme in any way.  You may have to wait a few to sit down and eat since the eatery only seats a little over 10 people but your experience will be well worth the wait.
author: Shiho F.

description: Primarily for meat eaters that are hungry and low on funds. The portion sizes are huge. WARNING this place is for those who LOVE greasy hole in the wall places and not for those suffering from high cholesterol. My suggestion, get the last combo - both chicken and pork.
author: Judy L.

description: YUMMY! They make the best cabbage salad ever...you can order that alone and it's amazing. The meat sauce is fantastic...and the chicken is fabulous. Cheap...cheap...cheap...and you can easily get 2 meals out of the #5.
author: Sherie R.

description: Hole in the wall? who said that, I am gamed. The meal is simple and good, Column A - grill chicken, pork, or spring roll. Column B - rice, rice noodle or salad. Any combinations you can think of is on the menu already. And since this is SF, you can have your sauce or dressing on the side if you so desired. If that doesn't make you feel like a king, I don't know what will... and cheap too. I am not sure it worth another star, but it is cleaner than most other hole in the wall places I've been to.
author: Mr P.

description: Little dirty hole in the wall with awesome food. Just get the cheapest plate. Don't ask. It's the best.
author: matt c.

description: It's all about the chicken plate. For dinner, smaller appetites can even order the lunch sized plate, for a mere 50 cent difference. the veggie rolls are to die for.  Nice lady there who runs the place. Watch out for the 7p.m. rush if you want one of the 9 or 10 seats there. Otherwise call in.
author: The Shmooze ..

description:
this place is not for the faint-hearted.

1.  mostly because the kitchen is right in front of you so you are tempted to ignore some dirtiness that you may observe from the cooks (things not being covered, etc.).
2.  they serve this rice with meat sauce that LOOKS real gross but, thankfully being brought up on equally looking gross but yummy stuff in the traditional chinese fashion AND being egged to gobble with my eyes closed by the blistering cold last winter, tastes real good.
3.  how SMALL and cramped this joint is.  imagine a true HOLE IN THE WALL.

but i liked how cheap the place was.
you get alot of food for what you pay for (e.g. the sampler dish).
and i loooooved their imperial rolls.

i want to bring more people to this restaurant but ive got to choose people that don't scare so easily.
author: Angela Q.

description: The food is great! It's not the type of place to bring a good date as the place doesn't look very good - a little dirty, the atmosphere isn't that nice, but the food there is awesome! You won't regret it! I really wish I had their recipes! I would buy a recipe book if they sold them - somehow, they spice up their meat so good that it's like nothing you'll have ever tasted. Large portions too! And cheap! AWESOME A++
author: Alton Y.

description: So after a long debate of where to eat, my friends and I decided to go here.  I live in the area and was very surprised I had never been to this place.  Now you definitely do not go here for the service.  But I would have to say I was thoroughly impressed that the cook was also the person who answered the phone, and the person who rang people up.  The staff of 3 works incredibly hard.  As far as the food, it's a GREAT bang for the buck.  I ordered the number one which consisted of a huge plate of rice with meat sauce, a salad, some awesome beef, and a crispy egg roll.  Was the quality of the food fantastic? Not particularly.  Was it a great meal for 6.55? YES!  I would definitely go back here.  The next time I go, however, I think I would get the chicken or the noodle bowl.  I tried my friends chicken and it was amazing.  So until next time.
author: Rachel S.

description: Awesome chicken and rice w/meat sauce (the #4 combo), a phenomenal meal if you've got the appetite (it's a half-chicken). No booze here, but there are lots of bars over on Polk. Absolutely worth the wait if you have to. If you're Asian, it's like eating at your auntie's house.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
This is on the list of great cheap eats. 

The restaurant is the quintessential hole in the wall.  After reading tons of yelp reviews on Cordon Bleu, I felt like it was time to check it out.  The place is small and only really has two tables and up to 10 bar stools.  It is run by two ladies who are constantly cooking all night.  There's high turnover but because it takes a while to cook the meat, people aren't constantly flowing in and out.  I wouldn't recommend coming with any more than 2 people.

It is highly recommended to order on the phone though.  

I ordered the #5 which comes with bbq pork and beef.  There's also a deep fried imperial roll.  Let's just simply say that the food is gooooooood.  It's tasty and there's a lot of it.  No need to write a long review.  Just come here and try it.
author: Scott L.

description: For a quick bite with no frills, this is the spot.  Restaurant is small and food has a home-cooked feel.  The imperial rolls and kabob are fantastic.  The meat sauce on rice is unique and tasty. Great hangover food.
author: Brittany T.

description:
A little bit of Hanoi comes to San Francisco...

We're regulars here -- take in a flick at the Lumiere, and have dinner next door at Cordon Bleu (or "Gordon Blue" as our friends call it -- check out their sign for why).

This place is like the best Vietnamese street food shacks -- great food, cheap prices, cooked fresh in front of your eyes in a tiny, hole-in-the-wall place with a few counter seats and a couple tables.  The owner is a sweet lady who works the char-grill cooking up fabulous 5-spice chicken and roll platters.  My partner always orders the noodle salad, and I switch back and forth between the 1/2 chicken platter with meat sauce and the spicy pork chops.  Both are great!  You might have to wait some nights, it can get busy, but definitely worth it!  Unless you are ravenous (or just always clean your plate, like me) you will have plenty left over for lunch the next day, too.

Just go -- you won't regret it.
author: Bob E.

description: Run over to Cordon Bleu for some delicious and casual home-style Vietnamese food. The portions are plentiful and the prices are jaw-droppingly low. This a good place to go solo as it's super tiny, plus they have a long counter space that faces the kitchen so you can watch the cooks work their magic as you wait patiently for your plate of food.
author: joolia f.

description: This is the greatest cheap meal in all of SF.  My sis came here before me (thank you dummy sis) and I have met a crew of folks who have frequented this joint for 10s of years.  Its an establishment and neighborhood beacon.  This place has almost singularly served as the barometer for all of the women I have dated in SF.  If they can handle this dive and check any judgements before sitting and ordering, then I think we can handle a second round in this town.  The owner is the sweetest woman around, a wizard on her grill, and lovely lady.  There is food here for all types though the menu is small and limited.  Rest assured its all good and if you catch them on the right day (very hard), you may catch a batch of fresh won tons or something else that is specially prepared.  I dream of these days though the Number 5 is plenty good to suffice all primal urges and desires.  Eat happy people
author: Porfirio R.

description: The bun is the best in the area.  I have also had the chicken salad and their egg roll.  All were very good, and the ladies working their are super nice.  Amazing what they do in such small place.
author: Elizabeth J.

description: OMG! I know what you're going to say, "totally overrated, 5 stars!" but this place is great, a total hole in the wall, might-as-well-have bathed in type of joint, because you leave the place smelling like what you ate...but its definitely freakin tasty and "homestyle" cooking (so the faint of heart, be warned) My faves are the Chicken Salad which is a heaping mountain of chopped cabbage, julienne carrots, greens and savory slices of five spice chicken along with peanuts and fresh basil topped with a sweet/sour vinaigrette - GREAT! Then, there's the n#3 which is grilled, marinated THIN slices of pork with rice and a freakin' amazing "secret meat sauce", no really it's called "meat sauce" and its just fabulous! ONLY go to this place when you haven't eaten in a few days!!
author: Audrey C.

description: This is by far the smallest restaurant I've ever been in.  Seating for, maybe, 20 people, tops.  Everyone in my party had the 5 Spice Chicken, and even though they serve generous helpings, nobody left any on their plate.  Inexpensive and tasty.
author: Philip T.

description: I like this place.  I have a thing for divey places and Cordon Bleu definitely falls into this category.  Don't be scared by this because the 5 spice chicken is delicious!  They serve it with rice and some sort of meat sauce.  It is difficult to describe the meat sauce, but it's good.  Add a little chili sauce and it is even better.  The price can't be beat and it is a great place to go if you are craving some Asian comfort food.  I prefer to eat out so I don't have the lingering smell of bbq meat on me all night long.
author: Julie P.

description: This is quintessential hole in the wall.  Don't go there if you're looking for a nice ambience and it's pretty hard to find a seat, but the 5-spiced chicken rocks my world!  The menu options are scarce but the portions are huge.  One of my favorite comfort foods in SF.
author: Helen T.

description: Don't let the fact that this place looks like a small homeless-soup kitchen or the fact that homeless crack-heads come in trying to use the bathroom on occasion (they don't let them use it) fool you. This place is as delicious as it gets. Also, don't let the pictures that look like someone just puked on a plate detour you. The heavenly meat sauce and flavor packed bbq chicken and pork kebab stuff are to die for. The triple fried imperial roll is off the charts. It is all super cheap as well, so bring enough cash but not enough to incentive a crack-head to try to jump you.
author: Dan V.

description: MMMMM.  I was kind of iffy when I first went in because it was so small and crowded.  But man oh man, the food was so good.  When they told me it was going to be Vietnamese food, I assumed it would be like all of the other Vietnamese restaurants around my house (Tully st, San Jose).  But no, I've never tried most of the dishes on their menu.  The flavor, texture, and presentation hit the spot.  I recommend ordering take-out, only because the wait would be a little less.  Also,  they cook the food right in front of you.  So, if you want to avoid smelling like food, it's best to order take out.    You definitely don't want to stink up all the cubicles near you after coming back from your lunch break.  Been there, done that...not a fun feeling.
author: Jacquelynne S.

description: This little place is so funky, I love it. It's really small so you might have to wait if it's full, but I don't usually see lines. They do take phone orders! Most of the seats are at the counter, and you can watch them cook your food. The ladies that work there are super nice, and you get a heap of tasty home-made style food for pretty cheap. I think of this as Vietnamese soul food. Rice with "Meat Sauce"!? Weird and good in a comfort food way. The imperial rolls are dy-no-mite!
author: Tyler H.

description: Yum, I want this now.  Many people complain about the characteristics of how they prepare food, etc. They probably handle it better than a lot of places-we just don't see it.  More room for me at the counter.  The food is great!
author: Gillian F.

description: This place is amazing.  I definitely recommend the chicken salad entree and imperial rolls.  Since the place is small, I worry it may become overcrowded when everyone else catches on to how good it is.  The decor is minimal at best and the capacity for the place is approximately 10 but, this is definitely one of my neighborhood favorites.  Some of the best Vietnamese food I have ever had.
author: Nina W.

description: Tiny hole in the wall with good country style Vietnamese food.  They have a limited menu b/c they do what they do right.  The 5 spice chicken is great.  You get a huge plate of food for cheap.  They have this strange meat sauce they throw on the rice...either you like it or you don't.  I don't.
author: Scott W.

description: I first ate here about 16 years ago when I worked up the street.  I immediately became something of a regular.  Excellent, cheap, flavorful food.  Had the same meal everytime I went:  5 spiced chicken, meat skewer, imperial roll and the most amazing rice with meat sauce,  salad.   Delicious!    Unfortuneately, I no longer work in the area, but I do go back a couple of times per year.    Nothing has changed:  The prices are within a dollar of what I used to pay all those years ago for the exact same meal.  Huge portions.  Great tastes.  Really friendly people.  Wish I was in the neighborhood more often.
author: Kassy A.

description: Cordon Bleu is one of my top 5 comfort food stops...When you need that satisfying, familiar kickass good food, this is where you should come, people.  I have to admit, for years I would call them for take out and I couldn't remember the combination that I liked, but I knew it was the biggest one possible, so I got everything.  The staff very patiently would correct me when I called to order a "#6" that they only had 5 combination plates.  In the past few years the menu has expanded to include some terrific new dishes, like the spicy pork chops and refreshing noodle salad.  Cordon Bleu is deservedly a San Francisco institution--check it out!
author: Jennifer F.

description:
I first went to Cordon Bleu when my sweetie and I had first moved to SF in 1983. Yes. 1983. We lived in the Tenderloin and happened into their place (now gone, as I understand it) and have been hooked ever since. I haven't lived in CA since 1989 but I still long for their food and can't wait to get myself back so I can go there again. For two young kids who barely had two nickels to rub together and lived in a residence hotel, Cordon Bleu kept us fed, well, for a long long time. Cordon Bleu got me through a nine month bout with morning sickness; it was literally the only thing I could eat during my pregnancy, and probably the reason my son has a real love of Asian cuisine.

Their Imperial rolls are the bar to which I hold all fried rolls. Their five spice chicken? Is unequaled anywhere else, from CA to Alaska, as far as I'm concerned. I've finally mastered the chicken cabbage salad, but while mine is good, it's not "Cordon Bleu good". Their Pho soup? Divine. (Do they still make that?)

I'm dying to know what's in that meat sauce, and would love even something only vaguely resembling a recipe. I can't even describe it well enough when I go into Vietnamese restaurants for them even to hazard a guess as to what it is, or what could be in it. (Should I be afraid?)

If anyone could get me a recipe (or even an ingredients list!) I'd be most thankful! In the meantime, the first time I can get my Alaskan butt down there, Cordon Bleu will be the first place I go. In the meantime, I wonder... do they deliver? To Alaska?
author: Vickie M.

description: Tasty, satisfying food that is very affordable with generous portions served in a quaint environment.  The meat sauce over rice one of my "comfort" foods.  AND I seem to meet nice, interesting people there.
author: Betsy L.

description: I love the food and the owner is so sweet. If you want a warm home cooked meal then go eat here. It is money well spent. the food is freash and tasty with full of flavor. Best Food in the City.
author: John R.

description: Yum Yum YUM!!!! - Their 5 spice chicken is fantastic - just make sure you over order - because it will be gone before you know it.  Not as into the meat sauce.
author: Marina O.

description: definition of a whole in the wall.  good food cheap prices. bottom line.
author: Ricky Y.

description: If you have man-size hunger this is the place. The meat sauce is great, some people come just to order that....thier imperial rolls are unbeatable.
author: Ross J.

description: What these people don't know is putting the meat under the counter adds flavor.
author: Dave F.

description:
The food is good, the prices are right, and the owner is a kick to talk to!

Knocking the look of the restaurant's patrons and the menu's grammar is a sad way for the last reviewer to rate this establishment.
author: D M.

description: I am a fan of the greasy spoon eateries. This is very casual and the staff is always accomodating and generous with the portions. Love that meat sauce..! Only one gripe.. lost a star for the odd hours.
author: Hale L.

description: i love the down-home intimate vibe here. great place to grab a bite before or after a show at the lumiere or a night of encore karaoke. menu=super simple. i admit as a veggie-person, it's a bit meaty. but there are veggie options. my friend ordered the meat...he liked. if you sit at the bar you'll have meat cooking right in front of you. i overlook this. i could survive off of those veggie spring rolls and peanut sauce alone. mmmm!! the peanut sauce....the peanut sauce...and oh-so affordable.
author: Isabel C.

description: This place is amazing and a huge bang for your buck. I would recommend it to anyone that likes a tasty bbq chicken or kebab over rice. You can't go wrong here!
author: A D.

description: I usually won't give a place 5 stars if the food is good but there's no parking.  This place is the exception to the rule.  The food here is straight up home cooking like mom makes.  The only item you need to order here is the #5.  You get a quarter five spice chicken, some grilled beef, a giant imperial roll, some type of slaw with meat gravy over rice.  Wow.  You can tell that the ladies in the front put a lot of love into the cooking, and believe me you can tell by the taste.  And a nice little secret, if you get your order to go, the five spice chicken is better cold.  The flavor and spices seem more intense cold, don't know why, just tastes good.  If you live in the city or even if you don't, this is a place that must be tried ASAP.
author: Shane Y.

description: This place is incredible good.  Small, and a bit grungy, but authentic food, friendly servers, big portions, and cheap prices.  BYOB.
author: Eric W.

description: Thoroughly delicious, cheap and satisfying. We'll be back. The only reason it missed the 5 stars is because the food is a little too savory to eat every day :-D
author: Cody J.

description: Very cute family owned restaurant. Good price and good amount of food. Tasty chicken!
author: R L.

description: If you are one of those "gourmet eaters" looking a restaurant with stars in the Michelin guide, don't go to Le Cordon Bleu, in San Francisco. But, if you love the delicious food that ordinary people eat, believe me, you will love it! And, if you are really hungry, this place is the best place you can find because is cheap, good size portions and delicious. The restaurant is small and not a good looking place, but the food definitely is wonderful. For sure that is the reason that always it is full of people. The woman that cook, maybe the owner, is very nice and obliging. Five stars absolutely!
author: Ricardo T.

description:
What can I say? I have dropped to the status of carnivore, and as such, now get to experience the delicious 5 spice chicken of Cordon Bleu!  I still love their Vegetarian rice noodle salad. Love it. But that chicken is DAMN good!  Personally, I suggest getting that meat sauce on the side.  I cleaned my plate of all but the skin, bones and meat sauce. 
I love most of what I've tasted there. The shish kebab (pork) is very tasty, and the veggie rolls (both kinds) are great.  I also like the owner. 
My one star deduction is for the fact that I've actually seen dead roaches in the window since I first reviewed, and the meat sauce creeps me out. I tried it tonight (note- on side) and just can't get into it.  It has ground pork, and I don't  know what else, but it tastes very much like Spaghettios sauce with much less sugar. I like sweet stuff, but find this odd due to its gelatinous lumps and lack of salt.
None of that keeps me from returning again and again. Even if some of my dining companions will no longer go with me b/c of the view of the cooking area...
So glad I can now enjoy the chicken AND shish kebab!
author: Allucaneat G.

description: This place is cheap, delicious with big proportions, and in a cool quarter
author: Dave C.

description:
I love the place. The Five Spice Chicken, Imperial Roll, and Shishkaboob are fantastic.  The meat sause on rice is also very tasty as is the chicken salad that they serve with it. There is no place in San Francisco that has cuisine like this. 

There is one problem though.  Roaches. Last year when I took my wife there they had just painted the place. I don't know what effect that it had on the place but they seemed to be parachuting down to the counter.  Like TuLan they keep a lot of the food underneath that counter and there's no telling what critters are lucking there.  

That said, I still love the food but my wife refuses to return.
author: Nick C.

description: I just love Cordon Bleu. I first ate here in 1982 when I moved to The City. And ate here for the next two decades. I moved to Los Angeles in March 2002 but everytime I visit SF I make it a point to eat here. The food is GGGOOOODDD! The owner is great and friendly. I LOVe the egg rolls, chicken, salad and sauce. I take all my friends there to eat the good food.
author: Hwd C.

description: You can't beat the number 5 combo, though the Imperial Roll is the best thing on the menu, so you might want to get a couple of those...
author: Jeremiah J.

description:
I'm getting in line behind the rest of these cats, 4 stars all the way.  Yes its a hole in the wall, but if you're in walking (or busing distance for that matter) on blistery night, this place will warm you right up.  Sit and watch the cooking happen in front of you at the rap around bar.  Two more little tables to hold the over flow in the back.  The Girl and I ordered Combo 4 and 5, easily enough for dinner and the next day's lunch.  Don't miss the chicken, their signature.  You can taste the colonial French influence in every bight without forgetting you're eating Vietnamese. The "Shish" Kabob is a misnomer but good, pounded thin pork, grilled in front of you.  First timers I recommend Combo 5, you get a taste of everything and enough to take home.  When packing the to-go container's right in front of us, she asked if we wanted more rice.  Sure, we said.  I guess rice comes with the obligatory "Meat sauce."  We weren't disappointed, tasty stuff. As we dined people were coming in and out picking up to-go orders seemingly on schedule; it seemed as though the chef was making sure all her neighbors were well fed.

Bottom line, Good Eats. Damage under 20 for two, beat that Cala Foods.
author: Jason F.

description: Oh yeah - I just moved, and I now live walking distance from this place.  I couldn't wait to try it.  I was not disappointed in the least.  Cheap and delicious food.  That's a winning combination any day in my book.  I had a combination plate, which included imperial roll, 5 spice chicken, BBQ pork, salad, and rice covered with their meat sauce.  It filled me up, and I'm pretty sure I couldn't even finish my plate, which is rare for me.  Dinner for two, tip included, is easily within $20.  Highly recommend.
author: Alan C.

description:
I ate here for the first time two weeks ago for lunch based on a friend's recommendation. I had the 5 Spice Chicken salad and it was delicious! 
I highly recommend this restaurant for simply delicious food at outstanding prices. I will be back.
author: Jenny J.

description: Tasty five-spice chicken.  This is one of my favorite neighborhood hole-in-the-wall joints.  Their combo plates are very reasonably priced (the big combo with the five-spice chicken, beef shish-kebab, imperial roll, salad, and pork sauce over rice costs less than $9 and could easily feed two people).
author: Timothy L.

description:
Who started this review, anyway? Please don't humiliate yourself by not having the facts about any establishment.  The owners are Chinese. The spices used in their dishes are Chinese. 

This place has a short menu. It's good and a better bargin than tacos. Not quite the best place for dinner, unless it's your beer buddy or roommate whom you see all the time anyway. 

Closed on Mondays.
author: Charles J.

description: i get why some people wrote less than stellar reviews...yes the place is tiny, yeah if its busy you're gonna wait for forever, no it's not the cleanest looking place on the best street...but if you look past that trivial stuff, you will be rewarded with awesome chicken!  My gurts and i went to cordon blue on the recommendation of a coworker and had the same reservations when we peeked inside interested in a quick meal before a night of karaoke goodness next door at Encore.  We did, however, go inside just before the rush and were pleasantly surprised at the service and yumminess of the food.  We each ordered a #1...shish kabob, rice with meat sauce, imperial roll and salad.  It was super delish!  the shish kabob meat was cooked perfectly and was super umami,   the rice was the perfect stickiness and covered in the sweet/tangy/meaty sauce, the salad was crisp and lemon-y and the imperial rolll was crispy and hearty (filled with veggies and pork) and not at all greasy.  Some guy ordered chicken but left before it was ready, so the ladies let us have that, too...sweet jumping jeebus!  It made me realize that, as good as everything else was, the chicken is soooo the business!  crispy skin, tender juicy meat, and flavorfull through out.  So if you're in the area, dont be afraid to stop by, your taste buds will be richly rewarded!!!
author: Rena H.

description: Great spot to get take out when you have a cold and don't want to cook dinner. $17 for a #4 and #5 (tons of food) that was spicy enough to temporarily clear my nose. I will be back!
author: Kay T.

description: Two words: Katie *rocks*... best Vietnamese chicken salad in town.
author: David G.

description: Best food ever. EVERRRRRRRRRR.  Vietnamese country-style food served up by a nice lady by the name of Katie.  Be aware that all of the entrees & specials come with hot tea included in the price (this is only indicated at the bottom of the entrees section where it says "tea is not included with a la carte orders") and they should give you free refills on the tea as well if you ask for more or if they notice that your cup is running low, but ask if you want more.  Highly recommended: the #5 (five-spice chicken, imperial roll, rice with meat sauce, country salad (which is a cold vinegared cabbage dish) and the shish kabob, which is less like what you would think of when you think of like a Greek kabob and more like Vietnamese bacon - $7.95), the noodle salad (rice noodles with a yummy sauce, imperial roll, shish kabob and lots of veggies- great hot weather food - $7.00) and the spicy pork chop (3 big pork chops, which are not actually spicy, but awesomely tender, over rice with green onions which comes with a not-really-worth mentioning iceberg/tomato salad - $7.95).  The chicken salad is okay, but the noodle salad is way better.  They offer vegetarian dishes, but they're not that great, and the same goes for the ma po tofu - meh.  Not recommended for germaphobes - so you people go to restaurants without open kitchens where you can't see all the gross things they do to your good (I bet this place is cleaner than many).  Tiny place, only a couple of wobbly tables, so expect to sit at the counter.  I go here with my boyfriend often and I love getting so much delicious food that I have to get a second wind halfway through eating for $20 including a generous tip.  Oh, and please don't turn off the light in the bathroom - it turns off the lights by the table as well and then an employee has to go turn it back on.
author: Green T.

description: So good it's not normal. I get the #3 with no meat sauce (sacrilege?) and a little extra of the sweet sauce on the side topped off with some rooster. Never left hungry. Never left unsatisfied. Having to wait sometimes for a seat due to its size can suck, but you can't knock them a star for that. Only takes cash, but can't knock the hustle either.
author: M.F. J.

description: I love coming here not only because the food is good, but mostly because the food is made with love.  This is what your mom would serve you if she was Vietnamese and had her own diner.  The woman who runs this place (it's been around for 40 years!  who ate Vietnamese 40 years ago?) is really nice and gives me tea when it's cold outside (which is all the time in SF)  It's not haute cusine, it won't win awards for interior design, but it is simple food, good food in a convivial atmosphere.  Go there and then go to the Lumiere next door for a movie.
author: jessica d.

description: the chicken was good but was not a fan of the meat sauce!  it was tomatoe-ey and probably had a hint of ketchup.
author: Emm C.

description: Great little hole-in-the-wall dining experience with good food. The meat sauce over the rice was interesting and tasty (sort of a Chef Boyardee experience, Vietnamese style), but I think in the future I'll opt for the white rice with scallions a friend ordered with his pork chops (which he likened to jerky - in a good way). I could see the meat sauce becoming the type of thing you crave, though, like SpaghettiO's with meatballs (which I recognize are FrancoAmerican, not Chef Boyardee). The five spice roast chicken lived up to expectations. I can see why it's a favorite here. But, for me, the best items were the "shish kebabs" (really blackened strips of steak - no skewers) and imperial rolls. In fact, I give the prize to the imperial rolls. Crisp, bubbly wrappers overflowing with meaty filling. Another patron was shoveling in the noodles and it looked really satisfying, so maybe I'll get them next time. With imperial rolls on the side, of course.
author: Veronica L.

description: This has some of the best 5 spiced chicken I have ever had. I walked by one day (2007) while walking in my new neigborhood (Nob Hill) at the time and smelled this incredibly grilled chicken. I walked right in, asked what it was & ate half a chicken in 10 minutes. It was so flagrant, tender and succulent that I wanted more but didn't want to feel like a glutton so ate the side salad (which was also tangy & tasty) and just meditated (or marinated)...om..om...yum...yuuuum : ) And Katie, the proprietor is the most incredibly funny, smart, sweet, stylish person in the biz. So down to earth but works way too hard. The Chicken salad is also good and the veggie roles are da bomb baby.. The venue inside is like a small & cozy like Al Diner from the 70's tv show "Alice" but not too small where you don't feel like eveyrone knows your name (Cheers). The PERFECT date place. Thanks Katie. we love you. Michael Dorame (find me on Facebook y'all) : )
author: Michael D.

description: THIS PLACE KICKS ASS. Incredible food, humongous portions, and CHEAP!!!  I ordered their #4: 1/2 five spice chicken, meat sauce over rice, and cole slaw for $7.  The chicken is awesome but even better is the meat sauce with rice.   i don't know what they put in the sauce but it is so damn good! this place is a hole-in-the-wall so if you're looking for a fancy date place this is not it, it is all about the FOOD.  the lady who mans the grill (probably the owner) is nice, too
author: Richard K.

description: try the #1 and the #5 ("the sampler"). they're worth it. and beware the imperial roll--it's extremely tasty, yet extremely hot right out of the fryer. you'd think i'd learn that the first bite will ALWAYS burn the shit out of my mouth. but i don't.
author: Dean E.

description:
good
- five spice chicken
- imperial rolls
- the crazy, meaty spaghetti sauce they put over the rice (sounds weird, tastes good)

bad
- only seats like 3 people
- kinda greasy to eat too often
author: Anthony W.

description: Eli, Kent and I graced this fine establishment for a last supper of sorts.  The sky was gray and so was I, but armed with cash and an appetite for the taste of the far South East, at the counter we sat. Ordering three number 5's we relaxed enyoing the simple  ambience of this big little restaurant by the bay. The moist chicken, coupled with imperial rolls, rice and meat sauce proved delightful to the palate, as did the budget-friendly cost.  Leaving full and happy I couldn't help but utter, with pride, Here's to you, Cordon Bleu!
author: Brian C.

description: twenty year rule, this cubby hole counter has been doing it for so long; five item menu, with or without meat sauce, grilled chick, pork on the side ... sometimes diners sit on each other, its lost a bit of its edge, the meat sauce is looser than i remember it ... but hey,  this is the original "slanted cubby hole door" ...
author: tim y.

description: extremely small but cozy place, watch your order get cooked on a grill while you do nothing.
author: Sydney L.

description: Went there today for lunch for the very first time.  I needed to go to a bank and it was right next door to a WAMU.  Since I found a sweet parking spot; hard to do in SF, I decided to hang around the area before going to my next client.  I saw the blue awning that said "5-Spice Chicken".  I walked in and the place reminded me of Yamo's, except a bit brighter and cleaner.  The prices on the menu is a bit more than Yamo's but I gave it a shot anyway.  I saw the 5-spice chicken and asked how long it takes to prepare, because of my upcoming appointment.  The lady with the nice smile stated that it's fast.  So I went for it.  Man, was it good!  The chicken was tender, the slaw was OK, and the rice with meat sauce was awesome.  The portion was worth the price and I couldn't believe I finished the whole thing.  The cook saw how clean my plate was and asked, with that great smile again, if it was my first time.  I said it was and it will not be my last.  I saw her prepare the deep fried egg rolls, and it looks like something to come back for.
author: Nino M.

description: i've only been here twice many years ago but what i do remember is that the food was excellent and the portions were very generous.  they cooked it right in front of me which was cool even though i smelled like bbq for the next 3 days but its well worth it.
author: Landon Y.

description: I don't go for the service or atmosphere.  The food is great!  I have never had anyone ask me if I want gravy on my rice.
author: Antony E.

description: Great vietnamese soul food - i love their ingenious self closing door using elastic bands, and they let you bring beer in from outside!
author: anthony i.

description: and the lady who owns/runs the place is soooooooooo nice!!!! i love her!!!!!!!!! she still recognizes me after all these years!!!
author: Julien N.

description: Holy crap is the chicken tasty!  I've gotten the chicken over rice with meat sauce plenty of times.  I usually ask for just 1/2 the meat sauce they typically put on and it's enough.  It really fills you up for around $10.  Just do yourself a favor and don't look behind the counter.
author: Tom Z.

description: One of the best deals in town.  A combo plate will run you about eight bucks and you'll be stuffed.  The five-spice chicken is great, but the real winner here is the spicy porkchop.  The imperial rolls are also delicious.  If ambiance is important to you, don't even bother going, but if you are all about tasty food this place is right up your alley.  I will be dreaming about the pork chops tonight.
author: C H.

description: Absolutely Fabulous! It's adorable, comfy, affordable, and delicious!
author: Monica t.

description: Their 5 spice chicken is definitely something to try. I actually liked it quite a bit, however, the place is dingy and I can't stand that.
author: Richard C.

description: The food is good, the portions are generous, and it's really cheap. Try the number 5 for a taste of almost everything on the menu. Seating is limited, so plan on taking out or going at an off time.
author: Emily D.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants.  The menu has never changed for as long as I've been going, for five years now.  For under 10 dollars (including tip) you can get a big plate with a five-spice style chicken quarter from the grill, rice with a yummy, yummy sauce, beef strips marinated to perfection (maybe a little tough but still SOOOO good, and a crispy, crispy spring roll, and their country salad, which is kinda like cole slaw without the mayo, and tangy good crunchy to go with the meat.  This is a perfect place to go before or after a movie next door or any time, really.  And the people that work there are really nice, they look like a family and eating there makes me feel good.
author: Sophie B.

description: This is a great little hole in the wall gem! The food is great and cheap. I love it.
author: Jubilee M.

description: this place is like an asian waffle house, and a meat eater's heaven. the menu is simple with five combinations of various meats and rice. if you have trouble deciding between your meats, don't worry because for under 10 bucks you can get everything their menu has to offer. the wait time was a little long, but i was so mesmerized by the lady grilling beef and deep frying imperial rolls, i really didn't mind. for such a little hole in the wall, i was amazed that there were people waiting outside for a barstool to open up, and even more people coming in to pick up their take out orders. if you're looking for some cheap, no frills food, in a cozy diner style environment, this is a great option.
author: Mary Beth D.

description: This has been one of my all time favoritie bbq type places for a long time.  It only seats about 8 people so you might have to wait but it is worth it.  The several reasons I like this place are as follows:  For $6.55 you can get a combo plate of really good imperial rolls, meat or roasted chicken, cabbage salad and rice with a magical meat sauce on top.  I asked the owner if she would fill a jar of the meat sauce for me to take to go - it's that good.  I also like to watch my food being made and the counter seating fits that requirement.  The place is tiny and sometimes even smoky, not a problem for me, but maybe for others.  The only thing I don't like, and this knocks a 5 star rating down to 4 is that they have the chicken marinating at room temperature, in a pan of the floor.  There were some things that looked a little unsanitary in there.  I'm usually good with smaller divey mom and pops, in fact I prefer them, but having experienced the joys of salmonella ( not from here ) it scares me a little.
author: Soups C.
